title: State responsibility in the context of cyberwarfare: dilemma identification and path reconstruction
abstract: This article examines the evolving challenges of attributing state responsibility under international law in the domain of cyberwarfare, highlighting critical normative failures and proposing a comprehensive techno-legal reconstruction of existing frameworks. Drawing on the theory of international law subjectivity, the authors identify three core dilemmas: the breakdown of attribution caused by technological anonymity undermining the “effective control” criterion in the Draft Articles on State Responsibility; the difficulty of defining a clear use-of-force threshold for non-kinetic cyber operations under Article 2(4) of the United Nations Charter; and the normative conflicts arising from countermeasure legitimacy in “forward defense” strategies. Through a cross-disciplinary methodology combining legal doctrinal analysis, conceptual genealogy, and threshold doctrine critique, the paper traces the emergence of the cyberwarfare concept from military science to jurisprudence—from early RAND Corporation reports and Fifth Dimension theory to contemporary cyberattacks in Georgia, Iran, and Syria—and reviews competing jus ad bellum approaches: purpose, instrumentality, and scale-and-consequence theories. The authors argue that the scale-and-consequence approach, exemplified by Michael Schmitt’s seven criteria in the Tallinn Manual 2.0, has gained wider acceptance but remains insufficient for nuanced state responsibility in cyberspace. To address these gaps, the article proposes a dynamic attribution model that integrates technical verification with legal presumption and introduces “substantial support” as an alternative criterion when comprehensive control theories prove ineffectual. The normative reconstruction further encompasses preventive responsibility to curb risk spillover, due diligence standards, and technology-neutral evidence collection mechanisms to bridge the technical-judicial divide. Procedurally, it advocates establishing a United Nations–based International Cyber Arbitration Tribunal and supporting cyber-peacekeeping forces to ensure impartial adjudication and enforcement. These reforms aim to operationalize the principle of equivalence of effect, clarify indirect responsibility for non-state actors, and embed technical governance within international legal institutions. While primarily theoretical, the framework offers a path toward a technologically empowered governance paradigm for cyberspace. The authors acknowledge the need for empirical validation of attribution mechanisms, development of multilateral evidence standards, and consensus-building for proposed institutions. Their contribution lies in reconfiguring the constitutive elements of state responsibility and charting a dual-track normative and institutional model to mitigate the diffuse damage of cyberwarfare and enhance legal clarity.

title: State responsibility for cyberattacks as a use of force in the context of the 2022 russian invasion of Ukraine
source: IDP. Revista De Internet, Derecho Y Política
abstract: This article by Olena Nihreieva provides a comprehensive legal analysis of state responsibility for cyberattacks in the context of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, focusing on when such operations constitute a use of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter and thus give rise to international responsibility. Highlighting the lack of clarity in existing international law regarding cyber operations conducted alongside conventional military force, the study adopts an interdisciplinary methodology, integrating legal interpretative analysis with insights from computer science. Drawing on primary sources—including UN Group of Governmental Experts reports, national contributions to the UN compendium, policy papers from Germany, France, Canada, Australia, and the UK, and incident data from Google’s Threat Analysis Group—the author investigates three main scholarly approaches to defining a use of force in cyberspace: instrument-based, purpose-based, and effects-based. A detailed survey of state practice and opinio juris reveals consensus that cyber operations inflicting severe physical or functional damage qualify as uses of force, yet significant legal gaps persist regarding less destructive cyber activities. The paper examines the divergent national thresholds for intensity, intent, and attribution, and underscores the formidable challenges in legally attributing cyberattacks to state actors—especially when private or proxy entities are implicated. Building on the Tallinn Manual 2.0 and national policy documents, Nihreieva constructs a novel classification framework that delineates criteria—scale, effects, context, and intent—to guide states and international bodies in assessing when a cyber operation reaches the threshold of a use of force. The article also explores Ukraine’s specific experience, from large‐scale DDoS attacks on its defense and banking infrastructures to high-impact attacks on critical networks, illustrating the practical application of the proposed schema. The study’s primary contribution is its cohesive classification model, which identifies highly destructive cyberattacks as internationally wrongful uses of force attributable to the Russian Federation, thereby justifying countermeasures or self-defense under the UN Charter. Limitations include the exclusion of self-defense doctrine analysis and alternative legal remedies, which the author suggests for future research. The article concludes by recommending multilateral negotiations to establish binding international rules governing lower-intensity cyber operations, further empirical research on non-destructive cyber espionage, and comparative studies of emerging national legal frameworks to foster broader consensus and strengthen legal certainty in cyberspace.

title: The role of strategic culture in shaping iran's cyber defense policy
source: International Journal of Intelligence and CounterIntelligence
abstract: This study examines how Iran’s strategic culture—shaped by historical memory, national pride, and a revolutionary ethos—has influenced the evolution of its state-led cyber defense policy since 2003. Grounded in a multidisciplinary cyber conflict framework, the research employs a qualitative case study methodology that systematically analyzes over a dozen high-level leaked government documents, including minutes from Supreme Council of Cyberspace sessions (2021–2023), ministerial proposals, and parliament advisory letters, supplemented by articles from Persian-language strategic journals affiliated with Iran’s intelligence and military establishments. The analysis situates these primary sources within the concept of strategic culture—defined as a set of shared beliefs, narratives, and behavioral norms that shape a nation’s security objectives and institutional design—and assesses how these cultural assumptions translate into cyber governance structures and operational priorities. Findings reveal that Iran’s strategic culture, characterized by self-reliance and defensiveness against perceived external threats, drove substantial state investment in cyber capabilities and centralized coordination under the Supreme Council of Cyberspace created in 2012. Key state actors—the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) and the Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS)—emerge as the principal architects and executors of both offensive and defensive cyber operations, reflecting a dual emphasis on protecting critical infrastructure and controlling domestic information flows to maintain regime stability. While centralized doctrinal clarity and state funding constitute systemic strengths, persistent weaknesses are exposed in technical infrastructure, threat monitoring, and organizational discipline. The study also uncovers a deliberate preference for indigenous technical solutions and cautious cyber diplomacy, even as Iran forges closer technical cooperation with strategic partners such as Russia and China. By integrating previously overlooked Persian-language scholarship with primary leaked materials, the research offers an empirically rich, culturally attuned model of state-led cyber defense that extends existing scholarship on cyber policy. Limitations concerning the authenticity and representativeness of leaked data are acknowledged and mitigated through credibility assessments, while recommendations for future research include exploring Iran’s cyber collaboration dynamics with external partners, the impact of political shocks on strategic culture’s adaptability, and implications for international cyber norms and deterrence frameworks. This study thus advances understanding of how ingrained cultural assumptions shape cyber policy and institutional behavior in non-Western contexts, providing a template for comparative analyses of strategic culture’s role in global cyber conflict.

title: Small actors, big disruptions: the chaos of shadow strikes in asymmetric cyber warfare
source: International Conference on Cyber Warfare and Security
abstract: This paper examines the emergence and strategic impact of ‘shadow strikes’—asymmetric cyber operations carried out by small, resource-constrained actors that inflict disproportionate harm on state-level adversaries. Drawing on three landmark case studies—Stuxnet’s disruption of Iran’s nuclear facilities, Operation Aurora’s exploitation of global supply chain vulnerabilities, and the Ukraine power grid attack’s demonstration of cyber-physical coercion—it reveals how attackers leverage cyberspace’s borderless anonymity, low entry barriers, and systemic interdependencies to bypass conventional defenses and destabilize critical infrastructures. Employing a mixed-methods comparative analysis, the study synthesizes technical forensic reports, government advisories, and industry white papers with theoretical constructs from Foucault’s networked power dynamics, Bourdieu’s capital and fields, and Habermas’s communicative legitimacy to elucidate the relational, structural, and discursive mechanisms underlying asymmetric cyber conflict. The findings identify recurring vulnerabilities in industrial control systems, software supply chains, and human factors, showing how shadow actors deploy low-cost tactics—ransomware, phishing, distributed denial-of-service—and strategic communication campaigns to generate cascading failures, erode institutional trust, and amplify symbolic impact. Theory-driven insights reveal that cultural capital, including technical expertise and insider knowledge, underpins the attacker’s advantage, while cognitive warfare initiatives leverage disinformation to undermine public confidence and institutional legitimacy. In response, the paper proposes a comprehensive resilience framework integrating Zero Trust Architecture for continuous verification and micro-segmentation, AI-driven behavioral analytics for real-time threat detection, DevSecOps practices and automated supply chain risk assessments to secure software dependencies, and multilateral cyber defense agreements to strengthen information sharing and normative enforcement. It further recommends mandatory ICS reporting protocols, workforce development programs, and proactive cyber diplomacy measures—such as economic sanctions and standardized incident response—to enhance deterrence and accountability. Acknowledging limitations related to case selection and secondary data reliance, the study calls for expanded empirical research on emerging cyber-physical threats and rigorous evaluation of proposed frameworks in diverse contexts. By bridging technical, organizational, and policy domains, this research advances a multidisciplinary paradigm for cyber conflict analysis and offers a pragmatic roadmap for policymakers, security professionals, and scholars to bolster adaptive resilience against asymmetric threats in the evolving cyber landscape.

title: Cyberattacks on Lunar (and other Non-Earth Orbiting) Satellites: Legal Issues
abstract: The rapid expansion of the lunar economy and the limited number of satellites orbiting the Moon have created a new frontier of cyber risk that demands urgent legal and policy attention. As governmental and commercial actors alike deploy assets into cislunar space, adversaries are likely to exploit vulnerabilities in command and control systems, satellite communications, and ground segment infrastructure to disrupt or degrade lunar capabilities. This paper addresses the pressing need to clarify the legal regime governing cyberattacks on lunar and other non-Earth orbiting satellites by situating the analysis at the intersection of emerging space activities and established international law norms. Its primary objective is to determine whether cyber operations against lunar satellites constitute internationally wrongful acts or armed attacks and to assess the scope of the right of self-defense under the UN Charter and the Outer Space Treaty (OST). Employing a doctrinal methodology grounded in treaty interpretation and state practice, the author conducts a comprehensive review of specific lunar missions and commercial projects, comparative case studies of cyber incidents against Earth-orbiting satellites, and textual analysis of foundational space treaties and military manuals. Key findings reveal that cyberattacks on satellites can meet the threshold of internationally wrongful acts and, under certain effects-based criteria, may qualify as armed attacks triggering Article 51 of the UN Charter. A detailed examination of Article IV of the OST and related treaty provisions demonstrates that the treaty’s restrictions on weapons deployment in space do not bar states from exercising self-defense through cyber means when confronted with hostile actions against their space assets. The paper contributes a normative argument and legal framework asserting that the inherent right of self-defense prevails over OST limitations, thereby affirming and extending space security for lunar satellites. This framework addresses both governmental and commercial assets, emphasizing the vital role of clear legal norms in deterring adversarial cyber behavior. The analysis acknowledges limitations stemming from the nascent state of lunar operations, the reliance on Earth-orbit analogies in the absence of actual lunar cyber incidents, and potential ambiguities in attributing cyber intrusions in cislunar space. The author suggests avenues for future research including empirical studies of emerging lunar satellite architectures, development of technical measures for attribution and resilience, and multilateral negotiations to elaborate norms and confidence-building measures tailored to cyber operations in non-Earth orbits.

title: International law attempts to protect critical infrastructures against malicious cyber operations
abstract: This article by Kouloufakos offers a comprehensive legal analysis of how existing international law frameworks seek to safeguard critical infrastructures from malicious cyber operations. The study begins by mapping the current landscape of critical infrastructure protection, defining critical infrastructure in the context of state security, public welfare, and global interdependence. It examines how cyber operations targeting critical systems—such as energy grids, telecommunications networks, transportation systems, and financial infrastructures—pose existential threats that transcend national borders, yet often fall into legal grey zones: below the threshold of armed conflict yet above mere criminality. The author then systematically reviews the applicability of core principles of international humanitarian law (IHL) and international human rights law (IHRL) to cyber activities. Through careful doctrinal research, the article argues that while IHL’s principles of distinction, proportionality, and military necessity can theoretically constrain cyberattacks during armed conflict, there remains uncertainty over when and whether a cyber operation qualifies as a use of force under the UN Charter. The study highlights divergent state positions on the threshold for “armed attack” in cyberspace and underscores the need for customary international law to evolve. Next, it analyzes recent UN General Assembly resolutions, the Tallinn Manual project, and European Union directives—including the NIS Directive—and evaluates their practical impact on state and non-state actor obligations. The article identifies key legal gaps: the challenge of attribution, jurisdictional barriers to enforcing sanctions, and the absence of binding norms on due diligence obligations for states to prevent cyber harm emanating from their territory. Drawing on case studies in Eastern Europe and critical infrastructure breaches in North America and Asia, Kouloufakos illustrates how states have responded with sanctions regimes, mutual legal assistance treaties, and proposed multilateral agreements. The article concludes with policy recommendations to strengthen the international legal order: adopting a clear legal definition of cyber armed attack, codifying state responsibility and due diligence in cyberspace, enhancing transnational cooperation mechanisms, and integrating resilience and public-private partnership models into treaty frameworks. By bridging doctrinal analysis with emerging practice, the study provides a roadmap for policymakers and legal scholars seeking to bolster the protection of essential services and uphold international peace and security in an era of escalating cyber threats.

title: Collective Countermeasures in Response to Cyber Operations under International Law International Law and Cybersecurity
source: Legal Issues in the Digital Age
abstract: This article by Mikanagi and Mačák provides a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the United States’ prosecution of North Korean national Park Jin Hyok for his alleged role in state-sponsored cyber operations, including the WannaCry ransomware attack, offering critical insight into the evolving nexus between technical attribution capabilities and the application of international law to cyberspace. The authors begin by reviewing the U.S. government’s technical and factual evidence—ranging from network forensics and IP tracing to malware analysis—demonstrating that, despite inherent challenges such as resource constraints and the opacity of state cooperation, modern investigative techniques can yield robust indicators of cyber operation origin and actor identity. They then interrogate the adequacy of the 2001 Articles on State Responsibility (ASR)’s substantive rules, highlighting the tension between these pre-cyber norms—which require proof of state control or direction over individual acts—and the dispersed, proxy-driven architecture of malicious cyber campaigns. Drawing on International Court of Justice jurisprudence, the authors examine procedural uncertainties around standards of proof and the admissibility of circumstantial evidence, arguing that tribunals, when faced with non-cooperating states, may invoke flexible evidentiary approaches and lower thresholds for non-grave breaches. Recognizing persistent gaps between technical and legal attribution, the article evaluates proposals for independent international attribution mechanisms, noting both state interest and the enduring reliance on ad hoc, decentralized assessments by public and private entities. As an alternative pathway, the authors advance due diligence as a complementary route to state responsibility, mapping six cumulative conditions—existence of wrongful acts, emanation from state territory, unlawfulness if state-attributable, serious adverse consequences, state knowledge, and failure to adopt feasible countermeasures—against the Park affidavit. They conclude that, although primary law thresholds (such as the scope of sovereignty and “serious adverse consequences”) require further definition, the affidavit’s allegations of operations launched from North Korean infrastructure, combined with evidence of governmental awareness and inaction, could satisfy due diligence obligations when direct attribution fails, thereby offering a practical palliative to the attribution problem. The article closes with policy recommendations, urging states to clarify opinio juris in ongoing UN processes—the renewed Group of Governmental Experts and the Open-Ended Working Group—and consider institutionalizing an independent attribution body to strengthen accountability and stability in cyberspace.

title: Cyberattacks in the context of international law enforcement
abstract:
Purpose – The article "Cyberattacks in the context of international law enforcement" by D. Alweqyan critically examines the emerging dilemma posed by cyberattacks and cyberwarfare under existing domestic and international legal frameworks. It highlights the exponential rise in cybercrime and state-sponsored cyber operations over recent decades, contending that current international law, largely designed to address kinetic armed conflict, fails to fully capture the unique characteristics of cyberspace operations. 

Design/methodology/approach – The author conducts a comparative legal analysis in three parts. Part I assesses whether cyberattacks should be treated as domestic crimes under national criminal statutes or as international crimes attracting the laws of war. Part II applies core principles of international law—including the UN Charter’s prohibition on the use of force (Article 2(4)), the right to self-defense (Article 51), and state responsibility—to cyber operations. Part III addresses attribution challenges and the involvement of nonstate actors, evaluating when a state may legitimately invoke its right to respond. The analysis draws on scholarly commentary and key instruments such as the Tallinn Manual, the UN’s Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts, and national cybercrime laws.

Findings – Alweqyan finds that domestic criminal law alone is insufficient to address cross-border cyberattacks because of attribution difficulties, divergent national definitions, and gaps in enforcement—exemplified by non-compliant states such as Russia and China. Moreover, decriminalizing cyberwarfare as mere domestic crime undermines state sovereignty and self-defence prerogatives. Conversely, framing cyberattacks as acts of aggression under international law better protects states’ legal rights. Using the “instrument approach” and “effects approach,” the article argues that cyber operations causing equivalent harm to traditional armed attacks—such as shutting down critical infrastructure—constitute armed attacks triggering the use of force under Article 51. Landmark incidents, including the 2007 Russian assault on Estonia and the 2012 Shamoon virus strike on Saudi Aramco, illustrate how cyber operations can meet the threshold of aggression.

Originality/value – The study provides a multidisciplinary perspective by synthesizing criminal, international humanitarian, and state responsibility law to propose a cohesive legal framework for cyber conflict. It recommends clarifying the definition of cyberattacks at the domestic and international levels, codifying state obligations in cyber operations, and developing tailored international instruments or treaty regimes to bridge current legal lacunae. The author suggests establishing an international cybercrime convention with strong attribution and enforcement mechanisms and reinforcing UN Security Council oversight to deter state-sponsored cyber aggression. By juxtaposing domestic criminal statutes from jurisdictions such as the USA, EU, Jordan, UAE, Germany, Kuwait, and the UK with international law norms, the paper offers unprecedented solutions for harmonizing cyber legal regimes.

title: Countering cyberattacks: gaps in international law and prospects for overcoming them
source: Journal of Digital Technologies and Law
abstract: This article by Rahman and Das provides a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the international legal frameworks regulating state conduct in cyberspace, identifies critical gaps that hinder effective countermeasures, and proposes a novel tiered framework for legitimate state cyber countermeasures. The authors pursue three core research questions: how cyberattacks and cyber warfare are classified under international law and national legislations; what legal frameworks and methods states and international institutions employ to counter cyber threats; and how international law and institutions might evolve to meet dynamic digital challenges. Employing formal, comparative, inductive, deductive, and forecasting methodologies, the study systematically examines international conventions, national statutes, judicial precedents, and doctrinal sources—including the UN Charter, Tallinn Manual, bilateral agreements, and leading scholarly works—to map the existing countermeasure regime. The analysis begins by unpacking the attribution conundrum in cyberspace, exploring the challenges of ascribing responsibility to state and non-state actors given anonymity, transnational infrastructures, and sophisticated obfuscation tactics. It highlights the accountability dilemma and the absence of standardized verification measures for cyber weapons. Next, the authors examine the principle of due diligence as a benchmark for state conduct, clarifying obligations to prevent malicious cyber operations originating within a state’s territory. They then assess the calibration of proportionality in cyber countermeasures, probing how traditional proportionality tests translate into the cyber context amid asymmetric capabilities and diffuse collateral harms. The study identifies obstacles to global collaboration—divergent national practices and the lack of binding norms—and scrutinizes the legal boundaries of anticipatory self-defence in cyberspace. The interplay between cyber countermeasures and human rights is addressed, emphasizing potential infringements on privacy, freedom of expression, and infrastructure protections in both peacetime and armed conflict. Through a critical survey of existing instruments, the article outlines urgent issues: the need for clear thresholds and use-of-force criteria, codification of cyber weapons definitions, and development of disarmament or limitation mechanisms for offensive cyber capabilities. In response, Rahman and Das propose a progressive, tiered countermeasure framework grounded in due diligence, lawful decision-making procedures, and proportionality calibrated to the severity of harm. They recommend multilateral norm-building processes, integration of human rights safeguards into cybersecurity regimes, and institutional innovations—such as an international convention or dedicated agency—to translate emerging cyber norms into binding rules. Acknowledging limitations posed by the rapid evolution of cyber operations and uneven state practice, the authors call for empirical validation of their model instruments, operationalized disarmament protocols, refinement of attribution technologies within legal thresholds, and enhanced state cooperation. This multidisciplinary approach advances both theoretical and practical underpinnings of cyber law, offering a roadmap to strengthen coherence and effectiveness of state responses to cyberattacks in an increasingly contested digital environment.

title: Conceptualising cyber deterrence and policy options for Pakistan
source: Journal of Security and Strategic Analyses
abstract: This paper examines the evolving challenges of applying traditional deterrence theory to the cyber domain and develops tailored policy options for Pakistan within the context of its longstanding strategic rivalry with India. Drawing on classical nuclear deterrence paradigms and recent scholarship in cyber conflict, the authors first trace the historical evolution of deterrence theory—from Bernard Brodie’s ‘‘absolute weapon’’ framework to Schelling’s game-theoretic analysis, through second-wave flexibility and third-wave critiques of rational decision-making—before adapting its core concepts to cyberspace. They argue that neither the mutually assured destruction model nor simple punitive retaliation can be directly translated to an environment characterized by anonymity, low entry costs, rapid attack cycles, and a multiplicity of state and non-state actors. Cyber deterrence, they contend, must therefore rest on a hybrid approach that balances denial and punishment strategies. Through a conceptual comparative analysis, the paper demonstrates that denial-based measures—such as robust hardening of critical infrastructure, adoption of international cyber norms consistent with the Lucca Declaration, and multilateral cooperation—offer a more sustainable foundation for resilience against spoofed attribution and asymmetric incursions. Punishment-based deterrence, meanwhile, must adopt a cumulative retaliation strategy calibrated to preserve credibility without triggering uncontrolled escalation or cross-domain kinetic responses. To operationalize these principles, the authors propose a suite of confidence-building measures between Pakistan and India, including a dedicated cyber hotline parallel to the DGMO channel, joint probing committees of cyber experts to investigate incidents, and formalized ‘‘rules of engagement’’ that safeguard critical infrastructure in line with the 1991 Non-Nuclear Aggression Treaty. These mechanisms aim to reduce misperception risks, marginalize non-state spoilers, and foster transparency, thereby creating strategic space for de-escalation in crisis scenarios. The paper also acknowledges practical constraints: the inherent offense-dominant bias of cyber operations makes strengthening defenses resource-intensive and technologically challenging; hostile bilateral relations may impede norm adoption and cooperative enforcement; and attribution deficits limit the immediacy of punitive threats. Nevertheless, by integrating deterrence theory with pragmatic policy design, the study articulates a conceptual blueprint for Pakistan’s cyber strategy that emphasizes denial in peacetime and calibrated cumulative punishment if deterrence fails—while cautioning that any response must remain confined to the cyber domain to avert cross-domain escalation. Finally, the authors call for future empirical research to model escalation thresholds, refine attribution capabilities, and explore legal frameworks for codifying norms under international law. Overall, this multidisciplinary analysis enriches the discourse on state behavior in cyber-nuclear environments and offers actionable recommendations for South Asian cyber stability.

title: Bridging the Gap: Strengthening Canada's Legal Framework Against Cyber Espionage
abstract: This paper critically examines Canada’s legal framework to confront the escalating threat of cyber espionage, situating its analysis within a comparative study of Canadian and United States law and international legal norms. In its introductory sections, the author articulates the definition, objectives, and principal actors in cyber espionage—drawing upon judicial definitions such as Qu v Canada and scholarly conceptions by Herb Lin and Russell Buchan—to distinguish espionage from cyber warfare. The paper then maps the international legal landscape, surveying pertinent treaties and customary norms that shape states’ authority to respond to covert cyber intrusions. It transitions to a comprehensive review of Canada’s domestic statutes, including the CSIS Act, the Security of Information Act, and the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, as well as landmark Federal Court decisions like China Mobile Communications Group Co Ltd v Canada and Yihdego v Canada, to evaluate current enforcement capabilities. Parallel examination of the U.S. cybersecurity framework and the Economic Espionage Act reveals divergent approaches, underscoring gaps in Canada’s capacity for prosecution and deterrence. Building on this comparative analysis, the author argues that Canada requires a multi-tiered legislative overhaul: adoption of clearer statutory definitions, establishment of a centralized cyber espionage incident database, ratification of targeted bilateral and multilateral treaties, and integration of mandatory cyber security protocols for critical infrastructure. The recommendations emphasize enhanced international cooperation, streamlined domestic procedures for evidence sharing, and calibrated penalties that reflect the severity of state-sponsored espionage. Concluding with a call for holistic legal innovation, the paper contributes to the discourse on state responsibility in cyberspace and offers a roadmap for strengthening national security through legal reform.

title: Cyber diplomacy through official public attribution: paving the way for global norms
abstract: This article investigates how the emerging practice of official public attribution by states is shaping international cyber norms and state behavior in cyberspace. In the absence of clear, enforceable rules governing state-sponsored cyber operations, states risk miscalculation and escalation. Official public attribution—publicly naming and blaming a state actor for cyberattacks—has become an informal mechanism to signal disapproval and delineate unacceptable conduct. The author first conducts a quantitative exploratory analysis of data from the European Repository of Cyber Incidents spanning 2000–2023, revealing a marked increase in attribution events by Western states since the mid-2010s. This trend underscores a growing willingness to publicly hold perpetrators accountable and communicates strategic expectations of acceptable behavior. Next, through a detailed case study of Iran’s 2022 cyberattack on Albania, the paper reconstructs the sequence of events and diplomatic responses, drawing on official statements by Albania’s prime minister, the United States, the United Kingdom, NATO, and open-source intelligence. Albania’s decision to sever diplomatic ties with Iran, bolstered by coordinated attributions from its allies, exemplifies the political utility of public attribution: it imposes reputational costs, clarifies ‘‘facts on the ground,’’ and implicitly defines forbidden actions. Framed within Finnemore and Sikkink’s norm life cycle—emergence, acceptance, internalization—the paper conceptualizes attribution events as norm–entrepreneurship acts that can catalyze a normative cascade among like-minded states even as formal United Nations negotiations remain stalled. The author argues that repeated attribution events cumulatively reinforce normative commitments and serve as informal enforcement mechanisms operating in parallel to formal UN processes. While acknowledging the nascent state of this practice and limitations such as reliance on public sources and the opacity of classified deliberations, the study proposes a framework for understanding public attribution as part of a broader cyber diplomacy toolkit. The paper concludes by recommending avenues for future research, including systematic longitudinal studies assessing behavioral changes among accused states, comparative analyses of attribution practices across geopolitical blocs, and examinations of the interplay between public attribution and formal norm-setting within UN fora. Through this multidisciplinary lens—integrating policy analysis, international relations theory, and empirical case methods—the article advances our understanding of how states leverage public attribution to foster accountability, shape international expectations, and pave the way for the emergence and codification of global cyber norms.

title: Mapping the Position of States on the Application of Sovereignty in Cyberspace
source: Polish Review of International and European Law
abstract: This article offers a systematic and comprehensive mapping of how states articulate and apply the principle and rule of sovereignty within the context of cyberspace, filling a critical gap in our understanding of the normative architecture governing state conduct in digital domains. Drawing on a detailed survey of 27 individual state positions and a collective declaration by the 55 member states of the African Union, the author, Lukasz Kulaga, identifies three predominant conceptual models of cyber sovereignty. The first model treats sovereignty as an international authority that requires explicit consent for cross-border cyber operations; the second conceptualizes sovereignty as a ‘‘soft norm’’ that guides state behavior without generating binding legal obligations; and the third regards sovereignty as an enforceable rule, the violation of which constitutes an internationally wrongful act. Grounding his analysis in the findings of the 2015 and 2021 United Nations Group of Governmental Experts reports—which acknowledged the relevance of sovereignty in cyberspace but left its practical contours undefined—Kulaga explores the critical distinction between principles and rules in international law, demonstrating how each model yields different implications for state practice and legal accountability. Key components of cyber sovereignty distilled from state declarations include jurisdictional claims over domestic infrastructure, the prohibition of harmful effects resulting from unauthorized access, and the protection of governmental functions from cyber interference. The article shows that while there is broad consensus on states’ jurisdictional rights and on proscribing harmful cyber effects, significant divergence remains regarding the permissibility of cyber espionage and non-violent unauthorized access. Kulaga further interrogates the intersection of sovereignty with the principle of non-intervention, illustrating how states vary in their categorization of espionage and other ‘‘non-harmful’’ intrusions as either permissible peacetime conduct or violations of sovereign prerogatives. The study also examines the emerging doctrine of due diligence in cyberspace, whereby states articulate positive obligations to prevent malicious cyber operations emanating from or transiting their territories. In its concluding sections, the article reflects on two broader normative questions: whether the sustained effort to define how general international law applies to cyberspace signals the emergence of a de facto lex specialis for cyber activities, and whether the proliferation of soft-law instruments and responsible-state-behavior frameworks strengthens or dilutes the enforceability of sovereign rights online. By synthesizing convergent and divergent state positions and by clarifying the conceptual underpinnings of cyber sovereignty, this work provides a foundational resource for scholars, policymakers, and legal practitioners seeking to navigate and shape the evolving rules of state conduct in cyberspace.

title: Enhancing accountability in cyberspace through a three-tiered international governance regime
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College.
abstract: In this article, Dan Efrony examines the acute deficiencies in the current international legal and normative framework governing state-sponsored cyber operations, arguing that soft-law norms and ad hoc attribution processes have consistently failed to deter politically motivated cyber attacks or to garner legitimate, broad-based support. Situating his analysis within the accelerating Great Power Competition among the United States, China, and Russia—nations whose rivals seek to challenge the Western-led international order—Efrony underscores the inadequacy of existing soft-law instruments such as the UN’s non-binding cyber norms and the Five Eyes’ collective attribution process, which suffer from legitimacy deficits, limited enforcement, and an inability to forestall rising levels of cyber aggression. He analogizes this failure to the Biological Weapons Convention’s enforcement gaps, noting that despite the recognized global threat posed by cyber ‘‘weapons,’’ no binding, enforceable mechanisms have been devised to regulate state behavior in cyberspace. Recognizing the geopolitical impossibility of achieving universal consensus on binding cyber rules in the current fraught climate, Efrony proposes instead a pragmatic ‘‘Triple-I’’ international governance regime comprising three interlocking tiers designed to reinforce one another and break the vicious cycle of unilateral action and under-regulation: first, an International Cyber Attribution Mechanism, an independent and impartial investigatory body operating according to transparent criteria and procedures to deliver official, multilateral attributions of state-sponsored cyber operations with greater legitimacy than unilateral statements; second, an International Cyber Security Initiative, which builds upon existing non-binding norms and coalitions—such as the List of Non-Binding Norms and the International Counter Ransomware Initiative—to harmonize cybersecurity standards, bolster collective deterrence, and strengthen member states’ defensive capabilities; and third, an International Cyber Law Convention, a comprehensive treaty that would codify binding rules of state conduct in cyberspace and embed both the Attribution Mechanism and the Cyber Security Initiative within its enforcement framework. Efrony carefully analyzes state practice, policy speeches, multilateral initiatives, and relevant legal instruments to demonstrate how these tiers mutually reinforce legal, security, and investigative pillars capable of transforming the international cyber regime. He emphasizes that the feasibility of the Triple-I hinges on a coalition of value-aligned states—led by sustained U.S. political will—and acknowledges residual risks such as exposure of sensitive intelligence and selective non-participation by some powers. The article concludes with concrete recommendations for further research on designing the Attribution Mechanism’s operational structure, strategies for coalition building, treaty rule-making processes, and the integration of private sector and civil society stakeholders to ensure the regime’s adaptability, legitimacy, and long-term effectiveness.

title: Trust, interdependence, and power in cyber statecraft
abstract:
Datta’s “Trust, Interdependence, and Power in Cyber Statecraft” offers a unified theoretical framework for understanding how states deploy cyber capabilities through the lenses of trust and interdependence within global information ecosystems. Recognizing a gap in political theory on cyber statecraft, the study defines “cyber statecraft” as the full spectrum of methods—espionage, sabotage, extortion, intellectual property theft, and supply-chain manipulation—employed by states to achieve political, economic, social, and technological objectives. Drawing on parallels with Cold War economic statecraft, Datta introduces a tripartite model linking structural interdependence (data flows, supply chains, telecommunications chokepoints), trust dynamics (information symmetry between states and private actors), and coercive power projection in cyberspace.

The article begins by posing fundamental questions: why do some states adopt offensive postures while others emphasize defense? How do domestic political economies constrain or enable these strategies? And how does trust, treated as an attribute of information systems, moderate the exercise of power? To answer these, Datta synthesizes interdisciplinary scholarship on power, interdependence, and trust, highlighting weaponized interdependence theory and economic sanctions paradigms. She then develops a typology of heuristics states employ—from traditional information operations to novel coercive techniques—and maps these onto state preferences for offense versus defense.

Key contributions include comparative analysis of Western and Chinese cyber ecosystems. Western democracies, characterized by multistakeholder governance and transatlantic alliances, leverage transparent norms and inclusive governance to preserve information symmetry while deploying coercive tools. In contrast, China’s state-led ecosystem uses legal instruments—data localization and counter-espionage laws—to exert domestic control and support corporate champions for geopolitical influence. Through case studies such as Stuxnet, Chinese semiconductor policy, and Western measures against Huawei, the paper demonstrates how varying political economies shape strategic outcomes and how weaponized interdependence can both enhance coercive leverage and erode trust, risking fragmentation of cyberspace.

Datta concludes by calling for updated policy frameworks that integrate trust preservation mechanisms—reciprocal data-sharing agreements, transparency norms, and inclusive governance structures—to mitigate misperception and escalation. This work lays the groundwork for future empirical research on the political economy of cyber conflict, the evolution of international cyber law, and the design of resilient architectures for cross-border cooperation in cyberspace.

title: Bytes and battles: pathways to de-escalation in the cyber conflict arena
abstract:
In “Bytes and Battles: Pathways to De-escalation in the Cyber Conflict Arena,” Royakkers explores the evolving landscape of state-based cyber conflict and proposes strategic, normative, and cooperative approaches to mitigate escalation and prevent cyber operations from spilling over into traditional kinetic warfare. Framing cyberspace as a “fifth dimension” of military strategy, the paper chronicles how major powers—the United States, Russia, China, and others—have developed offensive cyber capabilities encompassing sabotage, espionage, and disinformation, while simultaneously grappling with the challenges of attribution, legal ambiguity, and escalation risk. Drawing on illustrative cases such as Stuxnet, Operation Olympic Games, Russian cyber operations against Ukraine, and suspected Chinese economic espionage, the author highlights a continuum ranging from “cold” cyber conflict—where covert espionage and disinformation campaigns occur without open damage—to “hot” cyber conflict characterized by overt sabotage that directly harms civil infrastructure. Royakkers observes that states exploit the opacity of attribution through “non-denial denials” and retain plausible deniability to shape adversaries’ threat perceptions and preserve escalation stability. 

Noting that existing legal frameworks struggle to keep pace with novel forms of digital aggression, the paper surveys gaps in international law, including uncertainties over whether cyber sabotage constitutes an armed attack under humanitarian law and how the UN Charter’s Article 2(4) applies in cyberspace. The author contends that reliance on unilateral cyber retaliation or deterrence strategies is morally and practically problematic, as it perpetuates weapon proliferation and seldom yields decisive security benefits. Instead, Royakkers advances five complementary pathways to de-escalation and a more stable cyber strategic environment: 1) enhancing international cybersecurity collaboration by revitalizing multilateral fora, building trust through shared threat intelligence, and developing robust verification mechanisms for cyber arms-control; 2) establishing clear and enforceable cyber norms that delineate acceptable state behavior, restrict offensive operations against critical infrastructure and civilian targets, and codify responsibilities under international humanitarian law; 3) ensuring responsible management of cyber arsenals by obliging states to disclose and patch known vulnerabilities, coordinate with technology vendors, and jointly monitor arsenals to prevent uncontrolled proliferation or boomerang effects; 4) protecting the operational independence of global technology companies by preventing undue state influence or coercion, encouraging adherence to voluntary accords such as the Cybersecurity Tech Accord and Paris Call for Trust and Security, and developing export control regimes that restrict sale of offensive cyber tools to untrustworthy regimes; and 5) investing in public engagement and democratic oversight through civic education on cyber threats, transparent government reporting on cyber operations, and inclusive debate on national cyber strategies. 

By weaving normative analysis with policy prescriptions and real-world examples, Royakkers positions her work at the intersection of cyber policy, ethics, and international law. The paper concludes that while true “cyberwar” has yet to erupt, the ever-present “always-on” nature of cyber conflict poses profound risks to democratic institutions, economic stability, and global peace. Only through concerted, multidisciplinary efforts—combining legal innovation, technical cooperation, and societal mobilization—can states chart a path toward durable de-escalation in cyberspace.

title: Applying international law to cross-border cyber attacks sponsored by state actors
abstract: This article by Saili Hernandez examines the critical challenge posed by cross-border cyberattacks sponsored by state actors and evaluates the extent to which existing international law, particularly the jus ad bellum framework codified in the United Nations Charter, can address such operations in cyberspace. Hernandez begins by identifying a growing frequency of state-sponsored cyber intrusions—ranging from Estonia’s 2007 distributed denial-of-service attack to recent operations attributed to Russia, China, Iran, and North Korea—and underscores the deficiencies in current legal frameworks, which were originally drafted for kinetic uses of force. Through a doctrinal analysis of Articles 2(4) and 51 of the UN Charter, she demonstrates that prevailing definitions of “threat or use of force” and “armed attack” lack the precision required to guide attribution, determine thresholds of coercion, and incorporate non-state actors under state responsibility. The article then turns to case studies: the 2007 Estonia DDoS campaign, cyber operations between Russia and Ukraine, and alleged threats from China and Iran, applying traditional jus ad bellum tests and finding them insufficient to capture the nuances of cyber aggression. Hernandez also explores the intersection of cyber law and outer space law, focusing on satellite cyberattacks such as the Viasat KA-SAT incident and malware infections aboard the International Space Station, and contrasts the distinct regulatory regimes governing space and cyberspace. These examples reveal divergent state interests, attribution challenges, and the absence of binding norms, thereby impeding deterrence and response. Addressing these gaps, Hernandez proposes a comprehensive International Cyber Treaty modeled on the multilateral Outer Space Treaty. She outlines a conceptual framework that would: codify clear definitions of cyberattack and use of force in cyberspace; establish binding norms for state behavior and mechanisms for attribution; include guidelines for collective defense and assistance; integrate non-state actors under state responsibility; and leverage UN expert bodies to monitor compliance and build capacity in resource-constrained states. The proposed treaty would reconcile conflicting standards, clarify contested legal concepts, and strengthen collective response capabilities. Hernandez acknowledges limitations posed by the non-binding nature of current UN resolutions, the political frictions among major cyber powers, and the nascent stage of cyber norm development, but argues that, as with Cold War diplomacy leading to the Outer Space Treaty, divergent geopolitical interests need not preclude consensus on cyber governance. She calls for further empirical research into state practice, refinement of legal tests for cyber use of force, and engagement with multidisciplinary experts to transform normative proposals into enforceable commitments that enhance global cyber stability. The article contributes to cyber law scholarship by articulating the insufficiencies of existing legal frameworks and advancing a tangible, treaty-based path to address state-sponsored cyber conflict.

title: Unraveling the impact of deepfakes on international conflict through the lens of information warfare: an analysis
source: Lawfoyer International Journal of Doctrinal Legal Research
abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of how emerging deepfake technologies are reshaping international conflict governance through information warfare and assesses the adequacy of existing legal instruments and policy frameworks to address these threats. The study opens by tracing the evolution of deepfake technology—highly realistic AI‐generated audio‐visual manipulations—and situates its rapid proliferation within the broader context of state‐sponsored and state‐tolerated disinformation campaigns. Through critical examination of foundational international agreements including the Geneva Conventions, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the EU Code of Practice on Disinformation, the author demonstrates that these treaties lack explicit provisions on synthetic media, leaving significant attribution, jurisdictional, and enforcement gaps. The paper reinforces these theoretical critiques with three emblematic case studies: the Pelosi video controversy, the Navalny poisoning deepfake incident, and disruptions at an EU Diplomatic Summit. Each case illustrates how current legal norms struggle to assign responsibility, deter malign actors, and preserve diplomatic norms under duress from AI‐driven deception. The analysis then surveys national regulatory regimes—India’s Information Technology Act, U.S. digital disinformation statutes, and the U.K.’s regulatory regime under the Information Commissioner’s Office—highlighting their uneven readiness and failures to integrate human rights and ethical safeguards. In response to these deficiencies, the author proposes a suite of policy recommendations: amendments to existing treaties to explicitly criminalize deepfake misuse in interstate disputes; the establishment of a Global Cybersecurity Agreement among major powers to facilitate real‐time threat intelligence sharing; a Transparency and Attribution Accord to standardize investigative processes; and the integration of human rights and ethical principles into national AI governance. Specific measures include creating a federal oversight body in the U.S. to monitor technological harms, clarifying deepfake liability within India’s IT Act, and guiding the U.K.’s ICO in balancing free expression with security imperatives. The paper concludes by acknowledging limitations—namely, the rapid pace of AI innovation and persistent cross‐border enforcement challenges—and calls for future research on dynamic legal architectures, interoperable attribution technologies, and multilateral threat intelligence frameworks. By charting a proactive legal and policy roadmap, this analysis advances the multidisciplinary discourse on cyber conflict and offers strategic pathways to fortify international order against deepfake‐enabled information warfare.

title: Attributing Digital Covert Action: the curious case of WikiSaudileaks
abstract: The study addresses the persistent challenge of attributing digital covert action by revisiting the 2015 ‘WikiSaudiLeaks’ hack-and-leak—a high-profile, unresolved case in which a trove of Saudi Foreign Ministry documents surfaced online under the guise of having been provided to WikiLeaks. This paper highlights the significance of early and complex digital covert campaigns that evade traditional attribution paradigms and seeks to understand why WikiSaudiLeaks remained unattributed when other comparable operations were successfully linked to state actors. The authors aim to demonstrate that hack-and-leak events are often composite operations involving network exploitation, attack, deception, and influence, and they pose the research question of whether deconstructing such events into discrete stages can enable limited attribution. Employing a qualitative case-study methodology, the authors conduct the most detailed public investigation of WikiSaudiLeaks to date, drawing on open-source data, press reports, and technical analyses to map the sequence of collection, disclosure, and amplification efforts. They perform a granular reconstruction of each phase, identify persistent deception tactics and a covert influence campaign, and survey competing hypotheses regarding potential perpetrators. Their findings reveal that the apparent unity of the leak conceals multiple operations with varying evidentiary profiles and that at least one component of the campaign can be confidently attributed to Iranian intelligence. By proposing a multi-stage attribution framework, the paper contributes a novel conceptual model for analyzing hack-and-leak events and offers new insights into how states manage deniability and investigative responses. The authors acknowledge that their analysis is constrained by reliance on publicly available material and the absence of declassified intelligence, which limits the confidence and completeness of attribution judgments. They call for further archival research, comparative studies of early hack-and-leak cases, and refined methods for integrating technical, operational, and political indicators to advance the theory and practice of digital covert action attribution.

title: Can a Cyberattack Become an Act of War? European and Trans-Atlantic Perspectives
authors: Sorin Ducaru; Mihail Caradaica; Ana Maria Costea
abstract: The proliferation of cyberattacks against state and critical infrastructure in recent years has challenged traditional understandings of war and collective defense, prompting NATO and its members to confront whether a sufficiently severe cyber incident could amount to an act of war under Article 5 of the Washington Treaty. This question has gained urgency as digitalization accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic and notable incidents such as WannaCry, Stuxnet, SolarWinds, and Heartbleed demonstrated how nonkinetic operations can inflict physical, economic, and societal harm while testing the limits of existing legal and strategic frameworks. The authors address the central research questions: can a cyberattack be considered an act of war, and under what circumstances might NATO invoke its collective defense clause in response to such an attack? Through a qualitative methodology comprising a specialized literature review, procedural analysis of NATO cyber policy evolution, and a comparative evaluation of national cybersecurity strategies of members pre-2023, the study examines how allies define cyber threats, categorize actors, and establish thresholds for invoking Article 5. The literature review incorporates international law perspectives such as the Tallinn Manual, classical and contemporary theories of war, and emerging scholarship on cyber deterrence. NATO developments analyzed include key summit declarations and policy statements from Prague (2002), Riga (2006), Defending the Networks (2011), and the Vilnius Communiqué (2023), tracing the Alliance’s progressive inclusion of cyberspace as a military domain. The comparative analysis of national strategies deploys variables for actor typologies (state versus criminal, terrorist, and individual nonstate actors), threat categories (cyberattack, espionage, sabotage, warfare, hacktivism), and explicit triggers for collective defense, drawing on programmatic documents from all member states. Findings reveal that although NATO has formally recognized cyberspace as an operational domain and updated its policies to offer Article 5 protection against cyberattacks, member states differ significantly in threat perceptions, attribution requirements, threshold criteria, and legal interpretations of what constitutes an armed attack. This divergence hampers the establishment of a unified standard for collective response. The study contributes a comprehensive analytic framework that integrates legal, strategic, and doctrinal dimensions of cyber conflict to assess the feasibility of triggering Article 5 for cyber incidents, offering policymakers a structured approach to harmonizing national cyber strategies and alliance-level decision-making. Limitations include reliance on publicly available strategic documents that may not reflect classified national deliberations or evolving operational plans, and the exclusion of members joining after 2023. The authors suggest future research to incorporate empirical case studies of attributed cyber operations, simulation-based decision-making exercises to test alliance responses, and extension of the comparative framework to emerging NATO members and partner states to refine consensus on thresholds and attribution standards.

title: When democracies attack: examining the offensive strategies of democracies in cyberspace
authors: L Hunter; C Albert; S Cauthron; R Antilla
abstract: This study investigates how democratic states engage in offensive cyber operations, a relatively unexplored dimension of interstate conflict in the information age. Drawing on democratic peace theory and regime‐type scholarship, the authors combine large‐N quantitative analysis with detailed qualitative case studies to examine every known state‐sponsored cyberattack initiated by democracies from 2005 through 2020. Leveraging data from the Council on Foreign Relations Cyber Operations Tracker Dataset and supplementing it with a theoretical framework grounded in regime‐type literature, the study addresses three primary questions: Why do democracies carry out cyberattacks? Which regime types do they target most frequently? And how do their tactics vary according to the political systems of targeted states? Quantitatively, the analysis confirms that democracies rarely target other democracies, reflecting a digital extension of the dyadic democratic peace. Instead, democracies overwhelmingly direct cyber operations against authoritarian regimes, viewing them as more legitimate and lower‐cost targets for coercive measures. Qualitatively, case studies reveal that democratic targets typically face low‐intensity espionage and disruption operations, whereas authoritarian regimes are subjected to more aggressive forms of cyberaggression—including data destruction, sabotage, and denial‐of‐service attacks—designed to coerce and degrade capabilities. These patterns are explained by the institutional constraints, shared norms, and diplomatic preferences that characterize democratic interactions, which foster restraint and reliance on diplomatic mechanisms when dealing with fellow democracies. Conversely, democracies perceive authoritarian regimes as external challengers warranting more forceful cyber tactics. The findings substantiate the argument that democratic institutions not only reduce the likelihood of cyber conflict but also shape the severity and methods of cyber operations, thus extending classical democratic peace insights into cyberspace. Methodologically, the mixed‐methods approach offers both statistical generalizability and nuanced understanding of state motivations, tactics, and target selection. The authors acknowledge limitations due to reliance on publicly reported incidents and potential open‐source biases, suggesting further research to broaden temporal and geographic scopes, refine definitions of cyber operations, and explore the roles of attribution, signaling, and allied coalition dynamics in shaping cyber strategy. By elucidating the interplay between regime type and offensive cyber behavior, this work contributes novel empirical evidence to international security studies and offers a conceptual framework for categorizing cyber conflict along a spectrum of aggression tied to political systems.

title: Unpacking russia's cyber-incident response
abstract: This article examines why the Russian Federation has largely refrained from public attribution of foreign cyberattacks (PAC) despite being a frequent target of state-sponsored intrusions, and situates this behavior within a novel multidisciplinary theoretical framework that blends securitization theory and criminological analysis. The author argues that Russia’s strategic restraint in PAC, even when significant damage to its critical infrastructure occurs, results from a ‘‘double asymmetry’’: Moscow’s technological inferiority relative to Western powers and the instrumental benefits it derives from internationally tolerated cybercrime. While Western states increasingly employ PAC combined with indictments, sanctions, and ‘‘naming and shaming’’ campaigns as instruments of cyber deterrence and diplomacy, Russia’s tolerance of foreign cybercrime enables the Kremlin to steal and reverse-engineer advanced technologies, enhance its defensive and offensive cyber capabilities, and conduct covert information operations against democracies with minimal fear of reciprocal attribution or punishment. Empirically, the study tests this framework through mixed methods: a quantitative analysis of 6,209 Russian-language media reports from state-owned outlets, revealing that only 1.9% contain instances of PAC, and qualitative examinations of forensic investigations and policy documents to assess reporting patterns and state responses. The findings demonstrate that threat perception in cyberspace is socially constructed and contingent upon the distribution of cyberpower among states and the political utility of tolerated cybercrime, rather than a uniform security imperative. Extending the analysis to post-2022 developments, the article shows that, despite occasional PAC statements by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, FSB, and Security Council accusing the United States, NATO, or Ukraine of targeting Russian critical infrastructure, these pronouncements lack forensic rigor and punitive follow-through and function primarily as rhetorical devices to reinforce the Kremlin’s strategic narrative during the invasion of Ukraine. A competing line of state-media reporting further obscures attribution by framing cyber incidents as originating from nonstate ‘‘hacker groups’’ or ‘‘couch hackers’’ rather than implicating specific governments, and Russian officials continue to publicly decry Western ‘‘double standards’’ in cyber attribution while refusing to adopt similar punitive measures. The study’s securitization-theoretical contribution emphasizes that political responses to state-sponsored cybercrime depend on a ‘‘double asymmetry’’ of relative cyberpower and the intrinsic strategic value of tolerated intrusions. For policymakers and analysts, these insights caution against assuming that PAC is a universally applicable tool of deterrence; instead, they recommend that evaluations of attribution diplomacy account for a state’s technological maturity and the ways in which it may benefit from cyberattacks, thereby offering a more nuanced understanding of global cyber norms and attribution dynamics.

title: Going nuclear: the development of american strategic conceptions about cyber conflict
abstract: This article traces the intellectual, cultural, and political evolution of American strategic conceptions of cyber conflict from the 1980s through the early 2000s, revealing how sensational ‘‘cyber Pearl Harbor’’ narratives came to dominate U.S. national security discourse despite limited empirical precedent for catastrophic cyber attacks. Cameron Ross argues that three intertwined themes underpinned this development: analogies to nuclear warfare and Pearl Harbor that sensationalized early cyber advocacy, dramatized vulnerability of interconnected critical infrastructure to galvanize institutional attention and resources, and framing cyber threats within existing security paradigms of terrorism and strategic bombing. Employing a historical-interpretive methodology, the study analyzes a broad corpus of declassified government directives, Joint Chiefs of Staff strategies, Department of Defense roadmaps, congressional testimony, scholarly literature, media coverage, and memoirs of senior leaders. Qualitative content analysis reveals how early proponents of cyber operations deployed apocalyptic scenarios to secure political and budgetary support, navigating organizational politics and leveraging popular fears spawned by nuclear deterrence debates and high-profile terrorist attacks. The findings demonstrate that strategic cyber narratives were not organically self-evident but rather manufactured through advocacy efforts that conflated novel technological vulnerabilities with familiar high-stakes security threats. This conflation fostered a strategic imagination that emphasized the speed and reach of cyber attacks—likened to the ‘‘speed of light’’—over the substantial operational challenges of network reconnaissance, access, and payload development. Ross highlights how doomsday forecasts eclipsed more common, lower-intensity cyber intrusions such as espionage, sabotage, and subversion, skewing policy priorities toward defense postures ill suited to counter protracted, campaign-style cyber operations. The analysis underscores a critical limitation: reliance on partially declassified materials constrains full visibility into state-sponsored cyber activities and internal policy deliberations. Nonetheless, the study offers the first focused historical account of American cyber strategic thought, illuminating the cultural and political drivers that shaped prevailing policy discourses. By unraveling the origins of catastrophic cyber narratives, Ross urges policymakers to critically reassess foundational assumptions about cyber capabilities and vulnerabilities, advocating for more nuanced threat models that reflect empirical realities. He calls for future research to exploit newly released archival materials to evaluate the correspondence between rhetorical constructs and operational outcomes, and to examine how early conceptual frameworks continue to influence current U.S. cyber posture and deterrence strategies. In sum, the article contributes a conceptual framework explaining the emergence and entrenchment of cyber doomsday scenarios in American strategic thought, offering both historical insight and practical guidance for more balanced cyber policy formulation.

title: A new era of armed conflict: the role of state and non-state actors in cyber warfare with special reference to Russia-ukraine war
authors: A Khalil; M Bitar; Sak Raj
abstract: In “A New Era of Armed Conflict: the Role of State and Non-State Actors in Cyber Warfare with Special Reference to the Russia–Ukraine War,” Khalil, Bitar, and Raj examine the integration of cyberspace operations into modern interstate armed conflict, focusing on the Russia–Ukraine war to explore the application and adaptation of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) to cyber warfare. The authors begin by framing cyberspace as the fifth domain of warfare, alongside land, sea, air, and space, noting its unique characteristics—such as anonymity, rapid attack evolution, and blurred lines between combatants and civilians—that challenge traditional legal frameworks. They underscore the growing strategic reliance by states on both government-directed and proxy non-state actors in cyber operations, highlighting the operational advantages proxies afford but also the legal accountability gaps they create. Employing a qualitative legal methodology, the paper analyzes key IHL treaties, customary law, International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) guidance, and state practice, alongside documented cyber incidents from the Russia–Ukraine conflict. Case studies of prominent attacks on civilian infrastructure—such as telecommunications networks, energy grids, and satellite communications—illustrate difficulties in attributing responsibility and distinguishing military objectives from protected civilian systems. Drawing on the principle of distinction and the doctrine of direct participation in hostilities, the authors scrutinize how the notion of “combatant status” must evolve to encompass cyber operators and civilian infrastructure that can be dual‐use. They argue that existing IHL provisions, including Article 36 weapon reviews under Additional Protocol I and the Martens Clause, serve as foundational safeguards but lack specificity for the digital domain, particularly regarding automated and anonymous cyber tools. The study identifies three primary legal challenges: (1) the burden of attribution in attributing state responsibility when non-state proxies or “hacktivists” are employed; (2) the need to refine criteria for direct participation in hostilities to differentiate civilian users, civilian infrastructure, and regulated military targets; and (3) the absence of tailored review mechanisms for cyber capabilities, which evolve faster than traditional weapons systems. To address these gaps, the authors propose a comprehensive framework for adapting IHL to cyber conflict. First, they recommend defining refined targeting criteria that distinguish dual-use cyber infrastructure based on function, access controls, and network topology. Second, they propose a protocol for attributing non-state actor operations to sponsoring states, incorporating indicators of state direction, control, and benefit. Third, they advocate institutionalizing formal Article 36 reviews specifically for cyber means and methods, supported by interdisciplinary expert panels—including technical, legal, and operational specialists—to assess compliance prior to deployment. The paper concludes by acknowledging limitations in publicly available incident data, evolving state practice in cyber operations, and the need for empirical research on attribution technologies. It calls for further comparative studies on state compliance with cyber-specific IHL reviews, development of real-time legal assessment tools, and strengthened international cooperation to codify cyber norms into treaty and customary law. This study thus contributes a multidisciplinary legal analysis and actionable recommendations aimed at strengthening civilian protection and reinforcing state accountability in the digital battlefield.

title: The Prohibition of Annexations and the Foundations of Modern International Law
abstract: The practice of transnational dissident cyber espionage, wherein State or State-related actors remotely infiltrate and surveil activists, dissidents, and human rights defenders located abroad, has emerged as a critical dimension of digital transnational repression. In Regulating Transnational Dissident Cyber Espionage, Siena Anstis systematically examines the contours of this phenomenon, identifies its human rights implications, and proposes an international legal framework to address the practice. Drawing on documented cases—such as the hacking of Saudi dissidents Ghanem Al-Masarir in the UK and Omar Abdulaziz in Canada, and the alleged spyware targeting of U.S.–Belgian dual citizen Carine Kanimba—the article situates dissident cyber espionage within broader patterns of authoritarian transnational repression. It demonstrates how the deployment of mercenary spyware, notably Pegasus by NSO Group, infringes on fundamental rights to privacy and freedom of expression, inflicts psychological harm, fractures advocacy networks, and fosters self-censorship. Despite these harms, international law remains ambiguous regarding the legality of remote-access cyber espionage. Anstis contrasts dissident cyber espionage with traditional political or industrial espionage, arguing for its distinct categorization due to its targeted human rights abuses and transnational impact. The article reviews the current state of international law on espionage, noting that, absent explicit treaty provisions, States either tacitly tolerate or inadequately regulate these intrusions. It then analyzes recent jurisprudential developments in host States’ domestic courts: in the UK, the State Immunity Act has been interpreted to permit dissidents to sue offending States for personal injury arising from spyware installation, while in the U.S., the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act continues to bar such claims. These divergent approaches underscore the need for harmonized treaty obligations. Anstis proposes a multilateral agreement that would (1) define transnational dissident cyber espionage and establish a common set of prohibited acts; (2) require ratifying States to enact domestic remedies, including the removal of State immunity defenses for personal injury and human rights violations, reversal of evidentiary burdens once a technical threshold of attribution is met, and recognition of psychiatric harm as compensable damage; (3) mandate host-State obligations for surveillance monitoring, early warning systems, and victim protection in line with international human rights law; (4) create structured mechanisms for international cooperation, including evidence and technical intelligence sharing, unified export controls on mercenary spyware, and coordinated sanctions; and (5) foster public–private collaboration to harness cybersecurity expertise from civil society and industry for detection, victim support, and technology assessment. Recognizing the challenges posed by intelligence alliances and State sovereignty concerns, Anstis argues that even partial adoption of such a treaty would exert normative pressure and signal global condemnation of dissident cyber espionage. The article concludes that addressing this practice through a dedicated international instrument is both necessary to safeguard democracy and human rights in the digital age and feasible given the growing transnational consensus on regulating mercenary spyware.
