title: Coercion in Cyberspace - Taking Stock of the Debate
source: Max Planck Yearbook of United Nations Law
abstract:
In “Coercion in Cyberspace – Taking Stock of the Debate,” Mohamed S. Helal offers a comprehensive analysis of how States define and apply the principle of non-intervention in the digital domain, focusing on the contested concept of coercion. Drawing on national and regional position papers submitted to the UN Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG) and the Group of Governmental Experts (GGE), Helal maps the varied definitions and thresholds of coercion that States invoke when assessing whether cyber operations constitute unlawful intervention. He begins by situating the prohibition on intervention within its customary and conventional foundations, as reflected in judicial decisions such as Nicaragua v. United States, regional instruments like the Organization of American States Charter, and UN General Assembly declarations (e.g., the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration). Building on this groundwork, Helal surveys State practice in cyberspace, highlighting how information and communication technologies have been deployed both as instruments of armed force and as tools of non-forcible interference—ranging from disinformation campaigns and election meddling to industrial espionage and ransomware attacks.

A central contribution of the article is its identification of divergent State positions on the threshold of coercion—the degree of harm or threat necessary to trigger the prohibition on intervention. Some States adopt a restrictive view, equating coercion with operations that cause physical damage or loss of life; others emphasize functional harms, such as significant disruptions to critical infrastructure or manipulation of political processes. Helal critiques these varied thresholds as tentative proposals for developing customary international law, rather than authoritative restatements of settled norms. He argues that the historical evolution of the non-intervention principle, from the drafters of the 1933 Montevideo Convention through mid-20th-century UN debates, reflects a consistent analogy between non-forcible intervention and armed coercion. Through this lens, the prohibition on intervention and the ban on the threat or use of force form a “pack” of complementary rules designed to safeguard both the territorial integrity and political independence of States.

Helal’s novel proposal is the adoption of a “unified threshold of coercion” that would apply to all forms of intervention—forcible and non-forcible alike. This unified threshold, he contends, better aligns with the original policy purpose of non-intervention, which is to prevent any statecraft instrument that yields pressure comparable to military force. Such a threshold would bring coherence to distinctions between economic, political, and cyber coercion, acknowledging that non-forcible acts (e.g., economic sanctions, diplomatic pressure, cyber-enabled disinformation) can inflict harms equal to or greater than kinetic attacks. While emphasizing that the prohibition on intervention remains broader than the ban on the use of force—encompassing any intrusion on a State’s autonomous sphere—Helal situates the latter as a lex specialis within this larger lex generalis. By tracing the interrelated evolution of these norms and synthesizing State opinio juris, he provides a conceptual foundation for future treaty negotiations and interpretive guidance. In conclusion, Helal calls for further research and sustained State practice to refine the definition and operationalize the threshold of coercion in cyberspace, thereby advancing a coherent framework for governing cyber conflict under international law.

title: Responding to public and private cyberattacks: jurisdiction, self-defence, and countermeasures
source: Public and Private Governance of Cybersecurity: Challenges and Potential
abstract: This chapter by Yarik Kryvoi addresses the pivotal challenge of distinguishing between private, hybrid, and state-sponsored (public) cyberattacks and sets out a comprehensive legal and policy framework for tailoring appropriate responses under domestic and international law. The author begins by defining private cyberattacks as those generally perpetrated by non-state actors motivated by financial gain or ideology—examples include ransomware, data theft, cyber-enabled fraud, and extremist propaganda. These are governed predominantly by domestic criminal and administrative law under territoriality principles, with limited international treaty support via mutual legal assistance and extradition. In contrast, public cyberattacks are orchestrated or sponsored by states to achieve political or strategic objectives—undermining critical infrastructure, disrupting democratic processes, or acquiring sensitive information—and trigger rights and duties under public international law. Hybrid attacks exploit this distinction by masking state involvement behind private proxies, further complicating attribution. Employing a doctrinal methodology, Kryvoi synthesizes international treaty provisions, state practice, judicial precedents, and authoritative statements (including the UN Manual on Computer-related Crime and the Oxford Statement on International Law Protections in Cyberspace) to delineate criteria for classifying cyberattacks. He proposes a conceptual matrix that categorizes attacks by perpetrator type, motivation, severity, applicable legal regime, and response mechanisms. For private attacks, emphasis lies on domestic jurisdiction and law enforcement cooperation, while public attacks warrant recourse to doctrines of self-defence, necessity, and countermeasures under the UN Charter. The chapter examines attribution challenges—technical complexity, transboundary dispersion, and evidentiary burdens—and surveys proposals for due diligence or strict liability approaches to state responsibility. Kryvoi finds that existing international law lacks dedicated dispute resolution bodies and clear jurisprudence to address interstate cyber disputes, resulting in fragmented state practice and reliance on naming and shaming rather than enforceable remedies. He argues for reassessing the application of self-defence and countermeasure concepts in cyberspace and for establishing a specialized international forum to adjudicate public cyberattacks, thereby fostering consistent jurisprudence and norm development. Acknowledging the limitations of nascent state practice and the absence of binding cyber-specific treaties, the author calls for future research to document emerging opinio juris, draft model treaty language on state due diligence and liability, and design the procedural and institutional architecture of a cyber dispute resolution body. By clarifying the legal distinctions between private and public cyber threats and advocating institutional innovation, this chapter lays the groundwork for more coherent, enforceable, and predictable normative governance of state conduct in cyberspace.

title: Network tango: examining state dispositions toward attribution in international cyber conflict
abstract: This undergraduate honors thesis examines the fragmentation of attribution capabilities in international cyber conflict and explores how legal frameworks can be adapted to reduce barriers to state accountability. Tracing the historical underpinnings of cyber security debates from the 1972 Ware Report to present-day discussions, the author situates cyberspace as a domain that both extends traditional intelligence operations and creates new vulnerabilities for infrastructural, economic, and political damage. Recognizing that states’ geopolitical positions and strategic incentives shape their engagement in cyberspace, the study asks whether implementing a heightened due diligence standard for data-sharing among states could streamline attribution processes and thus strengthen state responsibility. Employing a qualitative normative analysis, the research reviews foundational literature in international relations theory, cyber law, and intelligence studies while synthesizing doctrinal sources on due diligence and the technical principles of TCP/IP architecture. By contextualizing state behavior through lenses of legal ambiguity, diplomatic reluctance, and technological complexity, the thesis highlights that attribution challenges are rooted not only in technical limitations but also in insufficient cooperation and normative gaps. The principal finding is that a targeted treaty regime mandating conditional access to transport-layer metadata among trusted partners can narrow data pathways and create a dragnet effect for adversarial traffic. This approach promises to accelerate and improve the accuracy of attributions without violating sovereignty or core network design principles. As a normative contribution, the author proposes a novel “cyber due diligence” framework focused on residual data sharing for attribution—distinct from criminal assistance regimes—and advocates narrow, case-specific treaties to foster mutual confidence and expedite collective responses to malicious cyber activities. The thesis acknowledges states’ potential unwillingness to cede informational autonomy, the risk of inconsistent treaty participation, and adversaries’ capacity to develop covert channels. It concludes by recommending future research on incentive structures for treaty adoption, verification mechanisms for compliance, and technical safeguards against data abuse, thereby offering a multidisciplinary roadmap for enhancing international norms of attribution and deterrence in cyberspace.

title: The evolution of information warfare in Ukraine: 2014 to 2022
abstract: This article presents a comprehensive longitudinal study of information warfare tactics in the Russo-Ukrainian conflict, contrasting operations deployed during the 2014 Crimea crisis with those evident in the 2022 full-scale invasion. Employing a qualitative case-study methodology, the author synthesizes open-source reports, technical analyses, news articles, and secondary literature to chart how Russia and Ukraine have integrated cyber operations, disinformation campaigns, electronic warfare, and intelligence activities into their broader strategic playbooks. The 2014 phase exemplified early cyber-espionage campaigns and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against Ukrainian government sites, strategic website defacements invoking NATO narratives, and coordinated propaganda that leveraged Russian state media and pro-Russian troll networks to fracture social cohesion. Notable incidents included the Sandworm APT’s power grid outages in 2015 and 2016, which foreshadowed larger industrial cyberattacks, and the global collateral damage of the NotPetya wiper in 2017. The research identifies a clear evolution from loosely coordinated cyber and propaganda efforts to a sophisticated hybrid warfare model in 2022, wherein kinetic assaults were routinely synchronized with electronic jamming of communications, large-scale DDoS attacks, volunteer cyber armies targeting critical infrastructure, and pervasive social-media disinformation shaping domestic and international narratives. This maturation illustrates the emergence of an Information Warfare Life Cycle tailored to the Ukrainian theatre: initial probing and intelligence collection via open source intelligence (OSINT) exploits, followed by targeted cyberattacks to degrade civilian resilience, and culminating in integrated cognitive operations aimed at influencing stakeholder perceptions. The study discusses the legal and normative gaps exposed by these developments, highlighting the absence of consistent international frameworks to deter state-sponsored information warfare and recommending future research into quantitative assessment of cyber-psychological operation efficacy and comparative analyses across multiple conflict zones. By elucidating the patterns of tactical adaptation from 2014 to 2022, the work offers policymakers and defense planners an empirical model for anticipating adversary behavior in the information domain and underscores the imperative of building resilient multi-domain defenses that span cyber security, counter-disinformation efforts, and electronic countermeasures.

title: Ripeness theory in the digital age: when to log off from cyber conflict
abstract: This article evaluates the applicability of Zartman’s ripeness theory—a negotiation framework premised on a ‘‘mutually hurting stalemate’’ (MHS) and ‘‘mutually enticing opportunity’’ (MEO)—to the emergent phenomenon of pure cyber conflict, arguing that the digital domain’s unique dynamics challenge the core assumptions of conventional ripeness theory and require a revised conceptualization. After surveying debates on the definitions, norms, and regulatory frameworks governing cyber conflict, the paper establishes a broad definition encompassing state-sponsored information operations that intentionally undermine economic, political, social, or security systems, while excluding small-scale cybercrime and hybrid operations embedded within kinetic warfare. The author then critically examines ripeness theory’s track record in conventional disputes and identifies four key features of cyber conflict—limited escalation pathways, perception of cyber operations as reversible ‘‘off-ramps,’’ first-use technological asymmetries, and the plateaued tit-for-tat nature of cyber exchanges—that undermine the emergence of an MHS. To address this, the paper proposes replacing MHS with a ‘‘mutually harming standoff’’ (MHS2), capturing the sustained but manageable reciprocal harms characteristic of prolonged cyber confrontations, and reframes the MEO to reflect cyberspace’s inherent incentives for norm-building cooperation, power projection through noncoercive leverage, and mutual interest in preserving digital stability. The revised ripeness criteria are then applied to the 2015 US-China Cybersecurity Agreement: the protracted bilateral tit-for-tat in espionage and intrusions constituted an MHS2, while both parties’ interest in developing shared cyber norms and preventing uncontrolled escalation represented the MEO that precipitated negotiations. The case study demonstrates that pure cyber negotiations can achieve ripeness without a classical hurting stalemate, underscoring the importance of bilateral Track One and Track Two dialogues in diffusing norms and establishing legal understandings for cyberspace. The article concludes by recommending future research directions, including comparative analyses of other long-standing cyber rivalries (e.g., US-Russia, India-Pakistan, North Korea-South Korea) and deeper exploration of multilateral negotiation processes, to refine the theory and inform practical diplomacy. This theoretical adaptation offers policymakers and scholars a more accurate toolkit for determining optimal timing for cyber conflict resolution and advancing stable international cyber governance.

title: fact-finding and cyber attribution
authors: N Tsagourias; F Middleton; R Buchan; D Franchini
source: CHANGING CHARACTER OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE SETTLEMENT: Challenges and Prospects
abstract:
This chapter by Tsagourias, Middleton, Buchan, and Franchini examines the dual legal and factual dimensions of cyber attribution within the framework of international dispute settlement. It begins by defining attribution in international law—assigning a wrongful act to a State under the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on State responsibility—and situates cyberattacks in this context, emphasizing that attribution is prerequisite to any state responsibility or remedial measures. The authors highlight the interdependence of legal and factual attribution, noting that technical forensic investigations underpin legal determinations of responsibility, yet remain shrouded in limited evidentiary transparency. Through case studies—the U.S. attribution of the DNC hack to Russia, Germany’s Bundestag hack, UK-led allegations against units of Russia’s GRU, Norway’s accusations of Russian interference, and SolarWinds—the chapter illustrates how States routinely contest attribution claims by disputing facts or withholding evidence, thereby impeding accountability and peaceful dispute resolution.

Fact-finding is proposed as a mechanism to bridge these evidentiary gaps and facilitate the settlement of cyber attribution disputes in accordance with the U.N. Charter’s obligations to resolve conflicts peacefully. The authors critically analyze existing proposals for both state-led and private cyber attribution bodies, identifying challenges in sovereignty, authority, credibility, methodology, and accountability. They argue that private or permanent international institutions often face reluctance from States to cooperate or share sensitive technical data, while competing private entities may undermine confidence through contradictory findings.

To address these obstacles, the chapter offers a blueprint for an ad hoc, treaty-based Fact-Finding Mechanism (FFM) tailored to individual cyber attribution disputes. Key features include voluntary State consent to establish the FFM, a clear constitutive instrument defining mandate, scope, composition, methodology, applicable legal and evidentiary standards, decision-making rules, resource provisions, and transparency and accountability safeguards. The FFM’s membership may draw from State officials, international organization staff, private experts, or civil society, reflecting disputing States’ specific needs. Its mandate must delineate incident parameters, investigative reach, evidence handling, assessment criteria, standard of proof, and review procedures. Decision-making and reporting processes—whether consensual or majoritarian, public or confidential—are to be precisely stipulated.

The proposed design seeks to ensure that the FFM’s findings are both legally and technically robust, enhancing States’ willingness to accept outcomes and thereby promoting the peaceful resolution of cyber disputes. Concluding, the authors contend that a carefully calibrated fact-finding mechanism, anchored in international law and tailored to the distinctive challenges of cyber attribution, can substantially contribute to credible, effective dispute settlement and reinforce the rule of law in cyberspace.

title: The rationale and the perils of failing to invoke state responsibility for cyber-attacks: the case of the EU cyber sanctions
abstract: This article examines the European Union’s unprecedented decision to impose targeted sanctions for malicious cyber-attacks without attributing state responsibility, focusing on CFSP Decision 2019/797 and its recital disclaiming sovereign attribution. The authors first contextualize the growing strategic significance of cyber-attacks against critical infrastructure and essential societal functions, noting that the EU designed its cyber-sanction regime to deter and respond to operations that threaten its security. They detail how the Decision criminalizes unauthorized access, interference, and data breaches against systems in sectors such as energy, transport, finance, healthcare, and government functions, and empowers the EU to freeze assets and impose visa bans on responsible natural and legal persons, yet explicitly excludes state organs and scholarship of sovereign attribution. Employing doctrinal legal analysis of the Decision’s text, legislative recitals, EU practice, and related legislation, the article identifies three intertwined rationales for the EU’s refusal to invoke state responsibility: technical and evidentiary challenges in attributing cyber operations to states; institutional constraints under EU treaties and the Meroni doctrine limiting delegation of attribution powers; and member‐state reluctance to cede sovereignty over attribution determinations. The authors argue that this policy gap undermines legal certainty when cyber-attacks may breach the UN prohibition on the use of force and permits opportunistic exploitation of ambiguity by state actors. They survey recent EU developments—such as Directive (EU) 2016/1148 on network and information security, the enhanced mandate of ENISA, and the proposed Joint Cyber Unit—assessing their potential and limits for intra‐EU coordination and technical attribution. Concluding that political obstacles and contested competences will stymie a universally accepted mechanism within the EU or internationally, the article proposes future research into binding multilateral treaties for specific malicious cyber activities, institutional models inspired by the OPCW verification framework, and evolving state practice on lex specialis rules for cyberspace accountability.

title: President Obama and China: Cyber Diplomacy and Strategy for a New Era
abstract: This article examines President Obama’s cyber diplomacy initiatives in the context of his broader Grand Strategy, particularly focusing on the strategic pivot to the Asia-Pacific region and its impact on U.S.–China relations. Situating cyber policy within the broader framework of traditional diplomacy and international relations, the study analyzes how cyber issues were not isolated technical concerns but integral to achieving national security and economic objectives. In Obama’s first term (2009–2012), U.S. engagement with China in cyberspace was characterized by cooperation and collaboration, reflecting a security environment still dominated by the ‘war on terror’ and a global diplomatic focus that had yet to fully integrate cyber considerations. As domestic priorities shifted and leadership changes occurred both in Washington and Beijing, the pivot to Asia emerged as a central strategic doctrine in the latter half of Obama’s presidency. The article demonstrates that this pivot entailed not only a reallocation of military and economic resources but also a recalibration of cyber diplomacy toward a more assertive posture. Drawing on open-source U.S. government documents, speeches, media releases, and policy statements, the author charts the transformation from a cooperative cyber engagement to a competitive stance in Obama’s second term (2013–2016). The analysis highlights how cyber diplomacy initiatives—such as public attribution of cyber intrusions, the imposition of sanctions for malicious cyber activity, and efforts to forge regional alliances on cyber norms—were deliberately aligned with the pivot’s objective of reaffirming U.S. leadership and economic primacy in Asia. By comparing the rhetoric and policy actions of Presidents Obama and Xi Jinping, the study reveals how cyber diplomacy served as both a signal of U.S. resolve and a tool for reinforcing traditional diplomatic alliances. The findings underscore the necessity of integrating cyber strategy into a state’s Grand Strategy to ensure coherence in signaling and resource allocation. The article concludes with lessons for future policymakers: cyber diplomacy cannot be treated as a standalone domain but must be woven into the broader tapestry of national strategy, with clear alignment between cyber initiatives and overarching diplomatic objectives. This multidisciplinary approach offers a nuanced understanding of how cyber and traditional diplomacy interact, shaping the evolution of international norms and power dynamics in cyberspace.

title: Cyber -enabled international state-sponsored disinformation operations and the role of international law
source: Swiss Review of International and European Law
abstract: This article examines the emergence of cyber-enabled international state-sponsored disinformation operations (CISDOs) and explores the applicability of existing international law to regulate and prohibit them. Recognizing that while the spread of false information among states is longstanding, the advent of the internet and social media has exponentially amplified the scope, scale, and anonymity of disinformation campaigns, the paper defines CISDOs as deliberate state-sponsored efforts to deceive or manipulate public opinion across borders via online platforms. The author frames CISDOs within general principles of international law and key branches including international human rights law, communications law, humanitarian law, and the principle of non-intervention. On the principle of non-intervention, the article finds that CISDOs that intentionally manipulate political processes or public perceptions in target states constitute unlawful interference with state sovereignty. Under international communications law, Switzerland’s Broadcasting and Correction Conventions predate modern digital media but nonetheless illustrate the longstanding concern of cross-border misinformation; however, their limited scope renders them inadequate for contemporary CISDOs. In the realm of international human rights law, CISDOs’ targeted falsehoods infringe on individuals’ rights to truthful information and freedom of opinion, and during armed conflict, they may also violate international humanitarian law by undermining the protections afforded to civilians through deceptive means. The author further identifies obstacles that hinder the regulation of CISDOs under existing international frameworks: the diffuse involvement of private actors (e.g., “disinfo-for-hire” firms), challenges in attribution of online operations to state sponsors, the limited extraterritorial effect of human rights obligations, and ambiguity surrounding lawful countermeasures in light of international standards on freedom of expression. Additionally, the lack of a clear international consensus and outdated notions of sovereignty focused on territorial borders impede the development of effective legal remedies. To address these gaps, the article proposes the negotiation of a new international treaty specifically prohibiting state-sponsored disinformation, framed as a sui generis category of cyberoperation. Such a convention should complement rather than displace existing norms, focusing on the intent of state actors rather than content restrictions, and should integrate multi-stakeholder co-regulatory mechanisms—drawing on models like the EU Code of Practice on Disinformation—to harness both state authority and private-sector expertise. The treaty should affirm that state outsourcing of CISDOs to private entities cannot shield governments from responsibility and should establish clear attribution and accountability measures. Ultimately, the paper concludes that while 20th-century legal instruments provide foundational principles, only a dedicated, legally binding international regime can effectively deter and address the unique challenges posed by CISDOs in the post-truth era.

title: The plea of necessity in cyber emergencies
abstract: This article examines the plea of necessity as a customary circumstance precluding wrongfulness under international law and its application in cyber emergencies, addressing three doctrinal questions that remain underexposed in both state practice and academic literature. Lahmann begins by outlining the recognition of necessity by several States, including Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, and Switzerland, as well as its endorsement in the Tallinn Manual 2.0. Necessity allows a State to respond to an essential interest threatened by a grave and imminent peril—even if this response temporarily breaches other international obligations—without incurring state responsibility. In the cyber context, the defence is particularly relevant when imminent harm to critical infrastructure, such as pipelines or energy systems, is caused by malicious actors operating from foreign territory, and timely attribution is technically or forensically infeasible. The first issue explored is the “only way” requirement, which demands that no other legal means exists to safeguard the essential interest. While scholars have critiqued the strict interpretation of this criterion in traditional contexts, Lahmann argues that in cyber emergencies, where situational urgency and technical uncertainty prevail, States may justifiably adopt a more flexible standard when invoking necessity. The second issue concerns the condition of non-contribution, whereby a State invoking necessity must not have substantially contributed to the situation of peril. The author highlights the evolving norms on cyber hygiene and due diligence obligations for domestic cyber infrastructures, suggesting that failures to implement baseline security measures could preclude reliance on necessity by constituting a contributing factor. This raises questions about how emerging standards of care in cyberspace may affect future legal assessments of contribution. The third issue examines whether third States may lawfully assist an imperilled State invoking necessity. Drawing on Article 16 of the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility, Lahmann analyzes the interplay between the wrongful nature of the assisted act and the assisting State’s knowledge of the circumstances justifying necessity. He considers contrasting doctrinal positions regarding whether necessity precludes only the assisted State’s wrongdoing or also precludes responsibility for assisting States. The article revisits debates from the ILC drafting history, noting criticisms of the undifferentiated treatment of circumstances precluding wrongfulness and responsibility. It evaluates whether assistance amounts to an act of the imperilled State, requiring the assisting State to invoke necessity on its own behalf, or whether assistance is permissible provided the assisting State lacks willful blindness to the facts. Concluding, Lahmann calls for greater precision in State practice and official positions to clarify the scope of necessity in cyber operations, emphasizing the need for future normative guidance on the “only way” criterion, non-contribution standard, and the permissibility of assistance. He underscores the importance of explicit articulation by States to strengthen the international rule of law in cyberspace and to address the doctrinal puzzles that persist in applying the plea of necessity to cyber emergencies.

title: Pointing with boneless finger and getting away with it: the ill-substantiation problem in cyber public attribution
source: Revolutionary Approach to International Law : the Role
abstract:
This chapter examines the phenomenon of ill-substantiated public attribution in interstate cyber conflict and its implications for international stability and policy. Fan Yang argues that while public attribution is increasingly used by states as a tool to deter malicious cyber operations and signal accountability, its effectiveness is undermined by legal, technical, and political shortcomings. The chapter adopts a multidisciplinary framework—technical, political, and legal—to analyze how states build an evidentiary foundation for attributing cyber operations, decide the timing and form of public accusations, and rely upon an inadequate international legal regime to legitimize their claims and justify potential countermeasures.

First, Yang explores the technical dimension of attribution, highlighting the forensic processes—signals intelligence, malware reverse-engineering, and human intelligence—that underpin a state’s confidence in identifying an adversary. He observes that uneven technical capabilities among states lead to asymmetric patterns of public attribution, whereby technologically advanced states exploit their superiority to publicly name and shame weaker actors, reinforcing power imbalances in cyberspace.

Second, the author considers the political calculus driving states to make public attributions. He outlines various motivations—domestic legitimacy, deterrence signaling, norm-setting, and diplomatic leverage—and details the diverse mechanisms states employ, including indictments, economic sanctions, technical advisories, and official statements. This section demonstrates that political imperatives often trump evidentiary rigor, pushing states to publish allegations even when the evidentiary basis is questionable.

Third, the chapter focuses on the legal dimension, arguing that the existing corpus of international law lacks clear rules regarding evidentiary thresholds, attribution standards, and state responsibility for erroneous accusations. Yang reviews debates over the “control test,” due diligence obligations, and imputation principles in cyberspace, showing how legal gaps permit reckless public attributions without accountability. He critiques the absence of specific norms to govern state behavior in public attribution, noting that even leading cyber powers, such as the United States, do not adhere to strict legal standards when announcing political attributions.

Building on these insights, Yang articulates the “ill-substantiation problem” as a systemic issue rooted in technical constraints, political incentives, and legal frailties. He contends that unsubstantiated public accusations risk eroding international norms, provoking retaliatory measures, and destabilizing cyberspace by enabling states to leverage attribution as a geopolitical weapon.

To remedy these deficiencies, the chapter proposes the development of an international norm on responsible public attribution. Such a norm would establish minimum evidentiary requirements, clarify the role of due diligence, and introduce accountability mechanisms for states that make erroneous or malicious attributions. Yang outlines how multilateral diplomatic efforts, underpinned by technical standardization of evidence collection and legal codification of attribution procedures, could foster a more predictable and stable cyber environment.

Finally, the author acknowledges limitations—such as the focus on state actors to the exclusion of private firms and media—and suggests future research avenues, including empirical studies of attribution practices by non-Five Eyes states and normative development through international fora. By bridging technical, political, and legal perspectives, this chapter advances a multidisciplinary approach to reforming cyber policy and strengthening the rule of law in cyberspace.

title: Public secrets: the dynamics of publicity and secrecy in offensive cyber operations
abstract: This study by Gil Baram investigates the strategic choices states make between publicity and secrecy in offensive cyber operations (OCOs), challenging the binary assumption that such operations are invariably covert. Analyzing a systematically compiled dataset of publicly revealed OCOs from 1996 to 2019, the research identifies a spectrum of disclosure strategies available to both perpetrators and defenders, ranging from full concealment to public attribution. Employing multinomial logistic regression, Baram examines how state characteristics—such as regime type, GDP, and military power—as well as attributes of the OCOs themselves—attack severity, third-party involvement, and attack method—affect the probability of choosing each strategy. Findings reveal that full secrecy remains the default choice for perpetrators in 54% of cases and for defenders in 47%, yet public strategies are significant: perpetrators claim credit or issue denials in 20% of operations, while defenders publicly attribute or disclose attacks without attribution in about 50% of instances. Democracies are eleven to twelve times more likely than nondemocracies to claim credit for OCOs, whereas autocracies are four times more likely to issue public denials. Defenders in democracies are five to six times more likely to publicly expose both the occurrence of an OCO and its perpetrator, and higher GDP correlates with a 3.5–4 times greater likelihood of public attribution. Operations involving third parties and nonmilitary targets significantly increase the odds of both sides adopting public strategies, and severe attacks compel defenders toward either partial concealment or full public attribution; highly sophisticated methods favor continued silence. Baram’s work advances theoretical discussions in international relations, deterrence, and cyber norms by conceptualizing disclosure as a nuanced strategic choice rather than a simple reveal-or-conceal decision, empirically linking political and operational factors to states’ publicity behaviors. The research is constrained by reliance on open-source data of revealed OCOs, potentially underrepresenting unobserved operations, and suggests future directions to examine how defenders’ retaliation capability conditions disclosure choices, the differential treatment of kinetic versus purely digital targets, and the interplay between regime type and foreign policy motivations in publicizing cyber operations.

title: Deterrence by denial in cyberspace
abstract: Ashley Deeks’s article “The Geography of Cyber Conflict: Through a Glass Darkly” provides a rigorous doctrinal analysis of how the longstanding “unwilling or unable” test from the law of neutrality and jus ad bellum can be adapted and applied to high-intensity cyber armed attacks originating from neutral or non-hostile States. Deeks begins by recalling the historical roots of the test in neutrality law, which permits a victim State to use force in self-defense against non-State actors operating from the territory of a territorial State that is either unwilling or unable to suppress the threat. She then introduces cyber-specific nuances through hypothetical case studies, most notably an Israeli scenario in which Hezbollah conducts a debilitating cyber attack on Israeli military networks via servers in Turkey. Unlike kinetic operations, cyber attacks unfold at digital speed, generate complex attribution issues, risk wide collateral effects on civilian infrastructure, and place a premium on the victim State’s technological capacity to stop ongoing attacks. Deeks dissects these distinctive factors, showing that urgency demands rapid yet careful determinations of a territorial State’s technological ability and political will, while concerns over collateral damage heighten the incentive for precise legal thresholds. She further explores the territorial State’s dilemma: if it wishes to avoid extraterritorial self-help measures, it must disclose enough of its defensive cyber capabilities or consent to limited cross-border remediation—actions that implicate sensitive intelligence equities. Deeks juxtaposes this normative inquiry with U.S. interagency practice, revealing a cautious, precautionary approach embodied in classified legal memoranda and policy debates. U.S. decision makers emphasize stringent legal review, adherence to consent principles, reputational considerations, and reciprocal implications for future State practice. This approach, she argues, seeks to avoid the diplomatic fallout and unintended escalations that could arise from ad hoc cyber self-defense measures. While affirming the continued viability of the “unwilling or unable” test in cyberspace, Deeks highlights its reliance on evolving State practice and calls for more empirical research. She urges compilation of actual State invocations of the test, development of clear procedural protocols for timely determinations of territorial State willingness and capacity, and study of lower-threshold cyber operations to refine the applicability of self-defense doctrines. In doing so, Deeks offers a conceptual framework that balances the imperatives of self-defense, technological realities, and sovereign equality, thus contributing to the development of a coherent international legal architecture for managing cyber conflict in the digital age.

title: Public attribution in the US government: implications for diplomacy and norms in cyberspace
abstract: This paper provides a systematic empirical analysis of the United States government’s practice of publicly attributing state-sponsored cyber intrusions to adversary states and assesses the implications of these practices for diplomacy and the evolution of international norms in cyberspace. The author constructs a novel dataset of all US government public attributions of cyber incidents between 2010 and 2020, drawing on official statements, press releases, indictments, and technical advisories across multiple agencies, including the Department of Justice, intelligence community, and State Department. Through a mixed-methods approach that combines quantitative analysis of attribution timing and frequency with in-depth qualitative case studies, the study identifies four distinct policy ‘‘channels’’ through which the US government conveys attribution findings: criminal (led by the Department of Justice and characterized by formal indictments and prosecutions), technical (intelligence community disclosures of forensic evidence), official policy (executive branch or State Department announcements calibrated for diplomatic signaling), and unofficial policy (statements by senior advisors, task forces, or other non-diplomatic officials). The analysis shows systematic differences across channels in terms of timing—criminal attributions follow lengthy investigations and emerge on average 967 days after an intrusion, while unofficial policy statements appear much more rapidly—and in terms of intended audiences and purposes: criminal channels emphasize legal accountability, technical channels prioritize transparency of evidence to inform allies and adversaries, official policy channels seek to advance strategic diplomatic messaging, and unofficial policy channels offer agility but risk creating ambiguity about whole-of-government intentions. Two detailed case studies—of Iran’s Operation Ababil DDoS campaign (2012–2013) and Russia’s Dragonfly 2.0 attacks on critical infrastructure (2016–2017)—illustrate how organizational mandates, interagency competition, and channel-specific constraints shape attribution narratives and influence their reception by foreign governments. The paper finds that the fragmented nature of US public attribution complicates diplomatic coherence, as adversary states and allies may misinterpret isolated agency statements as representing unified national policy, which can undermine collective signaling, dilute deterrence messaging, and produce mismatches in expectation of potential retaliatory measures. Furthermore, divergent channel practices contribute unevenly to the normative environment, affecting perceptions of acceptable state behavior in cyberspace and potentially limiting the US’s ability to spearhead coordinated norm-development efforts. The author underscores the need for stronger interagency coordination and a unified public attribution framework to enhance the credibility of US statements, strengthen diplomatic leverage, and foster clearer international norms against malicious cyber operations. While acknowledging the US-centric focus and the limited scope of assessing norm diffusion beyond US attributions, the study lays the groundwork for extending this framework to other major cyber-active states, integrating private-sector attribution practices, and evaluating long-term normative effects on adversary behavior, coalition solidarity, and deterrence stability in the evolving landscape of cyber conflict.

title: Expanding the dyadic cyber incident and campaign dataset (DCID): cyber conflict from 2000 to 2020
authors: Ryan C. Maness; Brandon Valeriano; Kathryn Hedgecock; Jose M. Macias; Benjamin Jensen
abstract: This article presents the development and expansion of the Dyadic Cyber Incident and Campaign Dataset (DCID) 2.0, a state-of-the-art, open-source resource designed to capture the full scope of rival state-to-state cyber operations from 2000 to 2020. Recognizing that extant cyber incident lists and typologies often rely on ad hoc curation and fail to reflect social-science best practices, the authors employ rigorous coding procedures with inter-coder validation to standardize variable definitions, operationalize severity scales, and ensure replicability. DCID 2.0 builds on prior versions by systematically integrating additional incidents discovered through comprehensive web-search algorithms, manual cross-validation by trained coders, and an exhaustive review of complementary datasets—including CSIS Significant Cyber Incidents, CFR’s Cyber Operations Tracker, and financial-sector timelines—for maximum coverage. New dimensions introduced in this iteration include categorical flags for ransomware deployment, supply-chain compromise, and linkage with information operations, thereby enabling scholars to disentangle pure disruption from coerced sabotage or espionage activities. The dataset comprises 429 discrete incidents, each coded along multiple axes: actor dyad (initiator and target states), operation type, functional impact, targeted critical-infrastructure sector, attribution confidence, temporal and geographic markers, and coercion context. Reliability testing demonstrates high intercoder agreement, underscoring the dataset’s methodological robustness. Empirical analysis reveals that cyber operations have steadily risen in frequency and sophistication, shifting from low-level probing to multi-vector campaigns combining malware injection, distributed denial-of-service, and data exfiltration. Notably, involvement of Western states and strategic adversaries such as Russia, China, Iran, and North Korea exhibits distinct operational preferences and escalation trajectories, suggesting that national doctrine shapes both tactical choices and intensity. The authors argue that these patterns underscore cyber operations as integral instruments of state power, often embedded within broader coercive diplomatic or military strategies rather than isolated technical incidents. By providing policymakers with granular evidence of how, when, and against whom states employ cyber means, DCID 2.0 supports more informed deterrence postures, defense policy adjustments, and international normative debates regarding responsible state behavior in cyberspace. The dataset’s open-access codebook and reproducible coding protocols further invite the academic community to augment and refine this groundwork, ultimately fostering a shared empirical foundation to guide cyber policy formulation, treaty negotiation, and legal frameworks governing cross-border cyber conflict.

title: There and Back Again? Russia's Quest for Regulating War in Cyberspace
abstract: This article examines Russia’s persistent efforts to introduce a binding legal instrument specifically regulating State behavior in cyberspace, focusing on its proposals within the United Nations Open-ended Working Group (OEWG) on security of and in the use of information and communications technologies (ICTs). The author (Liina Lumiste) highlights the long-standing divergence between Russia and most Western States over the applicability of international humanitarian law (IHL) to cyberspace, noting that Russia accepts general principles of international law and the UN Charter yet resists the extension of specialized regimes—particularly IHL—as “just applied” to cyber operations. Through analysis of Russia’s repeated submission of draft conventions and concept papers between 2011 and 2023, this study situates Russia’s quest for a new treaty within the broader context of its state-centric approach to international law-making, which reserves law-creation authority exclusively for States and, to a more limited extent, recognized intergovernmental organizations. This approach, rooted in Russian scholarly and constitutional frameworks, privileges treaty law over customary law and rejects the participation of non-state actors—such as NGOs or transnational corporations—in formal law-making processes. In exploring Russia’s rhetoric, the article argues that behind the normative veneer lies a pragmatic strategy to reinforce Russia’s power status and constrain the operational freedom of its adversaries in cyberspace. Russia’s calls for binding rules are juxtaposed with its aggressive use of cyber means in the ongoing war against Ukraine, revealing a measure of hypocrisy and underscoring the instrumentalization of law-making for strategic gain. The study further traces historical patterns in Russia’s engagement with IHL, recalling the Russian Empire’s and Soviet Union’s influential roles in developing humanitarian law instruments while often seeking to shape these rules to serve future conflict advantages. By linking contemporary cyber norm debates to these historical precedents, the article demonstrates continuity in Russia’s maneuvering to secure “moral credit” and control institutional mechanisms—such as attribution processes—while preserving sovereign discretion to avoid external supervision. In the domain of IHL, Russia’s insistence on halting the automatic application of IHL in cyberspace and its conflation of jus ad bellum and jus in bello questions are analyzed, revealing a conceptual slippage toward “just war” paradigms that complicate the differentiation between use of force and armed attack thresholds. Ultimately, the article concludes that Russia’s advocacy for a new treaty does not signal genuine commitment to progressive development of IHL or equitable rule-making but rather reflects broader philosophical-political disagreements on international law, where Russia challenges Western “rules-based order” narratives and seeks to codify a cyber regime that cements its own strategic advantages while eroding those of others.

title: Drawing a line: Digital transnational repression against political exiles and host state sovereignty
abstract: This article explores how authoritarian regimes employ digital technologies to perpetuate transnational repression against political exiles and how these practices constitute violations of host state sovereignty. While prior research has primarily examined digital transnational repression (DTR) as a human rights issue affecting targeted individuals, the authors shift the analytical focus to the broader normative and security implications for the states hosting these exiles. Mobilising emerging scholarship on digital sovereignty and cybersecurity, they argue that DTR represents extraterritorial enforcement jurisdiction incompatible with international law principles of sovereignty, interferes with open debate and national self-determination in host states, and impedes adherence to international humanitarian law norms. The authors also contend that DTR undermines host state authority and domestic sovereignty by weakening institutions, rule of law, and social cohesion—thereby running counter to host states’ self-interest. Empirically, the article details methods of DTR—surveillance, malware attacks, online harassment, and disinformation—often intertwined with traditional coercive tactics, illustrating how regimes exploit border-blurring digital networks and private surveillance industries. The paper situates DTR within a post-territorial notion of sovereignty, challenging conventional Westphalian conceptions and advocating for an elastic, effects-based understanding that adapts to the digital age. Three legal arguments ground the sovereignty violation thesis: (1) extraterritorial enforcement jurisdiction: DTR constitutes state action on foreign territory without consent; (2) distortion of public debate: DTR’s silencing of diaspora voices infringes sovereign self-determination; (3) impediments to humanitarian norms: DTR erodes host states’ capacity to protect fundamental rights, undermining sovereign commitments. A political self-interest argument highlights how DTR’s corrosion of domestic institutions detracts from integration capacities and societal stability. To counter DTR, the authors propose a distributed cyber deterrence framework engaging public, private, and civil society actors to deny perpetrators opportunities and impose costs. Key measures include collaborative digital threat investigations, enhanced cyber resilience training for civil society, targeted sanctions, and punitive measures against surveillance firms. They call for strengthened international norms: clarifying sovereignty interference thresholds in cyberconflict rules (e.g., Tallinn Manual), defining attribution standards and timeframes for legitimate reprisals, adapting state immunity doctrines to digital contexts, and regulating the export and use of offensive cyber capabilities through binding agreements analogous to nuclear oversight. The paper emphasises that host governments must reconceptualise migrants as referent security objects, recognising DTR as a shared threat to democratic resilience and human security. By reframing sovereignty in the digital era as protective of individual rights beyond territorial access, the authors advocate expanding sovereign responsibilities to secure exiles against extraterritorial authoritarian coercion. This human-centric approach to cybersecurity aligns sovereignty and human rights, offering a normative and strategic basis for inclusive global condemnation and curtailment of digital transnational repression.

title: Rethinking US Concepts and Actions in Cyberspace: Building a Better Foundation for Deterring China's Aggression
abstract: This article examines the burgeoning involvement of civilians in cyber operations during armed conflict and its deleterious impact on the bedrock International Humanitarian Law (IHL) principle of distinction. Kubo Macák first documents a qualitative and quantitative shift, whereby the low technical threshold of cyber tools and the exponential scalability afforded by digital networks have erased traditional barriers between combatants and non-combatants. Macák illustrates this “civilianization” of the digital battlefield through three scenarios: (1) State-licensed outsourcing of offensive cyber operations to civilians, including distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) participants and volunteer hacktivist collectives; (2) the repurposing of civilian smartphone or e-government applications to crowdsource real-time tactical intelligence from unwitting or voluntary civilian users; and (3) the recruitment of civilian contractors and private intelligence actors to perform reconnaissance and offensive tasks. Against these examples, the author interrogates the narrow threshold under IHL at which civilian cyber engagement constitutes direct participation in hostilities, thereby stripping individuals of protected status and exposing them to lawful targeting. The article then explores the IHL and human rights implications of State encouragement of civilian direct participation in cyber hostilities. Under IHL, States have obligations of “constant care” and “passive precautions” to distinguish civilians from combatants and to protect civilians from the effects of hostilities; intentionally facilitating civilian involvement in cyber attacks risks breaching these duties and may independently violate prohibition norms—particularly when minors or uninformed volunteers are induced to participate. From a human rights law perspective, the encouragement of dangerous cyber activities raises potential violations of the right to life and the right to private life, notably where civilians are not apprised of combat risks they undertake. Drawing on jurisprudence from the European Court of Human Rights and UN treaty bodies, Macák asserts that States must inform civilian participants of the risks and limit their roles to non-combat support functions, such as logistics or administrative tasks, which do not meet the IHL direct participation threshold. A comparative analysis distinguishes such civilian mobilization from lawful conscription, underscoring that volunteer civilians receive no combatant protections and face increased legal and physical peril. In its conclusion, the article advances policy recommendations for State and military authorities: cease promotion of civilian direct participation in cyber hostilities; ensure full transparency and legal clarity regarding the status and risks for civilian contributors; and reorient civilian cyber skills toward support roles that safeguard their protected status. Macák warns that without urgent corrective measures, the principle of distinction—and by extension the normative integrity of IHL—will continue to erode, threatening civilian safety and undermining the core rules governing armed conflict in cyberspace.

title: Preparing the Cyber Battlefield: Assessing a Novel Escalation Risk in a Sino-American Crisis
authors: B Buchanan; Fiona S. Cunningham; Robert Chesney; J Shires; M Smeets
abstract: The intensifying strategic rivalry between the United States and China in cyberspace has raised acute concerns about crisis instability, where cyber espionage activities may be misconstrued as preparations for high-end attacks, prompting preemptive escalation into kinetic conflict. As policymakers warn that offensive cyber capabilities could incentivize the use of force rather than diplomatic bargaining during a Sino-American crisis, scholarly debate remains unsettled on whether such capabilities meaningfully contribute to escalation risk. This chapter addresses that gap by focusing on the operational preparation of the environment (OPE)–espionage distinction problem, a novel escalation pathway whereby states misinterpret cyber reconnaissance for imminent attack preparations. The authors seek to determine whether this distinction problem poses a real risk of inadvertent escalation in a future US-China crisis, asking specifically how official policies, strategic writings, and bilateral relations shape incentives to misperceive cyber operations. Employing a qualitative case study methodology grounded in open-source analysis, the authors systematically review US leadership statements, threat perceptions, cyber–operations authorization procedures, organizational structures, capabilities, and publicly available policy documents, alongside Chinese military strategy texts, information security journals, and expert commentaries. This approach follows established best practices for analyzing great-power strategic interaction in domains lacking historical precedent. The analysis reveals that US doctrine explicitly acknowledges the risk that espionage activities could be mistaken for OPE, yet recent shifts toward “defending forward” may exacerbate these misperception vulnerabilities; by contrast, Chinese strategic literature concurs on the technical difficulty of distinguishing espionage from OPE but largely overlooks the implications for crisis stability. Moreover, the lack of mutual understanding and transparency in Sino-American cyber engagement heightens the probability of misinterpretation of benign intelligence collection as preparatory steps for destructive attack, potentially triggering preemptive cyber or kinetic responses. The chapter contributes new empirical evidence on the independent effect of cyber reconnaissance activities on great-power crisis dynamics, offering the first systematic assessment of how OPE-espionage ambiguity operates within both US and Chinese strategic frameworks. However, the findings are constrained by limited and uneven source availability, especially regarding Chinese internal deliberations, and by the hypothetical nature of a Sino-American crisis, which cannot be empirically observed in peacetime. The authors caution that their conclusions may under- or overstate escalation risks if leaders choose to deprioritize or mismanage these concerns despite their presence. Future research should seek to enrich this open-source analysis with classified insights, explore experimental and wargaming approaches to simulate decision-making under cyber-espionage ambiguity, and assess whether confidence-building measures or bilateral cybersecurity dialogues can mitigate inadvertent escalation pathways in a real-world crisis.

title: The Application of the Principle of Precautions to Cyber Operations
source: Military Law and the Law of War Review (MLLWR)
abstract: This article examines the application of the International Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) principle of precautions to cyber operations, arguing that the interconnected character of cyberspace demands a shift in emphasis towards humanity rather than a strict balancing with military necessity. Traditionally, LOAC distinguishes three core principles governing hostilities—distinction, proportionality, and precautions—but the latter has been sidelined in both scholarship and military doctrine. The author contends that applying the principle of precautions in cyber contexts is uniquely challenging due to the pervasive dual-use nature of information and communication technologies and the social dimensions of interconnectivity. From a technical perspective, 98% of government communications traverse civilian networks, obscuring the distinction between military objectives and civilian objects and amplifying collateral risks. Cyber operations against dual-use systems, such as power plants, can precipitate cascading failures in critical civilian infrastructure, even beyond state borders. Social factors further complicate this landscape by embedding civilian stakeholders—engineers, facility personnel, and everyday Internet users—within the attack surface. The article surveys key LOAC provisions—Articles 57 (precautions in attack) and 58 (precautions in defense)—and highlights the ambiguity state delegates and legal advisers have noted in their drafting and interpretation. By exploring customary practice and state examples, including the United States’ use of segregated classified networks (NIPRnet, SIPRnet, JWICS), Ukraine’s migration of government data to commercial cloud platforms, and Estonia’s ‘‘data embassy’’ under pacts safeguarding critical data via blockchain, the author outlines feasible precautionary measures. These include network segregation, digital ‘‘safe havens,’’ advanced threat mapping, controlled folder access on civilian endpoints, and coordinated public–private cyber defense initiatives. The article also interprets the gap-filling function of Article 58(c), urging belligerents to adopt proactive measures—ranging from civilian cyber training and threat warning systems to technical assistance and emergency network isolation—to protect civilians from cyber operations. Concluding with insights from the Russia–Ukraine conflict, the author emphasizes how whole-of-society approaches and public–private collaboration can operationalize the principle of precautions in cyberspace, thereby reinforcing the humanity-based core of LOAC in the digital age.

title: The U.S.-china cyber warfare in the 21st century: implications for international security
abstract:
In “The U.S.-China Cyber Warfare in the 21st Century: Implications for International Security,” Khan and Abbasi map the strategic militarization of cyberspace by the United States and China, situating their analysis within the broader contours of international security, escalation dynamics, and evolving norms of cyber conflict. The authors argue that the advent of cyber warfare as an independent warfighting domain has reconfigured great power competition, elevating cyberspace—once a force multiplier within conventional operations—to a contested battlefield in its own right. Drawing on official doctrinal publications, policy documents—including the U.S. National Defense Strategy and the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace—defense white papers from the People’s Republic of China, and secondary literature on USCYBERCOM and PLA cyber units, the study provides a two-pronged doctrinal and institutional history of U.S. and Chinese cyber commands. The first strand of analysis chronicles the evolution of U.S. cyber capabilities: from the establishment of U.S. Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM) in 2009 and its elevation to a unified combatant command in 2018, to its current force structure of 6,200 personnel organized into specialized mission, combat, protection, and support teams; and the integration of cyber operations into joint warfighting doctrine. The authors highlight how successive U.S. national security strategies have framed cyberspace as the “fifth battlefield,” driving investments in non-kinetic tools for reconnaissance, disruption, and coercion against both state and non-state adversaries. The second strand examines the PLA’s doctrinal shift toward “informatized” and “unrestricted” warfare, documenting the establishment of dedicated cyber and electronic warfare units within China’s General Staff Department and the operationalization of information warfare concepts designed to achieve strategic surprise and decision dominance over an adversary’s decision cycle. By juxtaposing these parallel developments, Khan and Abbasi demonstrate that mutual recognition of near-peer cyber capabilities has fueled a cyber arms race characterized by covert campaigns targeting critical infrastructure, sophisticated attribution challenges, and a growing temptation to use cyber means for coercive statecraft under the threshold of armed conflict. 

The study further interrogates the implications of this strategic competition for deterrence theory and the prospects for normative restraint in cyberspace. It argues that the low attribution costs and deniability of cyber operations complicate crisis stability, potentially lowering the threshold for escalation even as states codify non-binding “rules of the road.” The authors point to emerging international legal debates on state responsibility and the applicability of jus ad bellum and jus in bello principles to cyber attacks, though they acknowledge the limitations of publicly available data in accessing classified operational plans. They conclude by advocating for future research on how multilateral cyber defense pacts, third-party attribution technologies, and evolving normative frameworks can shape power dynamics in cyberspace and constrain strategic competition between great powers. Through its comprehensive doctrinal mapping and normative inquiry, the article contributes a multidisciplinary framework for understanding the operationalization of cyber power, offering policymakers and scholars a rigorous empirical basis to assess the evolving contours of cyber conflict in the digital age.

title: International law and the regulation of cyberoperations below the jus ad bellum threshold. An irish cybersecurity perspective
source: Journal of Military History and Defence
abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the applicability and utility of international law for regulating state-led cyberoperations that fall below the jus ad bellum threshold, focusing on Ireland as a representative small state. It begins by situating sub-threshold cyberoperations within a contested international environment marked by divergent state positions and legal uncertainty. While there is broad agreement among states that existing legal frameworks—principally the UN Charter and customary international law—apply to cyberspace, disputes persist over the precise contours of this application and the threshold at which cyber activities constitute an armed attack. The study reviews two parallel United Nations processes—the Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) and the Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG)—and illustrates how geopolitical rivalries have impeded consensus on binding norms, creating exploitable legal lacunae. Against this backdrop, the paper evaluates the role of informal lawmaking fora, notably the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence’s Tallinn Manuals, and non-binding norms adopted in UN GGE reports. Although these instruments lack binding force, they have incrementally shaped state practice and opinio juris by providing shared interpretations of existing law and promoting behavioural expectations. Integrating theories of small state security drawn from Keohane’s Lilliputian model and ‘soft’ security paradigms, the paper argues that small states like Ireland can leverage both formal international law and non-binding norms to enhance cyber deterrence. It proposes that the promotion of legal norms serves as a strategic tool for small states to cultivate collective resilience, impose reputational costs on aggressors, and compensate for their limited coercive capacities. Empirical evidence is drawn from Ireland’s voluntary national contributions to UN processes and Irish cybersecurity strategy documents, forming the basis of an original framework that fuses doctrinal legal analysis with state security paradigms. The paper identifies persistent challenges to the regulation of sub-threshold cyberoperations: the inherently transnational nature of cyberspace, the rapid pace of technological change outstripping doctrinal development, and deeply entrenched geopolitical fault lines that hinder multilateral cooperation. Nevertheless, it concludes that international law, when complemented by non-binding norms and potentially a future cyber treaty, remains an indispensable component of a comprehensive cybersecurity strategy for small states. The author calls for further empirical research into how legal norms influence state behaviour in cyberspace and the mechanisms for solidifying customary law, including more explicit state declarations of adherence to specific legal principles and enhanced participation in norm-building processes.

title: Critiquing the US characterization, attribution and retaliation laws and policies for cyberattacks
abstract: This paper addresses the critical problem that the United States lacks clear, coherent processes for characterizing, attributing, and responding to cyberattacks on critical infrastructure, undermining its ability to defend against evolving cyber threats. Given the increasing frequency and sophistication of state and state-sponsored cyber operations against U.S. assets, the absence of standardized categorization, a centralized attribution authority, and a precise retaliation framework poses significant national security risks. The research justifies itself by highlighting these deficiencies and aims to answer the question of how U.S. laws and policies governing cyberattack response can be improved. Specifically, it critiques existing characterization guidelines, decentralized attribution functions, and inconsistent retaliation policies, and proposes legal and policy reforms. Methodologically, the study employs a qualitative legal and policy analysis, drawing on official U.S. government documents—including Government Accountability Office reports, Department of Defense definitions, and existing statutes such as the proposed Cyber Deterrence Remediation Act—as well as scholarly work on cyber norms, attribution frameworks, and threat actor tactics. The author synthesizes these sources to identify gaps and inconsistencies. The analysis finds that the U.S. characterization process relies on an outdated Threat Table last substantially revised in 2005 despite dynamic changes in threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures, impeding rapid and accurate identification of cyberattacks. Attribution remains fragmented across multiple agencies and private firms without a single, central authority, leading to potential contradictions and inefficiencies. Retaliation policies are dispersed across various documents and lack the precision and consistency needed to deter adversaries effectively, as evidenced by U.S. inconsistencies in applying response measures. The contribution of this work lies in its comprehensive set of recommendations: first, the creation of a Joint Characterization Guideline produced jointly by USCYBERCOM, DHS, FBI, CISA, and private sector partners, with annual updates to reflect evolving threat motivations; second, the establishment of a National Cyber Investigative Agency endowed with exclusive authority to publicly attribute cyberattacks, supported by a Cyber Attribution Guideline to govern both public and private sector attribution activities; and third, the development of a Cyber Retaliation Toolbox and a Cyber Enforcement Strategy under the Office of the National Cyber Director to standardize proportionate, transparent, and enforceable response options for different classes of cyberattacks. The paper acknowledges limitations including its focus on U.S. law without comparative analysis, reliance on publicly available documents rather than classified data, and absence of empirical testing of its proposed frameworks. For future research, the author suggests empirical studies of threat actor behavior to inform the updating of the Threat Table, evaluation of interagency coordination in attribution, and assessment of the effectiveness of the proposed retaliation mechanisms in deterring state and non-state cyber aggressors.

title: Cyber Military Threat and International Law: Assessing the Response to Cyber Attacks in the Military Context
abstract: In an era of escalating geopolitical tensions and technological integration, the convergence of cyberspace and military operations presents a significant challenge to the existing international legal framework. The author highlights that cyber-attacks transcend national borders and blur the line between civilian and military targets, undermining traditional notions of armed conflict and state responsibility under the UN Charter. This research addresses the critical gap in understanding how international law responds to cyber-military threats by assessing legal responses to cyber-attacks in the military context. The study aims to determine how well current conventions and expert guidelines regulate cyberspace hostilities and to propose recommendations for future legal instruments, with particular reference to the informal Tallinn Manual as a potential foundation for binding norms. Employing a doctrinal methodology supplemented by content analysis, synthesis, and analytical techniques, the author systematically reviews fifty-one professional studies to ensure an objective assessment of prevailing legal approaches. The analysis reveals that attribution and identification of the cyber-attack initiator pose formidable obstacles to assigning responsibility, especially when civilian infrastructure or personnel are involved. Equally problematic is the lack of consensus on whether cyber operations constitute use of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, complicating efforts to harmonize rules governing cyber warfare. The study further identifies that key legal concepts such as “cyberwar” and “cyberattack” remain undefined in international instruments, exacerbating the legal vacuum. In response to these findings, the author assesses expert guidance in the Tallinn Manual, which offers interpretations of self-defense, nonuse of force, and thresholds for armed attack in cyberspace. The research contributes a critical evaluation of this manual’s role as a stepping stone toward a future convention that could codify state obligations and procedures for attributing and responding to cyber aggression. The study underscores that without political will and concerted international cooperation, formalizing such norms will remain elusive. Limitations of the research include its reliance on secondary literature and the evolving nature of state practice in cyber operations, which may outpace doctrinal analysis. Recognizing these constraints, the author suggests that empirical case studies of recent cyber incidents and comparative analysis of national legislation could enrich future inquiry. The paper proposes further exploration into defining cyber warfare thresholds, refining attribution mechanisms, and integrating jus in bello principles into digital conflict regulation, thus paving the way for robust international standards to regulate state conduct in cyberspace.

title: Mind the Gap(s) - The Need to Resolve Uncertainties in the International Law of Cyber Warfare
abstract: This article investigates how the emerging practice of official public attribution by states is shaping international cyber norms and state behavior in cyberspace. In the absence of clear, enforceable rules governing state-sponsored cyber operations, states risk miscalculation and escalation. Official public attribution—publicly naming and blaming a state actor for cyberattacks—has become an informal mechanism to signal disapproval and delineate unacceptable conduct. The author first conducts a quantitative exploratory analysis of data from the European Repository of Cyber Incidents spanning 2000–2023, revealing a marked increase in attribution events by Western states since the mid-2010s. This trend underscores a growing willingness to publicly hold perpetrators accountable and communicates strategic expectations of acceptable behavior. Next, through a detailed case study of Iran’s 2022 cyberattack on Albania, the paper reconstructs the sequence of events and diplomatic responses, drawing on official statements by Albania’s prime minister, the United States, the United Kingdom, NATO, and open-source intelligence. Albania’s decision to sever diplomatic ties with Iran, bolstered by coordinated attributions from its allies, exemplifies the political utility of public attribution: it imposes reputational costs, clarifies ‘‘facts on the ground,’’ and implicitly defines forbidden actions. Framed within Finnemore and Sikkink’s norm life cycle—emergence, acceptance, internalization—the paper conceptualizes attribution events as norm–entrepreneurship acts that can catalyze a normative cascade among like-minded states even as formal United Nations negotiations remain stalled. The author argues that repeated attribution events cumulatively reinforce normative commitments and serve as informal enforcement mechanisms operating in parallel to formal UN processes. While acknowledging the nascent state of this practice and limitations such as reliance on public sources and the opacity of classified deliberations, the study proposes a framework for understanding public attribution as part of a broader cyber diplomacy toolkit. The paper concludes by recommending avenues for future research, including systematic longitudinal studies assessing behavioral changes among accused states, comparative analyses of attribution practices across geopolitical blocs, and examinations of the interplay between public attribution and formal norm-setting within UN fora. Through this multidisciplinary lens—integrating policy analysis, international relations theory, and empirical case methods—the article advances our understanding of how states leverage public attribution to foster accountability, shape international expectations, and pave the way for the emergence and codification of global cyber norms.
