title: Voting by proxy - meddling in foreign elections and public international law
source: Indiana Journal of Global Legal Studies
abstract: In "Voting by Proxy – Meddling in Foreign Elections and Public International Law," Professor Patrick C.R. Terry examines the legality of foreign electoral interventions under public international law in light of both historical and contemporary practices, including cyber-enabled influence operations. Framing the issue with early American warnings against foreign interference and the recent focus spurred by alleged Russian actions in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, Terry observes that election meddling is not novel but rather has been conducted at scale since World War II. Drawing on Dov Levin’s empirical work identifying over a hundred partisan electoral interventions by the United States and the Soviet Union between 1946 and 2000, Terry argues that the key legal benchmark for assessing any form of election interference—whether traditional or cyber-based—is the prohibition on interventions in the internal affairs (domaine réservé) of sovereign states. He systematically defines prohibited intervention as conduct that is coercive, aimed at altering another state’s election outcome, and beyond the target state’s capacity to terminate at will. Open expressions of foreign-state electoral preferences, while potentially unwelcome, remain lawful persuasive speech. By contrast, deceptive or manipulative operations—such as covert funding of journalists or political actors, dissemination of fake news, espionage for campaign-damaging information, or disguised social media campaigns that impersonate domestic sources—cross the threshold into coercive intervention because they deprive the targeted electorate and state of an effective response. Terry further explores the legal contours of coercion, illustrating that intervention occurs when target states cannot halt interference through domestic means, thereby compelling foreign ends. Notably, he highlights a paradox: economic coercion through conditional promises or threats of sanctions remains lawful under international law, as sovereign states retain discretion over their external economic relations. Applying his analysis to two emblematic episodes—the U.S. intervention in Italy’s 1948 election and Russian cyber operations in 2016—Terry demonstrates the robustness and limits of the non-intervention principle. He also critiques alternative legal bases, including state sovereignty and the right of self-determination, arguing that these norms either fail to capture all forms of electoral meddling or risk being accepted only by a Western liberal subset of states. Concluding that an internationally negotiated framework is urgently needed to define permissible conduct and curb emerging threats—particularly cryptocurrency-enabled financing and cyber-tampering with vote tallies—Terry calls for an inclusive dialogue transcending democratic exceptionalism to develop clear rules governing foreign influence in elections in the digital age.

title: Understanding transnational cyber attribution
authors: B Kuerbis; F Badiei; K Grindal; M Mueller
source: moving from "whodunit" to who did it
abstract: This book chapter examines cyber attribution as a fundamentally socio-technical and politically contested process, tracing its evolution from technical forensic practices to proposals for institutionalizing credible, transnational frameworks. The authors begin by situating attribution within dual roles of deterrence and accountability: while defensive cybersecurity measures can delay adversaries, only robust and credible attribution can impose political costs, reinforce norms against malicious behavior, and deter future attacks. They distinguish between identifying intrusion sets—clusters of tactics, techniques, and procedures—and "true attribution" to responsible state or non-state actors, drawing on multi-level models that consider machines, human operators, and ultimate parties of responsibility. Through a dataset of 82 publicly disclosed cyber incidents between 2016 and early 2018, the chapter documents a marked shift toward private-sector actors issuing attributions, sometimes alongside or even ahead of state attributions. It analyzes the divergent incentives, evidentiary standards, and timing across attributing actors, noting that while algorithmic clustering and advanced forensic tools promise more precise linkages, they also drive strategic obfuscation by threat actors such as with the CIA’s Marble Framework and cross-use of exploits like EternalBlue. Recognizing the political biases inherent in attribution, the authors survey prominent institutional proposals for transnational attribution: Microsoft’s state-centric “Digital Geneva Convention,” the RAND Consortium model emphasizing technical independence, and hybrid structures advanced by ICT4Peace and the Internet Governance Project. They critique these models’ varying scopes, actor participation, and incentive alignments, drawing lessons from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons’ laboratory network. Building on these critiques, they describe an emergent network of academic, civil society, and private researchers seeking to develop an independent, scientific attribution capability that upholds transparency, reproducibility, and methodological rigor. The chapter identifies three major challenges to such a collective endeavor: overcoming geopolitical rivalries that may undermine consensus; securing sustainable financial and institutional support for independent forensics; and aligning private sector incentives when corporate actors already possess advanced attribution capabilities. Addressing these challenges requires careful design of governance mechanisms—whether hierarchical international bodies, consensus-based multistakeholder networks, or decentralized consortia—and clear procedures for evidence collection, data sharing, and public communication. The authors propose a research agenda to deepen understanding of attribution practices, including how stakeholder responses vary by source of attribution, how to integrate scientific norms into forensic processes, defining suitable confidence levels, and architecting governance models that distribute costs and benefits equitably. Concluding that while ideal institutional forms remain untested, it is both feasible and imperative to move from the technical question of "whodunit" to the political imperative of "who did it" in cyber conflict, thereby strengthening international norms, accountability mechanisms, and global cyber stability.

title: Pulling the strings in cyberspace: legal attribution of cyber operations based on state control
source: Closing the Gap : Responsibility in Cyberspace …, 2023
abstract: This chapter by Evgeni Moyakine confronts the enduring challenge of attributing cyber operations conducted by non-state actors to sponsoring states under international law. Recognizing that modern cyber campaigns frequently employ proxies—animating non-state actors to avoid direct state responsibility—Moyakine situates his analysis within the framework of the Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (ARSIWA) and the Tallinn Manual 2.0. He argues that prevailing tests of state control, namely the strict “organ” test and the “effective control” criteria, are ill-suited to capture the diffuse, covert, and technologically complex nature of cyber operations. Instead, he advances the “overall control” test—which assesses whether a state finances, organizes, coordinates, or hierarchically directs non-state actors—as a more flexible and evidentially sensitive means of linking sophisticated hacker collectives to state sponsors. The chapter proceeds to illustrate this approach with a detailed case study of the Stuxnet attack. Moyakine reviews public disclosures and open-source evidence suggesting the United States and Israel orchestrated and financed the Equation Group’s development and deployment of the Stuxnet worm against Iranian facilities, highlighting factors such as unity of goals, hierarchical planning, operational support, and covert technological tools (e.g., NSA’s “Grok” keylogger). He shows that while ARSIWA Articles 4 and 5 (organ and conduct tests) might not apply if hackers are not formal state organs, Article 8’s overall control test could attribute responsibility where evidence reveals state direction and material support. Extending the analysis, Moyakine examines the WannaCry 2.0 and SolarWinds incidents. In the case of WannaCry, he notes public attributions to North Korea but underscores the evidentiary hurdles in demonstrating effective control; nonetheless, he argues that financial support and coordination with the Lazarus Group could, in principle, satisfy an overall control standard. Similarly, he observes that political attributions of the SolarWinds hack to Russia exceed what could be legally imputed under strict conduct tests, whereas an overall control test offers a clearer pathway to state responsibility when a well-structured group like Cozy Bear (Nobelium) exhibits operational alignment with state objectives. In conclusion, Moyakine identifies evidence-gathering deficits in legal attribution and calls for advancing customary international law to reflect cyber realities. He urges judicial and political bodies to adopt the overall control concept, refine outward signs of authority, consider novel “soft control” or “working in tandem” tests, and establish international attribution mechanisms that balance transparency with secrecy. He also recommends interdisciplinary research on state-proxy cyber relationships, the evolution of due diligence obligations, and empirical strengthening of evidentiary bases for holding states accountable in cyberspace.

title: Non-Escalatory Attribution of International Cyber Incidents
abstract:
In "Persuasion About/Without International Law: The Case of Cybersecurity Norms," Steven R. Ratner examines how states and non-state actors deploy, contest, and shape international legal argumentation in the fragmented normative environment of cybersecurity. Ratner opens by situating cybersecurity among global collective action problems—alongside climate change—highlighting its complexity, including abundant malicious malware, sophisticated perpetrators, harm to critical infrastructures, attribution challenges, and the inadequacy of isolated national regulation. Unlike more established domains of international law—use of force, human rights, environmental law—cyber-international law remains characterized by a thin or contested consensus. The chapter identifies four levels of legal disagreement: whether binding rules exist; the content of any existing rules; the desirability of enacting new binding rules versus non-binding norms; and the precise content of any proposed legal instruments.

The first section maps the current international legal landscape governing cybersecurity, delineating areas of emerging convergence—such as the applicability of existing jus ad bellum and international humanitarian law principles to cyber operations—and persistent divergences, including the debate over whether international law adequately addresses state-sponsored cyber espionage and critical infrastructure attacks. It also considers the regulatory roles assumed by non-state actors—private corporations, technical communities, and standard-setting bodies—that fill gaps through voluntary norms.

Section II develops a theoretical framework of "multilevel persuasion," exploring how states rhetorically invoke the existence, meaning, and content of international law to persuade other actors. Ratner analyzes the strategic calculus behind invoking or disclaiming legal rules, showing how legal argumentation serves diplomatic, reputational, and deterrence aims. This analysis accounts for both ex ante advocacy—campaigning for new norms or treaties—and ex post responses to cyber incidents, revealing law’s dual role as constraint and instrument of power.

Section III extends this framework to non-state actors—corporations, academics, think tanks—detailing how these actors craft and circulate claims about current or prospective international legal norms to influence state behavior and public opinion. Ratner underscores their significance in norm diffusion and in shaping the interpretive and persuasive context within which states operate.

In a concluding section, Ratner reflects on broader implications: how the cybersecurity case challenges assumptions in legal theory about consensual rule-based discourse, illuminating the motivations, modalities, and effects of legal argumentation in domains where binding rules are thin. The chapter thus offers a nuanced, multidisciplinary account of cyber lawmaking, persuasion, and the evolving role of international law in digital conflict.

title: Positioning Diplomacy Within a Strategic Response to the Cyber Conflict Threat
authors: K Renaud; A Attatfa; T Craig; S Parkin; L Vigano
abstract: In “Applying International Environmental Legal Norms to Cyber Statecraft,” Healey and Pitts propose that established principles of international environmental law—particularly those governing transboundary harm, due diligence, and state responsibility—offer a novel and promising framework for regulating state and non-state conduct in cyberspace. After surveying existing responses to cyber insecurity—the Technical Approach of engineering fixes, the Criminal Approach of law enforcement collaboration, and the Warfare Approach of military doctrine—the authors demonstrate that each, while valuable within its domain, fails to reconcile the fundamental tension between state sovereignty and obligations to prevent harm emanating from a shared global domain. Drawing on landmark environmental law decisions such as Trail Smelter and Corfu Channel, the authors introduce “cyber pollution” as an analogy for distributed denial-of-service attacks, malware propagation, and botnet operations that cross borders and inflict harm on other states. They show that environmental norms can clarify thresholds for harmful acts, articulate when state inaction amounts to wrongful transboundary harm, and attribute responsibility to host states for non-state actors operating from their territory. Key cases—the 2007 Estonian denial-of-service attacks and takedowns of the Rustock and Waledac botnets—illustrate both the prevalence of cross-border cyber harm and the efficacy of coordinated state and private actions informed by environmental principles, such as diplomatic pressure and reputational mitigation. Healey and Pitts critically examine limitations: uneven state capacity to police networks, the absence of explicit state consent to extend environmental norms to cyberspace, and the challenges of adapting enforcement mechanisms to a decentralized, rapidly evolving digital ecosystem. To overcome these constraints, they recommend initiating normative dialogues within UN Groups of Governmental Experts, the OECD, G20, OAS, and APEC to build consensus on definitions, thresholds, and compliance mechanisms for cyber pollution. They advocate for empirical research into state practice adopting environmental norms for cyber incidents, the establishment of monitoring and verification institutions, and domain-specific guidelines for emerging technologies such as cloud computing and the Internet of Things. By mapping environmental norms onto cyber governance, this article contributes a multidisciplinary approach that bridges public international law and cyber policy, reinforcing sovereignty, due diligence, and shared responsibility while enabling deterrence, accountability, and cooperation. The authors conclude that leveraging pre-existing legal frameworks can demystify cyber governance, aid in the preventative crafting of norms, and strengthen the normative architecture of cyberspace alongside technical, criminal, and military strategies.

title: Extending the 'attribution problem': why who-based attribution is insufficient to deterring cyberattacks
abstract: This article advances the scholarly understanding of cyber deterrence by identifying a critical intelligence-centric barrier that extends beyond the well-documented ‘‘attribution problem.’” The author argues that even when states can publicly attribute a cyberattack to a perpetrator, the indirect and multi-stage nature of offensive cyber operations generates an ‘‘analytic ambiguity dilemma’’ that thwarts timely, clear, and proportionate punitive responses. Drawing on an extensive literature review and detailed qualitative case studies of the 2016 Russian election interference campaign, the 2017 WannaCry ransomware outbreak, and the NotPetya destructive malware incident, the paper demonstrates how the unique characteristics of cyberspace—indirect effect delivery, external dependency on defender resilience, and overlapping tactical footprints across reconnaissance, exploitation, and payload deployment—complicate judgments of an attacker’s motive, intent, and culpability. In practice, these features prolong the evidentiary timeline, erode confidence in linking observed harms to specific intentions, and undermine the normative requirements of punishment-based deterrence. The Russian election interference case illustrates how evolving goals and fractured legal authorities within the U.S. intelligence community delayed recognition of the threat and obscured a unified deterrent response. The WannaCry example highlights how reliance on private-sector forensic tools produced timely technical attribution to North Korea, yet policymakers struggled to justify coercive measures given uncertainties about the ransomware’s intended targets and collateral effects. NotPetya further underscores the dilemma by showing how destructive malware masquerading as ransomware produced widespread collateral damage, making proportional retaliation politically and legally fraught. Through these cases, the paper identifies indirectness and multi-stage dynamics as systemic constraints on deterrence by punishment, suggesting that states require alternative models—such as deterrence by denial or strengthened normative frameworks—to manage cyber aggression. The author acknowledges limitations in generalizing from three high-profile incidents and calls for empirical research to quantify the temporal impact of analytic ambiguity and to explore hybrid deterrence strategies better aligned with the epistemic realities of cyberspace.

title: Developing Applicable Standards of Proof for Peacetime Cyber Attribution
abstract: States responding to hostile cyber operations currently face an uncertain legal and political landscape in which no explicit standards of proof govern attribution, yet such attribution is a necessary precondition to lawful countermeasures, self-defence, and retorsion. As cyber operations assume an increasingly central role in strategic competition and the coercive toolbox available to states, the absence of clear evidentiary thresholds heightens the risk that victim states will either refrain from countering wrongful acts for fear of misattribution or respond precipitously and unjustly, undermining international stability and deterrence. This paper addresses the critical need for applicable standards of proof in peacetime cyber attribution by asking what level of evidentiary certainty should correspond to different categories of state responses and how international law might evolve to reflect those thresholds. Adopting a doctrinal methodology rooted in analysis of customary international law principles, state practice manifest in United Nations Group of Governmental Experts reports, ICJ jurisprudence on use of force, and expert guidance such as the Tallinn Manual, the author conducts a comprehensive legal analysis to determine appropriate standards for attribution. The research reveals that existing international law applies a broad“reasonableness” standard for self-defence claims, a vague threshold for countermeasures, and no defined requirement for retorsion, resulting in inconsistent state behaviour. To address this gap, the paper proposes a tiered framework: a preponderance of the evidence standard for attribution underpinning countermeasures, a clear and convincing evidence standard for attributions justifying forcible measures and self-defence responses that risk death or destruction, and a demonstration of considered evidentiary basis beyond mere impulse for acts of retorsion. This calibrated approach balances three essential probabilities: correctly holding the responsible state accountable, minimizing harm to innocents, and ensuring third-party acceptance of attribution. By linking distinct standards to the severity of the responsive measures, the framework contributes a novel procedural model for evidentiary assessment that both preserves victim state freedom of action and enhances the legitimacy of their responses under international law. The paper acknowledges limitations inherent in relying on evolving state practice rather than binding treaty provisions, the potential subjectivity in applying a clear and convincing standard, and the uneven capacities of states to gather and present evidence. Future research should empirically assess state receptivity to these proposed thresholds, examine the role of multilateral mechanisms in enforcing evidentiary standards, and explore how evolving cybersecurity technologies may affect both attribution capabilities and the calibration of proof requirements.

title: Essential Questions for Cyber Policy: Strategically Using Global Norms to Resolve the Cyber Attribution Challenge
abstract: The increasing frequency and sophistication of cyber operations by state and non-state actors have exposed critical gaps in existing policy and legal frameworks for attributing and holding actors responsible in international cyberspace, a challenge that threatens both deterrence and stability among states. This paper contends that prevailing conceptions of cyberspace as a purely virtual domain have exacerbated the attribution problem by obscuring the physical infrastructures and human elements integral to digital operations, and it seeks to demonstrate how a refined, holistic understanding of cyberspace can underpin the development of enforceable global norms for state responsibility. Specifically, the authors aim to answer how policymakers can leverage global diplomatic forums and international legal principles to create binding standards that hold nation-states accountable for wrongful cyber acts, thereby enhancing both deterrence and cooperative security. Employing a normative policy analysis methodology, the study systematically reviews U.S. Air Force doctrinal definitions, key speeches such as Secretary Clinton’s public remarks on Internet freedom, United Nations resolutions, and strategic documents from the Department of Defense, mapping the intersection of physical, logical, information, and human layers of cyberspace against existing international law. It also surveys multilateral venues—from the UN General Assembly to regional organizations such as ASEAN and the OSCE—to assess their potential roles in sponsoring and propagating these norms. The findings reveal that current emphasis on technical attribution overlooks the inextricable linkage of digital activity to tangible networks and operators within sovereign territory and that existing multilateral platforms offer untapped opportunities for consensus-building. The analysis demonstrates that by adopting a characteristics-based model of cyberspace and channeling U.S. leadership into established diplomatic fora, it is possible to craft a coherent global culture of cybersecurity, anchored in principles of state responsibility under jus ad bellum. The primary contribution is a policy framework that integrates conceptual redefinition of cyberspace with strategic sponsorship of international norms, outlining specific stages for norm emergence, codification, and internalization across diverse institutions. This framework provides policymakers with a roadmap for transforming diffuse, technical debates into a structured agenda for multilateral negotiation and legal articulation. The authors acknowledge that the brief’s scope is constrained by its reliance on secondary doctrinal and policy sources and that empirical validation of norm adoption processes remains to be conducted in subsequent research. They also note the pending publication of a more extensive monograph that will expand the theoretical foundations and case studies. Future research is thus directed toward conducting empirical case analyses of norm diffusion in regional forums, developing metrics for assessing state compliance, and exploring mechanisms for embedding cyber norms within binding international treaties, thereby advancing the strategic utility of global norms to resolve the cyber attribution challenge.

title: International law and cyberspace: what does state silence say?
abstract: This article examines the largely overlooked phenomenon of reactive state silence in the development and application of international law in cyberspace. Reactive silence—when a state does not respond verbally or physically to another actor’s claim or conduct—can convey acceptance, non-acceptance, or opposition under principles of customary international law, yet cyberspace actors have rarely articulated its legal significance. Drawing on doctrinal analysis of the International Law Commission’s Draft Conclusions on Subsequent Agreements and Customary International Law Identification, the authors adopt a descriptive and normative lens to explore how silence may shape cyber norms and law. They establish key thresholds for silence to carry legal weight: the silence must occur in circumstances calling for a reaction, the state must have knowledge of the practice, and a reasonable time and capacity to respond. The chapter then surveys three illustrative contexts where reactive silence manifests in cyberspace: 1) Internet governance—states’ omissions in multistakeholder bodies such as ICANN, where silence on jurisdictional claims has allowed non-state institutions to fill regulatory gaps; 2) state-sponsored covert cyber operations—instances where states neither publicly condemn cyber intrusions into foreign ICT networks nor clarify legal norms, excluding silent acquiescence or dissent from formal legal discourse; and 3) unilateral state proclamations on cyber law—voluntary norms endorsed in UN GGE and OEWG reports, where states often endorse non-binding “norms of responsible behaviour” without specifying whether these codify existing legal obligations. Through literature review, interpretive case study, and analysis of UN GGE reports, court judgments, and state practice, the authors document the dearth of explicit state engagement with reactive silence in cyberspace and identify patterns of partial silence—where states respond substantively but remain silent on legal foundations—and catalysing silence—where absence of formal legal reaction spurs alternative norm-building outside traditional international institutions. The analysis highlights contextual conditions mediating silence’s salience, including clarity of applicable legal rules, transparency of conduct, state technical capacity, and the dynamic evolution of ICTs. These factors may explain cyberspace’s current absence of reactive silence discourse and raise normative questions about the equity of imputing legal acceptance or opposition when only technologically advanced states may perceive or respond to conduct. The chapter concludes by calling for systematic empirical documentation of state silences in cyber contexts, further exploration of their interaction with emerging cyber doctrines, and inter-disciplinary research to assess whether the conceptual categories of reactive, partial, and catalysing silence can advance understanding of law-making and norm contestation in the digital domain.

title: THE FINAL FRONTIER OF CYBERSPACE: THE SEABED BEYOND NATIONAL JURISDICTION AND THE PROTECTION OF SUBMARINE CABLES
authors: D Guilfoyle; TP Paige; R McLaughlin
source: International & Comparative Law Quarterly / Volume 71 / Issue 3 / July 2022
abstract: This article examines the legal regime governing submarine telecommunication cables—the physical backbone of global cyberspace—which lie for the most part beyond any State’s sovereign jurisdiction yet underpin strategic, economic, educational, cultural, and military activity. It begins by surveying existing ‘‘law of peace’’ frameworks: the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) provisions on laying and protecting submarine cables in exclusive economic zones and beyond, the 1884 Convention for the Protection of Submarine Telegraph Cables, technical recommendations from the International Cable Protection Committee, and soft-law guidelines from the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). The authors demonstrate that while these instruments permit the untrammelled deployment of submarine cables, they have not kept pace with the modern cables’ multifunctionality (data transfer, environmental sensing) or the increased State and private reliance on them. The article then shifts to the law of armed conflict (LOAC) and the law on the use of force (jus ad bellum and jus in bello) to address the hitherto neglected question of deliberate damage to cables in peacetime and wartime. A detailed analysis shows that no treaty or customary norm specifically prohibits or permits State or non-State attacks on submarine cables. Historic Hague Regulations concerning the cutting of cables between occupied and neutral territories offer only limited, narrowly applicable rules. Accordingly, targeting must be assessed under LOAC’s general principles of military objectives and proportionality. Submarine cables can qualify as military objectives if they make a tangible contribution to military operations—such as enabling command, control, communications, surveillance, or use of unmanned systems. However, the global interconnectedness and societal dependence on these networks mean that even localized cable severances would cause extensive, foreseeable collateral harm: economic disruption, degraded civilian and military communications, cloud-service outages, and cascading effects on financial and data-storage systems across belligerent and neutral States. The proportionality test—requiring incidental civilian damage not to be excessive in relation to the concrete military advantage—cannot realistically be satisfied given the diffuse and systemic nature of harms and the necessity of multiple, network-wide cable cuts to achieve significant military gains. The authors conclude that while LOAC does not categorically forbid strikes on submarine cables, in practice the law’s proportionality constraints render such attacks functionally unlawful. They call for a holistic, updated legal framework—integrating principles of the law of the sea, State responsibility, use of force, and armed conflict—to govern submarine cable protection in peace and war and to reflect their strategic importance in the digital age.

title: contributing to cyber peace by maximizing the potential for deterrence
authors: J Trahan; Sj Shackelford; F Douzet; C Ankersen
abstract: This chapter, written by Jennifer Trahan, Clinical Professor at NYU and Director of the Concentration in International Law & Human Rights, explores how the International Criminal Court’s (ICC) Rome Statute can be leveraged to criminalize and thereby deter the gravest cyberattacks that cause serious loss of life or physical damage, thus contributing to “cyber peace.” While acknowledging that the Rome Statute’s gravity threshold limits its applicability to a narrow subset of cyber operations, Trahan argues that those severe attacks – akin to conventional genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, or aggression – should be recognized as prosecutable under existing international criminal law. The chapter begins by defining cyberattacks with consequences similar to kinetic attacks and reviews the Statute’s crime categories, emphasizing challenges of meeting proof beyond reasonable doubt and attribution. It highlights the deterrent potential of ICC jurisdiction, noting that increased awareness of prosecutorial possibilities may itself deter would-be perpetrators. Trahan then provides a background survey of the diversity of cyberattacks—from data theft and election interference to the NotPetya and Stuxnet examples—while specifying that only those causing mass casualties or physical destruction fall within the Statute’s scope. She notes state parties could embed Rome Statute crimes within domestic laws, potentially extending jurisdiction beyond the international court’s limitations, yet focuses on using the ICC as the permanent tribunal. The chapter proceeds to examine international criminal law’s role in deterrence, summarizing scholarship on deterrence pessimism and optimism. It cites studies, such as interviews with the Macedonian Armed Forces in 2001, that suggest tribunals like the ICTY influenced combatant behavior, and research indicating the ICC has had some deterrent effect. Trahan stresses that while international law has not fully eradicated atrocity crimes, any deterrent capacity warrants maximization. Drawing on normative frameworks – international humanitarian law, human rights law, and UN Charter use-of-force norms as applied to cyberspace – she argues that law’s application, though imperfect, must be exploited to reinforce the rule of law online. The chapter concludes that embedding Rome Statute criminalization of cyberattacks within state and international legal regimes, coupled with robust attribution and prosecutions, can enhance the ICC’s deterrent impact and advance the goal of cyber peace. Even if full deterrence is unattainable, the existence and acknowledgment of legal accountability for mass-casualty cyberoperations is an essential component of global cyber governance and peacebuilding.

title: Insurance Policies and the Attribution of Cyber Operations Under International Law: A Commentary
source: New York University Journal of International Law & Politics
abstract: The dramatic escalation of state-backed cyber operations has exposed critical gaps in both commercial insurance frameworks and the international legal regime governing state responsibility for cyberattacks. This commentary emerges against the backdrop of the NotPetya incident in June 2017 in which destructive malware allegedly deployed by the Russian Federation inflicted over $10 billion in global losses, triggering high-profile insurance disputes brought by victims such as Merck and Mondelez when insurers invoked war or hostile act exclusions to deny coverage. The central question addressed is how cyber insurance policies engage with the established rules of attribution under international law and what evidentiary standards should govern determinations of “state-backed” cyber operations for the purpose of insurance exclusions. To answer this, the author reviews insurance industry practices, model policy clauses from Lloyd’s of London, and the strict rules of attribution codified in international law instruments alongside the more politicized public attributions made by States. Methodologically, this commentary adopts a doctrinal analysis of policy documents and legal texts, combined with case study examination of NotPetya-related litigation and Lloyd’s of London’s market bulletins on state-backed exclusions. It further assesses the evidentiary frameworks outlined by the International Court of Justice’s Statute and comparative national court practices. The analysis reveals that insurers increasingly rely on uncontextualized political attributions—public statements by States asserting responsibility without disclosing underlying evidence—as sufficient proof to trigger war exclusion clauses, thereby sidestepping both transparency and the rigorous evidence thresholds required for legal attribution under international law. This practice risks entrenching opaque state claims and undermining legal certainty, since political attributions often lack the subsidiary evidentiary clarity needed for judicial scrutiny. The commentary contributes a critical insight by arguing for a harmonized approach whereby insurers and courts should demand concrete, demonstrable evidence—such as forensic reports from cybersecurity firms or independent expert analyses—in conjunction with state statements before excluding coverage. It further proposes that national court decisions grounded in robust evidence may serve as persuasive authority for international tribunals and foster a more consistent attribution jurisprudence. A key limitation acknowledged is the commentary’s reliance on publicly available policy documents and case filings, which may not reflect private negotiations or undisclosed evidentiary materials. The author also notes that evolving cyber threats and varied state practices may complicate the development of uniform evidentiary standards. Future research could explore comparative empirical analysis of national litigation outcomes on cyber insurance exclusions, examine the potential for an independent international attribution mechanism, and assess how emerging norms in cyber diplomacy influence both commercial insurance practices and international legal adjudication of state responsibility for cyber operations.

title: Applicability of international law in cyberspace: positions by Estonia and Latvia
source: SOCRATES. Rīgas Stradiņa Universitātes Juridiskās Fakultātes Elektroniskais Juridisko Zinātnisko Rakstu Žurnāls / SOCRATES. Rīga Stradiņš University Faculty of Law Electronic Scientific Journal of Law
abstract: This article provides a focused comparative analysis of how two Baltic states—Estonia and Latvia—interpret and promote the applicability of international law in cyberspace within multilateral forums and their national cybersecurity strategies. Against a backdrop of escalating state-sponsored cyber‐attacks and hybrid warfare tactics that threaten international peace and security, the study addresses the urgent need to clarify how existing international legal norms apply to state conduct in cyberspace. Employing a qualitative, document‐based methodology grounded in foreign policy analysis, the author examines primary sources including national cybersecurity strategy documents, official statements made at United Nations Group of Governmental Experts (UN GGE) and Open‐Ended Working Group (OEWG) meetings, and relevant UN General Assembly resolutions. The research reveals that Estonia has established a comprehensive and proactive legal stance, contributing to all four consensus reports of the UN GGE since 2004 and consistently engaging in OEWG deliberations. Estonia’s detailed position papers articulate how core principles of the UN Charter, international humanitarian law, self‐defence, and countermeasures apply to cyber operations. By publicly sharing its legal reasoning, Estonia strengthens global understanding of norms governing responsible state behaviour in cyberspace and provides expertise to less active states. In contrast, Latvia has refrained from articulating detailed legal positions or participating in GGE processes, limiting its public contributions to generic support for the principle that existing international law governs cyberspace. The scarcity of Latvia’s official materials suggests that resource constraints or limited expertise may impede its influence on evolving normative frameworks. The divergence between these two similar states—geographically and politically—underscores the role of historical experience, notably Estonia’s response to the 2007 cyber‐attacks, in shaping ambitious cyber foreign policy and legal advocacy. The article argues that national‐level advocacy is instrumental for developing and reinforcing non‐binding norms and paves the way for potential binding instruments, while also highlighting ongoing debates over whether to negotiate a new treaty versus strengthening existing legal regimes. Key limitations include reliance on publicly available documents, exclusion of in‐depth legal exegesis, and the potential underrepresentation of Latvia’s evolving positions. The study concludes by calling for deeper legal analysis of national contributions, assessment of Baltic advocacy’s impact on UN norms, and encouragement for Latvia to publish detailed legal positions. These steps will foster a more robust and inclusive understanding of responsible state conduct in cyberspace and the evolution of international law in the digital domain.

title: Due diligence and defend forward
abstract: This article advances a novel framework for distributed cyber deterrence grounded in classical just war theory and tailored to contemporary cyber operations, integrating public international law, private defensive measures, and civil society participation. Recognizing key features of cyberspace—low execution costs, attribution challenges, and frequent interference with public deliberation—the author argues that traditional kinetic-focused legal frameworks and state-centric deterrence models are inadequate to address non-physical, non-kinetic cyber aggressions such as electoral interference and corporate hacking. Drawing on Francisco de Vitoria’s concept of ius communicationis, the paper contends that the right to free communication constitutes a normative basis for proportionate sanctions against cyber attacks that disrupt democratic discourse, thus extending jus ad bellum beyond physical violence to rights-based violations in the public sphere. Vitoria’s early proposals for transparent, multi-stakeholder forums anticipate modern institutional calls for independent attribution bodies, addressing credibility gaps in deterrence by ensuring due process and mitigating false attribution risks. The study then turns to Hugo Grotius’s doctrine of bellum iustum privatum to justify private “hack-back” and active defense measures under strict proportionality and due process safeguards, arguing that private actors—when states are unable or unwilling to protect their own digital infrastructure—should be empowered to undertake limited reprisals to uphold rights and reinforce deterrent signals. By combining state-led sanctions and regulated private countermeasures, the proposed framework aims to bridge the legal and strategic vacuum in addressing non-physical cyber harms. The analysis critically evaluates existing instruments such as the Tallinn Manual 2.0 and the U.S. Active Cyber Defense Certainty Act, highlighting their failure to address non-physical public-sphere attacks and to legitimize private actor roles. Beyond legal doctrine, the paper introduces the concept of civilian-based deterrence, where a digitally literate and informed public contributes to resilience and deterrent credibility by recognizing, resisting, and publicizing malicious cyber operations, thus complementing state and corporate defenses. Through doctrinal, historical, and normative analysis, the author presents seven lines of argument supporting distributed deterrence: the post-territorial nature of cloud assets; the analogy to private anti-piracy actions; the necessity of distinguishing private from international conflict; the stabilizing role of multi-actor deterrence; the economic motivations of private entities; legislative developments on hack-back; and the individual right to resist as a check on digital power. Although primarily theoretical, this multidisciplinary policy architecture outlines practical pathways for empirical evaluation, including case studies on hack-back incidents, design principles for attribution bodies, and legislative strategies to codify private active defense rights. By synthesizing international legal theory with cyber policy, this work offers an operational roadmap for enhancing peace and security in the digital age through a holistic, multi-stakeholder deterrence system.

title: Jus contra bellum in cyberspace and the sound of silence
abstract: This article by Johann Ruben Leiss addresses the significant gap in interpretative clarity surrounding the application of jus contra bellum—the Charter-based prohibition on the use of force—and its customary equivalents in cyberspace. Although states and the UN Group of Governmental Experts (UN GGE) and Open-Ended Working Group (UN OEWG) processes broadly accept that the UN Charter applies in its entirety to cyber operations, they notably refrain from detailing how core concepts—such as ‘use of force,’ ‘armed attack,’ threshold of an armed attack triggering self-defence, and the line separating cybercrime from acts of war—should be understood in the digital domain. Leiss diagnoses this widespread interpretative silence as a deliberate strategy to preserve states’ strategic flexibility, rooted in a traditional ‘freedom of state’ paradigm that views ambiguity as beneficial amid evolving technical uncertainties. He contends, however, that under Articles 31–33 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, silence can amount to acquiescence, allowing objective factors—customary norms and general principles of international law—to fill interpretative gaps absent a clear subsequent agreement. The lack of a centralized interpretative authority exacerbates uncertainty: international courts, UN organs, and the International Law Commission have not definitively resolved how jus contra bellum rules apply to cyber operations, and the UN GGE and OEWG, while inclusive forums, lack binding legal authority to settle normative debates. Leiss surveys state practice and expert contributions up to 2021, noting that although a growing number of states publish cybersecurity strategies and statements on international law in cyberspace, many major powers remain silent or ambiguous in articulating precise legal positions. He warns that protracted silence risks crystallizing undesirable customary interpretations without broad consensus and increasing the potential for unintended escalation in cyber conflict. From a rule-of-law perspective, Leiss advocates for greater state engagement to clarify treaty-based norms, encourage publication of interpretative statements, and enhance transparency through global, regional, or bilateral initiatives. He highlights potential trajectories beyond the UN processes, anticipating norms development within like-minded coalitions or regional organizations, but cautions that fragmentation of the international legal discourse could undermine the universal character of the UN Charter. The article concludes by urging states to overcome interpretative reticence, proactively articulate how jus contra bellum applies in cyberspace, and thus guard against normative voids and the risks they pose to international peace and security.

title: 2022 russian invasion of Ukraine through the prism of international law: a critical overview
source: Paix Et Securite Internationales - Journal of International Law and International Relations
abstract: This article by Olena Nihreieva provides a critical international legal overview of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, examining a broad spectrum of issues that underscore the multidimensional character of modern armed conflict. Beginning with a concise chronology of background events, the paper situates the 2022 assault within a longer history of unresolved territorial disputes dating back to the 1990s. It then focuses on Russia’s violation of the prohibition on the threat and use of force under the UN Charter, highlighting how preparatory measures, public statements, and mobilization of military force against Ukraine contravened international law. A dedicated chapter addresses the status of cyberattacks as a form of use of force, analyzing specific incidents that targeted Ukraine’s critical infrastructure and arguing that certain cyber operations, when sufficiently severe and destructive, meet the threshold of an internationally wrongful use of force. The article dispels Russian claims of collective self-defense based on the recognition of the Donetsk People’s Republic and Luhansk People’s Republic, demonstrating the inconsistency of these justifications with established state recognition principles and the ICJ’s jurisprudence. It also tackles Russia’s arguments of genocide in eastern Ukraine, demonstrating through treaty interpretation and factual analysis that the criteria of genocidal intent are unfulfilled. The relevance of international humanitarian law (IHL) is explored, with a careful assessment of occupation law and the protection afforded to civilians under the Geneva Conventions. Nihreieva underscores the importance of applying IHL rules to cyber operations when they occur in the context of an armed conflict. In its final substantive section, the article surveys the prospects for accountability through both national prosecutions in Ukraine and international criminal mechanisms, including the International Criminal Court. She assesses challenges in attributing individual responsibility for war crimes, aggression, and cyber-enabled offenses, and reflects on institutional constraints, such as the absence of compulsory jurisdiction and Security Council vetoes, that hamper enforcement of international legal obligations. In concluding remarks, the paper emphasizes how the conflict in Ukraine reveals structural weaknesses in the existing international order and the peril of double standards in state practice. Nihreieva calls for the development of more coherent legal frameworks for cyber operations, more consistent recognition practices, and stronger enforcement mechanisms to uphold the peremptory norms of non-aggression. By systematizing these diverse legal issues, the article offers a holistic understanding of the legal implications of Russia’s hybrid warfare, including cyber components, and the broader challenges this poses to international law and global security.

title: EU common position on international law and cyberspace
authors: A Osula; A Kasper; A Kajander
source: Masaryk University Journal of Law and Technology
abstract: This article examines the European Union’s ambition to forge a unified position on the application of international law to state-sponsored cyber operations, situating the analysis within the broader scholarly and policy shift from questioning the applicability of existing legal norms in cyberspace to exploring their precise contours and implementation. Prompted by the EU’s renewed cybersecurity strategy and its stated goal of normative leadership, the authors—Osula, Kasper, and Kajander—undertake a systematic qualitative content analysis of publicly available national statements issued by EU Member States between 2019 and 2021. Drawing on sources including national policy papers, contributions to United Nations Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) reports, NATO doctrine, and other relevant documents, the study traces how Member States articulate core principles such as sovereignty, non-intervention, prohibition on the use of force, attribution standards, lawful countermeasures, and human rights obligations in the digital domain. The findings reveal broad consensus on the applicability of general international law to cyberspace, with all surveyed Member States affirming the relevance of sovereignty and human rights norms online. Yet significant divergences emerge concerning thresholds for identifying a use of force in cyberspace: some countries advocate high evidentiary standards and narrow definitions rooted in traditional kinetic frameworks, while others propose more flexible criteria to accommodate the hybrid nature of cyber operations. Similarly, views differ on the lawfulness of countermeasures, with debates centering on proportionality and attribution burdens, and on procedural versus substantive requirements for responding to malicious acts. The article contrasts these national positions with precedent-setting international fora, noting that EU Member States often build upon or refine consensus achieved in UN GGEs and NATO’s Allied Joint Doctrine for Cyberspace Operations, but also introduce novel interpretations to suit regional strategic interests. By mapping areas of convergence—such as unanimous support for non-intervention in cyberspace and adherence to human rights law—and highlighting fault lines in the interpretation of jus ad bellum and state responsibility, the study provides a diagnostic tool for EU policymakers. It identifies domains where an immediate common EU stance is feasible and those requiring further negotiation, thereby informing collective advocacy in venues like the UN Open-ended Working Group. The authors acknowledge limitations inherent in relying on publicly accessible documents, which may not reflect internal deliberations or evolving policy trajectories, and caution that rapid developments in the cyber threat landscape could soon outpace current analyses. They recommend future research to examine informal EU-level discussions, assess how emerging high-profile cyber incidents influence national legal stances, and explore mechanisms to reconcile interpretive disparities—ultimately supporting the EU’s aspiration to shape robust and coherent international cyber norms and bolster collective resilience.

title: The use of cyber attacks during traditional armed conflicts. Specific and the commitment of state responsibility
source: Journal of Law and Public Administration
abstract: This article by Vasile Coman examines the emergence and legal significance of cyber attacks within the context of traditional armed conflicts, highlighting the urgent need to adapt existing international law frameworks to the challenges posed by offensive cyber operations. Coman begins by situating cyber attacks alongside kinetic hostilities, arguing that the stealth, extended duration, and potentially non-physical but disruptive effects of such operations challenge classical thresholds for the use of force under the UN Charter. Drawing on case studies—most notably the Estonia attacks of 2007, the Russia–Georgia conflict of 2008, and ongoing operations in the Russia–Ukraine war—he demonstrates how cyber activities often blur the lines between espionage, terrorism, and acts of war. Through a doctrinal analysis grounded in international humanitarian law (IHL) and state practice, Coman proposes a four-step attribution process—identifying indicators of compromise, correlating activity patterns, precisely identifying actors, and ascertaining motivations—to underpin legitimate state responses and ensure accountability. He emphasizes that accurate attribution is the foundation for determining whether a cyber incident constitutes an armed attack, thereby triggering rights of self-defense. The article then addresses the principle of due diligence, positing that states bear an obligation to prevent harmful cyber operations emanating from their territories and that failure to discharge this duty engages state responsibility. In this light, victim states may lawfully adopt active cyber defenses—tailored, proportionate countermeasures in cyberspace—as a more precise and less escalatory alternative to kinetic retaliation. Coman underscores the necessity of balancing military necessity with jus in bello principles, articulating criteria for proportionality that account for non-physical damage and distinguishing between ongoing, imminent, and failed attacks. The discussion further explores the convergence of cyber warfare and cyber espionage, noting that intelligence‐gathering operations may precede or accompany hostile cyber activities, thus complicating the legal categorization of events. By integrating attribution standards, due diligence duties, and proportionality metrics into a coherent normative model, Coman contributes concrete legal guidelines intended to foster predictability and stability in state behavior. He acknowledges limitations in his doctrinal approach, particularly the scarcity of empirical data to quantify thresholds for “serious and direct” harm and the operational challenges of implementing early‐warning systems. To bridge these gaps, Coman calls for future research on treaty‐based due diligence mechanisms, case‐based evaluations of active defense measures in practice, and the development of quantifiable metrics for classifying cyber operations as armed attacks. Ultimately, this study advances a multidisciplinary perspective on cyber conflict law and proposes an actionable legal framework for attributing, preventing, and proportionately responding to cyber threats within traditional armed conflicts.

title: Seeing and connecting the dots: legal challenges to countering foreign cyberattacks launched from within U.S. domestic cyberspace
source: North Carolina Journal of Law & Technology
abstract: In “Seeing and Connecting the Dots: Legal Challenges to Countering Foreign Cyberattacks Launched from Within U.S. Domestic Cyberspace,” Lt. Col. Mark A. Visger examines the pressing legal impediments facing U.S. Cyber Command and other federal agencies when foreign adversaries exploit domestic networks to conduct espionage or destructive operations. Motivated by revelations such as the SolarWinds breach, where attackers routed malicious cybercommands through U.S.-based cloud infrastructure, the Article identifies a jurisdictional blind spot: U.S. Cyber Command lacks clear constitutional or statutory authority to observe, interdict, or counter cyberattacks occurring on American soil. Visger poses two central questions: what domestic Fourth Amendment, Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA), and executive power constraints inhibit defensive cyber operations, and how might Congress structure a coherent “cyber domestic authorities” statute to remedy this gap while safeguarding privacy and separation-of-powers principles? Using a doctrinal legal methodology, the Article dissects constitutional precedents, FISA’s probable-cause and foreign-power tests, and executive branch directives. It finds that the Fourth Amendment’s warrant requirements likely apply to nonconsensual network intrusions; FISA’s probable-cause standard and procedural burdens (including minimization and targeting rules) impede rapid response and risk politicization; and the President’s inherent authority to direct military operations domestically remains ambiguous, raising separation-of-powers concerns. Together, these constraints empower adversaries to “see all the dots” while U.S. defenders cannot. Visger then synthesizes design principles for a specialized statute: (1) a calibrated legal threshold for action, potentially higher than FISA’s probable cause to reflect the significant privacy interests at stake; (2) differentiated standards based on whether the adversary is a foreign power or an unaffiliated actor, with tailored nexus and proof requirements; (3) tiered approaches to accessing various categories of domestic cyberspace—distinguishing core infrastructure signaling functions from private cloud or personal networks; (4) provision for delayed notice to affected U.S. persons or entities to preserve operational security while ensuring transparency; (5) limited liability for government-caused network disruption only when the entity has followed industry best cybersecurity practices; and (6) clear allocation of operational responsibilities among Defense, Justice, and Homeland Security to leverage existing expertise and authorities. Visger acknowledges challenges, including attribution difficulties, multi-agency coordination complexities, and risks of privacy intrusion, but argues that a narrowly tailored statute can balance effective homeland defense with civil liberties. He concludes by outlining future research directions, such as refining evidentiary standards for attribution, evaluating technical implementation in live operational environments, and strengthening oversight mechanisms to ensure accountability. By addressing this domestic legal gray zone, Congress can close the gap adversaries exploit and empower U.S. defenders to detect and counter threats before they escalate.

title: Illegal: the SolarWinds hack under international law
authors: A Coco; T Dias; Tv Benthem
abstract: This article examines the SolarWinds supply-chain hack of late 2020 as a landmark cyber operation under applicable rules of international law, focusing on principles of sovereignty, non-intervention, general due diligence duties, the no-harm rule, and states’ human rights obligations. The authors adopt a doctrinal methodology based on state practice, United Nations Group of Governmental Experts norms, intergovernmental expert reports, U.N. General Assembly resolutions, International Law Commission Draft Articles on State Responsibility, human rights treaty jurisprudence, and secondary literature. They begin by contextualizing the operation, which exploited a vulnerability in the Orion network-monitoring software update mechanism to implant a backdoor and deploy further malware—most notably the SUNBURST backdoor—across public and private networks in at least eight states. They then consider the hack’s multi-layered harm, including risks to critical infrastructure such as energy, health, education, and operational technology, and its undermining of trust in IT supply chains. Turning to international legal norms, the authors assess first whether the hack violated the sovereignty and non-intervention rights of affected states, concluding that compromising a software update integral to multiple states’ cyber-infrastructure infringed their territorial integrity and political independence. They argue that the origin state failed to exercise due diligence to prevent or halt the operation and neglected to redress foreseeable harm, thereby breaching the no-harm principle and incurring international liability. Next, they analyze the hack under international human rights law, explaining that both negative and positive duties to respect and protect rights such as privacy, life, health, and education may have been violated. Personal and institutional data exfiltration likely amounted to arbitrary interference with privacy, while intrusions into hospital and university systems raised concerns about states’ positive obligations to safeguard healthcare and educational services. The paper addresses the challenge of attribution and extraterritorial jurisdiction, noting that states may acquire jurisdiction beyond their territory through physical, regulatory, or functional control over ICT infrastructure or victims, and that such jurisdiction triggers corresponding human rights duties. Concluding, the authors highlight the inadequacy of framing cyber espionage as a purely permissive activity when collateral harm to critical services and individuals is severe and unpredictable, affirm the applicability of extraterritorial jurisdictional principles, and propose that international norms must explicitly address IT supply-chain integrity. They advocate for a structured legal framework uniting sovereignty, non-intervention, no-harm, and due diligence obligations and call for future research on cyber-attribution techniques, binding supply-chain security protocols, and the enhancement of human rights protections in digital contexts. The study underscores the need for clear legal certainty in “grey” cyber operations and urges the international community to recognize supply-chain integrity as a matter of collective concern.

title: Revisiting due diligence in cyberspace: crafting international law's arsenal against transboundary Botnets
source: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF LAW AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
abstract: This article critically examines the imperative of adapting both international and domestic legal frameworks to address the evolving challenges posed by state-sponsored cyber operations and social media–enabled political movements. Grounded in the emblematic Stuxnet operation against Iran’s Natanz nuclear facility and the digital mobilization that fueled the Tunisian uprising during the Arab Spring, the author contends that traditional jus ad bellum and jus in bello principles, as well as established human rights norms, are ill-equipped to adjudicate actions that blur the boundaries between armed conflict, espionage, and political expression. Drawing on doctrinal analysis of United Nations instruments, U.S. statutory provisions such as the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012, and seminal case law including the International Court of Justice’s Nicaragua decision, the article identifies four principal gaps in current legal regimes: (1) the difficulty of attributing cyberattacks to specific state or non-state actors under existing “effective control” standards; (2) the absence of clear sovereignty thresholds in cyberspace given the nonphysical nature of digital incursions; (3) the inadequacy of narrowly defined treaty provisions to accommodate rapid technological advancement; and (4) the risk of normative fragmentation as states pursue unilateral regulatory measures such as national firewalls or social media blackouts. The analysis proceeds from insights generated during the Emory International Law Review’s February 2012 symposium, which convened legal scholars, military policymakers, human rights advocates, and technology experts to debate whether existing frameworks suffice or if a novel body of cyber-specific law is warranted. Integrating scholarly commentary with illustrative state practices—Pakistan’s Twitter blockade during domestic unrest and the United States’ post-Stuxnet policy statements—the author illustrates how doctrinal reinterpretation might recalibrate the notion of “violation of sovereignty” to encompass significant data intrusions and advocate for relaxed attribution criteria proportional to the latency and stealth of cyber weapons. Furthermore, the article proposes procedural innovations to enhance legal clarity and state accountability, including a formal post-incident investigation mechanism for neutral forensic inquiry and multilateral consensus-building processes to establish objective thresholds for digital use of force. While acknowledging the limited empirical grounding of early state practice and the theoretical nature of symposium discussions, the author emphasizes the urgency of empirical research on state behavior in cyber incidents, the formulation of technology-neutral legal principles, and the promotion of procedural norms that balance security imperatives with the protection of online rights. By situating cyber operations within the broader continuum of armed conflict and political expression, the article offers a holistic normative framework aimed at guiding the evolution of cyber law and policy in an era of accelerating technological change.

title: A chinese perspective on public cyber attribution
source: China Quarterly of International Strategic Studies
abstract: A Chinese Perspective on Public Cyber Attribution examines how public attribution of cyber incidents has transformed from a technical endeavor into a central tool of Sino-American geopolitical competition. The study first conceptualizes public attribution in Chinese terms by distinguishing su yuan (technical source tracing) from gui yin (political responsibility determination), then applies a qualitative, comparative approach to analyze divergences in attribution practices between China and the United States since 2013. Drawing on open-source policy documents, published reports by states and cybersecurity firms, media accounts, and academic analyses, the authors trace major attribution events including the Mandiant APT1 disclosure and subsequent US indictments of Chinese military officers. They find that the United States has progressively instrumentalized public attribution as a policy lever—leveraging government, private-sector, and media attributions to shape global perceptions, advance naming and shaming campaigns, and justify legal and diplomatic countermeasures. By contrast, China maintains a high evidentiary threshold for public accusations and generally abstains from reciprocal naming, citing concerns over politicization and procedural dislocation. The resulting asymmetry deepens strategic distrust, as Chinese policymakers view many non-governmental attributions as biased, commercially motivated, and occasionally unsound, while US actors perceive Beijing’s reticence as a lack of reciprocal accountability. The paper also highlights how media and private-sector attributions citing government sources can bind official policy responses to public narratives, constraining space for bilateral dialogue. To mitigate these dynamics, the authors propose four policy recommendations: (1) Both governments should reassess the strategic utility and unintended bilateral consequences of public attribution, prioritizing direct government-to-government communication over unilateral announcements. (2) When public attribution is necessary, it should adhere to mutually recognized evidentiary standards and allow a pre-publication cooling-off period for diplomatic consultation, thereby reducing politicization and strategic escalation. (3) Parties should work within the United Nations to establish a multilateral attribution regime—modeled on the IAEA—that would professionalize attribution processes, enhance legitimacy, and deter malicious state-sponsored cyber activity. (4) Regular high-level and track-two exchanges on attribution methodologies and legal frameworks could help bridge perceptional gaps and build shared norms. The study concludes by noting its reliance on publicly available sources and its focus on the China-US dyad, urging future research to expand comparative analysis to other great powers and empirically evaluate proposed multilateral regimes. Overall, the paper offers a novel conceptual framework integrating Chinese and Western attribution paradigms and practical pathways to reduce cyber tension through institutionalized cooperation.

title: Not illegal: the solarwinds incident and international law
abstract: This article examines the SolarWinds cyber-espionage incident of late 2020—a state-sponsored campaign attributed to Russia’s Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) that compromised the software update mechanism for SolarWinds Orion and infiltrated thousands of public- and private-sector networks worldwide—to assess whether existing international legal norms categorically prohibit such large-scale, non-destructive cyber operations. Deploying a doctrinal methodology grounded in treaty interpretation, customary international law analysis (state practice and opinio juris), and interpretive sources including the Tallinn Manual and UN Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) reports, the author analyzes three core dimensions of international law relevant to cyber operations: (1) the prohibition on the use of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter; (2) the prohibition on unlawful intervention in the internal affairs of another state; and (3) emerging norms governing state sovereignty, due diligence, and human rights obligations in cyberspace. The analysis finds that SolarWinds did not amount to a use of force because it caused no physical damage or sufficiently coercive effects; nor did it qualify as unlawful intervention since it involved espionage—which states long tolerate—and did not manipulate another government’s decision-making. Regarding sovereignty and due diligence, the article concludes that current international law lacks a clear rule classifying non-destructive cyber intrusions as sovereignty violations and that states incur due diligence obligations only in response to a separately established internationally wrongful act, a threshold SolarWinds does not meet. Moreover, cross-border human rights obligations are constrained by jurisdictional limits—territorial or personal control—which Russia did not exercise over affected foreign individuals. The article identifies significant gaps and tensions in the international legal framework, underscoring that while cyber espionage poses policy and security challenges, it remains largely unregulated at the level of customary or treaty law. The author argues for cautious statecraft that balances the flexibility states currently exploit with the prospect of new norms to address these lacunae. Finally, this article calls on scholars and states to document state practice in international fora, pursue empirical studies of incident responses, and engage in normative debates aimed at clarifying or expanding international law to more comprehensively govern state-level cyber operations.

title: Back to the roots: the laws of neutrality and the future of due diligence in cyberspace
authors: Y Sun; Jm Lemnitzer; J Lemnitzer
source: New York University Journal of International Law & Politics
abstract: This article interrogates the indeterminate status and scope of the due diligence rule in cyberspace and proposes that the classical laws of neutrality—where due diligence first emerged in international law—offer the optimal template for crafting a flexible yet reliable standard to manage escalation risk at the fringes of cyber conflict. The cyber domain is marked by the routine use of third-party networks to conceal offensive operations, yet states disagree sharply on whether due diligence in cyberspace is binding, voluntary, or even applicable. While most Latin American and EU states endorse a mandatory due diligence duty, key actors such as the United States and the United Kingdom refuse to affirm its legal status, and multilateral reports adopt nonbinding “should” language. This schism poses a tangible escalation risk: victim states may resort to unlawful robust responses when third states are slow or unwilling to act against attacks routed through their infrastructure. Through a systematic doctrinal and historical analysis, the article reconstructs how neutrality law developed due diligence duties balancing flexibility and reliability: neutral states were required to legislate relevant prohibitions, monitor arms transit and communications, maintain heightened vigilance during conflicts, and respond swiftly upon notification, all without requiring formal attribution of the original belligerent. Three landmark cases— the Alabama arbitration (origin of the due diligence norm, imposing obligations independent of domestic legislation and escalating duties commensurate with risk); the Corfu Channel judgment (affirming liability for failure to “knowingly” prevent harmful uses of territory and enabling victim states to claim compensation without attributing the attack); and interwar radio monitoring practice—illustrate how due diligence principles evolved in response to technological and political change. By mapping these precedents onto contemporary cyber debates, the author articulates a neutrality-inspired due diligence standard for cyberspace that includes proactive national legislation, establishment and international integration of CERT teams, capacity-building support for less developed states, proportionate network monitoring protocols, and export controls on private cybersecurity firms. These measures, supported by multistakeholder norm-building processes and adapted to emerging technical phenomena such as botnets, would transform nonbinding expectations into concrete, widely accepted obligations that protect civilians, deter misuse of transit networks, and defuse crises before escalation. The article acknowledges limitations— contested norm development at the UN, legal novelty in vulnerability disclosure, and aggregate botnet attacks—but calls for immediate groundwork in national and international practice. It concludes that revisiting the roots of the due diligence principle in neutrality law provides the best roadmap for safeguarding peace at the digital frontiers of conflict.

title: Plea of necessity: legal key to protection against unattributable cyber operations
source: Masaryk University Journal of Law and Technology
abstract: This article examines the legal role of the plea of necessity as a means by which States may lawfully defend themselves against hostile cyber operations when attribution to a specific State cannot be established. Spáčil begins by situating the dilemma that modern societies face: growing reliance on critical infrastructure that is vulnerable to cyberattacks and the difficulty of identifying and holding State perpetrators accountable under existing international law frameworks. He underscores that while conventional instruments of State response—retorsion, countermeasures, and self-defense—require proof of wrongful attribution, the plea of necessity under Article 25 of the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on State Responsibility (ARSIWA) can justify protective measures absent such proof. Through a doctrinal and qualitative analysis of ARSIWA, International Court of Justice jurisprudence, and scholarly commentaries, the article teases out the four core conditions for invoking necessity: (1) the act must be the only way to safeguard an essential interest against grave and imminent peril; (2) it must not seriously impair the essential interests of other States or the international community; (3) the right of necessity must not conflict with an obligation excluding invocation of necessity; and (4) the peril in question must be such that it cannot be averted by any other lawful means. Spáčil then analyzes how these conditions translate into the cyber context, identifying specific criteria for what constitutes an “essential interest” (notably critical infrastructure and public order) and thresholds for “grave and imminent peril” in cyberspace (for example, attacks that threaten large-scale disruption of utilities or public safety). He also maps the national positions of six States (the Netherlands, France, Germany, Japan, Norway, and Switzerland) whose cyber strategies explicitly recognize necessity as a response option, revealing a nascent consensus but also highlighting each State’s interpretive caveats aimed at preventing abuse. Comparative review of scholarly debates—such as Lahmann’s work on unilateral remedies and the Tallinn Manual analyses—underscores ongoing tensions in delineating necessity from self-defense and countermeasures. Although no State has yet formally invoked necessity in response to a cyber operation, Spáčil argues that the doctrinal clarity provided by his framework can guide future State practice and policymaking. He concludes by acknowledging limitations, including reliance on analogies from conventional contexts and absence of empirical case studies, and calls for further research to operationalize necessity in real-time decision-making, assess proportionality in cyber countermeasures, and develop multilateral transparency and oversight mechanisms.
