title: Private-sector attribution of cyber incidents: benefits and risks to the U.S. government
source: International Journal of Intelligence and CounterIntelligence
abstract: Romanosky and Boudreaux examine the evolving role of private‐sector firms in attributing malicious cyber incidents to state actors and the implications for U.S. government strategy, intelligence, and policy. Centering on CrowdStrike’s high‐profile attribution of the 2016 Democratic National Committee breach to Kremlin‐linked groups, the authors analyze four core questions: why attribution matters to both private entities and the U.S. government (USG); the risks and benefits private‐sector attributions pose to USG agencies; comparative analytic capabilities of private firms and governmental bodies; and prospects for future public–private collaboration. Drawing on qualitative thematic analysis of public attribution reports (CrowdStrike blog posts, DHS/FBI “GRIZZLYSTEPPE,” and U.S. Intelligence Community statements) and expert interviews, the study reveals that private firms pursue attribution to warn potential victims and bolster market reputation, while the USG must balance domestic cybersecurity, intelligence secrecy, diplomatic signaling, and deterrence when issuing public statements. The authors highlight that robust commercial forensics can both complement and compete with governmental efforts: private attributions may precede official USG pronouncements, shaping political pressures and credibility debates; conversely, the USG retains exclusive access to classified intelligence but risks ceding primacy in attribution if it fails to leverage private capabilities. The paper describes several dynamics: first, the strategic motivations and reputational incentives driving private attributors; second, the USG’s diplomatic and policy constraints in public attribution; third, the comparative strengths of private‐sector network forensics versus classified analytical assets; and fourth, the emerging trust‐based mechanisms for sharing indicators and analyses between firms like CrowdStrike and agencies such as the FBI. The authors propose a conceptual framework for understanding how private attributions influence USG decision‐making, recommending institutionalized channels for evidence sharing, standard analytic methodologies to bolster confidence, and coordinated public messaging to reinforce deterrence and international cyber norms. Acknowledging limitations—including reliance on publicly available sources, U.S.‐centric focus, and absence of quantitative attribution metrics—the authors call for comparative cross‐national studies, empirical measurement of attribution accuracy, and policy experimentation to refine collaborative models. Their work underscores the importance of integrating private‐sector intelligence into government cyber policy to enhance attribution credibility, support robust deterrence, and advance legal and normative regimes in cyber conflict.

title: Decoding china's perspectives on cyber warfare
abstract: This article examines the evolution of China’s perspectives on regulating state conduct in cyberspace amid intensifying geopolitical competition and rapid technological change, focusing on the applicability of the jus ad bellum and jus in bello frameworks to cyber operations. China’s normative stance has significant implications for international law and the global cyber governance order, as Beijing, once a passive participant in multilateral discussions, has shifted to a proactive norm-entrepreneur role. The study begins by tracing the early development of cyber law debates at the United Nations, where China initially adopted a “wait and see” approach, deferring to Russia and maintaining a low profile through technical ministry representatives. Drawing on qualitative, doctrinal analysis of Chinese government speeches, United Nations documents, the International Code of Conduct for Information Security (ICCIS) submissions of 2011 and 2015, World Internet Conference declarations, and successive UN Group of Government Experts (GGE) reports, the author explicates China’s transition from passive alignment with the Russia-China Camp to active agenda-setting in international cyber governance. Core findings reveal two distinct objectives underpinning China’s resistance to explicitly affirming specific laws of armed conflict in cyberspace: (1) protecting domestic regulatory prerogatives from being bound by emerging or existing norms deemed unfavorable, and (2) building consensus for a United Nations treaty governing the use of cyber force. Triggered by high-profile US actions—including Hillary Clinton’s 2010–2012 “freedom in cyberspace” speeches, US strategies advocating for principles of responsible state behavior, and critiques of China’s domestic censorship—China elevated cyber governance to a diplomatic priority. Beijing’s proactive diplomacy involved shifting from technical to foreign affairs leadership and leveraging egalitarian forums such as the United Nations General Assembly to propose the ICCIS, which advocates for state sovereignty in cyberspace, non-use of information and communications technologies for hostile purposes, and adherence to UN norms. Despite accepting the general applicability of jus ad bellum, jus in bello, and state responsibility to cyberspace, China resists explicit affirmation of rules such as anticipatory self-defense and targetability criteria for dual-use infrastructure to preserve strategic flexibility. The article develops a nuanced conceptual framework, describing how China “embeds a firewall” in democratic multilateral negotiations to thwart the transplantation of established-power norms and to enable elastic treaty drafting accommodating domestic policy preferences. While recognizing limitations—chiefly reliance on publicly available normative statements rather than internal diplomatic communications or operational military practice—the study contributes the first comprehensive mapping of China’s normative evolution from concurrence to agenda leadership. It also identifies future research avenues: assessing impacts of China’s treaty proposals on state behavior, exploring interplay between emerging cyber norms and technological attribution advances, and examining norm diffusion among similarly positioned states in other multilateral contexts.

title: Reflections on information influence operations as illegal intervention
abstract:
In the article “Reflections on Information Influence Operations as Illegal Intervention,” Sharngan Aravindakshan examines the applicability of the international law prohibition on intervention to contemporary foreign information influence operations conducted in cyberspace. Spurred by high-profile cases such as Russia’s interference in the 2016 U.S. elections and alleged disinformation campaigns during the COVID-19 pandemic, the author observes a growing scholarly trend to treat state-sponsored online disinformation as a violation of the United Nations Charter’s non-intervention norm. Through a detailed analysis, the article identifies three principal obstacles to such an approach: the traditional coercion requirement in intervention law, the lack of consensus among states regarding definitions of information operations, and the technical and legal challenges of attribution in cyber contexts.

Part I of the article outlines the doctrine of non-intervention, rooted in customary international law and the U.N. Charter, emphasizing the requirement that an intervention must involve coercion in the target state’s internal affairs. It reviews academic proposals that argue for a broad interpretation of coercion to include cognitive effects—namely, the manipulation of public opinion via social media and other digital platforms. The author surveys positions advocating both holistic assessments of entire information campaigns and analyses of discrete actions, such as doxing or hacking and leaking political party communications, each tested against the non-intervention prohibition.

In Part II, Aravindakshan critically assesses these scholarly approaches, highlighting their overreliance on deception and concealment as proxies for coercion. The author argues that deception alone does not necessarily impair a population’s capacity to verify information or exercise free will. She also notes that states have, to date, offered only vague denunciations of disinformation as contraventions of “established international norms,” without invoking binding legal prohibitions or clarifying the scope of intervention law. Further, the article underscores the persistent difficulty of attributing digital influence operations to state actors in a manner satisfying international law’s stringent standards, a problem compounded by the need for cooperation from private social media platforms.

Part III places the debate within the broader evolution of sovereignty in cyberspace. While some scholars propose that emerging interpretations of territorial sovereignty might encompass cognitive domains, Aravindakshan cautions that most states remain reluctant to construe non-kinetic operations as per se illegal interventions. She proposes a refined ‘‘deception test’’ for coercion: prohibited intervention should be limited to cases where a state impersonates trusted or authoritative accounts—such as government or official figures—thus leveraging existing audience trust and limiting the target population’s opportunity to distinguish authentic sources.

In conclusion, the article contends that although tolerance for state-sponsored information influence operations is waning, significant doctrinal and political hurdles must be overcome before the non-intervention norm can regulate disinformation. A narrower deception test focused on the hijacking of trusted sources could strike a balance between safeguarding the right to online anonymity and effectively addressing truly coercive state information operations. The piece calls for further research into the linkage between coercion as defined under international law and the cognitive impacts these campaigns exert on targeted populations, while recognizing that states have yet to form a definitive consensus on the illegality of information influence operations.

title: Autonomous cyber capabilities under international law
abstract: This article examines the constitutional and statutory frameworks governing the use of cyber weapons by the United States and proposes a comprehensive legislative blueprint to enhance democratic oversight, delineate executive and congressional responsibilities, and mitigate the risk of inadvertent escalation in future cyber conflicts. It opens with an analysis of classic Supreme Court decisions—Bas v. Tingy, Little v. Barreme, and Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co.—that define Congress’s exclusive authority to initiate hostilities, the President’s tactical command once hostilities are underway, and the requirement that executive action remain within congressional authorization. The authors trace the evolution of congressional war-powers legislation, from the early republic’s statutes to the Vietnam-era War Powers Resolution, highlighting persistent ambiguities about the President’s unilateral authority to employ military force short of formal war and the challenges posed by cyber operations that may be rapid, opaque, and globally distributed. Through doctrinal and historical methodology, including case-law review, analysis of the War Powers Resolution and the Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative, executive directives, and correspondence between congressional committees and the Director of National Intelligence, the article identifies gaps in the current governance regime. Key findings reveal that the executive branch’s predominant role in cyber preparedness, combined with congressional under-engagement, has led to secrecy, turf battles, and blurred lines of authority that increase the likelihood of misperception, legal overreach, and uncontrolled escalation. To address these deficits, the authors articulate seventeen detailed recommendations: (1) requiring presidential written findings, in advance if practicable or within 48 hours post-operation, to justify significant cyber operations; (2) mandating immediate reporting of any significant offensive or defensive cyber use to designated congressional committees; (3) prohibiting classification or secrecy from withholding critical information; (4) delivering reports to full committees rather than select members; (5) banning automated offensive cyber responses in favor of human-directed decisions; (6) creating interagency structures to coordinate private-sector assistance and prevent risky commercial counterattacks; (7) reviewing and amending privacy and surveillance statutes to balance civil liberties with security needs; (8) appointing privacy and civil-liberties officers within the National Security Council’s cybersecurity directorate; (9) promoting public disclosure of cyber-warfare policies to enhance deterrence and public debate; and (10) forbidding outsourcing of cyber-weapon operations to private contractors, ensuring accountability by trained government personnel. The article acknowledges challenges in defining “significant use” and anticipating classified program contours, warns of potential enforcement difficulties, executive resistance, and judicial review, and calls for further research on interbranch consultation mechanisms and comparative legislative models among allies. By situating cyber conflict governance within the broader constitutional war-powers discourse and offering concrete legislative prescriptions, the study contributes a multidisciplinary perspective on bridging cyber policy, international law, and constitutional authority in the digital age.

title: Responding to proxy cyber operations under international law
abstract:
Responding to Proxy Cyber Operations Under International Law, authored by Lieutenant Colonel Durward E. Johnson and Professor Michael N. Schmitt, addresses the complex challenge of victim states lawfully responding to cyber operations conducted by non-state actors acting as proxies for near-peer adversaries within the grey zone of cyberspace. Motivated by strategic competition between the United States, its allies, and rival states such as Russia and China—and informed by historical events like Estonia’s 2007 denial-of-service attacks—the article examines how state responsibility principles and international legal thresholds apply to proxy cyber operations. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the authors analyze pertinent provisions of the United Nations Charter (particularly Articles 2(4) and 51), the International Law Commission’s Articles on the Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts, and the rules articulated in the Tallinn Manual 2.0. They integrate these sources with state practice, including U.S. sanctions regimes, allied doctrinal publications, and national positions from France, Finland, Germany, the Netherlands, Australia, and NATO, to elucidate the criteria that determine whether a proxy operation warrants countermeasures, invocation of self-defense, or other lawful state responses without breaching jus ad bellum or inadvertently triggering an armed conflict.

The authors develop a structured, tiered framework for assessing proxy use in cyberspace. At one end of the spectrum, tacit approval or failure to prevent non-state actors’ operations—exemplified by murky Russian involvement in Estonia’s 2007 incident—may suffice for attributing state responsibility under Articles on State Responsibility, Article 8, and enable countermeasures such as diplomatic protests, economic sanctions, or other non-coercive measures (retorsion). At the other end, where a state exercises direct direction or control over a proxy group—meeting the effective control test from Nicaragua v. United States—an operation may be attributable as a state act and thus trigger the right of self-defense under Article 51, provided that necessity and proportionality are satisfied. The article explores the grey-zone ambiguity arising when state involvement is intermediate, emphasizing the need for clear standards of attribution and due diligence obligations to discourage tacit complicity. It discusses how emerging doctrines of collective countermeasures may offer additional options for allied coalitions.

In their findings, Johnson and Schmitt demonstrate that precise distinctions between levels of state involvement directly inform permissible response measures, and that evolving state practice—including the U.S. imposition of sanctions against Russian Federation entities and cybercriminal intermediaries—reflects growing acceptance of cyber countermeasures as lawful responses to proxy operations. They acknowledge limitations stemming from the case-specific nature of proxy relationships, divergent national positions, and the persistent lack of universally accepted attribution standards. Looking forward, the authors recommend documenting further state declarations on the law of cyberspace, refining attribution criteria in the face of technological advances like anonymizing services and artificial intelligence, and exploring the feasibility and legal implications of collective cyber countermeasures under international law. This work fills a critical gap in guidance on applying state responsibility principles to proxy cyber operations and offers a practical framework to assist policymakers, military planners, and legal advisors in navigating the legal contours of cyber conflict in the grey zone.

title: Attribution: A major challenge for EU cyber sanctions. An analysis of WannaCry, NotPetya, Cloud Hopper, Bundestag Hack and the attack on the OPCW
abstract: This article offers a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the existing international legal framework governing state conduct in cyberspace, specifically assessing the applicability of the United Nations Charter and the non-binding Tallinn Manual to cyber-warfare and proposing a path toward a binding treaty. Epstein begins by surveying divergent conceptions of cyber-warfare—definitions based variously on the nature of the targeted object, the medium employed, and the syntactic, semantic, or hybrid characteristics of the attacks—and illustrates each category with hypothetical scenarios ranging from denial-of-service operations to semantic manipulation of critical information systems. He then turns to the core provisions of the UN Charter—Article 2(4)’s prohibition on the threat or use of force, Article 51’s right of self-defense, and Articles 41 and 42’s complementary measures—and demonstrates how these rules, crafted for kinetic conflict, struggle to accommodate cyber operations. Epstein examines the interpretive guidance of the Tallinn Manual’s rules on use of force, threat of force, necessity, proportionality, immediacy, collective self-defense, and permissible countermeasures, identifying four principal deficiencies: the misfit of traditional “use of force” and “armed attack” definitions in cyber contexts; the Manual’s unquantified scale-and-effects test; attribution and intent challenges; and the normative ambiguity created by reliance on a non-binding instrument. To remedy these gaps, Epstein advocates convening a U.S.-led international conference to negotiate a binding cyber-warfare treaty that builds upon the substance of the Tallinn Manual while introducing: a sliding-scale and effects test with quantifiable thresholds; explicit consideration of state intent; mandatory multilateral consultations before defensive or counter-cyber actions; illustrative examples to guide interpretation; and a universal obligation, analogous to Article 2(6) of the UN Charter, to ensure compliance by non-signatories to preserve international peace and security. Acknowledging procedural and political hurdles—such as achieving consensus among diverse state actors and keeping pace with rapidly evolving cyber threats—Epstein argues that without a binding instrument, states will continue to grapple with unacceptable legal uncertainty. The article concludes by urging U.S. leadership in treaty negotiations to establish a clear, adaptable, and legally precise regime that balances the flexibility needed to address emergent cyber threats with sufficient precision to deter unlawful cyber-attacks and sustain global stability.

title: Connected, continual conflict: towards a cybernetic model of warfare
source: European Conference on Cyber Warfare and Security
abstract: This paper contends that framing cyber warfare as simply an extension of electronic or information warfare fundamentally mischaracterizes its systemic nature, arguing instead for a cybernetic model of conflict that transcends traditional domain boundaries. Scott critiques prevailing definitions of cyber warfare—ranging from narrow conceptualizations centered on interstate IT-based attacks to broader notions encompassing both kinetic and non-kinetic actions—demonstrating that these perspectives overlook the interconnected dynamics that define contemporary conflict. Drawing on interdisciplinary insights from cybernetics, military theory, and information warfare, and informed by theoretical contributions from Marshall McLuhan, Norbert Wiener, and Qiao and Wang, the study posits that cyber warfare is inherently cybernetic: a form of contestation operating across all domains in which actions in one sphere reverberate through others, dissolving distinctions between war and peace, civilian and military, human and non-human actors, as well as kinetic and non-kinetic effects. Through conceptual analysis and case illustrations—from Stuxnet to drone swarms and hybrid force deployments—the paper identifies three core characteristics of cybernetic warfare: uncertainty driven by attribution challenges and deception; unboundedness that erases traditional barriers between private and public sectors, and between strategic, operational, and tactical levels; and unrestricted simultaneity enabled by autonomous systems and networked interactions. Scott synthesizes historical precedents and contemporary scenarios to show how existing military structures, firmly rooted in discrete service and functional silos, are ill-suited to this emerging reality. He contrasts network-centric and chaoplexic conceptions of conflict, advocating for a holistic ‘‘Gestalt’’ perspective that privileges system interdependencies over isolated nodes. The proposed cybernetic framework highlights the need for integrated operating concepts—such as the UK military’s Multi-Domain Integration—to foster flexible, systems-based strategic, deterrent, and doctrinal approaches. Recognizing the model’s current theoretical emphasis, the author calls for empirical validation through wargaming, simulations, and case-study analysis, and encourages further exploration of human–machine teaming, autonomous agent integration, and the legal and normative dimensions of state responsibility in cybernetic conflict. This multidisciplinary approach offers a robust theoretical foundation for understanding and responding to the protean challenges of twenty-first-century warfare, urging military and policy communities to embrace systems thinking and break down rigid silos if they are to effectively navigate the continual, connected nature of cybernetic conflict.

title: Mapping a Path to Cyber Attribution Consensus
abstract: This article by H. Merriman provides a comprehensive examination of state responsibility and accountability for cyber warfare under contemporary international law. It opens by defining the core characteristics of cyber warfare and the challenges it poses to established legal frameworks, including the blurred boundary between state and non-state actors, difficulties in reliable attribution, and the uncertain threshold at which malicious cyber operations amount to an armed attack under the UN Charter and Geneva Conventions. Drawing on the International Law Commission’s Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (ARSIWA), Merriman evaluates key legal principles—sovereignty, due diligence, and countermeasures—and interrogates their applicability through detailed case studies of the 2012 Shamoon attack on Saudi Aramco, the 2014 Sony Pictures hack, Russian cyber campaigns against Ukraine, and proxy operations linked to the Hamas–Israel conflict. Methodologically, the study melds doctrinal legal analysis with qualitative review of United Nations instruments and public incident reports, thereby illuminating how states interpret and apply norms in practice. The research uncovers significant accountability gaps: ambiguity in classifying cyberattacks as armed conflicts under existing humanitarian law; divergent state practices in implementing due diligence obligations, with many lacking pre-emptive cybersecurity measures; and the anonymity afforded by advanced cyber tools that facilitates plausible deniability and undermines attribution efforts. Moreover, states’ responses remain reactive and heavily influenced by geopolitical considerations, revealing a dearth of coherent strategies for legal countermeasures in cyberspace. To address these shortcomings, Merriman proposes a multi-layered accountability framework. At its core is a strengthened due diligence obligation mandating states to adopt and share minimum cybersecurity standards and to conduct risk assessments for sensitive infrastructure. The framework advocates standardized criteria for determining when cyber operations meet the threshold of armed attack, alongside institutional mechanisms for third-party technical verification to bolster attribution and enforcement. Furthermore, it calls for diplomatic norms of restraint, confidence-building measures, and information-sharing protocols to foster mutual trust, complemented by legal countermeasures such as targeted sanctions and regulated reciprocal cyber operations governed by treaty. Recognizing the limitations posed by rapidly evolving cyber capabilities, reliance on open-source data, and potential state resistance to new constraints, the author contends that a synergy of legal innovation, technological collaboration, and normative diplomacy can close accountability gaps. The article concludes with recommendations for empirical research on state implementation of due diligence measures, the development of internationally endorsed technical attribution standards, and comparative analyses of regional cyber conflict laws, with particular attention to emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and machine-learning-enabled operations. By articulating a cohesive accountability regime, this research aims to advance a principled international order in cyberspace and strengthen the rule of law amidst the evolving landscape of digital conflict.

title: I. The slow and imprecise art of cyber warfare
abstract: In “The Slow and Imprecise Art of Cyber Warfare,” Bronk and Watling critically examine the gap between popular narratives of cyber operations as rapid, scalable and decisive, and the complex, drawn-out reality of modern state-sponsored cyber campaigns. After surveying doctrinal sources, expert interviews and high-profile cases—ranging from Russia’s cyber pressure on Ukraine and North Korean state-linked hacking groups to Israel’s 2007 operation against the Syrian air defence network and hybrid operations in Nagorno-Karabakh—the authors map the multi-phase anatomy of a cyber attack. They deconstruct its lifecycle into reconnaissance, infiltration, malware deployment and execution, highlighting how the intangible virtual dimension—encoded in proprietary programming and markup languages—demands extensive time, bureaucratic coordination and cross-domain intelligence to yield reliable outcomes. By contrasting cyber offensives with electronic warfare capabilities, they reveal the narrowing technical boundary between the two, as cyber-derived system intelligence informs tailored electromagnetic attacks. The chapter assesses the strategic utility of cyber tools, arguing that while disruptive strikes on critical national infrastructure can inflict political costs, they seldom deter a resolved state adversary or replace hard power. Instead, offensive cyber assets are best viewed as force multipliers when integrated into joint operations: pre-emplaced payloads can ‘open the door’ for conventional strikes by blinding adversary sensors or degrading battle networks at critical junctures. Yet such integration requires high-level authorisations, multi-agency intelligence and precise timing before vulnerabilities are patched. Drawing on Russia’s persistent cyber campaigns against Ukrainian military and civilian systems, the authors illustrate a more plausible future of cyber warfare as a component of hybrid coercion—simultaneously shaping the human and technical terrain around kinetic force posturing, but rarely achieving strategic effect in isolation. Ultimately, Bronk and Watling call for military planners and policymakers to temper inflated expectations, invest in holistic cyber-conventional joint doctrines and refine the legal and normative frameworks governing offensive operations. They highlight the urgent need for empirical research into cyber-electronic convergence and its implications for escalation management, deterrence credibility and multi-domain operations in an era of intensified great-power competition.

title: United states joins with allies, including nato, to attribute malicious cyber activities to China
abstract: This article examines the Biden administration’s evolving strategy for confronting state-sponsored malicious cyber activities through coordinated international attribution and normative frameworks, with a focus on recent actions taken against China. Against a backdrop of persistent Chinese intrusions targeting critical infrastructure and private-sector entities—including the high-profile Microsoft Exchange hack—this study analyzes how the United States secured allied consensus on public attribution, sanctions, and incident response, thereby operationalizing a collective deterrence model in cyberspace. Beginning with a review of prior U.S.-China cyber agreements—from the 2015 Obama–Xi deal prohibiting commercial cyber-enabled theft of intellectual property, through successive Department of Justice indictments of Chinese military hackers— the article highlights the limitations of bilateral measures and the imperative for multilateral approaches. It then chronicles successive diplomatic initiatives in summer 2021: U.S. engagements with NATO, the G7, the EU, and the UK, culminating in the July 19 joint attribution of the Microsoft Exchange compromise to Chinese state-affiliated actors. Drawing on official summit communiqués, press releases, and public indictments, the paper details how the United States leveraged these forums to secure the NATO Comprehensive Cyber Defence Policy, the G7’s commitments on ransomware, the New Atlantic Charter’s reaffirmation of responsible state behavior, and the U.S.–EU ransomware working group—all of which reinforced existing international legal norms such as State Responsibility and the applicability of jus ad bellum to cyberspace. The article further describes the establishment of a Unified Coordination Group—an innovative incident response mechanism integrating government and private-sector actors—and the articulation of “off-limits” critical infrastructure sectors. Attention then turns to the mixed efficacy of these measures amid contemporaneous ransomware crises: the Colonial Pipeline shutdown, the JBS attack, and the Kaseya incident, all attributed to Russia-based groups. The discussion contrasts U.S. sanctions and indictments—criticized by analysts as insufficiently punitive—with proposed policy enhancements, such as sector-based immunities and expanded norm-building at the United Nations. A section on responses from target states includes China’s formal denials and accusations of U.S. cyber aggression, underscoring the contested nature of attribution and the risk of cyber arms races. The article concludes by assessing the promise and challenges of alliance-based cyber policy: while collective attribution and sanctions regimes may recalibrate adversary cost–benefit calculations, empirical assessment of deterrence effects remains nascent, enforcement gaps persist when malicious actors operate within permissive jurisdictions, and alliance cohesion may be tested by divergent strategic interests. The author calls for systematic evaluation of multilateral attribution’s impact on the frequency and scale of cyberattacks, development of metrics for cyber deterrence, and exploration of complementary technical and legal measures—such as enhanced critical infrastructure protection and expanded U.N. norm frameworks—to bolster the strategic objectives of allied cyber policy.

title: Factors That Motivate State-Sponsored Cyberattacks
authors: L Hunter; Craig Douglas Albert; Eric Garrett
abstract: The initiation of state-sponsored cyberattacks represents an emerging frontier in geopolitical competition that challenges traditional understandings of interstate conflict and necessitates rigorous empirical investigation. While the drivers of kinetic military conflicts have been extensively studied within international relations, the factors precipitating cyberconflicts remain underexplored, largely due to data scarcity. This study addresses that gap by posing the question of which political, economic, and military variables make a state more likely to initiate a cyberattack against another state between 2005 and 2012. Anchored in the broader context of cyberpower as an extension of hard power projection and framed by debates over the offense–defense balance, attribution challenges, and the erosion of deterrence in cyberspace, the research aims to elucidate the conditions under which states employ offensive cyber capabilities. Methodologically, the project adopts a quantitative, cross‐national approach, constructing a unique dataset that merges author-compiled indicators of state political regime type, military expenditures, economic strength, trade openness, and governance quality for 143 states with incident-level data on state-sponsored cyber operations drawn from the Council on Foreign Relations Cyber Operations Tracker Dataset. The analysis proceeds in two stages: first, a multivariate statistical examination tests hypotheses derived from conventional conflict theory—such as the influence of relative power, regime type, and dyadic relationships—on both the likelihood and frequency of cyberattack initiation; second, a complementary descriptive comparison contrasts the attributes of cyberattacking versus cybervictim states over an extended period (2005–2016) to contextualize the statistical findings. The results reveal that states with greater military and economic capabilities exhibit higher propensities to conduct cyberattacks, though the offense–defense balance and the difficulty of attribution moderate this relationship, enabling both lesser powers to engage in aggressive cyber operations and powerful states to calibrate their use of cyber tools. Regime type shows a nuanced effect, with more authoritarian regimes demonstrating a slightly elevated tendency to launch cyber operations, potentially reflecting both greater capacity for secrecy and lower constraints from domestic oversight. The descriptive analysis further underscores distinct profiles of attacker and victim states in terms of trade interdependence and alliance commitments. By integrating traditional conflict variables into the cyber domain and leveraging a novel longitudinal dataset, this research advances empirical understanding of state behavior in cyberspace and offers a replicable framework for assessing cyber conflict risk. Limitations include the reliance on publicly documented incidents, which may undercount covert operations, and the temporal constraints of data availability through 2012 for statistical tests. Future research should extend the dataset to include more recent years, refine measures of cyber capability and attribution certainty, and explore case-study analyses to unpack causal mechanisms behind quantitative correlations.

title: Cyber Deterrence: The Past, Present, and Future
authors: Stefan Soesanto; M Smeets; Frans Osinga; Tim Sweijs
source: NL ARMS Netherlands Annual Review of Military Studies 2020: Deterrence in the 21st Century—Insights from Theory and Practice
abstract: The evolution and feasibility of cyber deterrence occupies a central role in contemporary discussions of statecraft and conflict in cyberspace. The authors identify a critical problem in that, despite cyber deterrence serving as a foundational concept for political and policy debates over nearly three decades, there remains little consensus on practical approaches or unified academic frameworks. This chapter aims to situate the current cyber deterrence debate within its historical trajectory, clarify existing conceptualizations, and assess whether cyber deterrence retains analytical validity. Its objectives include reconstructing how deterrence thinking migrated from early phreaker skirmishes and broad information warfare doctrines to present definitions that encompass six distinct deterrence mechanisms, and evaluating avenues for future theoretical development. Employing a conceptual historical methodology, the authors review archival accounts of 1970s–90s hacker ‘wars’, early US Department of Defense information warfare experiments, and seminal scholarship on netwar and information-based deterrence, before synthesizing contemporary cyber operations scholarship. Their analysis yields three main findings: first, that cyber deterrence has undergone waves—from defensive hardening through purely offensive concepts to notions of resilience and cross-domain integration—yet has produced few operationally validated strategies; second, that current literature fragments into divergent schools disputing fundamental elements of deterrence theory in the cyber domain; and third, that emerging practice, such as U.S. Cyber Command’s ‘‘persistent engagement’’ strategies, indicates a shift toward continuous competition rather than classic deterrence. The contribution of this work lies in mapping the past, present, and prospective future of cyber deterrence, offering four strategic directions: integrating cyber deterrence within multi-domain security contests; deepening technical understanding at operational and tactical levels; refocusing on compellence as an alternative coercion model; and formulating novel strategic constructs to contain adversarial aggression beyond orthodox deterrence. Key limitations include the reliance on conceptual rather than empirical validation and the Western-centric perspective inherited from available case studies. To address these constraints, the authors propose future research that tests proposed mechanisms against empirical cyber incident data, examines non-Western approaches to deterrence, and explores how new strategic paradigms could be operationalized, thereby strengthening the theoretical foundations and practical applicability of cyber deterrence frameworks.

title: Virtually defenseless: america's struggle to defend itself in cyberspace and what can Be done about it
abstract:
This article critically examines the evolution, limitations, and future trajectory of United States defensive cyber policy over the past quarter century. Drawing on presidential directives, department-level assessments, and documented case studies, the author traces the history of US cyber defense from early alarm bells, such as the ‘‘cyber Pearl Harbor’’ warnings of the late 1990s, through a succession of high‐profile directorate initiatives and threat assessments that have repeatedly forecast catastrophic attacks. Despite sustained private‐sector investment in technical hardening measures and bold rhetoric from senior officials, US policy has persistently focused on low‐probability, high‐impact scenarios at the expense of countering the more diffuse, cumulative campaigns that adversaries like Russia, China, Iran, and aligned non‐state proxies regularly conduct below the threshold of armed conflict. 

The study diagnoses three central shortcomings: a flawed emphasis on reactive incident response rather than proactive defense; an overreliance on sanctions, diplomatic rebukes, and indictments with negligible deterrent effect; and a failure to integrate defensive cyber effects—including hunt‐forward operations and calibrated counter‐influence measures—into a coherent political warfare strategy. As adversary cyber capabilities matured in espionage, influence operations, and network disruption, US policy continued to treat each intrusion as an isolated technical incident rather than as part of orchestrated campaigns aimed at undermining democratic institutions, critical infrastructure, and economic stability. Consequently, American responses have been piecemeal and episodic, lacking the unity of effort across government, private sector, and allied partners required to impose costs and halt adversary campaigns. 

To remedy these gaps, the author proposes a strategic framework for embedding cyber defense within a broader post‐9/11 US grand strategy. Key recommendations include adopting a ‘‘persistent engagement’’ doctrine that processes adversary activity as a continuous contest; expanding hunt‐forward operations to eject adversaries proactively from critical networks; developing scalable defensive cyber effects that disrupt malicious campaigns closer to their source; and coordinating interagency and allied responses to counter disinformation and protect democratic processes. The article argues that cyber policy must transition from crisis‐driven, worst‐case planning to a dynamic model of competition and deterrence, underpinned by measurable metrics and aligned with political warfare objectives. While acknowledging the limitations of qualitative, publicly available data, this study lays the groundwork for future research on quantitative measures of cyber deterrence, the operational effectiveness of defensive cyber effects, and policy mechanisms to strengthen democratic resilience against influence operations. In sum, the article articulates a comprehensive vision for a resilient US cyber defense posture, integral to broader national security and foreign policy aims in an era of persistent digital conflict.

title: The Prohibition of the Threat or Use of Force in Cyberspace: Novel Legal Frontier or Adaptation of Old Frameworks?
source: Military Law and the Law of War Review (MLLWR)
abstract: This paper examines how pre-existing beliefs among foreign policy elites shape their attribution of responsibility for harmful state-sponsored cyber operations and explores the cognitive processes that may distort rational assessments in cyberspace. Focusing on two phenomena—‘seizing’ and ‘freezing’—the author investigates how decision-makers’ adversarial images influence both initial and updated judgements in response to a hypothetical degradative cyber incident that disrupts national elections. Seizing describes the inclination to latch onto ambiguous or minimal evidence that confirms existing biases, while freezing denotes the reluctance to revise initial attributions even when confronted with disconfirming information. To test these mechanisms, the study employs an online, between-groups survey experiment in which participants, primed to assume foreign policy authority, read a vignette involving a cyber‐enabled disruption in the fictitious state of Idimore. The treatment group receives contextual information about a rival state’s hostile past cyber behavior, whereas the control group encounters no historical context. Participants report their confidence in attributing blame to the rival and justify their judgements, both before and after they are presented with new contradictory evidence. Results show that those exposed to the rivalry context exhibit significantly higher initial confidence in the adversary’s culpability—demonstrating seizing—and exhibit smaller confidence reductions after disconfirming evidence—demonstrating freezing—compared to controls. Mediation analyses reveal that these effects are driven by affect-laden reasoning processes: participants rely on entrenched ‘enemy images’ when interpreting all information. The study controls for individual differences in risk tolerance, prior cyber event awareness, and personal exposure to cybercrime, finding that the seizing and freezing effects persist across these factors. The findings carry important theoretical implications for the emerging study of cognitive and psychological dimensions of international cybersecurity and suggest that biases in elite attribution processes may escalate interstate tensions in an environment characterized by ambiguous intent and technological complexity. In policy terms, the paper argues that reducing misperception‐driven escalatory risks in cyberspace requires institutional innovations such as systematic information‐gathering protocols, greater operational transparency, and structured deliberative mechanisms to counteract cognitive heuristics and motivated reasoning in attribution decisions.

title: The criminalization of cyber-operations under the rome statute
abstract: This article by J. Trahan addresses the emerging challenge of integrating certain high-impact cyber-operations within the International Criminal Court’s (ICC) Rome Statute framework, focusing on those operations that produce outcomes comparable to conventional kinetic attacks—namely, large-scale loss of life or significant physical destruction. Trahan situates her analysis at the crossroads between technological innovation and longstanding efforts to ensure accountability for atrocity crimes by exploring how the core Rome Statute crimes—genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression—could encompass malicious cyber-enabled acts committed by both state and non-state actors. The author utilizes a doctrinal legal methodology, examining treaty language, the Elements of Crimes, and ICC jurisdictional provisions in tandem with expert reports such as the Council of Advisers’ on cyberwarfare and state practice articulated in the Tallinn Manual 2.0. The analysis systematically maps the actus reus and mens rea elements of each crime onto hypothetical and real-world incidents, including the disabling of critical infrastructure like power grids, dams, hospitals, and air traffic control systems, as well as blended cyber-kinetic operations observed in Ukraine. Trahan assesses the requirements of gravity, attribution, intent, and leadership, concluding that while gravity thresholds and the burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt pose significant obstacles, a narrow class of cyber-operations—such as state-sponsored armed attacks by cyber-units under military command—could satisfy existing Rome Statute provisions without amendment. She identifies that cyber-operations constituting a ‘‘manifest’’ violation of the UN Charter, attributable to political or military leaders who planned, prepared, initiated, or executed them, may qualify as the crime of aggression, underscoring the deterrent potential of future prosecutions. The article also explores the interplay between international jurisdictional rules—particularly the Rome Statute’s lex specialis regime on aggression—and national implementing legislation, highlighting how domestic laws could address jurisdictional and ‘‘manifest’’ requirements more flexibly than the ICC. Acknowledging limitations—such as the narrow subset of qualifying cyber-operations, absence of precedent ICC case law, and complex territorial or nationality-based jurisdictional constraints—Trahan calls for expanded scholarship on the full spectrum of cyber-enabled atrocity crimes, refinement of attribution standards in international law, enhancement of national implementing measures, and proactive signaling by the ICC and states parties that grave cyber-operations are subject to international criminal accountability. This conceptual framework advances multidisciplinary understanding of how the ICC’s jurisdiction can extend into cyberspace and bolsters arguments for deterrence against the gravest forms of cyber attack.

title: Strategic Attribution: Target State Communications in Response to Cyber Operations
abstract: This paper reconceptualizes attribution in the cyber domain as a strategic instrument for target states, rather than a mere technical obstacle to deterrence. Building on a theory-building, descriptive methodology, Hedgecock situates her analysis within the literature on covert action, cyber deterrence, and public attribution. She argues that the intrinsic covert nature of cyber operations, combined with the inherent complexity and resource-intensiveness of technical attribution, affords target states distinct levers of agency in crafting their communication responses. Rather than passively constrained by attribution uncertainty, states can intentionally leverage deniability to manage escalation dynamics and preserve or calibrate deterrent credibility. Hedgecock develops a common lexicon to distinguish three communication postures available to target states: collusion (silence or tacit acknowledgment), disclosure (revealing the occurrence of an operation without naming a perpetrator), and public attribution (naming and shaming the alleged actor). Through illustrative plausibility probes drawn from public statements, government press briefings, and high-profile incidents such as the Sony hack and NotPetya, she demonstrates how states modulate their timing and transparency to influence domestic and international audiences. Integrating frameworks from Carson’s Secret Wars and Poznansky and Perkoski’s Rethinking Secrecy in Cyberspace, the study disaggregates attribution into two strategic decisions—whether to reveal and whether to blame—resulting in a multi-level, multi-player model of attribution as policy. Hedgecock’s key finding is that attribution uncertainty itself becomes a policy instrument that target states exploit to achieve nuanced escalation management, challenging traditional deterrence by punishment paradigms. The paper enriches the study of cyber diplomacy and conflict by offering a novel typology of strategic communication postures, illuminating how the timing and framing of attribution shape state behavior, and highlighting the role of third-party actors in reinforcing or undermining attribution credibility. Acknowledging the limitations of plausibility probes and the absence of systematic longitudinal data, Hedgecock calls for future empirical case studies to test and refine the proposed typology, to quantify the causal effects of communication strategies on escalation trajectories, and to examine the influence of allies, coalitions, and international norms on attribution practices. This work advocates for a paradigm shift that recognizes the strategic value of attribution uncertainty as a core dimension of cyber policy and statecraft.

title: Securing the precipitous heights: U.S. lawfare as a means to confront china at sea, in space, and cyberspace
abstract:
In “Securing the Precipitous Heights: U.S. Lawfare as a Means to Confront China at Sea, in Space, and Cyberspace,” Garret S. Bowman examines how the United States can harness “lawfare”—the strategic application of legal regimes, norms, and institutions—as a central pillar of its Indo-Pacific strategy to counter the People’s Republic of China’s (PRC) burgeoning influence across three contested domains: the East China Sea, outer space, and cyberspace. Situating his analysis within a broader great-power competition paradigm, Bowman argues that traditional military deterrence alone is insufficient against an adversary that deploys legal, political, and informational instruments to advance its strategic objectives and shape the international rules-based order. Drawing on doctrinal exposition of international law, game-theoretic reasoning, treaty texts, United Nations resolutions, Chinese “Unrestricted Warfare” and “Three Warfares” doctrines, and deterrence literature, he develops a cohesive framework by which the United States can operationalize lawfare to maintain its normative leadership, strengthen alliances, and propose binding arms-control measures that deliver political dividends irrespective of Chinese acquiescence.

The article opens by tracing the intensity of U.S. and Chinese competition in East Asia, noting America’s reliance on regional alliances with Japan, South Korea, and the Philippines and emerging partnerships such as with India. It then explores the limitations of deterrence in space—where kinetic anti-satellite (ASAT) tests create hazardous debris—and examines both soft and hard law approaches to arms control. Bowman contrasts U.S. hesitancy to engage in arms-control treaties with the PRC and Russian Federation’s coordinated diplomatic push via the draft Treaty on the Prevention of the Placement of Weapons in Outer Space (PPWT) and related United Nations resolutions, which serve as legal tools to shape the narrative on space weaponization and erode U.S. standing.

Building on an analysis of Chinese strategic writings on “political and legal warfare,” Bowman shows how Beijing’s lawfare extends across all domains to undermine adversaries’ cohesion and exploit institutional vulnerabilities. He then proposes that a narrowly tailored ban on kinetic ASAT tests—achievable under existing international legal instruments—offers the United States a lawfare advantage: if China and Russia accept, it mitigates the gravest debris-creating hazard and stabilizes space security; if they reject, the U.S. gains a moral and reputational victory as champion of responsible space governance. Applying a prisoner’s dilemma model, Bowman argues that the strategic offer of limited arms control yields benefits regardless of acceptance, reinforcing U.S. normative leadership and demonstrating lawfare efficacy.

Extending the framework beyond space, the article outlines how complementary legal strategies can counter PRC lawfare in cyberspace—through norms development, attribution mechanisms, and international cyber agreements—and at sea—by clarifying customary international law around freedom of navigation and maritime lawfare risks. In conclusion, Bowman emphasizes that U.S. space lawfare, anchored in binding norms like a kinetic ASAT test ban, can project American leadership, constrain Chinese ambitions adaptive to the rules-based international order, and promote stability across all domains without foregoing technological advantages. This multidimensional lawfare toolkit offers a refined approach to great-power competition that integrates legal, diplomatic, and strategic instruments to sustain peace and preserve U.S. influence in the twenty-first century.

title: Interrogating african positions on state sponsored cyber operations: a review of regional and national policies and legal responses
abstract: This paper critically examines the emerging positions of African states and regional bodies on state-sponsored cyber operations within the framework of international law. It opens by situating cyberspace as the fifth domain of warfare, alongside land, sea, air, and space, and highlights Africa’s evolving engagement with cybersecurity governance, which has traditionally prioritized cybercrime control. Through qualitative legal analysis of African Union instruments, national cybersecurity strategies, conventions, and declarations, alongside participation records in United Nations Groups of Governmental Experts (UNGGE) processes, the author maps the implicit and explicit treatment of state-directed cyber aggression across the continent. The chapter outlines the current state of African legal measures, noting their emphasis on cybercrime and general cybersecurity norms but an absence of explicit provisions on state-sponsored operations. It explores nascent military cyber initiatives, such as Nigeria’s Cyber Warfare Command and Exercise Crocodile Smile, underscoring both the strategic interest and the human rights controversies they provoke. The analysis reveals limited African participation in UNGGE forums and uneven policy awareness, resulting in a lack of cohesive national stances on applying jus ad bellum and state responsibility to cyber operations. Drawing on comparative perspectives, the chapter assesses whether African positions align with those of North America and Europe, Russia and China, or chart an independent course. It suggests that the African Union Non-Aggression Pact offers a latent normative foundation against state-sponsored cyber operations, albeit in need of explicit cyber-related revisions. The paper concludes by underscoring the African Union Peace and Security Council’s potential role in articulating a clear continental stance and identifies challenges such as uneven document availability, nascent governance structures, and the prevalence of other security priorities like terrorism. Finally, it calls for empirical case studies of specific African cyber incidents, deeper comparative analysis of norm-setting participation, and capacity-building initiatives to elevate policy awareness and align regional treaties with established principles of international law in cyberspace.

title: Cybersecurity and cyber diplomacy at the crossroad: an appraisal of evolving international legal developments in Bangladesh context
abstract: This paper examines the evolving landscape of international cybersecurity law and diplomacy, focusing on Bangladesh’s responses to emerging threats in cyberspace. Recognizing cyberspace as a ‘fifth domain’ of conflict alongside land, sea, air, and space, the author situates the 2016 Bangladesh Bank heist—where $81 million was illicitly transferred from the central bank—as a case study illustrating vulnerabilities in national sovereignty, legal frameworks, and diplomatic practice. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology alongside empirical data from index rankings and case studies, the study first traces the dual-use nature of information and communication technologies (ICTs), highlighting how their accessibility propels both socioeconomic development and novel security threats. It surveys international legal instruments, including UN Group of Experts reports, the Budapest Convention, and relevant treaties, identifying gaps in Bangladesh’s accession to binding cybersecurity agreements. The paper reviews Bangladesh’s fluctuating positions in the Global Cybersecurity Index, National Cyber Security Index, ICT Development Index, and the World Economic Forum’s Network Readiness Index, pinpointing regulatory and institutional deficiencies—such as the absence of a dedicated cyber-army wing, limited diplomatic engagement, and underdeveloped legal remedies for attribution and cross-border cooperation. Case study analysis of state-sponsored attacks demonstrates how non-cooperation by foreign jurisdictions impeded the recovery of stolen funds, with only $15 million recovered due to weak cyber diplomacy. In response, the author proposes a conceptual framework for integrating cybersecurity into foreign policy, bilateral investment treaties, and diplomatic training curricula. Key recommendations include establishing a specialized cyber diplomacy unit, enhancing legal instruments through accession to the Budapest Convention and active participation in UN Open-Ended Working Groups, and embedding cybersecurity provisions in future bilateral investment treaties. The paper underscores the importance of raising awareness among stakeholders, continuous technological updates, and cultivating a domestic culture of cybersecurity ‘prevention’ while advancing proactive international collaboration. Although limited by its country-specific focus and reliance on secondary sources, the study offers transferable insights into how developing economies can bolster cyber resilience. It calls for comparative research on state cyber-army models, empirical assessment of cyber diplomacy initiatives, and exploration of digital diplomacy mechanisms in multilateral settings, thereby contributing to the broader discourse on legally grounded, coordinated strategies for safeguarding sovereign cyberspace.

title: Defend forward & sovereignty: how america's cyberwar strategy upholds international law
source: University of Miami Inter-american Law Review
abstract: This article examines the legal framework underpinning the United States Department of Defense’s “defend forward” cyber strategy and its compatibility with international law principles, especially sovereignty. Motivated by the persistent and evolving threat of state-sponsored and proxy cyberattacks, the U.S. Cyber Command shifted in 2018 from a primarily defensive, reactive posture to proactive disruption of malicious activities at their source, even when those activities fall below the threshold of armed conflict. The author poses the central question: do these preemptive, cross-border cyber operations violate other states’ sovereignty under existing international law? To answer this, the study employs doctrinal legal analysis grounded in state practice and opinio juris, drawing on U.S. domestic authorizations such as the 2019 Authorization for Use of Military Force, official policy documents including the 2018 Department of Defense Cyber Strategy, and comparative positions articulated by the United Kingdom, France, China, and Russia. The analysis finds that sovereignty in cyberspace operates as a guiding principle rather than an inexorable rule prohibiting all cross-border cyber measures. U.S. domestic law constrains defend forward operations to proportional, responsive actions against ongoing or imminent threats, framing them as lawful retorsions rather than wrongful uses of force. Comparative state practice reveals normative flexibility: allies like the UK explicitly reject sovereignty as a rigid constraint in cyberspace, while adversaries such as China and Russia inconsistently invoke sovereignty to suit political ends, undermining its status as an absolute legal bar. The article synthesizes these findings into a coherent framework showing that defend forward missions, properly limited in scope and directly tied to self-defense, can be reconciled with international law. It further argues that U.S. state practice will shape emerging norms in the strategic gray zone, where tacit bargaining among states will crystallize acceptable behavior. The study acknowledges its focus on legal permissibility rather than operational effectiveness or escalation risks and calls for interdisciplinary research to evaluate the practical impact of defend forward on deterrence, escalation dynamics, and norm development. Ultimately, by bringing cyber operations to the adversary’s networks under a principle-based sovereignty regime and clear domestic constraints, defend forward provides the U.S. with crucial strategic flexibility in combating persistent cyber threats.

title: From GoldenEye to landsat-7: combatting cyber intrusions to space-based satellite systems utilizing international law
abstract: This article explores the applicability and adequacy of existing international legal regimes to address and deter cyber intrusions targeting space-based satellite systems. Recognizing the growing reliance on satellite assets for communications, navigation, environmental monitoring, and military operations—and the heightened vulnerability these systems face from state and non-state actors—the author employs a doctrinal international law approach to analyze how the UN Charter’s prohibition on the use of force, customary norms of state responsibility and sovereignty, and the principal space law treaties (including the Outer Space Treaty and the Liability Convention) may be invoked to classify cyberattacks on satellites as violations of international law and to define the permissible scope of state countermeasures and reparations. The Note begins by surveying documented incidents of ground-station intrusions—most notably attempts to interfere with U.S. military and civilian satellites (e.g., Landsat-7, Terra AM-1) allegedly by Chinese actors—and private contractor networks, illustrating how Internet-based hacks can compromise command and control functions without launching physical objects into orbit. It then examines the threshold at which a cyber intrusion gives rise to state liability or self-defense rights. Under the UN Charter, a cyber operation against a satellite may constitute a non-consensual use of force if it inflicts physical damage or functional paralysis of a system critical to national security. Customary countermeasures, including proportional cyber retaliation or economic sanctions, are permissible so long as they remain strictly reactive and proportionate to the initial violation. The Liability Convention’s fault-based regime, however, is shown to be ill-suited to intangible harms, since it confines state liability to damage resulting from ``launching States’’ and physical space objects, leaving no explicit remedy for purely cyberborne intrusions that inflict economic loss or theft of proprietary data. Absent direct physical damage, satellite-dependent states might pursue redress through domestic courts for intellectual property infringement or commercial loss, albeit constrained by issues of sovereign immunity and evidentiary hurdles. Concluding that the 1970s-era space law framework cannot keep pace with rapid technological change, the author advances a two-pronged reform agenda: in the short term, the international community should adopt flexible, cooperative norms—through UN declarations, resolutions, and best-practice principles—and establish an intergovernmental body dedicated to space cybersecurity to facilitate norm development and information-sharing; in the long term, treaty amendments or a new convention should explicitly broaden liability and enforcement mechanisms to encompass intangible cyber harms to satellite systems, balancing legal clarity with the agility needed to address emergent threats. The article highlights the political and practical challenges inherent in multilateral treaty negotiation and argues that interim measures—coupled with private sector engagement and dynamic norm-updating processes—offer the most viable path to a resilient legal regime for protecting critical space infrastructure.

title: Challenges regarding the Categorization of Cyber Force under International Law
abstract: This paper by Yaël Ronen provides a comprehensive examination of the evidentiary requirements for attributing unlawful cyber operations to states under international law. Recognizing the increasing frequency and geopolitical significance of state‐involved cyber incidents, Ronen identifies three core evidentiary dimensions—burden of proof, standard of proof, and means of proof—and analyzes how these dimensions have been addressed in both general international adjudicative practice and cyber‐specific contexts. Drawing on case law from the International Court of Justice, specialized tribunals (such as the Eritrea‐Ethiopia Claims Commission and the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea), treaty bodies, and the Tallinn Manual 2.0, the study reveals that international forums generally adopt a flexible, principle‐driven approach to evidentiary matters rather than fixed technical rules. While this flexibility can accommodate diverse procedural designs, it often engenders uncertainty and may deter states from seeking adjudication in high‐stakes disputes. In the absence of explicit treaty provisions on evidentiary rules, tribunals apply analogies to domestic procedural norms, yet comparative analysis uncovers significant variation in how standards of proof—ranging from “balance of probabilities” to “near certainty”—are articulated and applied. Cyber operations pose unique challenges to each evidentiary dimension: digital evidence is inherently volatile, dispersed across jurisdictions, and often requires cooperation from third‐party service providers, making timely collection difficult; its admissibility and probative value may be contested when sources and forensic procedures cannot be fully disclosed without compromising privacy or state secrecy. The paper explores the use of presumptions and inferences tailored to cyber contexts, contrasting proposals for conclusive attribution when operations originate from state‐controlled infrastructure with the Tallinn Manual’s caution that such assets may be compromised by non‐state actors. Ronen also addresses the admissibility and weight of illegally obtained evidence, arguing that unlike domestic criminal trials—where exclusion is intended to guard against abuses of power—inter‐state litigation tends to weigh probative value against the risk of state wrongdoing, excluding only evidence obtained in violation of jus cogens norms. Procedural safeguards for privileged and classified information receive detailed treatment: the ICJ has neither recognized blanket national security privilege nor drawn adverse inferences when states refuse disclosure, whereas tribunals like the ICTY have developed in camera review, redaction protocols, and judicial affidavits to balance confidentiality and fact finding. Building on these insights, the paper proposes a nuanced framework for a prospective international cyber attribution mechanism: it recommends specialized presumptions calibrated to cyber‐specific technical realities, clear guidelines for burden and standard of proof that reflect cyber complexity, and model rules for evidence sharing, confidentiality, and challenges to illegally obtained or privileged materials. Acknowledging the scarcity of fully adjudicated cyber disputes and reliance on analogies from non‐cyber cases, Ronen concludes by calling for empirical research on digital evidence use in pending cyber claims, refinement of evidentiary clauses in cyber treaties, and development of standardized procedural rules to enhance predictability and legitimacy of state‐level cyber attribution.

title: Protecting societies: anchoring a new protection dimension In international law In times of increased cyber threats
abstract: In “Protecting Societies: Anchoring a New Protection Dimension in International Law in Times of Increased Cyber Threats,” R. Geiss and H. Lahmann present a thorough doctrinal analysis of how existing International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and International Human Rights Law (IHRL) must evolve to address the diffuse yet systemic harms of state-led cyber operations in armed conflict. Recognizing that the classical framework of IHL was conceived to mitigate physical destruction and casualties characteristic of kinetic warfare, the authors argue that the digital transformation of modern societies demands the explicit protection of essential societal processes—economic, financial, healthcare, cultural, and public information systems—whose disruption can inflict civilian harm on a broad scale. Employing scenario-based mapping, they illustrate five hypothetical cases, from distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks on critical infrastructure to ransomware paralysis of healthcare networks, that expose interpretive gaps in the definition of “attack,” “object,” and “civilian population.” Through textual interpretation of core treaties, state practice—particularly contributions to the UN Group of Governmental Experts—and a progressive reading of IHL principles, the paper demonstrates that while cyber operations resembling kinetic effects clearly fall under existing norms, operations targeting intangible societal functions often remain legally defensible due to IHL’s traditional object‐focused conception. The authors document divergent state positions: some states acknowledge non-physical cyber effects as uses of force under jus ad bellum yet maintain that jus in bello protection requires physical damage. To resolve this “grey zone,” they propose three potential pathways: (1) dynamic interpretation of current rules through instruments like Tallinn Manual 3.0; (2) development of voluntary, nonbinding norms within UN GGE and OEWG processes; and (3) drafting a new treaty provision modeled on Additional Protocol I’s Article 54 to shield indispensable societal functions as protected assets. While acknowledging the challenges of threshold definitions, line-drawing, and state resistance, Geiss and Lahmann insist that as cyber capabilities converge with artificial intelligence, the time is ripe to establish a new protection dimension in IHL explicitly safeguarding the integrity and functionality of core societal processes. They conclude by calling for further empirical and policy research to refine criteria for identifying protected assets, gauge state willingness for normative innovation, and explore enforcement mechanisms, thereby initiating a vital multidisciplinary discussion on cyber conflict policy and law in the twenty-first century.

title: Are there international rules governing cyberspace?
source: Journal of International and Comparative Law
abstract: This article examines the evolving body of international rules governing cyberspace, arguing that despite the absence of a single, comprehensive treaty regime, a framework of binding and non-binding norms drawn from multiple sources has begun to coalesce. Wang first situates cyberspace as a distinct global domain—alongside land, sea, air, and space—whose transnational character has transformed economic activity, connectivity, and security dynamics. He then demonstrates that the UN Charter’s principles of sovereignty, non-intervention, and the use of force apply to state conduct in cyberspace, as reflected in UN General Assembly resolutions and the reports of the UN Group of Governmental Experts, which articulate a consensus that existing law governs state cyber operations. Beyond the UN, Wang analyzes regional and bilateral cyber agreements, including recent EU–US data-flow arrangements and emerging Asia-Pacific cyber pacts, as well as World Trade Organization obligations that regulate digital commerce. He further shows that International Court of Justice judgments and International Law Commission conclusions on customary international law provide methodological guidance for identifying how state practice and opinio juris forge cyber rules. Particular attention is given to the crystallization of special customary norms among principal cyber actors—major states whose consistent, uniform practices and declarations evidence both usage and legal conviction—potentially serving as precursors to broader customary norms. Wang highlights the complementary role of private-sector codes of conduct, which, while not directly binding on states, illuminate state and corporate expectations of lawful behavior and thus reinforce customary rule formation. Through a detailed case study of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation and the invalidated EU–US Privacy Shield, the article underscores the centrality of privacy and data protection to cyber governance and illustrates how judicial interpretation shapes transnational data flows. Recognizing the fragmented nature of current rules—stemming from divergent regional practices, the lack of universal treaty commitments, and rapidly evolving technology—Wang identifies critical challenges in measuring and harmonizing state practice. He calls for a multilateral legal regime that builds on existing international law foundations, strengthens protections for personal and social data, and fosters coordinated norm development among states, international organizations, and private entities. This integrative framework not only maps dispersed legal sources but also clarifies the processes by which customary cyber norms emerge and underscores the need for cooperative efforts to consolidate these norms into a coherent global order.

title: The vital role of international law in the framework for responsible state behaviour in cyberspace
abstract: This article by Harriet Moynihan in the Journal of Cyber Policy examines the indispensable role of existing international law for structuring responsible state behaviour in cyberspace and advancing global security. Moynihan begins by noting widespread agreement—embodied in successive United Nations Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) reports of 2013 and 2015 and endorsed by NATO, the OSCE, the EU, the Commonwealth, and the G7—that the UN Charter’s principles of sovereignty, sovereign equality, peaceful dispute settlement, and non-intervention apply fully to state cyber operations. Despite this consensus, significant doctrinal gaps persist: states disagree on when a cyber operation breaches sovereignty, whether a duty of due diligence to prevent third-party misuse exists, and the lawful scope of countermeasures in response to cyberattacks. To illustrate these challenges, Moynihan analyses two foundational peacetime principles: sovereignty and non-intervention. She traces divergent state positions in UN parallel processes—namely the GGE and the Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG)—demonstrating how competing interpretations hamper consensus. Nevertheless, voluntary norms agreed at the 2015 GGE, especially the norm against knowingly damaging critical infrastructure, serve as stepping-stones by implicitly reflecting binding obligations. Moynihan highlights the 2020 ICRC proposal and the Oxford Statement urging a domain-specific norm protecting healthcare from cyber operations, rooted in international humanitarian law. These advances underscore how multilateral deliberations and public articulation of legal positions foster transparent diplomacy and build states’ legal capacity. The article underscores the strategic value of ongoing UN consultations and regional dialogues (involving the African Union, EU, OAS, OSCE, and ASEAN Regional Forum) as confidence-building measures that deepen understanding of how international law governs cyberspace. Moynihan argues that even fragmented debates serve a constructive function: they pressure states to refine customary law arguments, develop national positions, and engage in open debate, all of which incrementally move the community toward cyber-specific legal understandings. She acknowledges limitations such as reliance on public documents and focus on only two legal principles, and suggests future research on empirical compliance patterns, evolution of opinio juris in regional forums, and the impact of emerging cyber alliances on customary international law. Ultimately, Moynihan concludes that while arriving at comprehensive cyber rules will take time, the journey of transparent, inclusive, and multidisciplinary engagement is itself strengthening the international legal framework and reducing risks of miscalculation, thereby contributing to a more stable and rules-based cyberspace.
