title: Cybercrime vs. Cyberwar: paradigms for addressing malicious cyber activity
source: Journal of National Security Law and Policy
abstract: In “Cybercrime vs. Cyberwar: Paradigms for Addressing Malicious Cyber Activity,” Eoyang and Keitner critically assess U.S. government responses to the growing threat of malicious cyber activity (MCA), highlighting the tension between militarized “armed conflict” and civilian “law enforcement” paradigms. Against the backdrop of increasing U.S. vulnerabilities—from state-sponsored espionage to transnational criminal operations exploiting the Internet of Things—the authors argue that policymakers have blurred the lines between crime and warfare. They trace the emergence of the armed conflict model to post-9/11 national security frameworks, including the establishment of U.S. Cyber Command in 2009 and the Department of Defense’s “defend forward” policy, as well as international efforts such as the Tallinn Manuals on cyber warfare and peacetime cyber operations. These developments reflect a view of MCA through the lens of armed conflict, which reallocates resources toward military responses, sidelines domestic law enforcement, and raises questions about appropriate legal authorities and thresholds for cyberattack. Conversely, the law enforcement model—embodied in the Department of Justice’s practice of “attribution by indictment” and the framework of the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime—provides human rights safeguards and emphasizes international cooperation, capacity-building, and the rule of law. However, the authors identify significant gaps in the global adoption of the Convention, uneven treaty participation, privacy concerns, and resource constraints that undermine effective criminal prosecutions of MCA. Through normative legal and policy analysis, Eoyang and Keitner demonstrate that neither paradigm alone suffices: armed conflict doctrines offer deterrence through threat of force but lack clarity on cyberattack thresholds and risk militarizing cyberspace, while law enforcement responses struggle with low detection rates, fragmented multilateral engagement, and diplomatic sensitivities when state-sponsored actors are accused. To reconcile these shortcomings, the article introduces a continuum-based framework, disaggregating MCA along a war/crime spectrum according to the degree of state involvement—from state-executed cyber forces to domestic non-government actors—and aligning calibrated legal responses, resource allocation, and international cooperation strategies accordingly. The authors advocate for hybrid approaches that leverage “legal strike back” through indictments and sanctions alongside mutual capacity-building initiatives by Interpol, the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, and civil society. They underscore the need for future research to empirically validate this continuum model via case studies, to develop cross-border evidence-sharing protocols that balance privacy and human rights, and to explore diplomatic mechanisms that incentivize universal treaty ratification and strengthen deterrence through both military and legal channels. This multidisciplinary analysis offers policymakers a novel lens for crafting coherent national and international strategies to deter and respond to the full spectrum of cyber threats.

title: No lockdown in cyberspace. State-sponsored cyberattacks during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic
source: Europolity: Continuity and Change in European Governance
abstract: This article examines the proliferation and evolution of state-sponsored cyberattacks throughout the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, situating these operations within broader international relations, policy, and legal frameworks. As global reliance on digital infrastructure surged in early 2020, threat actors—especially those backed by nation-states—escalated and diversified their cyber operations, targeting health facilities, critical infrastructure, and vaccine research to advance espionage, disruption, and coercive objectives. Employing a qualitative, case-study methodology grounded in extensive open-source reporting from reputable media outlets and institutional publications (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, ENISA, and WHO), the study maps major campaigns from March 2020 to March 2021. It details incursions against COVID-19 hospitals in Czechia, Germany, the UK, and the US, attacks on electrical grids and water treatment systems in Israel and Florida, and high-profile espionage operations exemplified by the SolarWinds and Microsoft Exchange hacks attributed to Russian and Chinese state actors. The analysis further scrutinizes the attribution challenges inherent in cyber conflict, noting how opaque evidence trails and technical complexities hinder timely and accurate public attributions. Despite these obstacles, the European Union and United States adopted coordinated sanction regimes, publicly attributed campaigns to Russia and China, and signalled a shift toward more assertive cyber deterrence policies. Findings underscore an unprecedented increase in both the intensity and sophistication of state-sponsored cyber activities during the pandemic, revealing how crisis-induced digital dependence created strategic opportunities for intelligence gathering and coercion. Drawing on international law principles and the Tallinn Manual 2.0, the article articulates an analytical framework linking pandemic conditions to opportunistic state behavior, and offers policy recommendations for strengthening attribution mechanisms, enhancing international legal norms on state responsibility in cyberspace, and integrating cyber deterrence into comprehensive security strategies. Limitations of the study include reliance on publicly available sources—exposing the analysis to potential reporting bias and incomplete attribution data—and the rapidly evolving cyber threat landscape which may render some case details provisional. The author concludes by calling for expanded interdisciplinary research in international relations that systematically incorporates real-time cyber incident analysis, the development of quantitative metrics to assess state cyber aggression, and longitudinal studies on the efficacy of cyber sanctions as norm-building tools. This research thus contributes a synthesized chronology of pandemic-era cyber operations, a nuanced understanding of state-sponsored cyber conflict under crisis conditions, and strategic pathways for policy and legal reform to bolster global cyber resilience.

title: Cyberattack and the Use of Force in International Law
abstract: This article confronts the foundational challenge of imposing legally coherent, technologically feasible borders on cyberspace by introducing the concept of sovereign state cyber interests as a decisive demarcation criterion. Recognizing that traditional analogies to physical borders and classical sovereignty theories—stemming from Bodin and Hobbes—are inadequate to address the fluid, extraterritorial character of digital interactions, the study advances a hybrid legal-technical framework grounded in the normative weight of national security imperatives. Drawing on a doctrinal methodology enriched by comparative judicial analysis, it systematically reviews divergent scholarly positions on cyberspace sovereignty and the absence of a unified boundary-setting algorithm, illustrating how this theoretical fragmentation undermines state capacity to deter cross-border cyber threats. By synthesizing domestic court decisions from multiple jurisdictions in which judges have implicitly applied considerations of national interest to cyberspace disputes, the author demonstrates that judicial reasoning already gravitates toward state-centered criteria, even in the absence of explicit international norms. Building on this empirical foundation, the article articulates a three-tiered model for cyber border demarcation: (1) identification of core state cyber interests—defined by the protection of critical infrastructures, strategic digital assets, and national security objectives; (2) mapping of digital domains through measurable technological indicators such as network traffic flows, geolocation data, and jurisdictional touchpoints; and (3) legal validation via alignment with established international law principles and emerging domestic jurisprudence. This innovative framework addresses the technical uncertainties of cyberspace by embedding normative thresholds—rooted in nationalist and security considerations—into boundary-drawing algorithms, thereby reconciling the inherently global reach of data flows with state prerogatives to assert sovereign control. The article further examines the political and legal implications of adopting a state interest–based demarcation standard, highlighting its potential to strengthen national cyber defenses, reduce legal ambiguity, and foster coherent multilateral dialogue on cyber sovereignty. In acknowledging limitations related to technological evolution and the current lack of uniform international adjudication, the author calls for empirical testing of the model under varied political regimes and technological environments, as well as ongoing efforts to harmonize cyber sovereignty norms. Ultimately, the research offers policymakers and legal scholars a disciplined paradigm to conceptualize and operationalize state sovereignty in the digital age, advancing both theoretical discourse and practical state practice in cyber policy and law.

title: Unilateral cyber sanctions: between questioned legality and normative value
abstract: This Article examines the emerging trend of unilateral cyber sanctions adopted by leading jurisdictions such as the United States, the European Union, and the United Kingdom in response to malicious cyber activities in the absence of binding international norms. The authors employ a doctrinal legal methodology to analyze how these measures intersect with public international law and international economic law, exploring their legality under the law of state responsibility, rules on state immunity, human rights law, WTO commitments, and investor–state dispute settlement. Part II situates cyber sanctions as self-help instruments arising from the failure of multilateral cyber governance efforts, detailing their motivations and cataloguing current state practice. Part III interrogates whether these measures breach customary international law, including the principles of non-intervention and sovereignty, and assesses potential defenses: whether cyber sanctions can be justified as countermeasures under differentiated thresholds of necessity, proportionality, and prior invocation requirements. The analysis concludes that unilateral cyber sanctions seldom satisfy established criteria for lawful countermeasures and may infringe human rights and immunity norms. Part IV evaluates consistency with WTO law, demonstrating that cyber sanctions are unlikely to fall under the WTO security exception as interpreted by dispute settlement bodies and risk challenging national treatment and most-favored-nation obligations. Moreover, the freezing of assets and broad designations expose states to claims of indirect expropriation and breaches of fair and equitable treatment under bilateral investment treaties and investment chapters in free trade agreements. The authors highlight that sanctioned entities and affected third-country investors may initiate claims before international tribunals, underscoring the significant liability states assume when imposing these sanctions. Despite these legal vulnerabilities, the Article recognizes the normative value of unilateral cyber sanctions in signaling and deterrence, potentially filling a regulatory void while simultaneously posing paradoxical risks: their legal ambiguity can both empower states to curb cyber threats and invite misuse for protectionist or technological supremacy agendas. In conclusion, the authors call for the development of interpretative approaches within existing international law frameworks, exploration of appropriate multilateral forums, and coordination mechanisms to balance states’ self-help needs with safeguards against abuse, thereby guiding the evolution of robust international norms governing cyberspace.

title: What is the future of cyber deterrence?
source: The SAIS Review of International Affairs
abstract: This article critically examines the evolving debate over the applicability and future of deterrence strategies in cyberspace, advancing a nuanced framework for understanding when and how states can effectively deter hostile cyber behavior. Lonergan and Montgomery begin by surveying traditional deterrence theory, highlighting four modalities—punishment, denial, entanglement, and norms—and exploring their relevance to the unique attributes of the cyber domain, such as anonymity, attribution challenges, low barriers to entry, offensive advantages, and the borderless nature of networks. They contrast skeptical perspectives, notably cyber persistence theory—which advocates constant engagement rather than deterrence as a strategy—with the continued reliance of U.S. policy on deterrence concepts, as exemplified in the Department of Defense Cyber Strategies and the Cyberspace Solarium Commission’s layered deterrence framework. The authors identify three core analytical dimensions: definitional clarity of cyber deterrence; distinctions between general versus specific deterrence; and the role of behavioral thresholds, arguing that each dimension imposes distinct constraints on signaling, credibility, and effectiveness. Through extensive literature review and conceptual analysis, they demonstrate that punishment-based approaches often lack credibility below use-of-force thresholds, whereas denial and entanglement strategies may succeed if adversaries perceive clear red lines. They caution against applying deterrence to routine espionage, where common norms tacitly accept such activity, and instead advocate targeted approaches above espionage but below kinetic conflict. The theoretical framework proposed delineates the precise conditions under which each deterrence modality is viable: punishment when attribution is rapid and the stakes rise to force-equivalent levels; denial when defensive resilience raises attack costs; entanglement where mutual dependencies create disincentives; and norms where reputational costs deter violations. Building on this framework, the authors offer actionable policy recommendations for the United States: refine declaratory policies to articulate specific red lines and response options; accelerate and streamline non-military cost imposition tools—such as sanctions and indictments—to reduce response times; institutionalize agile planning and execution processes to enhance credible signaling through rapid offensive cyber operations; strengthen allied coordination to present unified multilateral responses; and bolster the resilience of conventional and nuclear systems to preserve full-spectrum deterrence. Acknowledging limitations in current attribution capabilities, adversary perception data, and empirical measures of signaling effectiveness, Lonergan and Montgomery call for future research to operationalize behavioral thresholds, assess cross-domain deterrence interactions, and foster multilateral norm development. Their work guides policymakers toward a more tailored, adaptive cyber deterrence strategy that balances persistent engagement with selective coercion, thereby advancing robust statecraft in the digital age.

title: International Regulation of Cyber Operations
source: Yuval Shany and Tal Mimran, International …
abstract:
In “International Regulation of Cyber Operations,” Yuval Shany and Tal Mimran provide a comprehensive examination of the current and emerging international legal framework governing state behavior in cyberspace. They open by contextualizing cyber operations within an increasingly digitalized global environment marked by rapid technological change, expanded use of Internet of Things devices, and heightened vulnerabilities exemplified by recent critical infrastructure attacks and the COVID-19–induced surge in remote connectivity. The authors highlight states’ traditional reluctance to invoke international law against cyber-attacks—arising from political considerations, shared espionage interests, and the absence of a robust attribution mechanism—and trace the evolution toward more assertive legal postures by countries including Australia, France, Germany, Israel, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands. They analyze how these states have begun publicly articulating positions on the application of jus ad bellum and international humanitarian law to cyber operations, signaling a shift toward legal accountability for hostile actions in cyberspace.

Central to the paper is the attribution challenge: establishing the author of a cyber-attack is foundational to any lawful countermeasure. Drawing on the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility (ARSIWA) and relevant International Court of Justice jurisprudence, Shany and Mimran dissect the rules by which states attribute acts committed “by an organ of the state,” “pursuant to instructions,” or through “effective control.” They identify technical and evidentiary hurdles—such as anonymizing proxies, zombie networks, spoofing, and foreign-based servers—that complicate forensic attribution, then examine how intelligence capabilities and geopolitical context (e.g., Stuxnet, Sony Pictures) influence legal determinations. The authors assess divergent standards of proof articulated by the ICJ (“beyond reasonable doubt,” “clear and convincing,” “consistent with probabilities”) and current debates over whether lower or higher thresholds should apply depending on the severity of the alleged breach.

Shany and Mimran conclude by advocating for a more robust international agreement delineating states’ rights and obligations in cyber conflict, including clarified definitions of what constitutes an unlawful armed attack in cyberspace, streamlined attribution procedures, and mechanisms for public diplomacy and multilateral sanctions. They acknowledge challenges posed by divergent visions of digital sovereignty, the technical architecture of the Internet, and past failures to secure consensus (e.g., Russia’s proposed treaty banning pre-positioned malicious code). Nonetheless, they argue that an effective regulatory regime could harmonize national practices, incentivize capacity-building assistance, foster information sharing, and potentially establish an independent attribution body to reduce political disputes. Their study underscores the urgent need to strengthen the normative regime in cyberspace to ensure stability and reciprocal restraint among state and non-state actors on the global digital frontier.

title: Cyberattacks: a look at evidentiary thresholds in international law
abstract: This article examines the critical evidentiary gaps that plague state efforts to obtain legal redress for malicious cyber operations under international law. While states increasingly resort to public attribution—‘‘naming and shaming’’—to deter cyberattacks, the author argues that such informal practices lack sufficient legal rigor and carry limited punitive force. Instead, victims must navigate the strict standards and methodologies of international judicial fora, notably the International Court of Justice (ICJ), where the ‘‘no room for reasonable doubt’’ standard remains sacrosanct. Drawing on doctrinal analysis of foundational instruments—the Articles on State Responsibility, the ICJ Statute, and seminal jurisprudence from the ICJ (e.g., Nicaragua v. United States), NAFTA tribunals, and ad hoc tribunals—this study disentangles the dual regimes of rules of attribution (effective control, overall control, and emerging ‘‘control and capabilities’’ tests) from the distinct question of evidentiary thresholds (quantum and methods of proof). Through illustrative case studies, including the Kudankulam nuclear plant breach and high-profile public attributions by states and private firms, the paper demonstrates how technical indicators—IP signatures, malware provenance, linguistic markers, operational patterns—can serve as circumstantial evidence, provided alternative explanations like spoofing or obfuscation are negated. Yet, the author finds that most private investigative reports, however detailed, fall short of meeting the ‘‘fully conclusive’’ legal standard and instead may only function as corroborative adjuncts. In the example of the Kudankulam incident, the convergence of malware variants linked to the Lazarus Group, North Korean network characteristics, and linguistic traces, while suggestive, would likely fail to satisfy the ICJ’s evidentiary demands absent direct access to state-held intelligence and forensic data. The paper warns that misattribution under low thresholds could itself constitute an internationally wrongful act under the Tallinn Manual, underscoring the urgent need for alignment between forensic methods and legal requirements. Concluding, the author advocates a structured approach for policymakers and technologists to integrate rigorous evidentiary protocols—encompassing data collection, chain-of-custody standards, and collaborative public–private frameworks—into cyber attribution practices. He calls for procedural innovations in international courts to accommodate digital evidence and for normative development on state responsibilities to ensure that evidentiary hurdles do not perpetuate impunity in cyberspace. By clarifying the interplay between attribution rules and proof standards, this research contributes a multidisciplinary roadmap for strengthening accountability and deterrence of state-sponsored cyberattacks.

title: Look south: challenges and opportunities for the ‘rules of the road’ for cyberspace in ASEAN and the AU
authors: Irene Poetranto; Lau; Justin; Josh and Gold
abstract: This article examines the prospects for advancing the so-called “rules of the road” for responsible state behavior in cyberspace at the regional level by focusing on two regional organizations—the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the African Union (AU)—and on four member states (Indonesia and Singapore in ASEAN, and Kenya and South Africa in the AU) that qualify as “swing states” or “digital deciders” and that have actively participated in the United Nations Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG) on Information and Communications Technology (ICT) in the Context of International Security between 2019 and 2021. The authors begin by situating the debate over cyber norms and the applicability of international law to cyberspace within the history of United Nations processes, notably the Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) and the OEWG, and then argue that disagreements among major powers over binding vs. non-binding frameworks have made global consensus elusive. They contend that regional organizations, by convening smaller and more homogeneous groups of states, offer valuable venues for norm development, contextualization, and confidence-building. The article synthesizes public statements made by the four target states over multiple OEWG sessions, supplemented by relevant regional policy documents and secondary literature on cybersecurity governance. It finds that ASEAN has taken incremental steps toward developing common cyber norms, including the recent establishment of a working-level committee and ministerial-level dialogue mechanisms, but that progress is hampered by disparate levels of technological capacity among member states, divergent threat perceptions, and strong adherence to non-interference and sovereignty principles. In the AU, the adoption of the Malabo Convention on Cybersecurity and Personal Data Protection marks a significant normative achievement, yet implementation has been uneven across the continent due to resource constraints, limited institutional capacity, and varying political will. Across both regions, the presence of highly motivated states with stronger cyber capabilities—such as Singapore and South Africa—has been critical in championing norm adoption, but such leadership must be balanced with broader capacity-building efforts to bring less advanced members on board. The authors identify three principal challenges: (1) reconciling disparate sovereignty and non-interference norms with the need for cross-border cooperation; (2) addressing wide gaps in technological and policy capacity; and (3) securing sustained political commitment amid competing regional priorities. Conversely, they highlight opportunities afforded by existing regional partnerships, donor-supported capacity-building initiatives, and the potential for regionally tailored confidence-building measures to foster trust and operationalize voluntary norms. The article concludes that while regional efforts cannot substitute for universal cyber governance frameworks, they can complement global processes by developing practical, context-sensitive rules of the road, building state confidence, and generating momentum that feeds back into broader UN negotiations.

title: A multi-stakeholder foundation for peace in cyberspace
abstract: This article examines the evolution and potential of multi-stakeholder approaches to international peace and security in cyberspace, tracing how conceptions of Internet governance have shifted from its technical origins to a domain increasingly contested by state actors. Drawing on early Internet governance dialogues inaugurated by the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) in 2003–2005, the authors recount how the multi-stakeholder model—encompassing governments, private industry, technical standards bodies, academia, and civil society—successfully underpinned the resilience and interoperability of the global public Internet. They contrast this inclusive model with the exclusive state-centric formats that have characterized United Nations (UN) deliberations on cyber conflict, notably the UN Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) convened since 2004 under successive resolutions. Although the GGE process achieved consensus on foundational principles—affirming the applicability of existing international law and articulating non-binding norms of state behavior in cyberspace—the authors argue that its state-only composition has limited its capacity to adapt to the complex, rapidly evolving cyber domain and to leverage the technical, operational, and normative expertise of non-state stakeholders. The article maps the GGE’s six iterations, highlighting achievements in consensus building through 2015 and the subsequent stagnation evidenced by the 2017 and 2021 reports, which have produced minimal advances in new commitments. In response, the authors introduce a series of informal, multi-stakeholder initiatives that have emerged since 2018 to fill this governance gap: the Charter of Trust, the Cybersecurity Tech Accord, the Paris Call for Trust and Security in Cyberspace, the Contract for the Web, and the Let’s Talk Cyber dialogue series. Each initiative is analyzed for its structure, thematic focus, and role in catalyzing private-sector leadership and wider participation in norm development and capacity building for peace in cyberspace. These initiatives are credited with producing working groups on supply-chain security, cyber hygiene, responsible vulnerability disclosure, and norms implementation, as well as advocating for inclusive UN processes such as the Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG). The authors also detail methods, combining desk review of canonical documents, direct engagement in UN and multi-stakeholder forums, and insights from Microsoft’s global cybersecurity work, while acknowledging the private-sector vantage point’s limitations. Finally, they offer recommendations for ensuring that future UN cyber dialogues adopt genuine multi-stakeholder formats—formalizing channels for industry, civil society, academia, and technical bodies within GGE and OEWG mandates—to harness diverse expertise, enhance transparency, and strengthen collective responses to the escalation of interstate cyber conflict. The article concludes that broadening participation beyond states is essential for developing robust, adaptable norms and mechanisms capable of sustaining peace and security in the complex, interconnected digital domain.

title: From cyber denial to cyber punishment: what keeps japanese warriors from active defense operations?
abstract: This article investigates why, despite growing cyber threats and demonstrable technical capabilities, Japan refrains from implementing an active-defense cyber strategy—leveraging offensive countermeasures to deter adversaries—and remains committed to a passive, denial-defense posture. Katagiri identifies a substantial gap in scholarship on Japanese cyber deterrence, especially when contrasted with Western military-focused analyses, and seeks to fill it through a qualitative framework that synthesizes academic literature, empirical breach data from Japan’s Defense Information Infrastructure (DII), and legal and technical analyses. The central research question asks why Japan, though technologically capable of launching proportionate cyber countermeasures, avoids active defensive operations that could more effectively deter aggressors. The study draws upon a 2016 MOD breach by actors traced to China—despite rigorous network segmentation in the DII—and examines why Japan chose to strengthen defenses rather than threaten or enact retaliatory strikes. Quantitative breach data reveal a 96.8% success rate for attackers and a stable frequency of incidents, indicating passive defenses have failed to deter new cyber intrusions. Building on this, the paper develops a tripartite explanatory framework: First, Japan’s legal architecture—grounded in the postwar doctrine of senshu boei and constitutional constraints—codifies passive defense and broadly prohibits cyber operations that could be perceived as offensive. Second, substantial technical hurdles challenge the credibility of deterrent threats, including difficulties in ensuring precision, attribution, and control of escalation in cyberspace, which complicate public reassurance and risk management. Third, socio-political factors—public sensitivity to militarization, institutional risk aversion, and the lack of domestic consensus on expanding cyber authorities—further inhibit the adoption of active measures. The paper traces the historical evolution of Japan’s Cybersecurity Strategies (2010, 2015, 2018), which, despite expanding whole-of-government frameworks and multilateral engagements (including commitments under the Budapest Convention and UN GGE/OEWG processes), remain centered on damage mitigation rather than coercive retaliation. While acknowledging that international law offers limited enforcement against state or non-state actors, Katagiri emphasizes that domestic legal reform has consistently preserved denial-defense as the sole legitimate approach. The integration of private-sector cooperation under Society 5.0 and ongoing organizational reforms have enhanced passive capabilities but left deterrence efficacy stagnant. The article concludes with reflections on the analytical, rather than prescriptive, nature of the work, suggesting future comparative studies of active-defense adoption in other democracies, deeper empirical investigations of public opinion on offensive cyber operations, and exploration of institutional reforms that could recalibrate Japan’s balance between denial defense and deterrent countermeasures. By combining legal, technical, and socio-political lenses, this multidisciplinary study enriches understanding of state cyber strategy formulation and the nuanced interplay of norms, capabilities, and risk perceptions in national cyber policy.

title: Cyber attribution and state responsibility
abstract: Assigning responsibility for malicious cyber operations presents a critical yet unsettled challenge in international law, where the absence of explicit attribution standards has undermined victim states’ capacity to respond lawfully and has weakened traditional deterrence mechanisms. In the decade since the 2010 Stuxnet and Olympic Games operations against Iranian nuclear centrifuges, at least thirty-eight states—including Russia, China, North Korea and the United States—have allegedly conducted or sponsored cyberattacks such as the 2016 election interference, the Office of Personnel Management and Sony Pictures intrusions, and the disruptive WannaCry and NotPetya campaigns, exposing the legal and strategic importance of attribution. This paper matters because it confronts foundational questions regarding whether international law requires attribution of cyberattacks, what evidentiary benchmarks suffice for state responsibility under jus ad bellum and jus in bello, and how victim states can secure legal pathways to countermeasures while preserving international order. Through a doctrinal legal analysis of state responsibility principles, customs, and lex specialis rules as articulated in the Tallinn Manual, combined with a review of state practice and policy instruments such as the twenty-seven-state 2019 joint statement, the research constructs an integrative legal framework. The methodology is grounded in qualitative legal scholarship, case studies of high-profile cyber incidents, normative evaluation of proposals for global attribution mechanisms, and examination of scholarly debates on decentralized versus centralized attribution models. Findings reveal that international law lacks clear rules on cyber attribution, that confidentiality concerns obstruct transparency and consensus on evidentiary standards, and that advanced cyber states benefit from secrecy while weaker states face an arms race in detection and evasion. The study uncovers that existing domestic attribution proposals—such as centralizing attribution authority within the NSA or establishing a National Cyber Safety Board—fail to address the transnational nature of cyber operations, while decentralized approaches risk fragmentation. As a novel contribution, the author proposes a multifaceted roadmap: codifying lex specialis attribution benchmarks, fostering collective public attributions to crystallize opinio juris, and creating a neutral institutional body—potentially modeled on the CyberPeace Institute in Geneva—to collect attribution data from state and non-state actors, assist victims, bridge legal and normative gaps, and issue credible, publicly accessible reports. The paper also delineates technical and practical obstacles to attribution and traces a path to legal consequences for below-threshold cyberattacks by proposing the development of evidence-based victim state responses and international legal case-building, thereby bridging doctrinal theory and operational practice. It underscores the potential of lex specialis as a trumping regime over general state responsibility law and the importance of articulating specific cyber rules. The research acknowledges limitations including states’ reluctance to disclose intelligence sources and methods, the uneven technical capacities among states, and the absence of binding international agreement on procedural standards. For future inquiry, the paper recommends empirical research to define robust attribution benchmarks, governance structure design for an international attribution institution, evaluation of the efficacy of joint statements and institutional models, and longitudinal analysis of state practice to support the emergence of customary international law in cyberspace.

title: In defense of pure sovereignty in cyberspace
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract: Kevin Jon Heller’s article ‘In Defense of Pure Sovereignty in Cyberspace’ confronts the enduring legal uncertainty surrounding state sovereignty and low-intensity cyber operations—those unauthorized intrusions into another state’s computer systems that do not amount to the use of force or prohibited intervention. The work begins by charting the consensus reached in the United Nations Open-Ended Working Group’s 2021 report that ‘international law applies to cyberspace,’ yet underscores the report’s failure to resolve which cyber operations violate sovereignty. Heller identifies three competing state positions. First, the United Kingdom’s ‘principle-only’ view treats sovereignty as a mere guiding principle in cyberspace, never giving rise to a rule violation; second, the ‘relative-sovereignty’ stance prohibits only operations causing physical damage or impairing inherently governmental functions; and third, the ‘pure-sovereignty’ position bars all non-consensual cyber intrusions. Employing a doctrinal methodology grounded in state practice, opinio juris, treaty analysis under the U.N. Charter, and the normative outputs of expert bodies such as the Tallinn Manual 2.0 and the OEWG, Heller demonstrates that states overwhelmingly treat sovereignty as a binding rule in cyberspace, though they diverge over its scope. He locates state positions on a spectrum: the United Kingdom alone champions the principle-only view; a majority—including the United States, Russia, and Germany—adhere to relative sovereignty; and a minority—France, Iran, and Switzerland—endorse pure sovereignty. Heller argues that the relative-sovereignty rule’s ambiguities—particularly its undefined thresholds of ‘physical damage’ and ‘inherently governmental functions’—create grey zones that favor technologically powerful states, who can exploit them with impunity while weaker states hesitate to act for fear of asymmetric countermeasures. He counters that pure sovereignty, rooted in the first Lotus principle, coherently extends territorial sovereignty to cyberspace by unequivocally prohibiting any unauthorized penetration of a state’s information systems. This approach, Heller contends, provides clearer legal red lines, enhances predictability, and levels the playing field by deterring low-intensity cyber incursions. Critically, he addresses the most contentious exception: cyber espionage. Unlike relative sovereignty, which generally permits non-harmful espionage, pure sovereignty categorically forbids all unauthorized intrusions, regardless of their objective or harm. Heller rebuts the notion that states require unregulated cyber espionage for legitimate purposes, arguing it inflicts economic damage, erodes trust, and fuels instability. He further considers policy ramifications, acknowledging the challenge of achieving universal consensus among 193 U.N. member states and the management of residual grey zones, while urging future empirical study of state countermeasure practices and the development of institutional compliance mechanisms. Concluding that pure sovereignty offers a superior legal and policy framework, Heller asserts that all states—powerful and weak alike—benefit from an unambiguous, rule-based prohibition on non-consensual cyber intrusions in cyberspace.

title: Cyberspace and non-state actors: the state's international obligation
source: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research
abstract: This article examines the evolving obligations of States under international law to prevent and respond to malicious cyber operations conducted by non-State actors. It begins by situating cyberspace within the framework of international humanitarian law, noting the traditional distinction between international armed conflicts (between States) and non-international armed conflicts (between States and organized armed groups). The author surveys foundational definitions of armed conflict, including Oppenheim’s early twentieth-century conception and the Geneva Conventions’ common Articles 2 and 3, to explore whether cyber-attacks can trigger the threshold of ‘armed conflict’ despite their non-kinetic nature. Drawing on the International Committee of the Red Cross’s recognition that disabling acts may constitute ‘attacks’ absent physical damage, as well as jurisprudence from the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (notably the Tadić case on State organ attribution and ‘overall control’), the article argues that cyber operations disabling critical infrastructure may qualify as ‘attacks’ under Additional Protocol I and thus meet the armed-conflict threshold when attributable to State organs or those exercising overall control. The core of the paper is a detailed analysis of the customary due diligence obligation of States to prevent their cyber infrastructure from facilitating transboundary malicious acts by non-State actors. The author synthesizes doctrinal sources—including treaties such as the Council of Europe’s Convention on Cybercrime, the Corfu Channel decision, and the Pulp Mills judgment—to distill the twofold nature of this obligation: first, a permanent requirement to maintain a legal and administrative apparatus capable of controlling cyber activities; and second, a reactive duty to investigate and punish wrongful acts once a State has knowledge of them. Through a doctrinal methodology, the paper clarifies the content of due diligence in cyberspace, identifying ‘knowledge’ of a threat as a threshold element, and assessing the standard of care by reference to States’ available resources, technical capacity, and existing cyber infrastructure. The article underscores that due diligence does not demand perfect prevention but rather reasonable measures within a State’s means, cautioning against disproportionate burdens on less technologically advanced nations. The author highlights gaps in current State practice, noting the limitations of soft-law mechanisms like the Global Forum on Cyber Expertise, and argues for the negotiation of a dedicated international treaty outlining specific State obligations in cyberspace. The conclusion calls for harmonized legal norms, enhanced cooperation among States, industry, and civil society, and further empirical research to refine the due diligence standard and ensure accountability for cyber operations crossing international boundaries. By articulating a nuanced characterization of State due diligence in the cyber domain, this article contributes a foundational legal framework for regulating cyber conflict and guiding future treaty negotiations.

title: Foreign cyber interference in elections
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract: Foreign Cyber Interference in Elections by Michael N. Schmitt addresses the pressing challenge posed by state-sponsored cyber-enabled influence operations targeting democratic elections. Drawing on the 2016 and 2020 U.S. presidential contests—where Russia deployed sophisticated online campaigns to undermine public confidence and Iran sought to weaken support for President Trump—the study situates these incidents within a broader, global pattern of election meddling. Schmitt employs a doctrinal methodology rooted in treaty analysis, customary international law scholarship, and state practice to examine how existing rules of international law apply to cyber operations intended to manipulate both the technical infrastructure of elections and the informational environment surrounding them. Part II analyzes interference as a violation of international law along four axes: attribution, the prohibition of intervention, sovereignty protections, and human rights obligations. The author explores state attribution thresholds and confirms that operations attributable to a state that seek to manipulate public perceptions or disrupt electoral infrastructure can contravene non-intervention and sovereignty norms. He further argues that human rights instruments impose due diligence and positive obligations on states to prevent third-party interference that jeopardizes rights such as free political participation. Part III examines positive obligations in depth, distinguishing between general international law due diligence duties—triggered by ongoing or imminent cyber threats—and broader human rights obligations that demand anticipatory measures to safeguard electoral integrity. Schmitt underscores that protective obligations extend to all individuals within a state’s territory, even when harm originates from abroad, and highlights the challenge of extraterritorial protection. Part IV surveys response options available to victim states, from domestic regulatory measures regulating social media and countering disinformation to international dispute settlement, including recourse to the International Court of Justice or human rights bodies. Schmitt evaluates self-help measures under international law, contrasting retorsion—unfriendly but lawful responses such as sanctions and diplomatic expulsions employed by the Obama administration in 2016—with countermeasures, which require proof of attribution and a prior breach, and must observe proportionality, necessity, and temporal sequence. He also considers the plea of necessity for grave and imminent threats to essential state interests, illustrating the limited circumstances under which states may lawfully employ otherwise prohibited measures to halt ongoing election interference. In his conclusion, Schmitt elucidates the ‘‘fog of law’’ complicating definitive legal characterizations of cyber electoral interference, driven by evidentiary uncertainties and unsettled norm development. He calls for further empirical and normative work to refine attribution methodologies, clarify state practice on countermeasures, and build multilateral consensus—through treaty negotiations and customary crystallization—to fortify the international legal order against malign electoral interference in cyberspace.

title: The Dog That Did Not Bark, the Dog That Did Bark, and the Dog That Should Have Barked: A Methodology for Cyber Deterrence Research
abstract: The study addresses the critical challenge of understanding and researching cyber deterrence amid the growing significance of state and non-state cyber operations in international conflict. Scholars have long recognized that traditional deterrence theory struggles when applied to the cyber domain, where secrecy, ambiguity, and novel interaction patterns complicate the identification of deterrence success or failure. This article matters because without rigorous methodological tools, the field cannot systematically evaluate how states deter cyber aggression, undermining both theoretical development and effective policy formation. The author’s primary objective is to overcome entrenched methodological biases, particularly the focus on discernible failure cases, by redirecting research toward the observable adoption and employment of deterrence strategies. The core research question asks how a focus on strategy adoption can provide a more tractable and informative approach for studying cyber deterrence. To answer this, the author employs an analytical methodology grounded in conceptual analysis and a comprehensive review of existing deterrence literature, drawing on case examples and theoretical debates across positivist and interpretive paradigms. The author first revisits the three ‘‘dog’’ problems—cases that do not involve observable attacks (the dog that did not bark), ambiguous implications of cyber incidents (the dog that did bark), and undetected failures (the dog that should have barked)—to map the key methodological obstacles. Through comparative literature review and conceptual categorization, the article demonstrates that secrecy and attribution challenges in cyberspace exacerbate traditional biases, leading scholars to overemphasize failure and ignore strategies that successfully deter attacks. The findings reveal that focusing on the communicative act of issuing deterrent threats and the concrete measures states adopt for cyber deterrence—such as legal frameworks, public declarations, and institutional structures—offers a clearer empirical basis than attempting to infer success from the absence or presence of specific cyber incidents. By classifying adoption and employment along dimensions of explicitness, means, goals, and operational type, the author proposes a novel framework that both clarifies empirical research designs and accommodates methodological pluralism. This framework advances the literature by shifting the explanandum from the elusive outcome of deterrence to the strategy’s observable initiation and implementation. Limitations of this study include its conceptual orientation without direct empirical testing of the proposed framework and potential gaps in capturing covert or informal deterrence practices. The author acknowledges that establishing causal links between strategy adoption and deterrence outcomes remains a long-term research goal. Future research should apply the framework in case studies across diverse geopolitical contexts, develop quantitative indicators for strategy adoption, and integrate insights from practice-oriented actors. By doing so, scholars can build cumulative knowledge on how states articulate and operationalize cyber deterrence, thereby strengthening both theory and policy guidance for managing strategic competition in the digital domain.

title: Cyber warfare: a bane of the modern era
source: International Journal of Law Management & Humanities
abstract: This article offers a detailed doctrinal analysis of the international legal framework governing the use of force in cyberspace, examining whether and how traditional jus ad bellum and jus in bello norms apply to cyber operations that may amount to armed attacks or violations of humanitarian law. Drawing on treaty law, customary international law, state practice, and authoritative doctrine, the author surveys historical case studies, including the 2007 cyber attacks on Estonia and alleged U.S.–China cyber incidents, to illustrate the challenges of classifying disruptive cyber operations under the United Nations Charter’s prohibition on the use of force. Three analytical models are evaluated: (1) binary kinetic equivalence, which treats cyber acts causing effects akin to kinetic force as armed attacks; (2) overall effects assessment, which gauges the scale and impact of cyber operations on critical national infrastructure and equates significant economic or functional disruption with an armed attack; and (3) strict liability for any harmful intrusion against critical infrastructure. While proponents differ on thresholds, they converge on the view that certain cyber actions can constitute armed attacks justifying self-defense. The article then critically examines the traditional requirement of conclusive attribution to hold states responsible for cyber operations, noting the anonymity and technical complexity of cyberspace. It documents the evolution of imputed state responsibility doctrines toward an “indirect responsibility” standard, whereby states breach an emerging duty to prevent their territories from serving as sanctuaries for non-state actors when they fail to enact criminal legislation, cooperate in investigations, and otherwise deter cyber aggression. Under this standard, victim states may lawfully employ “active defenses” against cyber threats emanating from sanctuary states, subject to necessity and proportionality. The author argues that decisions to deploy active defenses should be centralized within national leadership structures rather than delegated to system operators, to adequately weigh legal and political risks. The conclusion emphasizes the necessity of developing standardized rules of engagement for cyber operations, legislative measures criminalizing malicious activity, and enhanced transnational cooperation to refine attribution thresholds and balance rapid response capabilities with adherence to international legal norms. Recognizing unresolved challenges in source identification and the risk of misattribution, the article calls for further scholarly work and policy development to ensure that states can manage cyber conflict effectively within the bounds of international law.

title: Cyberspace is used, first and foremost, to wage wars: proliferation, security and stability in cyberspace
abstract:
In “Cyberspace is used, first and foremost, to wage wars: proliferation, security and stability in cyberspace,” Frédérick Douzet and Aude Géry offer a comprehensive geopolitical and policy-oriented analysis of how and why cyberspace has become a strategic battleground for states over the last decade. The article begins by recounting the rapid transformation of the digital environment—from its revolutionary impacts on economics, society, and individual liberties to its current threat of weaponization under state-sponsored cyber operations and the proliferation of offensive cybertools. Drawing on the metaphor of Yves Lacoste—“geography, first of all, serves the purpose of waging war”—the authors argue that cyberspace has undergone a similar militarization and territorialization, driven by states’ urgent need to respond to strategic surprises and to cement their power in a domain once considered beyond traditional geopolitical rivalries. The authors trace this evolution through key milestones, including high-profile intrusions, distributed denial-of-service campaigns, ransomware outbreaks, and information-influence operations, which collectively illustrate both the growing sophistication of cyberattacks and the systemic risks they pose to global stability.

Central to their argument is the security dilemma faced by states: efforts to defend national networks and develop offensive capabilities invariably trigger escalatory dynamics, leading adversaries to harden their own cyber arsenals and prompting further militarization. The article examines how Western democracies, in framing cybersecurity primarily through a national security lens, have privileged military responses—even as they acknowledge the broader economic, criminal, and individual-rights dimensions of cyber threats. This tension is analyzed through the conceptual framework of securitization, as formulated by Barry Buzan and Ole Wæver, which highlights how political actors construct cybersecurity as an existential threat requiring extraordinary measures.

Douzet and Géry then turn to the multilateral governance landscape, showing how the very security dilemma that intensified militarization also spurred international negotiations aimed at regulating state behavior in cyberspace. They document a proliferation of initiatives—from United Nations General Assembly resolutions and Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) processes to the Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG), the “Paris Call” hosted by France, and private sector proposals like Microsoft’s “Digital Geneva Convention.” Rather than converging on a single binding treaty, these efforts have multiplied, reflecting divergent state interests: some favor strengthening systemic-resilience measures to curb the proliferation of cyberweapons, while others resist constraints that would limit their offensive freedom. The result is a complex, crowded field of norms-building exercises that risks inconsistency and undercutting state accountability, even as it raises awareness of cyberstability’s critical importance.

The article concludes that despite ongoing negotiations and the growing involvement of civil society and industry, the representation of cyberspace as a geopolitical risk continues to eclipse the perception of systemic risk. States remain reluctant to forego offensive cyber capabilities that they deem essential to their security. Consequently, the authors warn, the arms-race logic will persist, and cyberspace will remain “first and foremost” a domain for conducting dissimulation of power and conflict. Only by reconciling geopolitical rivalries with robust, binding norms to manage proliferation can the international community hope to stabilize the digital sphere on which modern societies so heavily depend.

title: Redefining deterrence in cyberspace: private sector contribution to national strategies of cyber deterrence
abstract: This article argues that national cyber deterrence strategies cannot be fully effective unless they incorporate private sector contributions alongside traditional state-centric measures. Deterrence in cyberspace faces unique obstacles — difficulties in timely and accurate attribution, an uncertain offense–defense balance, rapid technological innovation, and the predominantly private ownership of critical infrastructure. To address these challenges, the author develops a novel conceptual framework, “RCDC Deterrence,” which refines classical deterrence theory into four interrelated dimensions: Restrictive measures that limit adversary capabilities; Comprehensive measures integrating multiple instruments; Dynamic measures adapting to evolving threats; and Complemental measures leveraging synergies between state and non-state actors. Through a critical literature review spanning four research clusters (applicability of deterrence in cyberspace, offense–defense balance, cyber denial strategies, and norms development), the article systematically identifies and analyzes specific areas where private actors can bolster each RCDC dimension. In the Restrictive dimension, private entities can deploy advanced defensive technologies and share threat intelligence to raise the cost of attacks. Under the Comprehensive dimension, joint exercises and incident response collaborations expand resilience and signaling capacities. For Dynamic deterrence, private firms’ rapid attribution capabilities reduce attacker ambiguity by publicly associating malicious activity with actors, thereby strengthening the credibility of potential responses. In the Complemental dimension, public–private partnerships combine early warning with coordinated policy responses to enhance collective signaling. The article also critically examines legal, ethical, and security concerns: proprietary data sharing constraints, unclear legal authorities for active defense, conflicting profit motives versus national security priorities, and accountability deficits. While private sector engagement can enhance situational awareness, accelerate attribution, and multiply deterrent signals, it also risks governance gaps and liability uncertainties. The author concludes that integrating private contributions demands robust legal frameworks, ethical oversight, and clear policy design to align incentives and safeguard public interests. By mapping these contribution areas and exposing inter-dimensional synergies, this research enriches understanding of cyber deterrence and offers a strategic roadmap for policymakers. The article calls for empirical case studies of public–private deterrence initiatives, comparative assessments of jurisdictional legal frameworks governing private cyber operations, and modeling of private–public signaling effects on adversary decision-making. Such studies will refine the RCDC framework and support evidence-based policies that maximize cooperative benefits while mitigating risks, ultimately advancing a multidisciplinary approach to cyber conflict management.

title: #SorryNotSorry: why states neither confirm nor deny responsibility for cyber operations
abstract: Brown and Fazal’s article examines the pervasive use of ‘non-denial denials’ and ‘non-comments’ by states accused of conducting malicious cyber operations, arguing that these strategies constitute a distinct middle category of public signal between clear denial and outright admission. Drawing on a random sample of 164 cyberattack cases from the Valeriano–Maness database and in-depth qualitative case studies—such as Russia’s responses to allegations of meddling in the 2016 U.S. election, China’s reaction to suspected interference in India’s power grid, and the United States and Israel’s handling of the Stuxnet revelation—the authors trace how ambiguous public statements shape rival states’ perceptions of capability and resolve. They note that existing cyber conflict literature treats attribution as a binary choice, overlooking these ambiguous signals that allow perpetrator states to avoid the escalation risks of admission while preserving the benefits of remaining a suspect. Through systematic coding of government statements, press conferences, and public communications, the study reveals that strategic ambiguity serves two primary functions: first, it maintains crisis stability by averting the political fallout and legal liabilities that would follow an explicit admission; second, it operates as a form of costly signaling, prompting rivals to update beliefs about the perpetrator’s technical proficiency and willingness to absorb reputational costs. The authors also show how non-denial denials and non-comments reinforce deterrence within alliance settings by diffusing perceived capabilities among partners, as illustrated by NATO’s Cyber Defence Pledge and the joint U.S.–U.K. statement condemning Russian cyber aggression. Brown and Fazal develop an inductive theoretical framework that conceptualizes ambiguous signals as a strategic tool for coercion in cyberspace and extend insights from kinetic conflict theory—such as covert action and costly signaling—to the cyber domain. They address empirical challenges, including selection biases in publicly known cases and the difficulty of predicting when states will employ ambiguity, and outline avenues for future research: quantitative testing of hypotheses about the frequency of ambiguous signaling relative to strategic rivalry intensity, alliance asymmetry, and capability novelty; evaluation of the effectiveness of non-denial denials in achieving intended deterrent effects; and exploration of analogous signaling strategies in conventional conflict. The authors conclude that, far from being an accidental by-product of cyber’s opacity, strategic ambiguity is a deliberate diplomatic instrument that enhances the utility of cyber operations for coercive purposes, and they anticipate that such signaling strategies will remain a fixture of international cyber diplomacy.

title: 'Cyber Due Diligence': A Patchwork of Protective Obligations in International Law
authors: A Coco; Talita de Souza Dias
abstract: Amid rising geopolitical tensions marked by state-sponsored cyber espionage, ransomware attacks, and assaults on critical infrastructure, the concept of due diligence has emerged as a potential mechanism to hold states accountable for malicious cyber operations emanating from or transiting through their territories in the absence of definitive attribution. The absence of a universally agreed binding rule has generated binary debates over the existence of a distinct cyber due diligence norm, leading to legal uncertainty and impeding coherent policy responses. This article therefore addresses the pressing need to clarify states’ substantive obligations in cyberspace by shifting the focus from debates over terminology to an examination of the existing protective obligations embedded in international law. The authors aim to answer whether, irrespective of a standalone cyber-specific norm, states already bear binding duties to protect other states and individuals from cyber harms, and if so, what their scope and nature are. Employing a doctrinal research methodology, the study systematically analyses primary rules and principles drawn from state practice, judicial decisions, treaty provisions, customary law scholarship and authoritative instruments such as the 2015 UN GGE report and the Tallinn Manual 2.0. It revisits traditional cases including the Corfu Channel and Pulp Mills decisions, surveys state statements in UN open-ended working groups, and assesses general comments and articles of the ILC on prevention. The research identifies four interlocking clusters of due diligence duties applicable by default in cyberspace. First, the duty arising from the Corfu Channel principle obliges states not to knowingly permit their territory or infrastructure to be used for wrongful cyber activities that infringe the rights of other states. Second, the no-harm principle requires states to employ reasonable measures to prevent, halt and remedy significant transboundary cyber harms, even if caused by lawful acts. Third, the positive human rights obligation mandates states to protect individuals’ rights within their jurisdiction against cyber threats, adapting established IHRL frameworks to the digital domain. Fourth, the humanitarian law duty compels parties in armed conflict to respect IHL in cyber operations and to adopt practicable precautions against the effects of cyberattacks under customary rules and Additional Protocol I. These obligations share core features: they presuppose state sovereignty or control, are limited by capacity-based feasibility, entail both conduct and result obligations through legislative, judicial and executive mechanisms, and are triggered by varying thresholds from actual knowledge to objective foreseeability of harm. The study’s principal contribution is a coherent framework that reconceptualises cyber due diligence as a patchwork of binding protective obligations rather than a single contested rule, thereby providing policy-relevant clarity and a foundation for norm development. The authors acknowledge limitations inherent in the fragmentation of duties across multiple legal regimes, potential inconsistencies in interpretative approaches, and the evolving nature of cyber threats outpacing legal adaptation. As future research, they propose systematic scholarship on harmonising overlapping obligations into a general principle of due diligence in cyberspace, empirical analysis of states’ implementation practices, and exploration of treaty or customary avenues for codifying a unified cyber due diligence rule that builds on existing protective norms.

title: Deterrence in the cyber realm: public versus private cyber capacity
abstract: This article examines the potential of public cyberinstitutions (PCIs) as a novel mechanism for deterring strategic cyberattacks, defined as operations causing significant harm to a nation’s economy and security. Building on the challenges of attribution and the transient value of covert cyberoperations, the author argues that states—particularly middle powers with limited cyber arsenals—can deploy publicly observable, proactive efforts (PCIs) to signal their offensive and defensive cybercapacities without exhausting secret vulnerabilities. Kostyuk develops an incomplete-information signaling game in which a challenger assesses whether to attack a defender of uncertain cyber strength. The defender allocates scarce resources between covert cyber capabilities and PCIs: the latter serve as a costly signal that shapes the attacker’s beliefs. The model yields multiple equilibria and identifies three challenger types: disinterested (no strategic motive to attack), undeterred (attack regardless of perceived strength), and opportunistic (attack only if the defender appears weak). PCIs are ineffective against disinterested challengers, who never attack, and against undeterred challengers, who attack regardless of public signaling. However, PCIs can deter opportunistic challengers when two conditions are met: the challenger believes the defender’s actual cyber capacity is substantial and is sensitive to the marginal costs imposed by PCIs. Under these conditions, both weak and strong middle powers tend to overinvest in PCIs—weak states to mimic strength, strong states to avoid appearing as weak pretenders—resulting in suboptimal overall cyber capacity but achieving deterrence through signaling. The article illustrates these dynamics through election interference case studies: Sweden’s extensive PCIs preceding its 2018 election (budget increases to agencies, new interagency forums, public awareness campaigns, and development of offensive and defensive tools) successfully deterred Russian interference by raising perceived costs; Germany’s 2017 PCIs failed to deter a disinterested Russia due to non-cyber factors (media resilience, political polarization, electoral system features) that made interference unattractive; and France’s 2017 PCIs were ineffective against an undeterred Russia, for which the strategic benefits of influence outweighed any anticipated costs. Kostyuk’s work contributes to cyber-conflict scholarship by introducing PCIs as a third signaling mechanism distinct from attribution and covert operations, integrating cyber deterrence into bargaining models of conflict, and highlighting the role of information asymmetries, signaling costs, and resource allocation decisions. The study cautions policymakers against overreliance on PCIs, emphasizing comprehensive assessments of adversary incentives and the need for credible retaliation commitments, and suggests extensions to dynamic, multi-stage models and differentiation between defensive and offensive signaling.

title: Conventional attack vs digital attack in the light of international law
source: Polish Review of International and European Law
abstract: In “Conventional Attack vs Digital Attack in the Light of International Law,” Bobrowski undertakes a doctrinal analysis to expose the inadequacies of existing definitions of aggression—most prominently the 1933 Convention for the Definition of Aggression and UNGA Resolution 3314 (XXIX) of 1974—when applied to cyber operations. Building on a comprehensive review of legal instruments, treaty practice, judicial commentary, and scholarly literature, the author traces the evolution of the classical concept of aggression, which remains territorially bound, state-centric, and predicated on the physical use of force. Bobrowski demonstrates that these instruments fail to capture the a-territorial, remote, and often indirect nature of cyber operations, especially those carried out by non-state actors or carried out through proxy contractors. The article articulates the conceptual limitations encountered when attempting to classify digital intrusions and disruptions as armed attacks under current international law, highlighting the inability of traditional frameworks to attribute responsibility or justify countermeasures in cyberspace. Confronting these shortcomings, Bobrowski proposes a set of lege ferenda postulates to recalibrate the legal regime: first, expanding the definition of “aggressor” to encompass non-state entities and contracted perpetrators; second, reconceiving “territory” in cyberspace by introducing the notion of “functional state territory”—the arena of IT operations essential to a state’s strategic infrastructure; third, specifying criteria for conduct that rises to the level of cyber aggression by distinguishing between disruptions with material or strategic effects and lesser intrusions; and fourth, formulating evidentiary standards for attributing cyber operations to states through proof of institutional complicity or indirect involvement. The author also considers the state’s responsibility for omissions when it fails to prevent non-state cyber assaults and underscores the UNSC’s central role in authoritative determinations of aggression. While noting challenges such as evidentiary burdens and discretionary thresholds, Bobrowski’s framework offers a coherent model for aligning the law of armed conflict and state responsibility with the realities of digital conflict, thus contributing significantly to the emerging field of international cyber law and policy.

title: Attribution and knowledge creation assemblages in cybersecurity politics
abstract: This article investigates the centrality of attribution in cybersecurity politics by reframing it as a contingent, politically charged knowledge creation process rather than a purely technical exercise. Drawing on a post-positivist, critical security studies perspective and assemblage theory, the authors propose that attribution judgments—public declarations about who is responsible for cyber intrusions—emerge through dynamic, heterogeneous “knowledge creation assemblages” that coalesce technical data, organizational practices, and pre-existing political narratives. Through qualitative document analysis of publicly available technical reports, government statements, and secondary literature on the 2014–15 Office of Personnel Management (OPM) intrusions, the study traces the phased evolution of attribution across incident creation, incident response, and public attribution. In the incident creation phase, initial uncertainties about compromise paths are funneled through established network forensic practices and threat actor profiles, privileging actor-centric methods that rely on known adversary signatures. During the incident response phase, private cybersecurity firms and public agencies entangle, jointly interpreting telemetry and intelligence feeds; their shared assumptions about likely perpetrators reinforce dominant narratives and channel analytic focus toward familiar state rivals. In the public attribution phase, governmental statements and commercial threat reports converge to stabilize a “truth” that is then disseminated and contested within scholarly and international policy communities. The authors identify three interrelated lenses through which these assemblages operate: (1) assumptions about threat actors, which privilege existing enemy images and occlude novel or non-state actors; (2) the entanglement of public and private knowledge producers, who mutually reinforce analytic frameworks and politico-economic interests; and (3) variable practices of self-reflection and uncertainty management, which determine how much ambiguity is acknowledged or suppressed at each stage. Applying these lenses to the OPM case reveals that reliance on established threat profiles produced feedback loops—between proprietary telemetry and official analytics—that entrenched attributions to strategic state rivals; meanwhile, discrepancies between private-sector reports and academic analyses hinted at alternative actors and unresolved uncertainties. The study contributes to cybersecurity politics by demonstrating that attribution verdicts are neither objective nor neutral but are temporarily stabilized through networks of co-functioning human, technical, and institutional elements. The authors call for greater transparency and reflexivity in attribution assemblages, advocating for the inclusion of independent academic data collectors and alternative forensic artefacts to diversify threat images and challenge prevailing knowledge structures. This intervention seeks to open the attribution discourse to alternative perspectives, thereby informing more nuanced cyber policy and lawmaking in international security.

title: Cyber conflict vs. Cyber command: hidden dangers in the american military solution to a large-scale intelligence problem
abstract: In “Cyber Conflict vs. Cyber Command: Hidden Dangers in the American Military Solution to a Large-Scale Intelligence Problem,” Jon R. Lindsay examines the institutional and conceptual mismatch that arises from framing cyber operations exclusively as military activities under U.S. Cyber Command (CYBERCOM), despite their substantive resemblance to traditional intelligence and secret statecraft. Lindsay traces the evolution of cyber operations metaphors—from early analogies equating cyberspace to strategic bombing and weapons of mass destruction through contemporary notions of ‘persistent engagement’—and finds these warfighting frames ill-suited to the realities of digital intrusions, espionage, deception, and gray-zone influence campaigns. Through a historical and conceptual analysis grounded in public doctrine documents (Joint Publication 3-12, CYBERCOM’s vision statements), Title 10 (military) versus Title 50 (intelligence) legal distinctions, and the operational interplay between CYBERCOM and the National Security Agency (NSA), the study reveals that CYBERCOM’s insistence on a military identity creates a category mistake. Lindsay synthesizes scholarship on intelligence theory—particularly Michael Warner’s definition of intelligence as secret statecraft characterized by deception, clandestinity, and sovereign strategic benefit—and applies it to digital operations. He argues that despite CYBERCOM’s legal foundation as a unified combatant command, its operations (computer network exploitation, clandestine reconnaissance, digital influence, and defensive cyber maneuvers) mirror covert action, counterintelligence, and espionage at an unprecedented scale. By treating these activities as overt military maneuvers, CYBERCOM risks conceptual confusion that undermines both intelligence effectiveness and civilian oversight, and potentially erodes vital legal safeguards protecting covert methods. Lindsay demonstrates how metaphoric framing shapes bureaucratic structure, mission justification, and policy accountability: the military domain metaphor compels CYBERCOM to develop doctrines, tactics, and narratives aligned with warfighting—even when the core activities demand secrecy and deniability to achieve strategic advantage. This misalignment, he contends, may weaken intelligence governance, diminish clarity regarding authorities and oversight, and impair strategic policymaking. The paper contributes to cyber policy and multidisciplinary conflict studies by reframing cyber operations as a form of secret statecraft or digital deception, urging scholars and practitioners to realign organizational arrangements, legal frameworks, and doctrinal metaphors with the true nature of cyber activities. Lindsay acknowledges the U.S.‒centric focus and calls for comparative analyses of other national cyber-intelligence institutions, empirical assessments of doctrinal impact on operational outcomes, and exploration of alternative institutional designs that balance the dual imperatives of secrecy and accountability. By illuminating the hidden dangers of a military solution to what is fundamentally an intelligence problem, the article offers a critical policy lens for enhancing strategic coherence, legal clarity, and effective governance of state-sponsored cyber conflict.
