title: Non-violent cyber attacks: a contravention of article 2(4)?
abstract: Joshua Wood’s article examines whether non-violent cyber attacks—defined as state-sponsored operations that disrupt or corrupt another state’s computer networks to inflict non-physical damage—fall within the prohibition against the use of force under Article 2(4) of the United Nations Charter. Wood begins by applying the textual and contextual rules of treaty interpretation in Article 31 of the Vienna Convention, finding that the Charter’s framers intended “force” to refer to armed, kinetic actions typical of the 1940s, as evidenced by preambular language on “armed force,” the linkage of “use of force” to Article 44’s armed contingents, and the rejection of Brazilian proposals to include economic coercion in Article 2(4). He then assesses the potential for a “living instrument” approach—interpreting the Charter in light of modern cyber coercive capacities—and concludes that state practice and opinio juris remain too inconsistent to support a broad, contemporary reading. In examining customary international law, Wood surveys General Assembly resolutions and state statements, noting that while some states advocate that non-violent cyber operations contravene Article 2(4), their conduct often contradicts such positions. Employing an effects-based analogy, he compares non-violent cyber attacks to economic blockades—unilateral coercive measures recognized as uses of force under customary law—and finds moderate support for extending the analogy, given similar gradual economic and infrastructural harms. However, critical differences—namely the absence of overt physical threat and the clandestine nature of cyber tools—undermine a fully parallel classification. Wood acknowledges limitations stemming from the lack of clear treaty amendments, uniform state practice, and judicial precedent, and calls for continued monitoring of evolving state practice, the development of dedicated cyber norms or treaties, further refinement of analogies with other non-kinetic measures, and analysis of how emerging cyber capabilities might shape jus ad bellum interpretation. This systematic doctrinal study clarifies the ambiguity surrounding cyber coercion under Article 2(4) and highlights the need for more consistent international legal responses to non-violent cyber operations.

title: Regulating the Use and Conduct of Cyber Operations through International Law: Challenges and Fact-Finding Body Proposal
abstract: Cyber operations have emerged as a novel and increasingly prominent strategic instrument in interstate and asymmetric conflict, offering states the ability to inflict physical, economic, and political harm while avoiding the escalation to conventional warfare. The absence of a binding international consensus on the regulation of such operations alongside competing national approaches has fostered a security dilemma in cyberspace, in which states’ efforts to enhance their cyber defenses paradoxically heighten perceived vulnerability and spur an arms race in offensive cyber capabilities. This research addresses the pressing need to evaluate the extent to which existing international legal regimes can govern both the use and the conduct of cyber operations and explores alternative mechanisms for filling regulatory lacunae. It seeks to answer two core questions: What theoretical limits constrain the extension of existing jus ad bellum, non-intervention, and self-determination principles to cyber use, and what obstacles impede the application of International Humanitarian Law to the destructive effects of cyber warfare? Moreover, how might an independent fact-finding body contribute to the development of norms and reduce legal indeterminacy in cyberspace? Employing a doctrinal legal analysis enriched by insights from international relations theory, the article first examines three categories of internationally wrongful acts—use of force, non-intervention, and violation of self-determination—to demonstrate that traditional legal classifications struggle to capture the full scope of cyber-enabled state behavior. It then analyzes the character of cyber warfare and the structural features of contemporary societies to show that the principles of distinction, proportionality, and precaution under IHL are ill-suited to mitigate civilian harm arising from non-physical cyber effects. Finally, it assesses the political feasibility of a binding international cyber treaty, concluding that geopolitical rivalries and divergent strategic incentives render such an instrument unlikely. The analysis finds that although existing international law offers a conceptual framework for condemning certain cyber attacks, it lacks both the theoretical reach to define many cyber operations as internationally wrongful and the practical mechanisms to constrain their humanitarian impact. As a novel contribution, the paper proposes establishing an independent, non-enforcement fact-finding body tasked with investigating significant cyber incidents, publishing transparent reports, and thereby catalyzing the gradual crystallization of customary norms and state practice. While the proposal circumvents the political hurdles of treaty-making and leverages state reactions to informal investigations, the author acknowledges limitations, including the body’s absence of enforcement authority and reliance on voluntary cooperation and state responses to shape opinio juris. Future research is suggested to explore optimal institutional design for the proposed body, strategies to secure widespread state participation, and empirical assessment of how investigative findings influence state behavior and norm formation in the evolving cyber domain.

title: Cyberwar is What States Make of It
abstract: States increasingly capitalize on ambiguity in cyberspace to frame and legitimize cyber operations, creating a strategic environment where perceptions of cyberwarfare can be as consequential as technical realities. The article identifies this trend as a critical problem given the growing frequency and geopolitical significance of alleged state-sponsored cyberattacks, illustrated by high-profile incidents such as the Venezuelan grid outage in 2019, contested Russian and U.S. intrusions into critical infrastructure, and disruptive campaigns against Ukraine’s power network. Justification for this research rests on the need to understand how governments leverage uncertainty around attribution and operational success to advance policy objectives, influence domestic and international audiences, and develop emergent norms in the absence of transparent third-party confirmation. The author explicitly asks how state behavior and information packaging shape the evolving character of cyber conflict and what strategic options this leaves for future confrontations. Methodologically, the work employs a conceptual and case-based analytical approach, drawing on open-source reporting, government statements, news accounts, and intelligence leaks to construct a comparative narrative across multiple state actors. By synthesizing these case studies, the author examines patterns in attribution claims, denial strategies, and public framing efforts. Findings indicate that states often claim or disclaim responsibility for cyber operations not solely on the basis of factual evidence but to serve broader political aims: bolstering domestic legitimacy, deterring adversaries through ambiguity, or testing the resilience of opponents’ critical networks while avoiding escalatory backlash. This behavior transforms cyberwar into a socially constructed phenomenon where truth contests are waged as fiercely as technological offensives, leaving strategic misperceptions unchecked. The primary contribution lies in conceptualizing cyberwar as a co-authored state narrative, wherein governments act as both participants in and narrators of conflict, thereby shaping international norms and expectations. This framework challenges traditional deterrence and jus ad bellum paradigms by highlighting the dual role of information manipulation alongside technical capability. The author acknowledges limitations related to reliance on publicly available sources, the difficulty of verifying contested events, and the absence of a quantitative metric for packaging efficacy. Additionally, the analysis is bounded by the selectivity of illustrative cases and does not account for less visible operations. For future research, the article suggests empirical studies to measure the impact of state-sponsored narratives on adversary behavior, investigations into third-party verification mechanisms, and the development of normative frameworks to mitigate strategic deception in cyberspace. Such work would inform international law debates and guide policy on attribution, transparency, and stable deterrence strategies in an increasingly contested digital domain.

title: Entanglement in cyberspace: minding the deterrence gap
abstract: This paper addresses the unique challenges of deterrence in cyberspace by proposing a novel ‘‘deterrence-by-entanglement’’ framework that shifts the emphasis from traditional threat and denial models to one based on mutual interdependence. Conventional deterrence relies on credible threats of punishment or denial capabilities to elevate adversary costs, but in the cyber domain these approaches face severe constraints—anonymous and low-visibility intrusions, difficulties in attribution, asymmetric resources among state actors, and the prominent role of non-state participants. Against this backdrop, the author integrates Snyder’s ‘‘broad deterrence’’ concept with Keohane and Nye’s complex interdependence theory to conceptualize entanglement as patterns of cross-border cyber interaction—shared infrastructure, joint vulnerability disclosures, co-development of defensive platforms, and cooperative incident response—that create systemic ties through which offensive operations incur prohibitive economic, political, and security costs. Methodologically, the study adopts a conceptual and theoretical approach, synthesizing strategic deterrence scholarship, alliance formation literature, and cyber capabilities development research to construct a comprehensive model. The analysis identifies specific mechanisms by which entanglement fosters self-deterrent behavior: establishing positive reciprocity through shared norms, embedding states in networks of operational dependencies, and cultivating mutual opportunity costs that diminish adversaries’ risk appetite. These mechanisms reduce the expected benefits of offensive cyber actions relative to the potential fallout, encouraging restraint by aligning individual state incentives with collective stability. The paper further delineates conditions under which entanglement is likely to succeed—strong baseline interdependence, mutual willingness to bear integration costs, and compatible threat perceptions—and highlights scenarios where it may falter, such as zero-sum mindsets, asymmetric strategic interests, or low interdependence contexts. Finally, the author calls for empirical case studies to operationalize the entanglement framework, development of quantitative metrics for interdependence thresholds, and exploration of institutional pathways for embedding entanglement within multilateral cyber governance. This work contributes to cyber policy discourse by offering a dynamic, multidisciplinary deterrence model that complements existing portfolios and seeks to bridge the ‘‘deterrence gap’’ in the digital age.

title: Usefulness of cyber attribution indicators
source: European Conference on Cyber Warfare and Security
abstract: This paper provides an empirical and theoretical investigation of attribution practices in state-sponsored cyber operations, with a focus on understanding how technical and political indicators are used in public attributions and the implications these practices carry for policy and strategic decision-making. Utilizing the Council on Foreign Relations Cyber Operations Tracker, the study selects 45 recorded state-sponsored operations from 2017 and systematically analyzes open-source reports—ranging from major news outlets and cybersecurity vendor analyses to government documents—to extract and categorize attribution statements. The categorization framework is grounded in the Q model of attribution indicators developed by Rid and Buchanan (2015), which encompasses over a hundred questions across dimensions such as infrastructure, capabilities, motivations, and observable behavior. The analysis reveals that attributions predominantly rely on technical footprints, including IP addresses, malware signatures, language settings, and resource requirements, complemented by geopolitical assessments of apparent political objectives. However, these indicators often suffer from weak or circular evidentiary foundations: false flags, deliberate obfuscation, and reliance on prior attributions undermine measurement accuracy and scientific rigor. The paper further highlights the significant risks associated with public attributions of nation-states. Accusers face a power differential that may jeopardize sensitive sources and methods, and public finger-pointing may provoke escalation without enhancing deterrence. In exploring the interdisciplinary literature on attribution—spanning the Diamond Model, Cyber Kill Chain, and various intelligence agency frameworks—the paper situates its findings within broader discussions on the need for standardized, scientifically transparent methods. Key limitations include the exclusive reliance on a single open-source database with predominant English-language bias and a one-year temporal snapshot, which may constrain generalizability. The semi-structured categorization may also miss nuanced or classified indicators unavailable in public sources. Drawing on these insights, the author recommends expanding empirical scopes to multiple years and databases, developing robust, transparent attribution methodologies that balance open disclosure with protection of intelligence capabilities, and exploring collaborative frameworks—such as consortia of private actors, cyber-IAEA-like bodies, or international cyber attribution courts—to ensure credibility and reduce escalation risks. By empirically demonstrating the prevalence and limitations of Q model indicators in real-world scenarios, the paper offers critical policy-oriented guidance for practitioners and scholars seeking to strengthen the reliability and strategic utility of cyber attribution in interstate conflict contexts.

title: Countering Malicious Cyber Activity: Targeted Financial Sanctions
abstract:
In "Countering Malicious Cyber Activity: Targeted Financial Sanctions," Natalie Thompson provides a comprehensive policy analysis of the legal frameworks, designations, and efficacy of targeted financial sanctions—commonly termed "cyber sanctions"—imposed by the United States and European Union since 2012 to deter or punish malicious cyber actors. Beginning with an overview of the accelerating scale and severity of state-sponsored and criminal cyber operations, Thompson situates sanctions within the broader DIME(LE) toolbox (Diplomatic, Informational, Military, Economic, Law Enforcement) available to states confronting hostile activity in cyberspace. She reviews the evolution of U.S. authorities under successive executive orders and EU regulations, detailing some thirty-five sanctions actions by the United States and the EU’s inaugural designations in mid-2020. By examining the legal basis and key use cases—ranging from indictments of election interference operatives to responses to the 2015 German Bundestag hack—Thompson charts the interplay between bespoke cyber sanctions mechanisms and existing human-rights and foreign-policy sanctions regimes. 

Central to her analysis is interrogation of sanctions’ purported deterrent effect. Drawing on the sanctions literature and cyber conflict studies, she demonstrates the complex attribution challenges, the diversity of cyber-enabled harms, and the difficulty of isolating sanctions’ impact from other policy instruments. To address this, Thompson proposes a multi-purpose framework: beyond deterrence and cost imposition, sanctions may serve symbolic and functional goals including attribution of responsibility, information-sharing to private-sector defenders, audience satisfaction, ally cooperation, norm reinforcement, punishment, and disruption of malicious actors’ financial and logistical capabilities. For each function, she offers critical evaluative questions—such as whether designations clarify state responsibility, whether the private sector uses sanctions lists for threat intelligence, and how actors might mitigate or circumvent restrictions through alternative financial architectures. 

Thompson emphasizes that policymakers seldom articulate clearly which function they intend sanctions to serve, nor do they systematically measure outcomes against those functions. She argues that a more nuanced approach to sanctions designations requires explicit goal-setting, tailored metrics for each function, and comparative assessments against alternative policy tools to weigh long-term consequences for global financial stability and the risk of escalation. The paper concludes with a call for empirical research on the differential effectiveness of sanctions against state proxies versus criminal groups, and for clearer demarcation between "cyber" as a discrete domain of conflict and as a modality for preexisting security threats. Ultimately, Thompson contends that while academic skepticism of sanctions’ deterrence is well founded, the persistence of sanctions in U.S. and EU cyber-policy portfolios reflects their broader symbolic and strategic utility. She urges policymakers to harness this utility through deliberate design, transparent evaluation, and integration with cooperative international norm-building efforts.

title: Black Start: The Risk of Grid Failure from a Cyber Attack and the Policies Needed to Prepare for It
source: Journal of Energy and Natural Resources Law
abstract: In "Black Start: The Risk of Grid Failure from a Cyber Attack and the Policies Needed to Prepare for It," Benjamin Monarch examines the existential threat posed by cyber attacks on the United States electric grid and advances a comprehensive policy framework to mitigate catastrophic grid failure. Monarch begins by defining "black start"—the process of restoring an electric grid without external power sources—and underscores the paradox that, while household and institutional generators offer limited resilience, a nationwide grid collapse could leave the country powerless with no ready means to reinstate service. He contextualizes the grid as the world’s largest interconnected machine, comprising thousands of power plants, substations, transmission lines, and control systems, all increasingly vulnerable due to digital integration and legacy technologies with minimal security protocols. Drawing on emerging evidence of sophisticated cyber intrusions into industrial control systems, Monarch argues that current security measures are insufficient; the grid’s complexity creates innumerable points of entry for adversaries seeking to inflict large-scale disruption. To address this, Monarch proposes seven policy recommendations. First, he calls for a federally backed insurance program to offset financial losses stemming from grid disruptions, incentivizing utilities to invest in cyber defenses. Second, he advocates expanded training and certification of cybersecurity professionals specializing in industrial control systems to redress workforce shortages. Third, he urges the creation of a centralized information-sharing platform under U.S. Cyber Command, improving coordination among government and private sector stakeholders. Fourth, he suggests subsidies or tax incentives to bolster cybersecurity measures in small-to-mid-size utilities that lack resources for robust defenses. Fifth, Monarch recommends grants for academic research into grid security, paired with tax credits to encourage philanthropic support for cybersecurity programs at universities. Sixth, he addresses emerging technologies—such as the Internet of Things and smart-grid devices—warning that without legally mandated security standards, the digitized, disaggregated grid could magnify vulnerabilities; he therefore urges Congress to regulate development of energy-cloud platforms and smart devices to prioritize security. Finally, Monarch emphasizes the importance of offensive cyber capabilities as deterrents, calling for transparent rules of engagement and credible signaling of U.S. willingness to retaliate against grid attacks. In his conclusion, Monarch cautions that grid security is an ongoing struggle requiring sustained investment and policy innovation, asserting that while no system can be made impervious, proactive measures are imperative to forestall a crisis that could imperil the foundations of modern life.

title: Due diligence in cyberspace: an assessment of rule 6 in the Tallinn manual 2.0
abstract: This master’s thesis critically evaluates the due diligence obligations of states in cyberspace by assessing Rule 6 of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations. Recognizing the rapid increase in state and non-state cyber operations and the attendant ambiguity over state responsibilities, the author systematically examines how traditional international law principles—particularly those governing transboundary harm and state responsibility—apply in digital contexts and whether Rule 6 offers clear, robust guidance for state practice. Employing a doctrinal methodology, the thesis analyzes key primary sources: judgments of the International Court of Justice (including Corfu Channel, Trail Smelter, and Pulp Mills cases), decisions of the International Tribunal on the Law of the Sea, interstate arbitration awards, and resolutions and reports from the UN General Assembly, Security Council, Group of Governmental Experts, International Law Association, and NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence. Comparative legal analysis reveals that Rule 6 encapsulates the core essence of traditional due diligence duties—such as prevention, investigation, and remediation of harmful activities emanating from a state’s territory—but lacks specificity regarding thresholds for attribution, required standards for preventive and oversight measures, and procedural mechanisms to verify compliance. The thesis identifies potential divergences in state interpretations due to these ambiguities and argues that without clearer normative force, Rule 6 may lead to inconsistent state practice. To address these gaps, the author proposes a refined framework structuring due diligence obligations into tiered categories: (1) basic non-interference duties; (2) enhanced monitoring, cooperation, and information sharing; and (3) proactive enforcement and remedial measures. This framework is accompanied by detailed procedural recommendations for triggering investigations, collecting evidence, and coordinating cross-border responses. A consolidated matrix mapping Rule 6 against analogous environmental and maritime precedents further illustrates normative parallels and supports convergence of state expectations. Though the study is limited by its focus on legal texts without empirical verification of state behavior or stakeholder interviews, it lays the groundwork for future research involving case studies of cyber incidents and consultations with policymakers to assess operational feasibility. The thesis ultimately contributes to multidisciplinary cyber conflict scholarship by clarifying international legal obligations in cyberspace, offering practical refinements to the Tallinn Manual’s due diligence rule, and fostering predictability and consistency in state conduct regarding harmful cyber activities.

title: Conceptualizing an international framework for active private cyber defence
source: Indian Journal of Law and Technology
abstract: Basu and Hickok’s 2020 article develops a comprehensive legal and policy framework for Active Private Cyber Defence (APCD), examining how sovereign states can authorize, regulate, and integrate private-sector offensive and defensive cyber operations within both domestic and international law. They posit that the growing sophistication and cross-border nature of malicious cyber activity necessitate a shift beyond passive resilience—firms’ conventional firewalls and incident response—to include proactive measures, and that this evolution exposes significant lacunae in existing legal regimes. The paper first maps a spectrum of APCD models by reviewing policy initiatives and statutes across jurisdictions, and then categorizes five state–private relationship configurations: co-optation and banning (which preclude meaningful private autonomy), and delegation, orchestration, and sanctioning (which grant graduated operational independence). Employing qualitative, normative analysis, the authors overlay each configuration with principles of jus ad bellum, state responsibility, and emerging cyber norms, enriched by case studies of private-sector cyber practices. They argue that while co-optation and banning curb private engagement at the cost of adaptability, delegation, orchestration, and sanctioning can harness corporate capabilities to amplify national defence, provided that clear accountability and attribution mechanisms are in place. However, international law’s traditional doctrines are unevenly applicable to privately conducted cyber operations, generating uncertainties about permissible scope, legal obligations, and avenues for redress. Basu and Hickok further critique how geopolitical factors—jurisdictional overlap, conflicts of interest when security firms serve multiple states, and disparities between developed and developing nations—complicate uniform APCD adoption. They identify that delegation and co-optation pose the lowest escalation risks by enabling states to maintain ultimate strategic control and ensuring the “Three Cs” of deterrence: capability, credibility, and communication. Yet delegation alone may not guarantee private accountability without state-imposed oversight and monitoring, potentially requiring hybrid models that combine delegation with co-optation to leverage an ecosystem of state and non-state actors. The authors close by exploring how norm entrepreneurship—through international standard-setting bodies, industry-led cyber accord initiatives, and private-sector charters—could foster stability by codifying best practices and promoting interoperability. They call for future research on regulatory architectures, insurance mechanisms, and the Global South’s specific needs. Their principal contribution lies in articulating a typology of APCD configurations, critically analyzing each under international legal obligations, and advocating for carefully calibrated delegation or co-optation frameworks as pathways to predictable, lawful, and effective private–public collaboration in cyberspace.

title: Mixed Signals: A Flawed Approach to Cyber Deterrence
abstract: In “Mixed Signals: A Flawed Approach to Cyber Deterrence,” Alexander Klimburg offers a critical analysis of the United States Cyber Command’s (CYBERCOM) 2018 doctrine of “persistent engagement” and its wider implications for international stability, cyber norms, and legal frameworks. Klimburg begins by situating persistent engagement within the historical evolution of U.S. cyber strategy, tracing a trajectory from early intelligence-gathering and denial-based operations to the more assertive “defend forward” posture that mandates CYBERCOM to disrupt adversarial activities “below the level of armed attack.” He argues that this shift, in privileging public signaling and mixed messages—through press releases, high-profile statements, and academic articles—over formal doctrine, risks destabilizing established norms of transparency and restraint cultivated through decades of arms control practice. Drawing on critiques of the academic underpinnings from Harknett and Fischerkeller’s concept of “non-deterrence,” Klimburg demonstrates that cyber operations, absent complementary diplomatic or economic measures, rarely yield strategic concessions and may instead provoke reactive campaigns, as evidenced by Iran’s post-Stuxnet cyber activity. Klimburg highlights that public disclosures of pre-positioned cyber capabilities—such as U.S. malware in Russian power grids—depart from conventional arms control by embracing self-disclosure as deterrent, thereby challenging norms of sovereignty and inviting reciprocal operations. He further examines how persistent engagement bolsters the strategic narratives of Russia, China, and other states advocating for an “International Code of Conduct for Information Security,” threatening the multi-stakeholder model of internet governance by promoting securitization and an intergovernmental regime. Legally, Klimburg contends that forward-deploying cyber weapons in peacetime raises profound questions under international law, blurring distinctions between peace and war and undermining the very order the United States helped to establish. He warns that the weaponization of information through over-communication and aggressive signaling may accelerate an offensive cyber arms race and erode the liberal democratic commitment to an open internet. To mitigate these risks, Klimburg proposes a recalibrated deterrence posture characterized by genuine transparency—private and public multilevel discussions on strategic capabilities, restrained signaling, and renewed emphasis on multilateral norm-building—arguing that such an approach would better preserve strategic stability, the integrity of the global digital commons, and the foundational principles of international law.

title: The problem of cyber - attribution and how it matters for international law and global security
abstract: This master’s thesis by Leandro Pereira Mendes critically examines the persistent challenge of attributing cyber operations to their true perpetrators and situates this attribution dilemma within the broader framework of international law and global security. Beginning with the 2007 Estonian cyberattacks as a paradigmatic case, the study charts the evolution of technical attribution capabilities, noting that while advanced states now possess sophisticated tools to trace malicious traffic to specific networks or machines, converting these forensic findings into legally binding attributions remains fraught with uncertainty. Mendes offers a detailed doctrinal analysis of state practice, treaty obligations, United Nations instruments, and soft law frameworks such as the Tallinn Manual to interrogate how existing rules of state responsibility and jus ad bellum principles address—or fail to address—the evidentiary burdens, threshold standards, and attribution protocols required to establish legal culpability in cyberspace. This analysis reveals a critical gap: divergent state practices, the absence of binding adjudicatory mechanisms, and politically motivated reticence undermine international law’s capacity to deliver predictability and stability in response to cyber incidents. Layered atop this normative inquiry is a realist-inspired discussion of the security dilemma in cyberspace. The thesis demonstrates that the attribution gap exacerbates interstate mistrust, fueling reciprocal cyber capabilities and risk of misperception, potentially leading to escalation into kinetic or hybrid conflict. Mendes supplements legal theory with empirical examinations of high-profile cyber incidents—allegations of Chinese military intrusions, Russian operations against Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, and other contested intrusions—to illustrate how attribution disputes hinder diplomatic confidence-building measures and obstruct the collective development of binding norms. The study further explores the contributions and limitations of emerging non-state initiatives—multistakeholder dialogues, industry codes of conduct, and technical norm-setting bodies—arguing that while these soft law mechanisms offer valuable forums for norm articulation and confidence building, they cannot substitute for a robust, binding legal framework with clear evidentiary thresholds, dispute-settlement processes, and integrated technical protocols. In its conclusion, the thesis proposes a hybrid governance model that combines technological attribution mechanisms with diplomatic confidence-building measures and regional comparative studies to adapt norms to diverse security contexts. Mendes contends that closing the attribution gap is not merely a technical hurdle but a fundamental prerequisite for stabilizing cyberspace under international law, mitigating the security dilemma, and preventing cyber incidents from escalating into broader conflicts. This work thus advances the discourse on cyber governance by offering concrete recommendations to bridge the divide between technical attribution and legal accountability, underscoring the necessity of coherent, binding legal criteria to preserve international peace and security in the digital age.

title: state responsibility and the consequences of an internationally wrongful cyber operation
abstract: This chapter provides a comprehensive legal analysis of State responsibility in the context of internationally wrongful cyber operations under international law. Grounded in the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility and the Tallinn Manual 2.0, it first establishes that any cyber operation attributable to a State that breaches an international obligation automatically triggers the State’s secondary obligations, irrespective of any action or invocation by the injured State. The chapter then elaborates the tripartite framework of consequences owed by the responsible State: cessation, assurances and guarantees of non-repetition, and full reparation. Under the obligation of cessation, a State must immediately terminate any continuing wrongful cyber conduct without the need for a formal request, ensuring maintenance of the rule of law and upholding primary norms. Cessation is distinguished from reparation by its independent character and the absence of proportionality limits. The second obligation requires the responsible State to provide appropriate assurances and guarantees when circumstances indicate a risk of recurrence, serving as preventive safeguards. The third obligation, reparation, encompasses restitution to the status quo ante where feasible, compensation for quantifiable losses, and satisfaction for moral injury, with compensation often being the most practical remedy in digital contexts. The chapter addresses the particular challenges of quantifying cyber harm and selecting suitable forms of reparation. It further explores the regime of shared responsibility applicable when multiple States participate in a cyber operation. The analysis distinguishes joint commission, where States co-author a single wrongful act and share full liability, from situations of aid or assistance, where a supporting State is responsible only for its own contributory actions provided knowingly for an unlawful operation. Hypothetical examples—such as the sale of software vulnerabilities or provision of cyber-expertise—illustrate the nuanced attribution principles. It also clarifies that the mere transit of cyber traffic through a State’s infrastructure constitutes diligence obligations rather than assistance. Concluding remarks reiterate that upon non-compliance with cessation and reparation obligations, injured States may resort to judicial or extrajudicial measures, including countermeasures and other self-help remedies examined in the subsequent chapter. Overall, this chapter establishes a foundational legal paradigm for assessing State responsibility in cyber operations, articulating the interplay between established international law principles and the novel challenges posed by cyber activities.

title: A small state perspective on the evolving nature of cyber conflict: lessons from Singapore
source: Prism : a Journal of the Center for Complex Operations
abstract: This article examines the unique challenges and strategic responses of small states to state-sponsored cyber conflict through an in-depth case study of Singapore, situating cyber operations within traditional theories of coercion and statecraft rather than as an entirely new form of warfare. Drawing on Clausewitz’s conceptualization of war as a continuation of politics by other means and Schelling’s distinctions between deterrence and compellence, the author argues that cyber means function as limited coercive tools employed by great powers to influence targeted states without resorting to armed force. Singapore’s experiences, including its policy reactions to the 2007 Estonian attacks and subsequent participation in multilateral forums, illustrate how small states can leverage diplomacy and norm-setting processes to mitigate vulnerabilities to cyber coercion. The article synthesizes official United Nations Group of Governmental Experts (UNGGE) reports, ASEAN declarations, Singapore’s ‘‘Total Defence’’ framework—including the recent Digital Defence pillar—and analyses of divergent Western and Russian–Chinese approaches to information security to reveal key normative fault lines in the international system. Whereas Western democracies have historically emphasized the protection of critical infrastructure and individual rights such as freedom of expression, Russia and China have advocated for broader information security measures to govern the flow of information; this tension manifested in the 2015 UNGGE consensus, which favored technology-centric norms but left information operations largely unregulated. The study also highlights the growing importance of social media platforms as battlegrounds for state-sponsored influence operations, as underscored by NATO’s CyCon 2018, and explores Singapore’s domestic legal innovations such as the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act. Singapore’s proactive engagement in UNGGE and Open-Ended Working Group sessions is presented as a model for small-state diplomacy, emphasizing the need for a rules-based order in cyberspace that preserves sovereignty and deters coercion. The author identifies several challenges, including slow international lawmaking, difficulties in cyber attribution, and the divergent capacities of ASEAN member states. Limitations of the study include its single-country focus and reliance on open-source policy documents. The paper concludes by calling for empirical assessments of small-state resilience to cyber coercion, comparative analyses of regional norm-development processes, and exploration of mechanisms to operationalize and enforce international law in cyberspace. This multidisciplinary analysis contributes to cyber conflict scholarship by integrating classical strategic theory with contemporary policy debates, demonstrating that cyber operations complement rather than replace traditional foreign policy tools, and offering practical insights for small states navigating great-power competition in the digital age.

title: Institutionalising Cyber Attribution
abstract:
This article by Marco Roscini investigates the legal frameworks and procedural challenges surrounding the use of digital evidence as a means of proof before the International Court of Justice (ICJ). As interstate disputes increasingly invoke digital materials—ranging from emails, text files, and metadata to satellite imagery and audiovisual recordings—the ICJ’s absence of dedicated rules for digital evidence, save for Practice Direction IXbis, creates uncertainties for litigants and judges alike. Roscini contends that the ICJ’s general documentary evidence rules, embedded in its Statute and Rules of Court, implicitly encompass digital formats, since no category of documentary evidence is expressly excluded. He begins by reviewing how existing ICJ provisions on documentary evidence apply to digital documents. He demonstrates that requirements familiar from paper-based litigation—such as annexation of exhibits, chain-of-custody attestations, and authenticity certifications—also suffice for digital files, illustrated by case studies like the Pulp Mills dispute, in which satellite imagery was accepted together with expert witness testimony explaining its derivation and manipulation.

Next, Roscini examines challenges particular to audiovisual digital materials, including the need for precise technical descriptions of image or sound creation and encoding, and the interpretive disputes they often generate. He explores the roles of party-appointed versus court-appointed experts in digital forensics, highlighting the lack of a standing scientific panel within the ICJ akin to the ICC’s Scientific Response Unit. He suggests that the Court might benefit from institutionalizing a permanent expert body to advise on complex technical questions, thereby promoting consistent standards for authenticity and accuracy assessments.

Finally, the article tackles the admissibility of digital evidence obtained through unilateral transborder access—where one party accesses or copies data stored on servers in another state without permission. Roscini observes that such conduct arguably infringes territorial sovereignty and data protection norms, yet notes that neither the ICJ Statute nor its Rules contain explicit prohibitions against evidence obtained unlawfully. Drawing on the Corfu Channel judgment, he infers that the ICJ may admit unlawfully obtained evidence, evaluating its weight based on demonstrated authenticity and probative value rather than on the lawfulness of its collection. This precedent, he argues, reflects the consensual and egalitarian nature of international litigation, in contrast to domestic criminal procedures where exclusionary rules protect defendants against prosecutorial overreach.

Concluding, Roscini acknowledges the merits of developing tailored regulations to address digital evidence’s specificities. Nevertheless, he cautions that any new rules must preserve the Court’s flexibility to adapt to diverse case circumstances and evolving technologies. By clarifying how digital proof can be reliably produced, authenticated, and evaluated before the ICJ, his analysis fills a critical lacuna in the burgeoning field of cyber-related inter-state dispute resolution.

title: the question of evidence: from technical to legal attribution
abstract: This article examines the legal regime governing submarine telecommunication cables—the physical backbone of global cyberspace—which lie for the most part beyond any State’s sovereign jurisdiction yet underpin strategic, economic, educational, cultural, and military activity. It begins by surveying existing ‘‘law of peace’’ frameworks: the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) provisions on laying and protecting submarine cables in exclusive economic zones and beyond, the 1884 Convention for the Protection of Submarine Telegraph Cables, technical recommendations from the International Cable Protection Committee, and soft-law guidelines from the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). The authors demonstrate that while these instruments permit the untrammelled deployment of submarine cables, they have not kept pace with the modern cables’ multifunctionality (data transfer, environmental sensing) or the increased State and private reliance on them. The article then shifts to the law of armed conflict (LOAC) and the law on the use of force (jus ad bellum and jus in bello) to address the hitherto neglected question of deliberate damage to cables in peacetime and wartime. A detailed analysis shows that no treaty or customary norm specifically prohibits or permits State or non-State attacks on submarine cables. Historic Hague Regulations concerning the cutting of cables between occupied and neutral territories offer only limited, narrowly applicable rules. Accordingly, targeting must be assessed under LOAC’s general principles of military objectives and proportionality. Submarine cables can qualify as military objectives if they make a tangible contribution to military operations—such as enabling command, control, communications, surveillance, or use of unmanned systems. However, the global interconnectedness and societal dependence on these networks mean that even localized cable severances would cause extensive, foreseeable collateral harm: economic disruption, degraded civilian and military communications, cloud-service outages, and cascading effects on financial and data-storage systems across belligerent and neutral States. The proportionality test—requiring incidental civilian damage not to be excessive in relation to the concrete military advantage—cannot realistically be satisfied given the diffuse and systemic nature of harms and the necessity of multiple, network-wide cable cuts to achieve significant military gains. The authors conclude that while LOAC does not categorically forbid strikes on submarine cables, in practice the law’s proportionality constraints render such attacks functionally unlawful. They call for a holistic, updated legal framework—integrating principles of the law of the sea, State responsibility, use of force, and armed conflict—to govern submarine cable protection in peace and war and to reflect their strategic importance in the digital age.

title: Persistent enforcement: criminal charges as a response to nation-state malicious cyber activity
source: Journal of National Security Law and Policy
abstract: This article provides a comprehensive policy analysis of the growing use of criminal charges by the United States as a strategic tool to attribute and respond to malicious cyber activity sponsored or directed by nation‐state actors. Beginning with the U.S. Department of Justice’s first explicit allegations against five officers of the People’s Liberation Army in 2014, the authors document how the Justice Department has brought or unsealed at least 24 cases and 195 counts against 93 foreign nationals—officers and proxies from China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, Syria, and other states—between 2014 and mid-2019. The article situates criminal charges within the broader U.S. cyber policy landscape, including the 2018 National Cyber Strategy’s Deterrence Initiative, evolving guidelines on offensive cyber operations, and other diplomatic and military measures. It introduces a novel conceptual framework that distinguishes criminal charges from alternative state responses—such as public attribution statements, sanctions, or covert operations—and identifies five categories of policy objectives that charges can serve: signaling adversary accountability, imposing reputational costs, disrupting adversary networks, enabling international cooperation, and reinforcing domestic rule of law. Drawing on case studies across the five targeted states, the authors analyze how charges have been designed, the types of defendants (military officers, intelligence agents, mercenary hackers, or front-company contractors), and the strategic trade-offs policymakers face when deploying indictments against individuals unlikely to be apprehended. They also present trends in charge frequency, geographic distribution, and count composition, noting a marked increase under the Trump administration and a recent acceleration following the release of the administration’s Cyber Strategy. The article concludes that criminal charges, when integrated into a “persistent enforcement” approach, can complement other elements of U.S. cyber policy by maintaining continuous pressure on adversaries and shaping norms of acceptable state behavior in cyberspace. The authors offer recommendations for optimizing the design of future indictments—including clearer articulation of policy objectives, enhanced diplomatic coordination, and consideration of domestic and international legal implications—to maximize the deterrent and normative influence of criminal prosecutions in the evolving domain of cyber conflict.

title: Hacking for the state?: the use of private persons in cyber attacks and state responsibility
abstract: This thesis examines the phenomenon of states outsourcing cyber attacks to private actors and the consequent challenges of attributing legal responsibility under international law. Focusing on Russia’s alleged use of patriotic hackers, the Nashi Youth Group, and the Russian Business Network to launch Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks against Estonia in 2007 and Georgia in 2008, the study applies the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts—specifically Articles 4, 5, 8, and 11—to assess whether the requisite thresholds for attribution, such as effective control, adoption of conduct, and government authority, are met. Employing a doctrinal legal analysis supplemented by comparative case studies, the author draws on open-source materials including state practice, official statements, hacker forum postings, media reports, and documented confessions to test the applicability of the Draft Articles to clandestine cyber operations. In the Estonia case, waves of coordinated DDoS attacks crippled communication and banking infrastructure, and pre-attack forum communications suggested advanced coordination; nevertheless, the evidence falls short of proving that state organs directly directed the publication of attack instructions or exercised effective control over the perpetrators. Similarly, in the Georgia case, cyber attacks synchronized with kinetic military operations point to apparent state involvement, yet uncertainties regarding the provenance of instructions and the nature of the relationships between Russia and various hacktivist groups preclude conclusive attribution under the Draft Articles. The findings reveal that while both incidents exhibit strong indicia of state-sponsored tactics, the stringent evidentiary requirements for attributing non-state cyber operations to a sovereign state remain unmet. Consequently, the thesis argues that Russia cannot be held legally responsible for these attacks under Articles 4, 5, 8, or 11. This research contributes to multidisciplinary cyber conflict studies by clarifying the practical evidentiary gaps and legal hurdles inherent in attributing hostile cyber operations, demonstrating both the utility and the limitations of the Draft Articles as analytical tools in the context of deniable, hybrid warfare strategies. The author acknowledges that reliance on open-source data and absence of classified intelligence limit the depth of factual verification and suggests that evolving state practice and emerging attribution technologies may alter future assessments. To strengthen international accountability mechanisms, the thesis recommends developing more robust and standardized evidentiary standards, fostering cooperation for shared attribution, and adapting legal frameworks to address the covert nature of state-sponsored cyber tactics.

title: Deterring cyber coercion: the exaggerated problem of attribution
abstract: This article challenges the widely held assumption that anonymity in cyber operations renders deterrence by punishment ineffective. Grounded in classical coercion and deterrence theory, the author David Blagden disaggregates the traditional conflation of aggressor identity and aggressor interests, arguing that while technical attribution of a cyber attack’s origin remains difficult, coercive operations inherently reveal the attacker’s strategic preferences. By exposing what an adversary values, even anonymous cyber coercion provides a ‘preference-revelation mechanism’ that enables defenders to threaten those interests and thereby uphold credible deterrence. The paper systematically reviews prominent historical incidents—including the 2012 U.S. financial system attacks, the Saudi Aramco breach, the 2014 Sony Pictures hack, and North Korea’s 2014 intrusion—to illustrate that states facing coercive cyber aggression can infer aggressors’ motivations and impose retaliatory measures against collective or shared interests, thus penalizing the underlying actor despite imperfect identity attribution. Blagden situates this argument within a normative and conceptual framework, contrasting deterrence by denial and deterrence by punishment, and addresses counterarguments regarding cyber weapons’ unsuitability for explicit signaling, selection bias in empirical studies of non-occurrences, and the complexities of diverse cyber operations such as espionage, subversion, and extortion. He contends that these objections underestimate the strategic context in which cyber coercion unfolds and that the shrinking pool of capable culprits and escalating stakes of major-power cyber engagements bolster deterrent credibility. Acknowledging the study’s qualitative case-based methodology and calling for future empirical research on instances of successful deterrence non-occurrence, Blagden also urges examination of emerging attribution technologies, false-flag operations, and the role of international norms and third-party actors. By reframing ‘strategic attribution’ to focus on revealed interests rather than precise identities, this work extends classical deterrence theory to the cyber domain and offers policymakers a robust conceptual basis for designing credible retaliation strategies in an era of persistent and sophisticated cyber threats.

title: Personalised deterrence of cyber aggression
abstract: This article assesses the limitations of traditional state-level cyber deterrence and proposes a novel framework of “personalised deterrence” targeting individual cyber actors rather than state sponsors. The authors begin by diagnosing the core challenges of existing cyber deterrence: stealthy attack tools undermine signalling; rapid cyber tool obsolescence diminishes retaliatory credibility; and attribution difficulties discourage decisive punitive measures. Drawing on classical deterrence theory and empirical case studies—including US executive orders, prosecutions of PLA officers, DPRK hackers, and public naming and shaming campaigns—the article argues that focusing on individual perpetrators lowers the evidentiary threshold for enforcement and enhances the credible threat of tailored punishments. The article outlines a menu of legal and reputational instruments available to Western governments: visa bans, asset freezes, property and financial restrictions, corporate appointment prohibitions, criminal indictments, and public disclosure of personal data obtained via open-source intelligence or lawful cyber collection. By calibrating these measures to align with individual attackers’ motivations—such as career advancement, travel privileges, and financial gains—personalised deterrence reshapes hackers’ cost–benefit calculations and weakens their loyalty to sponsoring states. The authors review precedent: the Obama administration’s executive orders (EO 13694, EO 13757), which sanctioned individuals for malicious cyber activities; the 2014 indictments of five PLA officers for economic espionage; the DoJ and Treasury actions against DPRK’s Lazarus Group; and charges against Equifax hackers. They also note the strategic messaging by US Cyber Command during the 2018 US election cycle. The analysis reveals that these initiatives, though limited in scale, demonstrate proof of concept for individual-focused deterrence but lack pre-emptive signalling and coordinated coalition implementation. The proposed personalised deterrence framework systematically enumerates threat options, procedural considerations, and signalling mechanisms, emphasizing formal, public communication of potential consequences in advance of attacks. The authors acknowledge practical and ethical constraints: challenges in individual attribution, risk of misattribution and wrongful sanctions, jurisdictional disparities, and intelligence-gathering legalities. They caution that credibility hinges on coalition-building among Western allies to harmonize penalties and prevent safe havens. For future research, they recommend empirical evaluation of personalised deterrence outcomes, enhanced attribution technologies to reduce identification errors, and integration with international law and norms development. The article concludes that personalised deterrence offers a scalable, non-escalatory complement to state-level cyber counterstrikes and is essential for bolstering stability in cyberspace by harnessing low-cost legal and reputational levers tailored to individual cyber aggressors.

title: Three tales of attribution in cyberspace: criminal law, international law and policy debates
authors: D Broeders; Els De Busser; Patryk Pawlak
source: The Hague Program for Cyber Norms Policy Brief
abstract: Attribution of malicious cyber activities has emerged as a central challenge in contemporary interstate conflict, as states grapple with assigning responsibility in a domain where evidence is often sensitive and the stakes of public naming are high. This policy brief addresses the significance of attribution in cyberspace by examining how states navigate suspicion, accusation, and the ensuing consequences within criminal law, international law, and policy debates, asking how different legal and political frameworks shape the process and to what ends. The authors argue that understanding these “three tales of attribution” is essential for informing state strategies to deter cyber operations, enforce norms, and seek redress, prompting the research question: how do criminal, international, and policy-based approaches differ in their evidentiary thresholds, decision points, and strategic objectives? To answer this, the paper employs a qualitative, workshop-driven methodology, convening twenty international experts in The Hague and Brussels, who drew upon their backgrounds in law, policy, and intelligence to map the stages of attribution and assess their practical and normative implications. The analysis identifies a three-stage process—suspicion, accusation, and consequences—each interacting with disclosure dynamics: suspicion can rest on varying evidentiary rigor; the shift to public accusation raises questions of legitimacy and transparency; and attribution often triggers legal recourse or political countermeasures, with evidentiary standards shaping the proportionality and legality of state responses. Findings reveal that criminal law emphasizes formal investigations and high proof thresholds, international law offers flexibility but lacks consensus on standards, and policy debates focus on strategic objectives such as deterrence, cooperation, or signaling. The brief contributes a conceptual framework that clarifies the internal logic of each approach and highlights the dilemmas states face when linking attribution to broader policy goals, such as pursuing criminal indictments versus invoking state responsibility or crafting joint statements. It also underscores that attribution should not be an end in itself but a means to achieve defined objectives, from securing assistance to enforcing norms. A key limitation is its reliance on expert workshops rather than systematic case analysis, which may limit generalizability and overlook divergent state practices. The authors suggest future research should compare state case studies of public attribution decisions, develop clearer evidentiary benchmarks for international practice, and explore the role of non-state actors and private disclosures in shaping attribution outcomes, thereby informing more coherent and effective cyber conflict strategies.

title: Cyber operations and the principle of due diligence
abstract: The principle of due diligence is an obligation on States not to knowingly allow the use of their territory for the perpetration of acts contrary to the rights of other States. The duty of diligence was referred to by the International Court of Justice in the Corfu Channel case: every State has the 'obligation not to allow knowingly its territory to be used for acts contrary to the rights of other States'. The duty of diligence can be transposed to cyber activities. This would mean that it imposes a duty on States not to allow their territory to be used for the launch or transit of cyber operations targeting another State. In that perspective, due diligence may constitute an interesting palliative to the problem of attribution. The principle of due diligence in international law is particularly relevant regarding the behaviour of non-state actors, since the principle subjects this behaviour to some limitations imposed by international law by creating a bridge between them and State responsibility.

title: The law and politics of cyberattack attribution
abstract: In "The Law and Politics of Cyberattack Attribution," Kristen E. Eichensehr examines the largely unresolved challenge of publicly attributing cyberattacks to state actors, arguing that legal standards must govern such attributions to enhance accountability, deterrence, and stability in cyberspace. Although technical forensics constitute the initial stage of attribution, Eichensehr demonstrates that the political and legal dimensions ultimately determine whether and how states publicly blame other states for malicious intrusions. Through a comparative doctrinal analysis of state practice and domestic legal frameworks on evidence and attribution, and a review of proposals for an international attribution entity, the Article reveals significant divergences among existing domestic evidentiary regimes—which often fail to apply uniformly to all attribution mechanisms—and highlights the political motivations that shape current state practice. Eichensehr proposes a functionally defined evidentiary standard under international law, requiring that any public attribution of a cyberattack by a state rest on sufficiently transparent and corroborable evidence to permit independent crosschecking. Such a requirement would harness the complementary strengths of governmental and nongovernmental attributors, encourage the growth of customary international law norms, and potentially clarify unsettled general rules on evidentiary law. On institutional design, the Article critiques proposals for a centralized international attribution body, recommending instead a decentralized, multiplicity-based system in which diverse governmental and nongovernmental actors supplement—but do not replace—existing attribution mechanisms. This decentralized approach, Eichensehr argues, maximizes the likelihood that public attributions will achieve their intended goals—strengthening defenses, deterring hostile cyber operations, and maintaining stability below the threshold of armed conflict—while allowing for case-by-case intelligence sharing tailored to participants' risk profiles. Recognizing the costs and risks of broader intelligence exchange, the Article underscores the importance of proliferating confirmatory attributions by a geographically and politically diverse array of attributors to foster shared factual understanding of state behavior. Finally, Eichensehr acknowledges limitations related to reconciling disparate domestic regimes, the real-world costs of intelligence sharing, and the uneven initial application of a decentralized evidentiary standard, and she calls for future research into mechanisms for incentivizing global participation and refining institutional models to balance transparency, security, and diversity of voice in cyberattack attribution.

title: election interference is not cyber-war
abstract:
This chapter argues that although modern election interference employs digital tools such as email hacking and social media manipulation, it should not be understood under the international law framework of cyber-warfare. The author begins by tracing the evolution from traditional, non-digital election meddling—leafletting, radio broadcasts, and corrupt local political deals—to today’s cyber-enabled activities. The temptation to categorize digital election interference as cyber-attacks subject to the law of armed conflict arises from the emerging body of international cyber law, which often borrows principles from kinetic warfare. In particular, many commentators assume that rules governing “cyber-war” apply directly to election interference, leading to polarized views: some condemn interference as an illegal act of cyber-war allowing self-defense; others deny a right of response because the acts do not rise to the level of armed conflict. The author contends that this framing is deeply flawed and diverts attention from more appropriate legal regimes.

To support this claim, the chapter first articulates the foundational jus ad bellum (the right to resort to force) and jus in bello (the conduct of hostilities) distinction. It underscores that these domains are conceptually independent: whether an armed attack justifies self-defense (jus ad bellum) does not affect the rules governing conduct of hostilities (jus in bello). The text reviews recent philosophical challenges to this separation (revisionist just war theory), but observes that these debates have not influenced existing international legal doctrine. Consequently, state and non-state actors cannot bypass jus ad bellum requirements for military force—namely UN Security Council authorization or article 51 self-defense—by labeling cyber operations as countermeasures.

Next, the chapter explains that many cyber-attacks, including election interference, lack the requisite physical destruction or harm to qualify as “use of force” or “armed attack” under the UN Charter and the law of armed conflict. While cyber operations can trigger the law of armed conflict when they inflict kinetic-like damage, most election-related hacks and disinformation campaigns do not cross that threshold. Instead, these operations resemble tools of statecraft that inhabit a “domaine réservé,” regulated by international law but not by the laws of war.

The chapter then analyzes the U.S. response to Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, illustrating the range of non-kinetic legal measures available. President Obama’s executive orders under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and subsequent sanctions, the expulsion of diplomats, closure of intelligence compounds, and undisclosed cyber countermeasures demonstrate punitive retorsions and countermeasures distinct from lawful uses of force. The author notes the administration’s reluctance to invoke specific legal doctrines publicly, possibly to preserve strategic flexibility.

In conclusion, the chapter asserts that treating election interference as cyber-war is both legally inaccurate and strategically counterproductive. It calls for discarding the cyber-war framework in favor of more precise legal regimes. The subsequent chapters will examine sovereignty and self-determination as alternative frameworks: the first considers whether cyber interference violates state sovereignty; the second evaluates whether it breaches the collective right of peoples to self-determination. These frameworks, the author argues, better capture the democratic harm of election interference and the full range of international law tools beyond armed conflict rules.

abstract: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) position paper frames cyber operations as an increasingly significant means and method of warfare that must be constrained by existing international humanitarian law (IHL) during armed conflicts. The ICRC emphasizes that IHL principles of distinction, proportionality, precaution, and protection of civilian objects—including data and critical infrastructure—apply equally to cyber operations as to traditional kinetic weapons. Cyber activities during hostilities can disable essential civilian services such as electricity, communications, transportation, health, banking, and government functions, potentially causing death, injury, disruption of vital services, and long-term humanitarian consequences. The interconnectivity of cyberspace heightens risks that tools designed for precision may spread damage unpredictably, while the rapid, proliferative nature of cyber weapons amplifies the threat to civilian populations. The paper affirms that any use of force—cyber or kinetic—remains subject to the UN Charter’s prohibition on aggression and customary rules governing recourse to force. It calls on States to explicitly recognize that IHL governs cyber operations during armed conflicts and to clarify national interpretations of IHL in cyberspace, including whether new norms are needed to address unique cyber characteristics. The paper highlights the imperative to protect civilian data—such as medical, biometric, financial, and electoral information—arguing that deleting or tampering with digital files should carry the same legal protections afforded to physical objects under IHL. Moreover, it underlines the challenge of attribution in cyber warfare for assigning State responsibility, noting that while attackers can obscure origins to evade accountability, States must still ensure that entities under their direction or control comply with IHL. The ICRC welcomes ongoing UN General Assembly processes—the Open-Ended Working Group and the Group of Governmental Experts—on responsible State behavior in cyberspace and urges substantive discussions on how existing IHL applies and whether additional rules are necessary. The ultimate goal is to strengthen the legal framework to mitigate civilian harm from cyber operations, reinforcing that affirming IHL applicability neither legitimizes cyber warfare nor encourages militarization of cyberspace, but upholds humanitarian protections fundamental to the laws of armed conflict.

title: US cyber deterrence: practice guiding theory
abstract: This article examines the evolution of U.S. cyber deterrence practice across four presidential administrations and its implications for cyber deterrence theory. While deterrence theory has a century-long pedigree in domains such as conventional and nuclear warfare, cyberspace poses novel conceptual and operational challenges. The author asks how U.S. cyber deterrence practice has developed in policy, doctrine, strategy, and interagency coordination since the early 2000s, and how the empirical record of U.S. efforts can inform more robust theoretical models. Drawing on government publications, executive orders, agency reports, congressional testimonies, and scholarly literature, the study reconstructs the piecemeal formulation of U.S. cyber deterrence across the Bush, Obama, and Trump administrations. Under George W. Bush, nascent cybersecurity directives laid groundwork for critical infrastructure protection without fully articulating deterrence objectives. The Obama era emphasized building Department of Defense cyber capabilities, integration of Cyber Command, and attempts to codify deterrence in the 2011 Cyberspace Policy Report and subsequent National Infrastructure Protection Plan updates. Against this backdrop, private-sector partnerships and norm-building efforts in forums such as the UN GGE complemented U.S. doctrine. The Trump administration’s Executive Order 13800 (2017) tasked multiple agencies—State, Defense, Homeland Security, Treasury, Commerce, and intelligence—to deliver a unified deterrence report, culminating in a May 2018 public recommendations document and the September 2018 National Cyber Strategy. Throughout these stages, the United States developed offensive and defensive cyber tools and publicly declared retaliatory options, yet coherent theory has trailed practice. The temporal disconnect—the operationalization of tactics and policy before scholarly validation—has produced conceptual gaps in attribution, credibility, escalation management, and normative constraints. Wilner contends that systematic analysis of U.S. practice provides conceptual building blocks for a refined cyber deterrence theory: identification of policy gaps, the centrality of presidential directives, interagency dynamics, the role of public signalling, and the limits of attribution. He underscores the influence of emerging cyber norms and international law, suggesting that legal frameworks and alliance commitments can enhance deterrent credibility. The article further acknowledges methodological limitations due to reliance on publicly available sources and single-case focus, which may obscure classified deliberations and reduce generalizability. To advance both descriptive and prescriptive theory, Wilner calls for comparative studies of other states’ deterrence practices, empirical testing of the U.S.-derived propositions, and deeper exploration of the interplay between norms, legal restraints, and state conduct in cyberspace. By bridging practice and theory, this research offers a template for integrating empirical evidence into scholarly models of deterrence in the cyber age.

title: Evolving toward a balanced cyber strategy in east Asia: cyber deterrence or cooperation?
abstract: In this paper, Hon‐Min Yau critically examines the strategic viability of cyber deterrence in East Asia and proposes a balanced alternative grounded in regional cooperation. Noting intensified state reliance on cyberspace for economic, social, and military functions, Yau highlights a rising incidence of state‐sponsored cyberattacks—such as those against Estonia (2007), Georgia (2008), Iran’s Natanz facility via Stuxnet (2010), and the reported U.S. “left of launch” operation against North Korea (2017)—that deliver or threaten kinetic effects. Taiwan and Japan have each responded by embedding deterrence language and capabilities in national security documents, establishing dedicated cyber defense and offense commands, and enacting legal mandates like Taiwan’s Information and Communication Security Management Act (2018) and Japan’s Basic Act on Cybersecurity (2014). Despite these efforts, Yau argues that classic deterrence theory, derived from nuclear strategy, is ill‐suited for cyberspace. Four core barriers undermine effective deterrence: (1) attribution challenges obscure attacker identity and undermine credible threats; (2) the presence of non‐state or irrational actors falls outside rational cost–benefit models; (3) uncertain damage thresholds impede proportional retaliation; and (4) legal ambiguities complicate questions of state responsibility and collateral impacts on civil liberties. Drawing on a critical review of nuclear‐inspired deterrence constructs and theoretical literature in international relations, Yau reviews emerging cyber deterrence variants that shift focus from showcasing punitive means to shaping adversary perceptions and establishing normative constraints. He assesses Taiwan’s post‐2016 institutional reforms—including new cybersecurity departments and military cyber commands—and Japan’s evolving National Security Strategy, Cybersecurity Strategy, and defense guidelines to trace how each country has attempted to operationalize deterrence. Yau finds that neither classic nor modified deterrence approaches can be implemented in isolation without incurring significant conceptual and operational dilemmas. Instead, he argues for a “threat‐aligned architecture” that blends selective deterrence with enhanced cooperation: leveraging shared threat perceptions to foster joint capacity building through intergovernmental exercises, intelligence sharing, and co‐development of legal norms under international law. By situating deterrence within a broader framework of diplomatic engagement, legal clarity, and norm development—exemplified by Taiwan‐U.S. and EU‐NATO cooperative models—this balanced strategy offers greater credibility, resilience, and adaptability. Yau acknowledges limitations in empirical outcome data on regional cooperative mechanisms and calls for future research to develop metrics for cyber power assessment tailored to East Asian dynamics, to empirically evaluate cooperative frameworks, and to design legal instruments that clarify state responsibility and support collective deterrence. His analysis reframes cyber strategy away from one‐size‐fits‐all deterrence toward a multifaceted approach more suited to the complexity of cyber conflict in East Asia.
