title: The limits of deterrence theory in cyberspace
abstract: In “The Limits of Deterrence Theory in Cyberspace,” Mariarosaria Taddeo critically examines the applicability of traditional deterrence theory—originating in the context of kinetic warfare and nuclear standoffs—to the unique domain of cyber conflict. Acknowledging the growing reliance of states and non-state actors on cyber operations and the concomitant risks of escalation, Taddeo argues that fundamental differences between kinetic and cyber domains undermine the core assumptions of classical deterrence: clear attribution, credible threat of punishment, and controllable retaliation. Through a conceptual analysis grounded in international relations theory, philosophy of technology, and strategic policy documents, she unpacks the three core elements of deterrence theory—attribution, defense and retaliation strategies, and signaling—and contrasts how each element functions in cyberspace. Deterrence theory’s minimalist model (DM), based on rational choice assumptions and six key conditions adapted from Morgan’s framework, presumes a bilateral kinetic conflict in which actors can reliably identify adversaries, signal intentions, and execute punitive measures that are proportionate and controllable. In cyberspace, however, low barriers to entry, multiplicity of actors, dynamic threat landscapes, and pervasive ambiguity hinder precise attribution, expose signaling to misattribution and capability leaks, and complicate proportional responses. Taddeo distinguishes between general signaling—as when states publicly declare cyber strategies for reputational deterrence—and tailored signaling, which seeks to threaten specific adversaries but risks revealing sensitive capabilities or targeting the wrong actor. She contends that while general deterrence posturing may remain feasible for established powers, tailored signaling in cyberspace faces intractable trade-offs between credibility and secrecy, thereby weakening coercive leverage and raising risks of inadvertent escalation. Taddeo concludes that uncritical analogies between kinetic and cyber deterrence must be abandoned in order to develop a domain-specific theory of cyber deterrence. Such a theory must address the conceptual redefinition of violence, harm, and political power in cyberspace, confront normative gaps in extending just war principles and individual rights protections to cyber operations, and resolve regulative ambiguities in applying international humanitarian law to non-kinetic conflicts. She outlines future research directions focused on integrating conceptual, normative, and regulatory dimensions to craft deterrence strategies that are ethically sound, legally compliant, and effective in maintaining international stability in the cyber-enabled era.

title: Spotting the bear credible attribution and Russian operations in cyberspace
source: Hacks, Leaks and Disruptions: Russian Cyber
abstract: This chapter by Herpig and Reinhold examines the critical challenge of credible attribution in cyberspace, with a particular focus on operations linked to Russia, and explores how attribution underpins legal and policy responses to cyberattacks. Framed within the context of international law, notably Article 51 of the UN Charter, the authors define attribution as a prerequisite for legitimate self-defense, diplomatic measures, and sanctions. They distinguish three audiences for attribution—national decision-makers, transnational partners, and the public—each with differing evidentiary thresholds and information sensitivities. The chapter then articulates a two-dimensional framework of attribution measures: inner-scope (domestic network monitoring) versus outer-scope (foreign network cooperation) and preventive (continuous data collection) versus reactive (real-time tracking during an incident). Through doctrinal analysis of state responsibility and due diligence obligations, the authors argue that robust attribution requires a blend of exhaustive technical forensics and geopolitical intelligence corroboration, yet the very secrecy of intelligence undermines public and allied confidence. In the Russian context, the prevalence of false-flag operations, use of third-party infrastructure, and political incentives to both accuse and deny complicate attribution further. Case studies such as GRU-linked election interference, the joint US/UK/Netherlands attribution of APT28 cyber operations against WADA and OPCW, and historical incidents like Stuxnet illustrate the multi-tiered nature of evidence and the pitfalls of “conclusion shortcuts” in crisis situations. The authors critique existing instruments, notably the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime, for failing to address state cyber espionage or military uses and propose that binding international norms are needed to standardize data-gathering, transparency in evidentiary thresholds, and enforceable due diligence requirements. They note limitations in relying on open-source or declassified materials, evolving technical landscapes that may outpace legal frameworks, and the inherently politicized nature of attribution. Finally, they call for future research to refine multilateral cooperation protocols, establish secure evidence-sharing mechanisms, and develop confidence-building measures that can operate under classified conditions. Such efforts are deemed essential to transform attribution from an elusive technical exercise into a credible basis for stable cyber deterrence and effective international legal enforcement.

title: Cyber Deterrence: A Comprehensive Approach?
abstract:
This chapter provides a rigorous legal analysis of the conditions under international law for a state’s resort to forceful self-defence in response to malicious cyber operations, focusing primarily on the framework of the United Nations Charter.  It begins by situating the right of self-defence in Article 51 of the Charter, as clarified by Article 21 of the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility (ASR), emphasizing that only an “armed attack” can give rise to a lawful defensive response.  Drawing on seminal International Court of Justice (ICJ) jurisprudence—particularly the Nicaragua, Oil Platforms, and Armed Activities decisions—the author unpacks the distinction between “use of force” and “armed attack,” emphasizing the gravity standard that requires analysis of both the scale and effects of state conduct.  The chapter explores how the ICJ’s flexible, fact-driven approach has at times left a grey area in which lower-threshold uses of force cannot legally be met with counter-force, a deliberate constraint designed to prevent unchecked escalations and preserve the primacy of peaceful dispute resolution under Article 33 of the Charter.

The analysis then interrogates the controversial “accumulation of events” theory, under which multiple individually non-severe uses of force might cumulatively amount to an armed attack.  While Judge Schwebel’s dissent in Nicaragua endorsed such a cumulative view, subsequent ICJ rulings have only hinted at endorsement, and states and UN bodies have largely refrained from explicit support.  As a result, the chapter concludes that the accumulation doctrine remains insufficiently codified in state practice to be considered customary international law.  Next, the author examines the implications of attribution errors and mistaken belief doctrines for self-defence.  Drawing parallels to the ASR’s treatment of countermeasures, the chapter argues that factual errors in identifying the author of a cyber operation cannot exonerate a state from responsibility for unlawful use of force—thus precluding application of a “Rendulic Rule” in self-defence.

A critical contribution of the chapter is its examination of the temporal dimension of cyber self-defence.  It highlights how high-confidence attribution often depends on extensive forensic and intelligence analysis—as exemplified by the months-long Mueller investigation into Russian interference—which conflicts with the immediacy requirement for self-defence responses outlined in the Tallinn Manual.  The Manual’s allowance for treating a series of cyber incidents as a continuing “cyber campaign” risks diluting the immediacy constraint and effectively granting an open-ended license to use force, paralleling the expansive self-defence rationale post-9/11.  Such a broad interpretation, the author warns, undermines the foundational jus contra bellum restraint and heightens escalation risks in cyberspace.  The chapter concludes that, in most cyber incidents, the delay and difficulty of attribution will preclude lawful force under Article 51, obliging states to resort to non-forcible remedies and to maintain a close temporal nexus between cyber attacks and any defensive response if the Charter’s pacific purposes are to be preserved in the evolving cyber domain.

title: Naming without shaming? Accuzations and international law in global cybersecurity.”
abstract:
This article examines the rise of public accusations against States for state‐sponsored cyber operations and explores why, despite an explosion of naming practices, these accusations rarely invoke international law. Finnemore and Hollis first document the emergence of over twenty high‐profile public attributions by States and private actors against major powers such as Russia, China, North Korea, Iran, the United Kingdom, and the United States. They note that while naming practices have become commonplace—driven by both improved attribution technologies and heightened geopolitical tensions—the parallel practice of shaming has proved weak: victim States typically deny or ignore accusations, and behavior change is rare. The authors argue that this failure is not merely a matter of political will, but also reflects the absence of explicit legal framing and the unique evidentiary and strategic barriers in cyberspace. 

Drawing on constructivist international relations literature and doctrinal international legal analysis, they conceptualize ‘accusations’ in cyberspace as comprising three discrete processes—attribution (linking an operation to an actor or territory), exposure (publicizing the operation to third parties), and condemnation (signifying disapproval)—rather than the unitary notion of “naming and shaming.” The authors show that these processes vary in purpose and effect depending on the accuser’s identity, the credibility of evidence, and the diplomatic context. Through case illustrations of WannaCry, NotPetya, and other incidents, they demonstrate how private cybersecurity firms and States have developed diverse attribution methodologies and how these shape the degree of public exposure and condemnation. 

Finnemore and Hollis then interrogate why international legal norms are conspicuously absent from most public statements condemning cyber operations. They identify four primary barriers: first, the evidentiary challenges in proving State responsibility under international law, given contested standards of control and the need for high proof thresholds; second, political risks of escalation and domestic constraints that discourage explicit legal claims; third, the lack of readily available legal remedies to enforce compliance once a violation is alleged; and fourth, the strategic calculus that publicizing intrusions without credible means of redress may embolden further attacks. These barriers help explain the rhetorical turn toward generic “norms” or “irresponsible behavior” rather than treaty or customary law references. 

Despite these obstacles, the authors argue that strategic reforms could strengthen the legal dimension of cyber accusations and advance both compliance and norm development. They propose practical measures such as: attributing operations to a territory rather than specific agencies to provide face‐saving exit ramps for accused States; employing private communications channels for initial protests when evidence lacks full public release; reframing accusations to highlight a State’s failure to prevent non‐State actors’ misuse of its infrastructure, thereby tapping established rules of state responsibility; and creating lists or rankings of State cyber practices to foster a uniform practice and opinio juris necessary for customary law formation. They also advocate for standardized attribution protocols, neutral third‐party institutions for peer‐reviewed attributions, multistakeholder fora, and capacity‐building incentives tied to performance, all to enhance credibility and accelerate norm codification. 

Finnemore and Hollis conclude that accusations—properly tailored—can serve multiple functions beyond coercive shaming, including deterrence, defensive signaling, norm constitution, and legal rule‐making. Their multidisciplinary framework offers policymakers a toolkit for designing accusations that leverage legal and normative pressures in cyberspace, ultimately shaping the rules that govern State behavior in the digital domain.

title: The politics of attributing blame for cyberattacks and the costs of uncertainty
abstract: In “The Politics of Attributing Blame for Cyberattacks and the Costs of Uncertainty,” Marcus Schulzke explores how pervasive uncertainty around the origins of cyberattacks constrains democratic accountability, shapes public opinion, and empowers narrow elite frames to define security threats and appropriate responses. Drawing on the unique technical characteristics of cyber conflict—such as indirect routing through third‐party servers, the “many‐hands” problem in software development, and lengthy, resource‐intensive forensic investigations—Schulzke argues that attributional uncertainty is more than a technical challenge for cybersecurity professionals and policymakers. Instead, it is a profound political issue that undermines citizens’ ability to evaluate government actions, to update causal beliefs as new evidence emerges, and to resist conspiratorial narratives. Through detailed case studies of U.S. allegations of Chinese and Russian state‐sponsored hacking, North Korea’s disputed intrusion into Sony Pictures Entertainment, and the Solar Sunrise virus incident of 1998, the paper illustrates how initial attributions—often based on circumstantial or fragmentary evidence—rapidly become entrenched in public discourse. These early blame assignments persist in “feedback loops” fueled by elite framing and media speculation, defying correction even when subsequent investigations produce contradictory findings. Schulzke synthesizes insights from political science research on blame attribution, framing effects, and information processing to show that when citizens confront ambiguous evidence, they default to familiar enemy tropes or conspiratorial explanations, deepening public misunderstanding and polarizing attitudes toward cybersecurity policies. Such dynamics impede democratic oversight by obscuring the link between decision‐makers’ crisis responses—whether diplomatic measures, deterrence strategies, or legislative reforms—and the threat actors they are intended to address. The author warns that attributional uncertainty allows opportunistic elites to exploit public fear, justifying aggressive or ill‐defined policy agendas while stifling critical debate. To counter these risks, Schulzke calls for interdisciplinary research combining digital forensics, public opinion surveys, controlled experiments on framing effects, and educational initiatives to enhance digital literacy. He advocates for transparent, standardized forensic methodologies and publicly accessible reporting to narrow uncertainty windows and empower citizens with more reliable information. By politicizing the attribution problem beyond elite circles and linking forensic complexity to mass opinion dynamics, this paper underscores both the urgent need to reduce uncertainty in cyber conflict and the value of reinforcing democratic accountability in responses to emerging security threats.

title: Back to Reality: Cross Domain Deterrence and Cyberspace
abstract: This paper by Aaron F. Brantly advances scholarship on cyber deterrence by proposing a framework for cross-domain deterrence (CDD) against state-sponsored cyber operations, and by empirically testing it in two high-profile U.S. cases involving China and Russia. Departing from conventional cyber deterrence models that emphasize within-domain responses, such as denial or punishment confined to cyberspace, Brantly argues that effective state-level deterrence requires clear signaling and credible retaliatory options in other domains—diplomatic, economic, or military—thus expanding deterrence theory into a multidisciplinary context. After reviewing the literature on traditional deterrence, cyber deterrence, and cross‐domain coercion, he develops a theoretical model defining CDD’s essential components: public warnings, specificity of red lines, credible threat of punishment, and an iterated framework for maintaining pressure. In the first case, the United States confronted sustained Chinese cyber espionage targeting U.S. intellectual property and critical infrastructure. Collecting robust forensic evidence and leveraging indictments, sanctions, and diplomatic pressures over an extended period, the Obama administration successfully degraded certain espionage activities by signaling that further cyber theft would incur severe economic and legal costs. The second case examines Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. elections, including hacking of political organizations, dissemination of stolen emails, and influence operations via social media. Constrained by a compressed timeline and domestic political sensitivities, U.S. responses were limited to a private warning to President Putin, a joint public intelligence statement, and post-election expulsions and sanctions. Brantly shows that these belated, ad-hoc measures lacked the timeliness, scale, and policy consistency necessary to alter Russian behavior, underscoring the importance of pre-emptive and sustained cross-domain signaling. Through comparative analysis, the paper demonstrates that CDD strategies calibrated to an adversary’s threat profile and implemented through iterated, proportional actions are more likely to shift an adversary’s calculus than one-off cyber-only responses. Brantly concludes with policy recommendations for U.S. and allied governments: institutionalize cross-domain deterrence planning, enhance interagency and private sector collaboration to gather and share attribution evidence, codify clear public red-lines for cyber violations, and develop modular escalation mechanisms that maintain credible threat thresholds. The evidence suggests that, while CDD is not a panacea, it offers a practical path to strengthen deterrence below the nuclear threshold by integrating cyber policy with broader coercive instruments, thereby reshaping state behavior in cyberspace.

title: Law, borders and the territorialisation of cyberspace
abstract: In “Law, Borders and the Territorialisation of Cyberspace,” Nicholas Tsagourias provides a comprehensive analysis of how traditional notions of territorial sovereignty and international legal order are extended, reconfigured, and contested within virtual space. Beginning with an exposition of the mutually constitutive relationship between states, borders, territory, and international law, the article recalls the Montevideo Convention’s criteria for statehood—permanent population, defined territory, government, and capacity to enter relations—and highlights how geographic and normative borders underpin the Westphalian model of sovereign authority. Tsagourias then examines whether and how these foundational concepts can be transposed into cyberspace, a domain characterized by a-territoriality, borderlessness, and a layered architecture of physical, logical, and social components. He elucidates two core processes by which the territorial logic of international law manifests online. The first, “territorialisation,” refers to the extraterritorial application of domestic and international legal norms to persons, data, and objects operating across networked infrastructures, effectively assigning them to legal jurisdictions irrespective of physical location. The second process involves active assertions of sovereignty in cyberspace, as states seek to delineate national “cyber zones” through legislative, technical, and diplomatic means. Drawing on theoretical debates and empirical examples—including China’s stratified model of cyber sovereignty and contrasting approaches that favor cyberspace as a global commons—Tsagourias argues that while technology can facilitate the “curving” of networked space along territorial lines, political, economic, and ideological factors ultimately drive state strategies. The article culminates in a critical inquiry into the ontological status of cyberspace itself: it refutes the possibility of a sovereign cyberspace independent of existing states, emphasizing that authority in digital realms remains mediated by terrestrial jurisdictions and the physical location of people and infrastructure. Consequently, Tsagourias concludes, the pressing issue is not whether cyberspace can be governed by spatially bounded sovereignty, but rather how the scope and limits of state authority over and within cyberspace should be negotiated. This question, he contends, will be determined by each state’s legal, political, economic, social, and cultural priorities, as well as by multilateral efforts to balance national regulatory imperatives against the benefits of open, interoperable networks.

title: A game of code: challenges of cyberspace as a domain of warfare
abstract: This article examines the complex challenges posed by cyberspace as an emergent domain of armed conflict under existing international humanitarian law (IHL) and state responsibility regimes. Recognizing the unprecedented potential for cyber-attacks to incapacitate critical civilian infrastructure—such as hospitals and power grids—and thereby inflict harm tantamount to conventional war crimes, the study critically assesses whether the Geneva Conventions and Additional Protocol I (AP I) sufficiently regulate malicious cyber operations or whether novel treaty instruments are required. Through an extensive qualitative literature review and illustrative case studies, the author first explores the principle of distinction in cyberspace, highlighting the inherent difficulty in differentiating military objectives from civilian objects within a dual-use, interconnected Internet environment. The analysis demonstrates that, although the foundational rules of armed conflict extend to cyber means and methods, practical impediments—especially the dual-use nature of networks and tools—undermine adherence to distinction and proportionality requirements. The paper then interrogates the challenges of attribution and responsibility, arguing that anonymity and evidentiary gaps in cyberspace frustrate the legal imputation of state or individual culpability, enabling plausible deniability and asymmetrical power dynamics among technologically advanced and less capable states. Notwithstanding these obstacles, the study affirms that existing treaties and customary norms criminalize cyber-attacks that disable life-sustaining civilian facilities and that such acts constitute war crimes regardless of the means employed. In addressing enforcement deficits, the article underscores the underutilized potential of Article 36 weapons reviews, noting that few states systematically assess how emerging cyber capabilities align with IHL prohibitions. Drawing attention to the Tallinn Manual as a pioneering interpretative guide, the author advocates for more regularized, cooperative legal review mechanisms to anticipate and mitigate the harmful consequences of cyber weapons. The conclusion emphasizes that technological innovation does not absolve human actors or states from ethical and legal accountability: cyberspace’s expanding role in conflict demands that states strengthen commitments to IHL through robust weapons review processes, refined evidentiary standards for attribution, and multilateral transparency in Article 36 reviews. By situating cyber warfare within the established legal framework and proposing pragmatic pathways for enforcement and normative development, the study contributes a multidisciplinary perspective that bridges cyber law, policy, and international humanitarian principles, urging responsible state adaptation to preserve the protection of human life in an era of digital conflict.

title: Cross-border data access and active cyber defense: Assessing legislative options for a new international cybersecurity rulebook
abstract: The paper addresses the escalating threat of state and non-state cyber intrusions against the United States, highlighting high-profile incidents such as the Equifax breach and 2016 election interference to set the stage for congressional debate over active cyber defense measures and cross-border data access reforms. It argues that while proposals like the Active Cyber Defense Certainty Act (ACDC) respond to private sector demands for so-called “hack back” authority to identify and attribute intruders by breaching foreign networks, they carry definitional ambiguities, oversight gaps, and risks of international escalation that could undermine emerging cyber norms. The study asks whether alternative legislative and policy avenues might better enhance attribution capabilities and strategic deterrence without triggering reciprocal actions from adversaries or eroding the rule of law in cyberspace. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology combined with conceptual policy analysis, the paper examines U.S. statutory frameworks under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act and international law principles, reviews the text and oversight provisions of ACDC, and assesses the legislative history and diplomatic context of the CLOUD Act. It systematically compares how each proposal addresses privacy, civil liberties, and international cooperation. The analysis finds that ACDC’s ambiguous definitions of active cyber defense and insufficient liability protections would likely invite unintended escalation, challenge allied partners’ legal sovereignty, and weaken efforts to codify cyber norms. In contrast, the CLOUD Act’s bi-lateral executive agreement model successfully modernizes the Stored Communications Act by streamlining mutual legal assistance for data held abroad, incorporating privacy safeguards, and creating a framework for reciprocal access rights that can be extended to like-minded states. The paper contributes a novel legislative comparison, demonstrating that enhancing lawful cross-border data access can serve as a de facto attribution tool, foster international cooperation, and strengthen long-term deterrence without authorizing intrusive offensive operations. Limitations include reliance on publicly available legislative texts and authoritative commentary, leaving open questions about the practical negotiation and implementation of CLOUD Act agreements and the potential for adversarial states to refuse participation. The authors propose further research into monitoring and compliance mechanisms for executive agreements under the CLOUD Act, the development of international standards for “attributional technology” carve-outs, and empirical evaluation of how cross-border data sharing affects investigative timelines and deterrence postures. Future work should also explore refined legislative language for active defense that aligns with multilateral cyber treaties, assess information-sharing frameworks among victims, and examine the interplay between network-hygiene best practices and evolving international cybersecurity norms.

title: A Due Diligence Standard of Attribution in Cyberspace
abstract: The anonymity and technical complexity of cyberspace pose significant challenges to the attribution of cyber operations, undermining the capacity of the international law framework of State responsibility to hold States accountable for harmful cyber activities. This gap has attracted heightened attention since the publication of the Tallinn Manual 2.0, which confined its discussion of attribution to the International Law Commission’s Articles on State Responsibility without offering a cogent remedy for the unique obstacles posed by cyberspace. Against this backdrop, the present study argues that the principle of due diligence offers a more effective and appropriate standard of attribution by situating due diligence as a secondary rule of international law, thereby facilitating the attribution of cyber operations to State actors when they have knowledge of wrongful cyber conduct emanating from their territory and fail to take reasonable measures to prevent it. The explicit research questions are: why does the existing attribution framework fall short in cyberspace, and how can due diligence be reconceptualized to bridge this gap? To answer these questions, the article adopts a doctrinal methodology, systematically analyzing primary sources of international law—including the Articles on State Responsibility, the Cybercrime Convention, United Nations General Assembly resolutions, and the Tallinn Manual series—alongside relevant State practice and opinio juris drawn from multilateral instruments such as the Group of Governmental Experts reports, NATO policy declarations, and high-profile cyber incidents involving major cyber actors. This comprehensive legal analysis uncovers a three-level attribution problem in cyberspace—computer identification, human-machine nexus, and nexus to the State—that renders traditional attribution rules ineffective. It finds that recasting due diligence as a secondary rule creates a general condition of responsibility whereby a State is responsible when it has knowledge of an unlawful cyber operation from its territory, could have taken measures to prevent it, and failed to do so. This reconceptualization promotes international peace and security by lowering the evidentiary threshold for attribution, thereby enabling more robust recourse to countermeasures and dispute resolution mechanisms. The study contributes a novel framework for attribution that departs from the Tallinn Manual approach by elevating due diligence from a procedural obligation to a decisive standard of attribution, and demonstrates how treaties such as the Cybercrime Convention and non-binding instruments like the GGE reports and NATO Cyber Defense Policy collectively reinforce this emerging norm. The principal limitations of the research stem from the nascent and uneven State practice in openly attributing cyber operations, as well as the reluctance of many States to publicly acknowledge responsibility or victimhood in high-profile incidents. The authors acknowledge that the crystallization of due diligence into customary law will require further uniform practice and opinio juris, particularly as more States engage in public attribution and response. Future research directions include empirical tracking of State responses to cyber incidents to assess norm emergence, analysis of how countermeasure regimes interact with the due diligence standard in practice, and exploration of the implications of this attribution model for self-defence against non-State actors in cyberspace.

title: "virtual" disenfranchisement: cyber election meddling in the grey zones of international law
abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of how the centuries-old framework of state responsibility and countermeasures under public international law can be recalibrated to address wrongful cyber intrusions that do not rise to the level of armed attack. Recognizing that most cyberattacks fall below the threshold of use of force and thus cannot trigger the right of self-defense, the author, Lei Zhu, traces the historical evolution of countermeasures from early private reprisals in ancient Greece and Roman letters of marque through the UN International Law Commission’s 2001 Draft Articles on the Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts and key jurisprudence such as the 1946 Air Service Agreement arbitration and the 1997 International Court of Justice’s Gabčíkovo-Nagymaros Project judgment. Zhu identifies three core challenges to applying countermeasures in cyberspace: first, attribution difficulties and the risk of overextending state responsibility under the due diligence obligation when attributing cyber operations to state actors; second, the impracticality of traditional procedural prerequisites—such as prior notice and offers to negotiate—in the fluid and rapid environment of cyber operations; and third, the lack of clear, operational benchmarks for the proportionality test, which risks subjective or uneven application. To mitigate these uncertainties, the author proposes adopting a functional proportionality standard calibrated to the purpose of countermeasures—namely, to induce the cessation of wrongful acts—rather than strict equivalence of harm, thereby enabling tailored responses that account for disparities in state capabilities. Moreover, Zhu advocates for the recognition of cyber-specific countermeasures, including active defense measures—such as honeypots, sandboxes, and controlled hack-back techniques—that mirror the nature of the wrongful act while remaining within reasonable impact limits and thus more easily justified under proportionality. Through analysis of state practice, including U.S. economic sanctions on North Korea in response to the 2014 Sony hack and Estonia’s response to alleged Russian DDoS operations in 2007, the study illustrates how non-forceful countermeasures have been employed but remain underdeveloped in doctrine. Acknowledging the failure of the 2017 UN Group of Governmental Experts to reach consensus on procedural and substantive norms, the paper calls for empirical research on state countermeasure use, the development of quantitative proportionality benchmarks, and renewed multilateral dialogue to codify cyber-tailored procedural rules. Zhu concludes that while existing international law on countermeasures provides a foundational structure, its stringent prerequisites and ambiguous proportionality criteria hinder effective and lawful state responses in cyberspace. To ensure that countermeasures remain a viable and constrained mechanism, the author urges doctrinal clarity, the adoption of functional proportionality metrics, and empirical data collection to inform the codification of cyber-specific norms, thereby striking a balance between efficacy and restraint in the evolving domain of cyber conflict.

title: The Cyber Deterrence Problem
authors: A Brantly; T Minarik; R Jakschis; L Lindstrom
source: 2018 10TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON CYBER CONFLICT (CYCON X): MAXIMISING EFFECTS
abstract: The paper addresses the enduring challenge of applying deterrence theory to the digital domain, where sophisticated cyber actors can place critical assets at risk without deploying traditional military force, thereby raising urgent questions about the continued relevance of established deterrence frameworks. In highlighting the gap between nuclear-era deterrence concepts and the unique attributes of cyberspace, the author argues that understanding deterring adversary behavior in this new arena is crucial for maintaining interstate stability and shaping coherent national strategies. The study aims to clarify whether classical rational deterrence models, enriched by cognitive insights, can be adapted for both within-domain cyber signaling and cross-domain coercive threats, ultimately posing the research question of whether cyberspace is fundamentally compatible with deterrence or necessitates a fundamentally new approach. To answer this question, the work undertakes a conceptual and analytical review, first surveying the historical evolution of three waves of deterrence scholarship—from Bernard Brodie’s nuclear-era abstractions through the incorporation of behavioral economics and cognitive psychology—and then mapping those theories onto the tactical, operational, and strategic dimensions of cyberspace. This dual-method methodology combines literature synthesis with domain-specific technical analysis to illuminate how state and sub-state actors assess costs, benefits, and credibility when considering cyber operations. The analysis reveals that deterrence constrained to a single domain heightens risks and can undermine cost-imposing signals, while neglecting cross-domain interactions weakens overall efficacy. The paper finds that within-domain deterrence often fails due to ambiguity in signaling and the inherent complexity of attribution, and that effective coercion in cyberspace requires integrated measures across political, economic, and military tools. Building on these findings, the author contributes a dynamic framework that transcends traditional within-domain deterrence models by advocating an integrated approach to cyber deterrence that incorporates denial strategies, punitive options, and hybrid signals aligned with established interstate deterrence practices. This integrated cyber deterrence model emphasizes the need for combined signaling across multiple domains to generate clear, credible costs to adversaries. Although the theoretical nature of the study limits empirical validation and acknowledges that technical domain understanding is continually evolving, it establishes a foundation for refining national strategies that account for the interconnectedness of cyber and physical domains. The work concludes by outlining the trajectory for future research, including the development of operational guidelines for national cyber deterrence strategies and empirical case studies to test the proposed dynamic model in real-world conflict scenarios, thereby charting a path toward robust policy frameworks that can effectively deter state-sponsored cyber aggression.

title: Rethinking Secrecy in Cyberspace: The Politics of Voluntary Attribution
abstract: This article addresses the enduring challenge of secrecy in cyberspace by investigating why some actors choose to reveal their responsibility for cyber operations despite the technical feasibility and strategic benefits of anonymity. The authors note that most scholarship treats secrecy in cyberspace as a monolithic phenomenon that persists from inception through completion of an attack, thus underplaying the decision to claim credit once an operation concludes. They argue that while clandestinity—a default requirement for operational success to preserve surprise and prevent countermeasures—is nearly universal for cyber intrusions, the choice to act covertly by denying sponsorship is a discrete political decision driven by an actor’s objectives. The article asks why states and politically motivated nonstate actors sometimes forgo plausible deniability and voluntarily attribute cyberattacks, and whether they do so publicly or privately. To explore these questions, the authors construct a theoretical framework distinguishing between clandestine operations, in which the action itself is secret, and covert operations, in which the sponsor’s identity is hidden. They situate this framework within the life cycle of a cyberattack, identifying two decision points: at T0, when operational details are concealed to maximize tactical advantage, and at T1, when the actor decides whether to deny responsibility or claim it, either privately via discreet diplomatic channels and technical signatures or publicly through broad announcements. Employing qualitative case narratives drawn from secondary materials, official statements, news reports, and interviews, the authors examine illustrative incidents involving state-level cyber coercion—where private attribution serves to enhance target compliance while limiting escalation risks—and nonstate actor campaigns such as those by Anonymous, which publicly credit-claim to demonstrate capability, influence public opinion, and recruit supporters. They find strong support for their proposition that states are most likely to attribute publicly when coercion requires credibility but will do so privately to manage escalation, whereas nonstate actors consistently pursue public attribution to leverage media attention and mobilize resources. The article contributes a unified framework that integrates insights from the literature on secrecy in international relations and cyber warfare, clarifying when and why actors select into covert action or relinquish anonymity. It highlights the strategic parallels between cyber operations and conventional uses of force, suggesting that voluntary attribution can serve as a signal of resolve and intent akin to public threats in deterrence theory. The authors acknowledge limitations inherent in relying on open sources and secondary accounts, noting the difficulty of accessing internal deliberations of states and clandestine networks, and framing their study as theory construction rather than definitive testing. For future research, they propose empirical investigations into the efficacy of cyber coercion relative to traditional coercive measures, comparative analyses of attribution strategies across different actor types, and deeper exploration of how voluntary attribution decisions inform defensive and diplomatic policy responses in an evolving cyber threat environment.

title: Fake news and international law
abstract: This article examines the applicability and adequacy of existing international legal frameworks to the phenomenon of "fake news", understood both in its strict sense (deliberately false factual statements) and its wider sense (distorted or tendentious reporting), with a particular focus on state-sponsored disinformation campaigns that exploit modern communication technologies. Drawing on historical precedents from the League of Nations’ interwar efforts and the United Nations’ immediate post-World War II broadcasting and correction conventions, the author analyses how false and distorted news have been regulated, and tests these frameworks against the 2016 “Lisa case,” in which Russian government–funded outlets RT and Sputnik disseminated misleading accounts of an alleged abduction and rape of a Russian-German teenager in Berlin. The case study illustrates how false news—fabricated claims of abduction and rape—can be objectively disproven and may fall within the ambit of repressive regulation under the 1936 International Convention on the Use of Broadcasting in the Cause of Peace (“Broadcasting Convention”) and the principle of non-intervention in domestic affairs. The article argues that, while false news can be legitimately proscribed when its falsity is clear and attributable, distorted or tendentious reporting raises far more complex legal and normative issues. Distorted news—framing, selective emphasis, or omission of facts to induce false conclusions—enjoys stronger protection under the right to freedom of expression (Article 19 ICCPR; Article 10 ECHR) and is susceptible to abuse if subject to repressive measures. The author reviews case law (e.g., ECtHR Olafsson v. Iceland; Heinisch v. Germany) and policy practice (UK Ofcom’s finding against RT for lack of due impartiality) to demonstrate the narrow scope in which distorted news might be regulated without infringing fundamental rights. Recognizing attribution challenges in the information age—where false news may originate from informal online platforms, and distortions from identifiable media outlets—the article explores the utility of non-repressive remedial mechanisms. In particular, it highlights the 1953 Convention on the International Right of Correction’s right to reply, which obliges states (and the UN) to disseminate corrections, and suggests that cooperative networks could amplify corrective measures without requiring formal attribution of state sponsorship. The author further proposes that preserving media pluralism—through neutral antitrust enforcement and subsidies—and enhancing transparency of media ownership and fact-checking obligations can fortify trust in information ecosystems. Ultimately, the article concludes that a universal, formal legal standard against fake news must be applied neutrally across all actors to avoid double standards and the risk of instrumentalization by authoritarian regimes. A free and pluralistic press, complemented by targeted government information policies, fact-checking, and transparency requirements, remains the best safeguard against the multifaceted challenges posed by fake news in the digital era.

title: Ten Years after the Estonian Cyberattacks: Defense and Adaptation in the Age of Digital Insecurity Country in Focus
abstract: Over the past decade, the intersection of digital innovation and state security has given rise to a critical challenge: how can a nation safeguard its infrastructure and sovereignty against sophisticated cyberattacks that may be state-sponsored or politically motivated? In this context, the 2007 distributed denial of service strikes on Estonia, widely viewed as the first significant gateway cyberattack by a state actor, highlight the vulnerability of a highly digitized society reliant on online banking, government services, and critical utilities. This research matters because it examines how a small state transformed a disruptive episode into a blueprint for national and international cyber resilience. It aims to answer the question: what policy, legal, societal, and collaborative measures did Estonia deploy to deter, defend, and adapt to large-scale cyber threats in the years following the attacks? The study employs a qualitative case study methodology, drawing on government action plans, national security strategies, legislative texts, academic analyses of the April 2007 events, and reports from NATO, EU, and private-sector cyber emergency teams. By reviewing primary policy documents such as Estonia’s Cyber Security Strategy (2014–2017), legal amendments to the Emergency Act and Penal Code, and records of international exercises, the author reconstructs the evolution of a multi-dimensional defense posture. The findings reveal four complementary policy arenas that underpin Estonia’s enhanced readiness: first, the establishment of national cyber defense capabilities including the Cyber Defense League and resilient data infrastructure through government cloud and overseas data embassies; second, legal modifications granting authorities rapid incident-response powers and updating criminal statutes to penalize cyber sabotage; third, societal adaptation via public–private partnerships, volunteer networks, and a culture of cyber awareness embedded in e-governance; and fourth, proactive international collaboration with NATO, EU institutions, and bilateral partners to share threat intelligence and conduct large-scale exercises. Collectively, these measures not only restored Estonia’s operational networks within weeks of the 2007 attacks but also set global standards for integrating cyber considerations into Article 5 deterrence strategies. The study contributes a conceptual framework—the ‘‘Estonian template’’—for transforming acute cyber crisis into sustained strategic resilience, highlighting the importance of comprehensive legal, diplomatic, and societal components alongside technical defenses. The primary limitation of this work is its focus on Estonia’s unique characteristics as a small, technologically advanced state with strong Western alliances, which may constrain direct application to larger or less digitally integrated nations. Nevertheless, the research points to future avenues, including comparative analyses of cyber adaptation in other NATO member states, assessments of the template’s scalability to middle powers, and empirical evaluation of deterrence effects stemming from multinational cyber exercises. By distilling lessons from Estonia’s trajectory, this study lays the groundwork for broader inquiry into how states can craft proactive, law-based, and norm-building approaches to secure national assets in an era of digital insecurity.

title: State responsibility in cyberspace: the problem of attribution of cyberattacks conducted by non-state actors
abstract: This paper examines the challenges of attributing responsibility for cyberattacks conducted by non-state actors under existing international law frameworks and offers a categorical analytical model to guide legal practitioners and policymakers. As cyberspace operations become increasingly central to statecraft and interstate tensions, non-state actors often serve as proxies, enabling states to evade accountability for wrongful acts. The author undertakes a doctrinal review of the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on State Responsibility, relevant international case law, and scholarly commentary to interrogate whether—and under what conditions—states may be held liable for cyber operations executed by private individuals or groups. Building on this doctrinal foundation, two primary attribution theories are formulated: de facto organ theory and control theory. De facto organ theory (agency-based attribution) requires evidence of complete dependence, specific operational instructions, and effective integration of the private actor into the state apparatus, thereby treating the individual’s cyber conduct as an act of the state. Control theory (control-based attribution), by contrast, focuses on the degree of operational control a state exercises, the organizational capacity of the actor, and extraterritorial considerations to ascribe responsibility. The analysis contrasts substantive rules—defining what constitutes a state act—with evidentiary standards—determining the threshold of proof—demonstrating that high thresholds may permit states to evade liability, whereas lower thresholds foster accountability. Through comparative examination of high- and low-proof requirements, the paper highlights current ambiguities in state practice regarding evidentiary burdens in cyber contexts. The findings indicate that while uniform state practice has not yet crystallized, both theoretical models provide coherent legal mechanisms for attributing private cyber conduct to states, thus facilitating accountability for cyber aggression. Limitations are acknowledged, including evolving state practice, variability in evidentiary standards, and the fluid nature of digital evidence. To address these gaps, the paper calls for empirical research to document how states apply attribution models in real-world incidents, normative dialogue to refine evidentiary thresholds appropriate to cyber operations, and further exploration of how international jurisprudence may adapt to cyber-specific challenges. Ultimately, the proposed categorical framework bridges doctrinal attribution rules and the substantive and evidentiary complexities of cyberspace, offering a practical roadmap for clarifying state responsibility in cyber conflict and advancing more robust international norms for accountability.

title: Jurisdiction and attribution of state responsibility in cyberspace
abstract: This book chapter analyzes the application and adaptation of traditional principles of jurisdiction and state responsibility to cyber activities, highlighting the legal challenges posed by the borderless and anonymous nature of cyberspace. It first clarifies that, while states cannot claim sovereignty over cyberspace itself, they retain sovereign prerogatives to prescribe and enforce domestic law over cyber infrastructure and activities within their territory, including airspace and territorial waters. Territorial jurisdiction extends both subjectively—over incidents originating within the state’s territory—and objectively—over acts causing effects within the territory, regardless of origin. The chapter then examines extraterritorial bases of jurisdiction that states increasingly rely upon: active personality (jurisdiction over nationals), passive personality (jurisdiction over offences against nationals), and the protective principle (jurisdiction over acts threatening state security). It discusses the controversial principle of universal jurisdiction and its established scope in piracy and suppression of serious international crimes. Enforcing criminal jurisdiction abroad requires the host state’s consent, as affirmed by jurisprudence from the Permanent Court of Arbitration and the Permanent Court of International Justice. In the cyber context, the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime exemplifies a treaty-based approach using territoriality and nationality as jurisdictional bases, with UNODC studies confirming their effectiveness in practice. The chapter then turns to the attribution of cyber operations to states under international law, reviewing the Tallinn Manual, UN Commission reports, and ICJ jurisprudence. It surveys the standards of proof articulated by the ICJ—varying from “weighty and convincing” evidence to “fully conclusive” proof—and contrasts these with the pragmatic heuristics used by intelligence analysts. Through illustrative case studies, including the 2014 Sony Pictures hack and allegations of interference in the 2016 US presidential election, the author demonstrates how high burdens of proof and attribution asymmetry hinder victim states’ ability to hold perpetrators accountable. To address these shortcomings, the chapter presents the “virtual control” test, which would shift the burden of disproving state responsibility onto a state that funds or equips non-state actors, thereby creating a rebuttable presumption of involvement and incentivizing due diligence. This novel framework also presumes that use of state infrastructure for an attack implicates state responsibility unless convincingly rebutted. The chapter acknowledges limitations, including reliance on doctrinal analysis and case-specific examples rather than systematic empirical data, and notes that adoption of modified attribution standards depends on evolving state practice and potential judicial endorsement. Finally, it explores attribution of cyber acts to international organizations under the Draft Articles on the Responsibility of International Organizations, assessing consensus-based decision-making in NATO and the European Court of Human Rights’ jurisprudence attributing acts to the United Nations in Kosovo and to member states in Iraq. By synthesizing legal doctrine, treaty provisions, judicial decisions, and state practice, the chapter offers an integrated cyber law framework to guide policymakers, practitioners, and scholars in navigating the complex terrain of jurisdiction and state responsibility in cyberspace.

title: Understanding Nuclear Weapon Risks (John Borrie, et al., eds.) 61 (2017)
abstract:
This chapter examines the escalating vulnerabilities of modern nuclear and conventional weapons systems to cyber attacks, framing digital interference as a critical yet underexamined facet of strategic stability. Over recent decades, weapons capabilities have become inextricably linked to digital technologies at every stage of their operation—launch, targeting, command and control, security, and safety—rendering them susceptible to data theft, manipulation, and disruption by state and non‐state actors. The authors survey documented cyber intrusions across diverse critical infrastructures—energy grids, maritime transport, space assets, and financial networks—to illustrate the broad threat landscape. They then turn to the implications for nuclear deterrence, arguing that any compromise of nuclear command, control, communications, and intelligence systems could undermine the precarious balance of mutual restraint by introducing confusion and uncertainty into high‐stakes decision‐making. In particular, they highlight how unanticipated cyber interferences could obscure the origin of attacks, pressuring leaders toward hasty or erroneous responses and raising the specter of inadvertent escalation to conventional or nuclear war.

Drawing on historical near‐misses—such as Stanislav Petrov’s 1983 decision to discount a false missile alert and the NORAD simulation tape incident—the chapter illustrates how trust in data and systems is integral to strategic calculations. The authors argue for a comprehensive, all‐cyber‐risks approach to safeguard nuclear infrastructures, emphasizing layered vulnerability assessments that encompass personnel, air‐gaps, cyber hygiene protocols, and rapid incident reporting. They assess the spectrum of potential threats, from espionage targeting warhead designs and facility blueprints to manipulation of launch codes and satellite communications. Recognizing that state actors currently pose the greatest capabilities, they caution that evolving technologies will lower barriers for terrorist groups to inflict high‐consequence damage, necessitating proactive threat modeling and resilience planning.

Policy recommendations include harmonized international standards for nuclear cybersecurity; integration of cyber risk into deterrence doctrines; routine red‐teaming exercises; intelligence‐sharing agreements among nuclear alliances; and establishment of clear attribution frameworks to reduce misperceptions in crises. By foregrounding the interplay of technology, human judgment, and strategic doctrine, the chapter contributes a multidisciplinary perspective that bridges cyber policy, security studies, and arms control. It underscores the urgency of addressing cyber vulnerabilities to preserve the credibility of deterrence and prevent catastrophic escalation, ultimately calling for renewed international cooperation and robust cyber governance in the nuclear domain.

title: Stateless attribution: toward international accountability in cyberspace
authors: Jsi Davis; Ba Boudreaux; Jw Welburn; J Aguirre; C Ogletree; G McGovern; M Chase
abstract:
This report by Davis et al. addresses the critical gap in credible, transparent attribution of state and non-state cyber operations and proposes the establishment of an independent Global Cyber Attribution Consortium to enhance international accountability. The authors begin with a review of high-profile incidents such as the Bangladesh Central Bank heist and Democratic National Committee intrusion, highlighting inconsistencies in evidentiary standards, naming conventions, and the fragmentation of attribution practices across intelligence agencies, private cybersecurity firms, and academic researchers. Public skepticism towards attribution findings often stems from opaque decision-making processes, undisclosed analytical methods, and divergent thresholds for evidence. Drawing on a comparative analysis of existing multilateral organizations and investigative protocols in analogous domains—ranging from the United Nations Group of Governmental Experts to joint law-enforcement task forces—the report identifies key governance principles that underlie legitimacy: multistakeholder oversight, peer review, standardized procedures, and tiered reporting mechanisms. 

The authors assess the principal barriers to credible attribution, including political resistance due to state sovereignty concerns, the reluctance to share sensitive intelligence, and the absence of shared norms for evidence adjudication. They then present a conceptual blueprint for a consortium composed of government, industry, and civil society representatives, underpinned by a charter defining procedural rules, evidentiary requirements, and confidentiality safeguards. Core features include an independent secretariat, a peer-reviewed adjudication panel, and a public register of attribution reports with tiered disclosure levels balancing transparency and operational security. The consortium’s mandate would extend to standardizing metadata taxonomies, convening annual stakeholder workshops, and liaising with regional bodies to build cooperative networks. 

While acknowledging limitations—such as the lack of empirical validation of the consortium model and potential non-participation by powerful states—the report outlines a research agenda to pilot evidentiary frameworks in controlled exercises, legal analyses on state consent and liability, and policy dialogues to refine the governance architecture. Ultimately, the proposed consortium represents an innovative, multidisciplinary policy mechanism aimed at bolstering trust in cyber attribution, reinforcing norms of responsible state behavior, and deterring malicious activity through credible accountability pathways.

title: The control & capabilities test: How a new legal regime is shaping attribution in cyberspace
source: 2017 International Conference on Cyber Conflict (CyCon U.S.)
abstract: This article by Christopher Whyte investigates how states integrate cyber operations into influence campaigns, conceptualized as cyber-enabled influence operations (CEIO). Utilizing the novel Counter-Society Influence Operations (CSIO) dataset, which codes over 200 episodes of interference between 2000 and 2020, the author disaggregates distinct forms of cyber activity that underpin influence operations and evaluates their effects on campaign success, attribution risk, and alignment with domestic political factions. Quantitative analysis reveals that most CEIO episodes rely heavily on low-intensity preparatory intrusions—such as reconnaissance, malware infections, and botnet formation—that typically cease within three months of campaign onset. These restrained cyber actions serve to seed influence networks and evade detection, reshaping understandings of how cyber operations function in influence warfare. Conversely, severe cyber interventions such as denial-of-service attacks, data corruption, and website defacements are rare and counterproductive. Whyte finds a clear negative correlation between escalatory cyber activity and influence campaign success, alongside a positive association with attribution to belligerent actors and greater congruence with fringe domestic factions. This counterintuitive dynamic, termed the  subversion aversion paradox,  emerges when belligerent states, facing diminished prospects for covert subversion, resort to performative, high-visibility cyber measures that harden societal divisions and secure future operational advantages. Drawing on subversion theory, the article argues that visible cyber interference can legitimize extremist victim narratives and entrench  othering  effects, thereby creating longer-term windows for manipulation. The research contributes two principal insights to the study of cyber conflict and international relations: first, it highlights the predominance of low-intensity preparatory cyber actions in CEIO, challenging prevailing scholarship that emphasizes direct cyber attacks for influence generation; second, it conceptualizes the subversion aversion paradox by linking domestic political contexts to strategic shifts in cyber deployment. The author acknowledges limitations, including reliance on publicly available attribution data and the inability of statistical associations to establish causal process tracing. He calls for in-depth case studies of underexplored CEIO episodes—such as those involving the Belarusian Cyber Partisans, Brexit-era UK elections, and Chinese or Iranian operations—to validate and refine the paradox and dissect decision-making pathways from covert intrusion to overt cyber escalation. Future research should also pursue comparative analyses across diverse geopolitical contexts to elucidate how regimes navigate trade-offs between operational stealth and performative signaling in digital-age influence warfare.

title: Cyberspace Security: Trends, Conflicts and Strategic Stability
abstract:
In “Cyberspace Security: Trends, Conflicts and Strategic Stability,” Xu Longdi examines the evolution of national and international approaches to cybersecurity, framing cyberspace as a strategic domain alongside land, sea, air, and space. The paper first maps key trends in cyberspace security, highlighting the rapid pace of technological innovation—from big data analytics, cloud computing, and the Internet of Things, to emergent fields such as artificial intelligence, smart cities, trusted computing, and quantum communications. Xu underscores how these advances, while essential for growth and connectivity, equally amplify risks: sophisticated malware, ransomware (e.g., WannaCry), advanced persistent threats targeting critical infrastructure, and the exploitation of personal privacy and financial systems. He observes that major powers have responded by intensifying investments in cyber defense and offense capabilities, establishing specialized institutions, and codifying laws and policies to govern cyberspace.

The article then shifts to the sources of cyber conflict, exploring ideological, linguistic, and interest-based divisions among states. Xu contrasts the doctrine of “cyber sovereignty” championed by China and Russia—defined as the extension of traditional state sovereignty to online domains—with the Western advocacy for “cyber freedom” as espoused by the United States and its allies. He notes that although the United Nations Group of Governmental Experts and NATO have formally recognized cyber sovereignty principles, the concept remains contested. Moreover, he argues that cyber incidents cannot be uniformly categorized as acts of war; instead, their classification depends on factors such as actor identity, intent, degree of attribution, and potential consequences. He emphasizes that ultimate determinations of cyber warfare are inherently political decisions, with strategic stability in cyberspace vulnerable to disruption when cyberspace breaches cross thresholds of attribution, intention, and severity.

In the final section, Xu proposes a multi-faceted strategy for shaping cyber strategic stability and reducing conflict risks. He advocates enhancing international dialogue and cooperation to bridge interpretive gaps in technical and political terminology, foster mutual understanding, and build trust through channels such as bilateral cyber hotlines. He calls for sustained investment in domestic technological innovation and the cultivation of “cyber power,” underscoring that without core offensive and defensive capabilities, policy frameworks alone cannot secure cyberspace. On deterrence, Xu reviews Joseph Nye’s model—encompassing punishment threats, defensive denial, entanglement, and normative taboos—and recognizes both the utility and limitations of cyber deterrence given attribution challenges. He urges states to exercise restraint in offensive cyber operations, pursue arms-control measures, advance confidence-building mechanisms, and institutionalize cyber diplomacy. Collectively, these measures, he argues, will contribute directly and indirectly to a peaceful, secure, and stable cyberspace, preserving strategic equilibrium among states.

title: Is Cyberattack the Next Pearl Harbor
source: North Carolina Journal of Law & Technology
abstract: This chapter provides an in-depth examination of the self-help measures available to victim States in response to unlawful, state-sponsored cyber operations under existing international law, focusing on retorsion, countermeasures, and self-defence. It begins by situating these measures within the broader context of the decentralized enforcement of international law, emphasizing that in the absence of a global enforcement authority, self-help remains indispensable for upholding State obligations. The author defines retorsion as lawful but unfriendly acts—such as diplomatic severance, expulsions, travel bans, or economic restrictions—undertaken to signal displeasure while remaining within legal bounds, and contrasts it with countermeasures, which are otherwise unlawful acts rendered lawful as proportionate responses to internationally wrongful acts. The chapter introduces cyber retorsion, illustrating how States may tacitly encourage or tolerate distributed denial-of-service attacks against adversaries, and analyzes landmark case studies including the 2007 Estonia and 2008 Georgia cyber incidents and Operation Ababil against US financial institutions. In the discussion of countermeasures, the author argues that this modality should be the primary tool for victim States, permitting reversible, proportionate sanctions—such as network blocks or asset freezes—and demonstrates how the conditions set forth in the Articles on State Responsibility (notification, proportionality, non-use of force) legitimize cyber countermeasures, particularly given that most cyber intrusions do not meet the armed attack threshold under the jus ad bellum. The self-defence section reviews jus ad bellum criteria, clarifying that only a narrow subset of cyber operations qualify as armed attacks warranting kinetic or forceful responses, and introduces the “accumulation theory” whereby multiple lower-intensity events might collectively constitute an armed attack. It concludes that countermeasures should serve as the default response to state-sponsored cyber operations, reserving self-defence for exceptional scenarios. The chapter further examines emerging State practice—highlighting the United States’ use of public retorsion through sanctions and covert countermeasures following the Sony Pictures hack and the 2016 DNC intrusion—and warns of potential fragmentation of cyber norms after the impasse at the fifth UN Group of Governmental Experts, underscoring the urgent need to clarify cyber law at both the jus ad bellum and jus in bello levels.

title: Cyberspace and International Order
authors: M Carr; Hidemi Suganami; Madeline Carr; Adam Humphreys
source: The Anarchical Society at 40: Contemporary Challenges and Prospects
abstract: The rapid evolution of information and communication technologies has introduced profound uncertainties into the anarchical structure of international relations, as illustrated by the persistent difficulty of accurately attributing cyber attacks to state or non-state actors. This problem challenges core assumptions about state identifiability that underpin diplomatic engagement, deterrence strategies, and the application of international law in armed conflict. Recognizing this, the author sets out to examine how attribution uncertainty reshapes established social processes and institutions of international order, drawing on Hedley Bull’s framework from The Anarchical Society to frame the inquiry. The essay aims to answer the question of how problems of cyber attribution affect states’ motivations to comply with international legal obligations and participate in norm-building, and what implications follow for the future of peaceful cooperation in cyberspace. Methodologically, the research adopts a qualitative, theoretical approach, engaging in conceptually driven analysis of Bull’s social theory alongside a systematic review of diplomatic and legal developments, including the UN Group of Governmental Experts reports and state practice examples such as the power-grid attacks in Ukraine. Through this interdisciplinary lens, the author identifies that attribution uncertainty undermines three foundational motivations for legal compliance—obligation, coercion, and reciprocity—by allowing malicious actors to exploit anonymity and evade deterrent responses. At the same time, she finds that this same uncertainty has catalyzed multilateral negotiations on voluntary norms of responsible state behaviour, evidenced by the 2015 UNGGE consensus on non-binding principles, and opened new diplomatic pathways for managing tensions through social practices rather than legal adjudication alone. The contribution of this work lies in relocating the attribution problem from a technical or military domain into the social fabric of international order, offering a novel conceptual insight: that anonymity itself constitutes a new dimension of anarchy that states must navigate through both normative and diplomatic channels. Acknowledged limitations include the absence of empirical case study fieldwork and the focus on attribution’s legal and normative dimensions at the expense of deeper analysis of great-power strategic behaviour and the balance of power. The study concludes by advocating for future research to empirically investigate how emerging attribution technologies and diplomatic strategies interact in practice, to assess the transition of UNGGE norms toward customary international law, and to explore alternative social mechanisms for regulating state conduct in cyberspace beyond formal legal regimes.

title: Deterrence is Not a Credible Strategy for Cyberspace
authors: Michael P. Fischerkeller; Richard J. Harknett
abstract: The article addresses the persistent mismatch between U.S. national cybersecurity strategy and the distinctive structural and operational features of cyberspace, arguing that reliance on deterrence and operational restraint has produced a strategic deficit in protecting and advancing national interests. The authors justify their analysis by highlighting how cyber aggression in recent years has undermined the assumptions of deterrence, and they set out to propose and evaluate an alternative strategic framework—cyber persistence—that capitalizes on the domain’s uniqueness. Their objective is to demonstrate why deterrence alone is insufficient, to articulate the requirements for shaping international norms through active engagement, and to define the principles and mechanisms of a capabilities-based persistent strategy. Employing a conceptual policy analysis methodology, they draw on official doctrinal definitions, case studies of sabotage, espionage, and subversion operations attributed to state actors, analyses of domain characteristics such as low cost of entry, malleability, persistent contact, reversible effects, and their assessment of existing U.S. strategic documents and White House reports. They further examine practical examples of automated intrusion detection and mitigation techniques, moving target defense, deception measures like honeypots, and large-scale botnet disruption to illustrate the feasibility of continuous active engagement. The authors find that deterrence premised on fear of escalation overlooks cyberspace’s capacity for precise, temporary, and reversible damage, and that states embracing operational persistence can shape acceptable behavior and enjoy a resiliency advantage. They show that shaping norms through diplomacy without concurrent active operations leaves like-minded states in a weakened position relative to unlike-minded actors. As a contribution, the article introduces the concept of cyber persistence as a distinct strategic doctrine grounded in persistent engagement, domain shaping, automated courses of action, and integrated counter-subversion, and it outlines organizational and authority changes needed to implement it, including adjustments to Presidential Policy Directive 41 and Cyber Mission Force allocation. The authors acknowledge limitations in their analysis, noting that implementation would require significant legal and policy revisions, careful design of automated decision models, and the political will to accept proactive cyber operations. They also recognize that persistent engagement could challenge existing norms and that resource constraints may affect scalability. For future research, they propose empirical evaluation of automated cyber persistence tools, development of decision frameworks to balance persistence and escalation control, assessments of how persistent operations influence norm development in multilateral fora, exploration of optimal force structure within Cyber Command, and studies on integrating cyber persistence with diplomatic, intelligence, and military instruments to advance comprehensive national strategy.

title: Did Russian Cyber Interference in the 2016 Election Violate International Law Symposium: Tallinn Manual 2.0 on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations
abstract: Jennifer Maddocks’s article “Outsourcing of Governmental Functions in Contemporary Conflict: Rethinking the Issue of Attribution” examines the evolving legal framework for attributing the acts of private military, security, and cyber actors to sponsoring states under international law, with particular focus on the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (ARSIWA). Against the background of increased privatization and outsourcing across military and cyber domains—including private military and security companies (PMSCs) and private cyber operators—the article interrogates the criteria for when outsourced functions, traditionally exercised by states, give rise to state responsibility. Drawing on ARSIWA Article 5 and the associated commentary, Maddocks delineates the core elements of governmental authority, differentiating inherently public functions (such as offensive combat and law enforcement) from ancillary support roles. She then applies the "private person" test and broader contextual factors—such as location of operations, systematic or recurrent excesses of authority, and the identity of beneficiaries—to ascertain when private actor behavior constitutes an exercise of state power. The study further explores the legal empowerment requirement under ARSIWA Article 8, articulating that any form of positive authorization—whether by statute, regulation, contract, or other legal instrument—is sufficient to render private acts attributable to the state, even in the absence of explicit oversight or control. Maddocks demonstrates how states might seek to evade responsibility by employing proxies or cyber contractors, yet underscores that under a broad interpretation of ARSIWA, including the nonbinding but influential Tallinn Manual 2.0 scenarios for cyber operations (e.g., defense of government computer networks, offensive cyber operations, and cyber support to military campaigns), such conduct remains attributable when fulfilling government functions. Through case examples—ranging from contractor abuses at Abu Ghraib to the North Korean–linked WannaCry ransomware attack—the article illustrates the practical stakes of attribution in closing accountability gaps and deterring illegitimate outsourcing of coercive activities. Maddocks ultimately argues for a more inclusive approach to attribution that aligns with the inherently public character of problematic functions and deters states from outsourcing responsibilities to avoid liability. She acknowledges the limitations of a purely doctrinal methodology and calls for empirical research into state practice regarding cyber proxies, as well as clearer benchmarks for assessing effective state control and supervision in outsourced arrangements. Her analysis contributes to cyber law and policy discourse by clarifying how existing international legal principles can be applied to emerging challenges in cyber conflict, ensuring that states cannot evade responsibility for harmful actions undertaken on their behalf by private actors.
