title: Conflict in Cyberspace: How International Legal Norms Can Reduce Military Escalation in Cyberspace Policy
abstract: The rise of cyberspace as a contested operational domain has exposed the limitations of existing international legal frameworks in preventing and managing military escalation, underscoring the urgency of clarifying norms and confidence-building measures to mitigate risks of armed conflict in this borderless environment. This essay addresses the contested applicability of public international law—including jus ad bellum and the law of armed conflict—to cyber operations, investigates why states have been reticent to negotiate binding treaties governing military cyber activities, and explores how norm development and confidence-building measures (CBMs) can bridge the gap between technical challenges and legal obligations. Drawing on a normative legal analysis of United Nations Group of Governmental Experts (UN GGE) reports, the Tallinn Manual, state submissions, and scholarly discourse, the author formulates the research question: under what conditions can international legal norms and CBMs effectively reduce military escalation in cyberspace? Through a structured, policy-oriented review that outlines key characteristics of cyberspace—such as attribution difficulties, low barriers to entry for diverse actors, erosion of power asymmetries, and the technical sophistication spectrum from unsophisticated hacks to advanced persistent threats—the essay methodically examines the technical and legal dimensions of offensive and defensive operations. The analysis reveals that while states agree in principle that existing law applies to cyber conflict, the scope of its application remains highly contested, attribution challenges persist at the endpoint level, and current UN GGE deliberations focus disproportionately on critical infrastructure protection and crime cooperation rather than armed conflict. Moreover, CBMs have largely targeted law enforcement cooperation against organized cyber-crime, leaving military applications inadequately addressed. The author finds that the stagnation of norm discussions at the UN level, coupled with divergent state interpretations of what constitutes a use of force or armed attack in cyberspace, undermines the harmonization needed for deterrence and crisis stability. In response, the paper contributes an integrative framework for assessing norm viability by identifying three essential conditions: first, political will among major powers to define thresholds for the use of force; second, technical alliances to improve shared attribution capabilities; and third, institutionalized CBMs tailored to military actors, such as incident-notification protocols and joint exercises. These proposals aim to facilitate dialogue and confidence, thereby reducing incentives for escalation. Acknowledging its scope limitation to norms surrounding armed attack and use of force, the essay cautions that further empirical validation is required and that evolving technology may outpace normative development. The author suggests future research directions including comparative case studies of state practice in cyber incidents, empirical assessment of CBM efficacy, and the negotiation of supplemental protocols or treaty mechanisms to codify agreed thresholds and responsibilities. By connecting legal analysis with technical constraints and strategic imperatives, this work advances the policy debate on establishing robust, actionable norms to govern state behavior in the cyber domain.

title: The regulation of the civilian and military realms of cyberspace
source: Manchester Review of Law, Crime and Ethics
abstract: This article by J. Taylor offers a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the evolving legal and regulatory challenges arising from the convergence of civilian and military activities in cyberspace. Recognizing cyberspace as an emergent domain of human activity integral to both everyday life and state security, the paper systematically reviews existing international legal instruments—most notably the Additional Protocols to the Geneva Conventions, the law of armed conflict (LOAC), and the Tallinn Manual—to assess their applicability to cyber operations and to highlight critical lacunae. Through examination of real-world incidents, including disruptive attacks on SCADA systems and the rise of ransomware, Taylor demonstrates that traditional principles such as distinction, proportionality, and accountability are severely strained by the borderless, dual-use nature of cyber tools and the diffusion of capabilities among state and non-state actors. The principle of distinction is particularly compromised by the inherent indistinctness of cyber infrastructure, where an operation aimed at a military target often risks civilian harm. Proportionality is further complicated by the cascading, uncontrollable effects of malware once deployed, prompting controversial arguments about human responsibility for unintended consequences. Taylor also critiques the NATO-centric origins of the Tallinn Manual and the limited legitimacy of its norms beyond Western states. In response to these deficiencies, the paper proposes a recalibrated regulatory framework emphasizing proactive legal restraint, clearer criteria for state responsibility, and a normative consensus on weapon classification and civilian participation in hostilities. The author calls for enhanced predictability in cyber regulation through the development of universally accepted definitions and attribution mechanisms and urges empirical research into state practice, the interplay between emerging cyber norms and online freedoms, and legal strategies for countering terrorism-driven cyber operations. Limitations include the Western-centric doctrinal focus and the rapid technological evolution that may outpace legal adaptation. By integrating civilian and military perspectives, this study advances policy discourse and charts pathways toward a more coherent and secure regulatory regime for cyberspace.

title: State Responsibility and Cyberattacks: Defining Due Diligence Obligations
source: Indonesian Journal of International & Comparative Law
abstract: Cyberattacks are proliferating rapidly, with live trackers recording over six million daily incidents, and technology-dependent societies increasingly view these threats as destabilizing forces that demand state protection under international law. This paper addresses the significant issue of whether and how States owe due diligence obligations in cyberspace within the framework of State responsibility, given the unique characteristics of cyberattacks and the growing public demand for government accountability. The research aims to re-examine the content and triggering circumstances of cyber-diligence obligations, asking explicitly which legal analogies best inform a tailored model for cyberspace and what minimal thresholds should activate a State’s duty to act. Employing a doctrinal methodology, the author conducts a comparative legal analysis using an opening case study of Sino-U.S. hacktivist activities following the 2001 South China Sea collision, analogical reasoning with environmental law, law of the sea, and counter-terrorism due diligence models, and references to established principles of attribution and State responsibility under the International Law Commission’s articles. The analysis demonstrates that straightforward replication of environmental or maritime due diligence models is inappropriate for cyber contexts, while principles from counter-terrorism law offer the most applicable analogy. The paper finds that a State’s cyber-diligence obligation should be narrowly defined and is triggered, at minimum, when a territorial State has constructive knowledge of a cyberattack that causes serious injury—either physical destruction or incapacitation—of networked infrastructure within its territory. It further argues that ultimate responsibility for securing cyber-infrastructure should be channeled onto private industry to prevent overexpansion of State duties. The novel contribution of this research is a cyber-diligence framework that specifies the minimum contents—capacity acquisition and measures to terminate ongoing attacks—and precise triggers necessary to establish an internationally wrongful act, thereby enabling victim States to seek reparations. Limitations of the study include its reliance on select case studies, the absence of empirical state practice following a catalyzing catastrophic cyber event, and the hypothetical nature of compliance assessments. The paper suggests future research should empirically evaluate State and industry responses to actual high-threshold cyber incidents, gauge receptiveness to narrow due diligence duties, and refine the framework in light of evolving cyber norms and public pressures for enhanced regulatory measures.

title: Cyber warfare and self-defense from the perspective of international law
abstract: The rapid proliferation of cyber capabilities has transformed traditional battlefields and raised pressing questions about the applicability of established international law norms to novel forms of state conflict. This article tackles the challenge of defining cyber warfare within the jus ad bellum framework, with particular attention to when cyber operations amount to the ‘‘use of force’’ under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter and when they cross the threshold of an ‘‘armed attack’’ triggering the right of self-defense under Article 51. The authors argue that as states increasingly deploy offensive cyber tools capable of inflicting widespread damage on critical infrastructure, the international community must clarify how existing legal rules apply in cyberspace and refine attribution mechanisms to hold offending states accountable. Employing an analytical legal methodology, they survey the Charter’s text, customary international law, state practice, and judicial decisions—including ICJ jurisprudence and NATO responses—to identify interpretive criteria for distinguishing permissible cyber coercion from prohibited uses of force. Through case analysis of Estonia (2007), Georgia (2008), and Stuxnet (2010), the study finds that cyber operations causing physical destruction, human harm, or systemic paralysis of vital state services generally qualify as ‘‘use of force’’ and, if sufficiently severe, as ‘‘armed attacks.’’ It also highlights the interpretive challenges posed by non-kinetic effects that may be indistinguishable from economic or political coercion. The authors advance a framework based on six criteria—intensity, imminence, directness, invasiveness, measurability, and legitimacy—to assess whether a particular cyber incident resembles the effects of a conventional armed attack. They further examine attribution rules, arguing that state responsibility should attach not only to operations orchestrated by official cyber forces but also to those by private actors under a state’s effective control or tolerated by it. The paper’s contribution lies in offering a systematic conceptual model for determining when cyber activities constitute prohibited uses of force and when victim states may lawfully resort to self-defense, thereby filling a gap in the current legal literature. However, the authors acknowledge limitations inherent in a purely doctrinal analysis: the absence of universally accepted definitions of ‘‘critical infrastructure,’’ divergent state positions on pre-emptive self-defense, and evolving technological complexities that outpace legal codification. They call for future research to empirically examine state practice in cyber operations, to negotiate normative consensus on threshold criteria and attribution standards, and to develop specialized international instruments or protocols that address the unique features of cyber conflict.

title: The targeting of non-state-affiliated civilians in cyberspace: lagging LOAC principles cause uncertainty on both sides
source: North Carolina Journal of International Law
abstract: This article examines how the foundational principles of the Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) governing the protection of civilians have failed to adapt to the unique characteristics of cyber operations, thereby exposing non-state-affiliated civilian actors to prolonged and uncertain risk of lawful targeting or allegations of war crimes. Drawing upon a doctrinal legal analysis of the Geneva Conventions, Additional Protocol I, customary international law instruments (including the Lieber Code and the 1868 Declaration of St. Petersburg), and the Tallinn Manual’s interpretive guidance, the author distinguishes between state-affiliated civilian actors—who generally understand their risk of direct targeting and collateral damage—and non-state-affiliated civilians whose participation in cyber hostilities often occurs without clear legal status or temporal constraints. The paper details how traditional LOAC protections for civilians lose clarity when applied to cyberspace’s anonymity, attribution difficulties, and delayed effects, such that a cyber operation initiated by a civilian may trigger a legally justified targeting window that persists long after the actor has ceased participation. This temporal uncertainty is compounded by divergent state practices: some states may prioritize direct targeting under LOAC over domestic criminal prosecutions, while civilians face the alternative of possible criminal liability should they self-identify to terminate their lawful targeting status. To address this gap, the author proposes transplanting a renunciation mechanism from the Model Penal Code into a cyber LOAC framework: by formally notifying the attacked state of their cessation of hostile cyber activities, civilians could extinguish the causal link that sustains their status as lawful targets. The framework balances states’ need for certainty with civilians’ right to protection, yet the author acknowledges that adoption may incur adverse side-effects, including domestic prosecution risks and states’ reluctance to bind themselves to a formal renunciation clause. The article concludes by calling for multilateral consensus on defining direct participation in hostilities in cyberspace, standardized attribution and temporal standards, and the integration of renunciation procedures into international LOAC instruments to safeguard civilians while maintaining accountability for cyber hostilities.

title: Control and capabilities test: Toward a new lex specialis governing state responsibility for third party cyber incidents
abstract: States face mounting challenges in attributing responsibility for the internationally wrongful cyber operations of non-State actors, a challenge that directly shapes their legal rights and strategic options under the jus ad bellum and jus in bello. Without reliable attribution, states cannot effectively deter or respond to cyber aggression, making the rules of state responsibility in cyberspace an issue of critical public importance. This paper examines whether a new lex specialis is emerging to govern imputed state responsibility for cyber incidents when non-State actors operate without clear state direction or control. It asks whether state practice since 2014 supports a shift from the established “effective control” lex generalis to a “control and capabilities” standard. To answer this question, the author employs a legal-analytic methodology grounded in a systematic review of official state attributions, public indictments, and multilateral pronouncements by NATO’s Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence, the United Nations Group of Governmental Experts, and U.S. governmental bodies. By cataloguing cases such as the U.S. attribution of the 2014 Sony attack to North Korea, the 2016 Iranian DDoS indictments, and U.S. attributions of Russian involvement in the DNC intrusion and Yahoo breach, the analysis identifies a pattern: states assign responsibility based on a constellation of factors—including relationships, methods, motivations, code similarities, technical capabilities, geographic proximity, and digital forensic indicators—rather than the high threshold of express state direction or control required by the effective control test. These findings reveal a discernible trend toward a control and capabilities test that, if crystallized into customary international law, would supplant the lex generalis and lower the evidentiary bar for attributing cyber operations to states. The paper’s primary contribution is the conceptual articulation of this emerging lex specialis, providing policymakers and legal practitioners with a framework to interpret and engage in attribution debates. It outlines how a multifactorial approach better reflects modern cyber realities, enabling more consistent and timely state responses. The analysis acknowledges limitations stemming from the relatively small number of public attributions, the potential volatility of digital evidence, and the risk that technical indicators may not definitively identify individual perpetrators. The paper suggests that expanding state practice and deeper analysis of attribution methodologies are necessary to validate the control and capabilities test as a binding legal standard. Future research should document additional state attributions, refine the factors comprising the control and capabilities test, and assess how this emerging lex specialis interacts with evolving norms of cyber deterrence and international law.

title: Peacetime Cyber Responses and Wartime Cyber Operations under International Law: An Analytical Vade Mecum
abstract: The article addresses the challenge of applying established principles of international law to cyber operations occurring both in peacetime and during armed conflict, highlighting the ambiguity and strategic risks that states face in responding to malicious cyber activities. It emphasizes the significance of clarifying legal frameworks for state responses to harmful cyber operations in the context of rising geopolitical tensions and the prevalence of state-sponsored intrusions, arguing that legal uncertainty may undermine effective deterrence and provoke escalatory dynamics. To address this gap, the author aims to provide government legal advisers and policymakers with a practical analytical roadmap, posing the central question of how to assess cyber incidents against thresholds for self-defense, necessity, and countermeasures, as well as how to interpret targeting rules under international humanitarian law in cyber warfare. Methodologically, the article draws on doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the 154 rules and commentary of Tallinn Manual 2.0, deploying normative legal reasoning and structured flowcharts to translate complex legal norms into a step-by-step vade mecum for practitioners. The first flowchart guides states through the assessment of peacetime cyber operations, delineating criteria for armed attack, self-defense, the plea of necessity, and countermeasures, including attribution, breach of obligation, and proportionality, while the second diagram addresses the classification of cyber activities in armed conflict, covering definitions of attack, target identification, precautions, proportionality, and neutrality obligations. Key findings reveal that although existing international law principles can be applied to cyberspace, their operationalization requires careful parsing of intent, effects, and jurisdictional factors, and that the thresholds for invoking self-defense or countermeasures depend on the severity of harm and immediacy of threat. The article contributes a novel skeleton framework that systematizes the decision-making process, translating abstract rules into actionable steps that can support coherent state practice and strengthen legal deterrence. However, the author acknowledges limitations inherent in this skeletal approach, cautioning that the flowcharts offer only a general vector through a complex legal landscape and may not accommodate every incident’s unique features, and that the nascent state of international cyber law leaves many issues unresolved. For future research, the article underscores the need for empirical studies of state practice and opinio juris to refine legal norms, calls for more granular analysis of emerging gray-zone operations, and suggests that iterative feedback between practice and doctrine will be essential to evolve a robust legal regime governing cyber conflict.

title: Addressing Obstacles to Cyber-Attribution: A Model Based on State Response to Cyber-Attack
source: The George Washington International Law Review
abstract: The increasing reliance of states on information technology has elevated cyber-attacks into a prominent challenge for international security, yet their unique characteristics and legal ambiguity have hindered the effective application of existing jus ad bellum principles. Recognizing the milestone cyber-incidents such as the 2007 Estonia attacks and the Stuxnet operation against Iran in 2010, this article addresses the critical issue of cyber-attribution and its implications for lawful state responses. The authors argue that without a robust attribution framework, states face a dual risk: either unchecked escalation through misdirected self-defense or paralysis when pursuing peaceful legal redress. Motivated by the lack of consensus in scholarly proposals and the absence of binding international jurisprudence, the study aims to develop a model that aligns attribution requirements with the nature of the victim state’s response, thereby resolving the practical impasse in state practice. Employing a doctrinal analysis of public international law, the article leverages existing state practice, scholarly literature, and principles established in the United Nations Charter, particularly Articles 2(4) and 51. It examines the taxonomy of cyber-attacks—direct intrusion, indirect malware-based assaults, and denial of service operations—and assesses how each challenges traditional notions of the use of force, self-defense, and state responsibility. The findings reveal that the technical complexity and anonymity inherent in cyber operations render high thresholds for attribution essential when invoking self-defense, while the same hurdles impede legal recourse under international adjudication. To reconcile these conflicting demands, the authors propose a dual-tier attribution model: a strict ‘‘effective control’’ or high-evidence standard for self-defense measures to prevent misdirected force, coupled with a strict liability regime governing non-forcible state responses, under which host-state cooperation in evidence gathering constitutes fulfillment of attribution obligations. This framework incentivizes peaceful resolution, discourages unilateral retaliation, and leverages states’ mutual interest in legal cooperation. The novel contribution lies in linking attribution thresholds to the chosen response mechanism, thereby extending established doctrines of effective control and strict liability into the cyber domain. The model provides a structured pathway for victims to pursue legal remedies without being stranded by evidentiary hurdles, while preserving the integrity of self-defense law. The authors acknowledge limitations, including the challenges of enforcing host-state cooperation absent compulsory jurisdiction and the nascent development of international tribunals with mandates over cyber disputes. They also note that their model does not fully address countermeasure doctrines and leaves open questions about reciprocal obligations in transnational data flows. Future research is encouraged to explore mechanisms for compulsory adjudication in cyber-incidents, the role of emerging norms such as those in the Tallinn Manual, and the applicability of countermeasures under international law to refine the proposed attribution model and support its adoption within multilateral treaty frameworks.

title: Conflict in cyberspace: how international legal norms can reduce military escalation in cyberspace
abstract: Nicholas Ott’s 2017 article “Conflict in Cyberspace: How International Legal Norms Can Reduce Military Escalation in Cyberspace” examines the transformative role of cyber operations in statecraft and the enduring challenge of regulating offensive military activities in cyberspace under public international law. Recognizing that the United Nations formally acknowledged cyberspace conflict as a serious global concern in 2013, Ott argues that while most states concede the applicability of existing jus ad bellum and jus in bello principles to cyber operations, persistent disputes over core concepts such as “use of force” and “armed attack,” coupled with technical obstacles to reliable attribution, impede treaty-based regulation of military cyberspace activity. Through qualitative policy analysis of UN Group of Governmental Experts reports (2013, 2015), the Tallinn Manual, and regional proposals from the OSCE, ASEAN, and European Parliament, Ott identifies two pathways for risk reduction below the treaty threshold: the codification of legal norms through state practice and the deployment of confidence-building measures (CBMs) to foster shared expectations and crisis communication. He highlights the UN GGE’s focus on critical infrastructure protection over direct military norms, the enduring “attribution problem” caused by anonymizing techniques and hijacked intermediary systems, and the “endpoint security” obstacle in tying digital actions to responsible actors. Ott emphasizes the egalitarian effect of cyberspace’s low technical entry threshold, which empowers non-state actors alongside advanced persistent threats, thereby eroding traditional power asymmetries and complicating interstate norm negotiations. Drawing on case studies such as the Sony hack and the Stuxnet operation, he illustrates how varying levels of sophistication and intent shape state responses and the interpretation of existing legal frameworks. To bridge legal and technical communities, Ott proposes a conceptual framework linking the defining characteristics of cyber operations—such as anonymity, low cost, and boundarylessness—to potential normative instruments. He argues that effective norm development must clarify thresholds for “force” and “armed attack,” integrate pragmatic CBMs tailored to major cyber powers, and enhance attribution transparency through technical cooperation. Ott concludes that divergent conceptions of “cyber sovereignty” among key states and stalled UN negotiations threaten norm evolution, urging empirical evaluation of current CBM initiatives, bilateral and multilateral case studies on norm implementation, and continued technical collaboration. By synthesizing legal doctrine, policy debates, and technical realities, this work lays the groundwork for more robust international regimes aimed at preventing inadvertent or deliberate military escalation in cyberspace.

title: Grey Zones in the International Law of Cyberspace
source: Yale Journal of International Law Online
abstract: The essay addresses the growing problem of how states exploit ambiguity in international law to conduct cyber operations that fall short of overt armed conflict yet yield significant strategic benefits, illustrating the issue with Russia’s hacks of the U.S. Democratic National Committee and its covert involvement in Ukraine. It explains that these so-called grey zone activities exploit poorly demarcated or disputed legal norms—such as state sovereignty, prohibited intervention, jus ad bellum, and jus in bello—to avoid clear attribution and to frustrate proportionate responses, thereby gaining an asymmetric advantage over rule-of-law states. Motivated by the need to demystify these ambiguities and to encourage legal clarity, the author aims to identify critical grey zones in the international law of cyberspace and to propose means for states to narrow them, framing the key research question as how international law can be applied or interpreted more precisely to reduce strategic exploitation. Relying on a doctrinal methodology, the essay synthesizes the expert opinions of two multinational groups responsible for the Tallinn Manual and Tallinn Manual 2.0, examines state practice including United Nations Group of Governmental Experts reports, and analyzes legal texts such as the U.N. Charter, Articles on State Responsibility, and Geneva Conventions. The findings reveal persistent disagreements among experts over thresholds for determining what constitutes a cyber attack—whether disabling digital infrastructure requires physical damage or mere functional impairment—and whether data itself qualifies as a protected object, as well as uncertainty surrounding the concepts of sovereignty, intervention, use of force, and lawful countermeasures. These divergences underscore the need for interpretive consensus and more granular state practice. The essay’s contribution lies in cataloguing these grey zones, highlighting how legal uncertainty invites escalation, undermines deterrence, and incentivizes asymmetric lawfare, and proposing that states should clarify norms through expressions of opinio juris and transparent practice, thereby strengthening stability and deterrence in cyberspace. Acknowledging its limitations as a primarily normative analysis based on nonpublic state practice and expert opinion rather than empirical field data, the author concedes that the evolving nature of cyber operations and classified responses complicate norm crystallization. For future research, the author suggests systematic collection of state declarations and legal justifications for cyber operations, deeper examination of subsequent practice under the Vienna Convention’s interpretive rules, and further exploration of multilateral and bilateral mechanisms to clarify contested legal thresholds and develop new customary norms.

title: State Responsibility and Attribution of Cyber Intrusions after Tallinn 2.0
abstract: The manipulation of democratic processes through cyber intrusions has underscored profound challenges in attributing state responsibility and shaping international norms, especially in light of the infamous 2016 DNC hack and its aftermath. This paper examines the difficulty of establishing credible attribution of cyber operations against the backdrop of the Tallinn Manual 2.0, highlighting how the low evidentiary threshold in international law and the evolving technical environment complicate state accountability and deterrence. The research aims to pinpoint the gap between the normative legal framework and actual policy responses, asking how states can develop transparent and mutually recognized standards for attribution and countermeasures in cyberspace. It undertakes a doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the case study of the Russian-linked DNC intrusion, tracing official U.S. statements and intelligence assessments from July 2016 through early 2017, and juxtaposes these with the principles articulated in Tallinn Manual 2.0 and related customary international law. The analysis reveals that although attribution in international law does not demand high proof, practical attribution remains an all-source, intelligence-driven exercise hindered by secrecy and evolving spoofing tactics. The United States’ delayed formal attribution to Russia, driven by policy considerations including fears of escalation and diplomatic leverage over Syria, exemplifies the tension between public transparency and national security imperatives. The paper finds that this opacity undermines public trust and impedes the deterrent effect of cyber countermeasures. It further finds that current norms enshrined in Tallinn 2.0 regarding sovereignty and permissible countermeasures leave major cyber powers with asymmetric advantages, perpetuating a zero-sum dynamic in state behavior. By mapping these deficiencies, the paper contributes a conceptual framework for developing lex specialis in cyber operations law, proposing that states adopt shared criteria for attribution, engage in bilateral and multilateral agreements to codify these criteria into customary international law, and institute calibrated public transparency measures without compromising sensitive intelligence methods. The authors acknowledge limitations stemming from the classified nature of much attribution evidence, the dynamic interplay of emerging cyber tools that both aid and obscure attribution, and the lack of empirical data on the efficacy of various countermeasure strategies. They further note that reliance on legal doctrinal analysis may oversimplify the complex political and technical dimensions of cyber operations. Looking ahead, the paper calls for empirical studies on the deterrent impact of transparent attribution, comparative analyses of national cyber doctrines, and multistakeholder efforts to refine international norms that balance state sovereignty, secrecy, and the need for accountability in cyberspace.

title: How Should the U.S. Respond to a Russian Cyber Attack?
abstract:
In “Regulating Cyber-Security,” Nathan Alexander Sales critically examines prevailing U.S. legal and policy paradigms for safeguarding critical digital infrastructure and advocates a novel regulatory framework inspired by administrative law fields such as environmental law, antitrust, products liability, and public health. Sales begins by demonstrating that conventional approaches to cyber-security, which treat cyber-attacks either as criminal conduct or as uses of force in armed conflict, fail to address the market failures afflicting private operators of critical infrastructure. Citing the 2007 cyber-assault on Estonia and warnings of an “electronic Pearl Harbor,” he underscores the systemic underinvestment in cyber-defenses by firms that do not internalize the full social costs of their vulnerabilities. Sales then draws parallels between negative externalities in environmental pollution and cybersecurity risk, explaining that firms underinvest in protective measures because many of the harms from intrusions are borne by customers and third parties. He extends this analogy to antitrust law, noting that inter-firm cooperation on cybersecurity is hindered by antitrust concerns, and to tort law, where the near-absence of liability for breach victims leaves little incentive for defensive innovation. Public health law serves as a further analogy: just as disease surveillance, quarantine, and stockpiling medicines manage epidemics, so too could distributed monitoring networks, system isolation protocols, and reserve digital capacity bolster resilience to cyber-contagions. 

Sales’s regulatory lens yields four broad categories of policy interventions. First, he proposes a distributed cyber-biosurveillance system whereby private entities report incidents to public authorities, incentivized through liability shields and subsidies akin to antitrust immunity and public health funding. Second, industry-driven security standards co-developed with regulators would “harden” critical systems, supported by calibrated tort liability for noncompliance and liability protections for participants. Third, he advocates resilience-enhancing measures drawn from epidemic containment—namely, quarantining infected systems and maintaining redundant infrastructure that can be rapidly deployed during attacks. Finally, he considers calibrated countermeasures, or “hackbacks,” to deter adversaries and encourage better network hygiene among third-party hosts. 

Through a three-part structure, Sales first assesses whether private investment aligns with the social optimum, then reviews analogues from four administrative disciplines, and finally articulates concrete policy prescriptions for each. Crucially, he cautions against heavy-handed, command-and-control regulation, instead favoring hybrid strategies that leverage firms’ self-interest via positive inducements and targeted immunities, while reserving sanctions for egregious noncompliance. By reframing cyber-security as a regulatory challenge rather than solely a criminal or military one, Sales offers policymakers a richer menu of tools—monitoring, standards, resilience, and deterrence—that harness lessons from established regulatory regimes to strengthen national cyber-defenses.

title: Teaching old law new tricks: Applying and adapting state responsibility to cyber operations
abstract: The proliferation of state and non-state cyber operations in ostensibly peaceful contexts has created a pressing challenge for international legal order, as exemplified by the 2014 Sony Pictures Entertainment intrusion and subsequent U.S. counter-operation attributed to North Korea, which underscored both the severity of damage states can inflict through networked attacks and the murky legal status of peacetime cyber hostilities. Recognizing that much scholarship has focused on the jus ad bellum and jus in bello without addressing hostile cyber acts outside armed conflict, this Comment argues that the doctrine of state responsibility provides the most coherent framework for regulating such operations, prompting the research questions: which existing public international legal norms apply to cyber operations, how should attribution to states or non-state actors be assessed, and what normative gaps must be filled to ensure accountability? Employing a doctrinal methodology grounded in analysis of the 2001 Articles on State Responsibility and relevant state practice, treaties, and customary international law, supplemented by a case study of the Sony breach and response, the author systematically examines public international law sources to map obligations implicated by state cyber operations, assesses the thresholds for attributing both state and non-state cyber acts, and evaluates the risks of delegating cyber defense to private actors. The analysis finds that traditional norms of state responsibility—covering wrongful acts through state organs, effective control over non-state perpetrators, and obligations to prevent and redress internationally wrongful cyber conduct—are directly transposable to the cyber domain, yet attribution remains fraught with evidentiary difficulty and the existing regime leaves unresolved questions about private counterattacks and the scope of diplomatic protection. Building on this, the author contributes a tailored framework that adapts state responsibility principles to cyber operations, clarifies the attribution tests for both state and non-state actors in cyberspace, and issues a normative call for the development of new customary or conventional rules to address identified gaps, including clear standards for private sector involvement, thresholds for permissible countermeasures, and mechanisms for multilateral cooperation. The Comment acknowledges limitations in the reliability of attribution evidence, the potential for divergent state practice to undermine emerging norms, and the nascent state of cyber-specific jurisprudence. It proposes that future research should focus on empirical tracking of state practice in cyber deterrence, the elaboration of model treaty provisions on state responsibility for cyber operations, and the design of institutional mechanisms for cooperative attribution and dispute resolution to strengthen accountability in the transnational cyber environment.

title: Use of Force and Armed Attack Thresholds in Cyber Conflict: The Looming Definitional Gaps and the Growing Need for Formal U.N. Response Notes
abstract: The accelerating integration of computer technology into international relations has transformed the nature of conflict, enabling states and nonstate actors to deliver attacks that can disrupt critical infrastructure with the stroke of a key and challenging traditional legal frameworks for armed hostilities. This evolution has exposed significant definitional gaps in the thresholds for “use of force” under U.N. Charter Article 2(4) and “armed attack” under Article 51 when crimes move from kinetic to cyber domains, undermining states’ ability to assess the legality of cyber operations and to respond with proportional countermeasures. Motivated by widespread confusion among policymakers, scholars, and even major powers such as the United States and Russia regarding the applicability of existing Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) principles to cyber acts, this analysis aims to synthesize prevailing theories and propose clearer lawful thresholds, asking how the international community can achieve objective, enforceable standards for cyber use of force and armed attack. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the paper surveys current sources of LOAC and state practice, critically reviews scholarly expansions of Article 2(4) criteria and emerging thresholds below “use of force,” and examines case illustrations including the Stuxnet intrusion, Iranian DDoS banking attacks, the U.S. response to financial-sector hackers, and alleged Russian cyber operations in Crimea. The findings reveal persistent ambiguities: Stuxnet’s stealthy manipulation of nuclear centrifuges defies neat categorization under scale-and-effects tests, state responsibility remains uncertain in botnet-driven denials-of-service, and the precipitating moment and scope of an cyber armed attack lack consensus, frustrating self-defense judgments under Article 51. This study contributes to cyber conflict scholarship by articulating a novel conceptual framework that differentiates levels of cyber coercion based on invasiveness, measurability of harm, and presumptive legitimacy, and by advocating for a formal U.N. treaty to codify these thresholds, thereby enhancing reciprocity and legitimacy in LOAC tradition. Key limitations include reliance on doctrinal interpretation in the absence of binding state practice, the speculative nature of proposed thresholds pending multilateral endorsement, and the evolving technical complexity of cyber operations that may outpace legal constructs. To address these constraints, the author outlines future research directions, including empirical case studies of state cyber doctrines, comparative analyses of regional cyber norms initiatives, intergovernmental negotiations toward treaty language, and the development of technical metrics to calibrate threshold criteria in real time, all aimed at fortifying the international legal order against the unique challenges posed by cyber warfare.

title: Cybersecurity Norms for Reducing Conflict in an Internet-Dependent World
authors: Angela McKay; Jan Neutze; Paul Nicholas; Kevin Sullivan
abstract: This article offers a systematic and comprehensive mapping of how states articulate and apply the principle and rule of sovereignty within the context of cyberspace, filling a critical gap in our understanding of the normative architecture governing state conduct in digital domains. Drawing on a detailed survey of 27 individual state positions and a collective declaration by the 55 member states of the African Union, the author, Lukasz Kulaga, identifies three predominant conceptual models of cyber sovereignty. The first model treats sovereignty as an international authority that requires explicit consent for cross-border cyber operations; the second conceptualizes sovereignty as a ‘‘soft norm’’ that guides state behavior without generating binding legal obligations; and the third regards sovereignty as an enforceable rule, the violation of which constitutes an internationally wrongful act. Grounding his analysis in the findings of the 2015 and 2021 United Nations Group of Governmental Experts reports—which acknowledged the relevance of sovereignty in cyberspace but left its practical contours undefined—Kulaga explores the critical distinction between principles and rules in international law, demonstrating how each model yields different implications for state practice and legal accountability. Key components of cyber sovereignty distilled from state declarations include jurisdictional claims over domestic infrastructure, the prohibition of harmful effects resulting from unauthorized access, and the protection of governmental functions from cyber interference. The article shows that while there is broad consensus on states’ jurisdictional rights and on proscribing harmful cyber effects, significant divergence remains regarding the permissibility of cyber espionage and non-violent unauthorized access. Kulaga further interrogates the intersection of sovereignty with the principle of non-intervention, illustrating how states vary in their categorization of espionage and other ‘‘non-harmful’’ intrusions as either permissible peacetime conduct or violations of sovereign prerogatives. The study also examines the emerging doctrine of due diligence in cyberspace, whereby states articulate positive obligations to prevent malicious cyber operations emanating from or transiting their territories. In its concluding sections, the article reflects on two broader normative questions: whether the sustained effort to define how general international law applies to cyberspace signals the emergence of a de facto lex specialis for cyber activities, and whether the proliferation of soft-law instruments and responsible-state-behavior frameworks strengthens or dilutes the enforceability of sovereign rights online. By synthesizing convergent and divergent state positions and by clarifying the conceptual underpinnings of cyber sovereignty, this work provides a foundational resource for scholars, policymakers, and legal practitioners seeking to navigate and shape the evolving rules of state conduct in cyberspace.

title: Cyber Espionage and International Law
source: Global Internet Governance Academic Network, Annual
abstract:
In “Cyber Espionage and International Law,” Aaron Shull examines the twin challenges posed by state practice and legal norms in regulating cyber espionage under international law. The paper begins by observing that, unlike traditional human espionage which directly violates territorial integrity, cyber intrusions do not obviously offend this principle, creating ambiguity as to their legality. To assess the legal status of cyber espionage, Shull turns to customary international law, focusing on state practice and opinio juris. He identifies the customary norm of non-interference — enshrined in the 1965 UN Declaration on Intervention and the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration — which prohibits “any form of interference” in a state’s political, economic, and cultural affairs. Building on the International Court of Justice’s Lotus and Nicaragua decisions, Shull argues that acts of cyber espionage which coerce or compel a change in a target state’s policies breach the principle of non-interference, and thus are illegal absent explicit treaty authorization.

Despite the theoretical illegality of cyber espionage, Shull demonstrates that weak customary constraints have allowed widespread, largely unchecked practice among states. He analyzes Operation Aurora — the 2010 cyber infiltration of Google’s servers allegedly attributed to a foreign state actor — to show that states habitually deny responsibility and exhibit no consistent sense of legal obligation to abstain from espionage. The result is a gap between the normative prohibition and persistent state behavior.

Shull then explores the transnational legal process by which states engage in “regime-building” to codify emerging norms. He reviews U.S.-China dialogues, where the United States sought bifurcation between “economic” and “security” espionage, urging prohibitions on intellectual property theft while tolerating traditional security-related intrusions. China, however, rejects distinctions between economic and military espionage, decrying any stratification as an attempt by Washington to “dictate rules” in cyberspace. This divergence highlights a shifting normative landscape: the United States, backed by domestic laws and the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace, champions an explicit prohibition on economic cyber espionage, while China and Russia hypocritically pledge to renounce hostile acts even as they constitute the most active economic intruders.

In his conclusion, Shull warns that a bifurcated legal regime predicated on discerning the intruder’s motive — economic versus security — is unworkable, since attribution and intent in cyberspace are inherently opaque. He recommends that international efforts focus instead on clarifying and harmonizing a single, robust norm against unauthorized state cyber intrusions. The goal is to bridge the disconnect between customary prohibitions and state practice by articulating clear treaty obligations and reinforcing them through domestic criminal and extraterritorial legislation. Controlled evolution of these rules, supported by major powers, will determine whether cyber espionage becomes subject to enforceable law or remains a contested gray zone in international relations.

title: Applying the law of neutrality while transiting the seas of cyberspace
abstract: This article examines the application of the international law of neutrality to cyber operations that traverse neutral States’ telecommunications infrastructure, proposing a doctrinal foundation for recognizing a right of transit passage in cyberspace. Drawing upon international legal instruments—including the UN Charter, the Hague and Geneva Conventions—and state practice observed during the 2008 Russo–Georgian conflict, the author clarifies the rights and obligations of neutral States in the context of cyber warfare. Through qualitative doctrinal analysis and case studies, the paper demonstrates that although existing practice—such as Poland’s and Estonia’s provision of server space and data transit for Georgia, and assistance by private U.S. firms—did not breach neutrality rules due to the telegraph exception in Hague V, the technical impossibility of tracing packet pathways imposes an unworkable burden on both belligerents and neutrals under current law. The author argues that cyberspace, like maritime international straits, should be subject to a recognized right of transit passage, institutionalizing the de facto norms permitting data flows across neutral jurisdictions while preserving sovereign authority to regulate domestic content. This analogy reconciles the Internet’s essential resilience and openness with legitimate state controls over harmful content and sovereignty interests. Acknowledging the limitations of maritime analogies and the evolving, decentralized Internet architecture, the paper highlights the practical challenges of establishing route transparency without undermining packet-switching principles. It concludes by calling for multilateral treaty negotiations to codify transit passage rights, further research into mechanisms that balance transit freedoms with content regulation, and the design of technical and normative measures to support a robust, legally sound international regime for cyber neutrality and conflict.

title: Cyber Norm Development and the United States Law of War Manual
source: Defence Centre of Excellence, International Cyber
abstract: This chapter, authored by Sean Watts and published by the Defence Centre of Excellence, International Cyber, critically examines the United States Department of Defense Law of War Manual (the Manual) as a window into sovereign approaches to international cyber norm development. Opening with an overview of competing conceptual frameworks for cyberspace—"Exceptionalism," which posits cyberspace as a wholly novel, unregulated domain resisting sovereign control, and "Sovereigntism," which views cyberspace as fully subject to traditional international law—the chapter situates the Manual within broader scholarly and non-state advocacy debates, notably contrasting it with the privately authored Tallinn Manual. The author notes that non-state actors have dominated cyber norm discourse, often outpacing state participation, and that the Tallinn Manual exemplifies a Sovereigntist approach, asserting that ius ad bellum and ius in bello govern cyber operations.   Against this backdrop, Watts evaluates the Manual’s treatment of cyber operations, particularly its restraint in articulating new or refined norms. While the Manual affirms the applicability of existing law of war principles to cyber conflict, it declines to resolve long-standing ambiguities—such as defining the threshold of attack for cyber means, direct participation in cyber hostilities, and review obligations for cyber weapons. Watts identifies three plausible explanations for this reticence: the Manual’s methodology, which eschews definitive opinions on the law of war and treats the Manual as non-opinio juris; its timing, suggesting that States defer treaty-making until problems become tangible, although two decades of cyber incidents might argue otherwise; and security classification constraints, which may relegate detailed legal analyses to classified venues.   The chapter contrasts the Manual’s sparse normative contributions with the more assertive, consensus-driven Tallinn Manual, underscoring the U.S. comfort with persistent legal ambiguities in cyber operations. Watts argues that this reflects a conscious U.S. policy stance favoring flexibility over precision in cyber norms and a reluctance to constrain military or intelligence capabilities through new international obligations. The Manual thus serves as both a snapshot of the current state of international cyber law and an indicator of U.S. reticence to cultivate explicit, binding norms in cyberspace. Watts concludes that while the Manual offers extensive descriptive analysis of existing legal frameworks, it falls short of clarifying or advancing the law of war in cyber conflict, leaving unresolved issues to the international community and signaling a preference for strategic ambiguity.

title: Defining the Role of Intelligence in Cyberspace
abstract: Leaven and Dodge’s article critically examines the strategic and legal rationale behind the United States’ decision to establish the United States Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM) in lieu of immediately acceding to a binding international treaty governing cyber warfare. The authors open by identifying a critical regulatory gap: conventional arms control treaties—crafted for observable and conventional weapons systems—are ill-suited to address the low-cost, rapid, and often anonymous nature of cyber operations. Drawing on a doctrinal methodology enriched by comparative legal analysis, Leaven and Dodge review historical arms control frameworks, notably chemical weapons conventions and European monetary union experiences, to illustrate both analogies in treaty design and the fundamental divergences presented by cyberspace. Primary sources, including Department of Defense policy directives and public statements from senior U.S. defense officials, inform their assessment of whether treaty-based constraints would serve national interests or unduly restrict operational flexibility. They argue that without robust technical attribution mechanisms and enforceable signaling protocols, any treaty would be ineffective—failing to deter cyber aggression, risking inadvertent retaliation against innocent third parties, and potentially embroiling the United States in peripheral conflicts. Case studies of Russian cyber operations against Estonia in 2007 and declassified U.S. logic-bomb activities in 1982 demonstrate attribution challenges that undermine deterrence and complicate enforcement. Against this backdrop, the authors posit that USCYBERCOM’s creation constitutes a pragmatic interim strategy: by investing in domestic offensive and defensive cyber capabilities, the United States can maintain strategic freedom of action while technological advances and normative developments in attribution mature. They caution that prematurely entering a treaty could constrain U.S. responses, citing risks of treaty overbreadth—mandating responses to trivial incidents—and underbreadth—omitting actionable threats—thus potentially impeding both national security and global cyber-infrastructure stability. Leaven and Dodge further analogize the U.S. decision to Britain’s delayed adoption of the Eurodollar, suggesting that abstention allows for observation of treaty imperfections and refinement before commitment. The article concludes that, given the unique complexity and anonymity of cyber-enabled conflict, national capacity-building via USCYBERCOM and parallel efforts to advance attribution technologies and modular, adaptable treaty architectures offer a more effective pathway than immediate treaty ratification. They call for future research into the integration of technical attribution systems into legal frameworks and the design of flexible international instruments capable of evolving with cyberspace dynamics.

title: Anonymity and Attribution in Cyberspace
authors: A Brantly; William W. Keller; Scott A. Jones
abstract:
This chapter explores how the uniquely intertwined features of anonymity and attribution in cyberspace fundamentally reshape state decision-making about offensive and defensive cyber operations. Drawing on political science and technical modeling, Brantly argues that states weigh not only relative cyber power against adversaries but also the probability of preserving anonymity—concealing both the instigator and the target of an attack—and the capacity to attribute cyber operations post facto. He frames anonymity across three dimensions: obscuring the attacker’s identity, masking the occurrence of an operation, and concealing its objectives. Building on case studies such as the Titan Rain espionage campaign and hypothetical scenarios from intelligence expert Joel Brenner, Brantly demonstrates how higher anonymity increases the likelihood of state-initiated cyber attacks by offering plausible deniability and tactical surprise while complicating adversary defense. Conversely, delayed attribution, the legal and technical process of identifying perpetrators, mainly supports defensive postures, as real-time awareness of an attack’s existence and target proves more critical than post-event identification for interrupting hostile actions.

Employing a hazard-function approach, the chapter offers a probability-based decision model that quantifies anonymity across attack stages and complexities: low-level web propaganda, common among many actors, carries a high anonymity probability, whereas sophisticated hardware intrusions, achievable only by advanced states, present greater anonymity erosion over time. Brantly’s model integrates legal frameworks from Susan Brenner and anonymization metrics to assess state likelihood of engaging in offensive cyber operations under varying anonymity conditions. He contrasts cyber deterrence with conventional paradigms, noting that credible retaliation demands cross-domain readiness and prepositioned assets; mere attribution absent timely countermeasures fails to deter or halt attacks. 

The chapter contributes a novel multidisciplinary framework, revealing that anonymity probabilities can be as decisive as technical capabilities in assessing cyber power and predicting offensive behavior. Brantly acknowledges limitations in empirical parameterization and urges systematic quantitative measurement of diverse incidents to refine anonymity estimates. He advocates further research to validate the model across broader case sets, investigate emerging attribution technologies, and examine the evolution of international legal norms to mitigate anonymity’s offensive utility.

title: Attribution of Malicious Cyber Incidents: From Soup to Nuts
abstract: Attribution of malicious cyber incidents presents a fundamental challenge in cyberspace, where confusion about responsibility and the implications for deterrence and policymaking abound. The author identifies that while numerous well-researched studies address individual aspects of attribution, including technical forensics or legal frameworks, there exists a pressing need for an integrated approach that connects technical, human, and political dimensions with policy questions. Addressing this gap, the paper aims to synthesize the best insights from existing technical, intelligence, legal, and historical analyses with original perspectives to provide decisionmakers with a coherent model of how attribution functions in practice and why it matters for state-level conflict, deterrence, and international law. Methodologically, the work is a qualitative synthesis drawing on a broad literature review of forensics, signals and human intelligence, case studies such as the Sony hack, and geopolitical analysis, enriched by the author’s experience in cyber policy research. From this synthesis, four core findings emerge: first, attribution must be understood at three distinct levels—ascribing malicious activity to a machine, to the human actor operating it, and to the ultimately responsible adversary; second, effective attribution requires integrating multi-dimensional evidence spanning technical, intelligence, historical, and geopolitical sources; third, every attribution judgment carries inherent uncertainty, necessitating transparency about confidence levels; and fourth, the very possibility of adversary error or incomplete concealment underpins cyberspace deterrence, since uncertainty on both sides shapes strategic calculations. The paper’s primary contribution is a unified conceptual framework linking these attribution types and evidence streams to policy objectives, thereby clarifying how states can assign responsibility, calibrate diplomatic or legal responses, and enhance deterrence. It highlights the legal and political stakes of attributing a state actor under international law principles of state responsibility and jus ad bellum, and underscores how probabilistic evidence judgments influence due process and public credibility. The author acknowledges limitations, including the difficulty of ensuring independence among corroborating clues in deceptive environments and the challenges of translating qualitative judgments into quantifiable metrics. Finally, the paper points toward future research on refining methods to assess evidence independence, exploring adversary concealment techniques, and evaluating the efficacy of active cyber defense measures in reinforcing deterrence.

title: The Impact of Cyber Conflict on International Interactions
abstract: States are increasingly deploying cyber operations as tools of foreign policy, yet debate over the significance of these actions often outpaces empirical evidence. This discrepancy poses a challenge for policy-makers seeking to ground deterrence strategies, norms development, and legal frameworks in factual understanding. Maness and Valeriano address this gap by asking how cyber conflict affects interstate relations and whether different methods and objectives of cyber malice alter conflict-cooperation dynamics. They employ an international relations framework and leverage weekly events data, drawing on the Distributed Cyber Incident Data (DCID) and the Goldstein scale–coded WEIS events to quantify foreign policy responses following cyber incidents. Using a ten-year panel of forty directed dyads and random‐effects regression, their methodology controls for dyadic heterogeneity and temporal trends to isolate the impact of cyber tactics on subsequent cooperative or hostile interactions. The analysis reveals that among various forms of cyber aggression, only distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks produce a statistically significant increase in conflictual behaviors and diminish cooperative exchanges between states. Furthermore, the study identifies that regional powers and those involving the United States exhibit pronounced effects: while most cyber incidents sour relations, Chinese cyber operations targeting the United States elicit primarily diplomatic responses aimed at relationship improvement. These findings challenge prevailing assumptions that cyber conflict uniformly revolutionizes interstate interaction and instead suggest that its impact depends on tactic and target. The authors contribute a novel empirical test of “cyber restraint,” a theory positing that cyber actors face intention-based constraints that condition their effects on foreign policy dynamics. Their work advances scholarly understanding by operationalizing cyber conflict within established international relations metrics and by integrating cyber incidents into models of conflict escalation and cooperation. Constraints acknowledged include limited severity within observed incidents, potential attribution biases inherent in open-source data, and the exclusion of additional variables such as economic sanctions or militarized disputes due to collinearity and data coverage limitations. Maness and Valeriano propose that future research extend temporal and dyadic scopes to incorporate emerging cyber operations, refine normative frameworks through analysis of Track II and United Nations dialogues, and examine the interplay of cyber deterrence and state coercive diplomacy in regions such as Russia–West relations. Their dataset and analytical approach lay groundwork for subsequent investigations into how cyber tools integrate with traditional power projection and influence international legal norm development.

title: State responsibility in digital space
source: Swiss Review of International and European Law
abstract:
This article examines the evolving contours of state responsibility in the digital domain, where the ubiquitous nature of cyberspace has exposed critical vulnerabilities and created novel challenges for the attribution and redress of wrongful acts. Drawing upon established principles of international law — particularly the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on State Responsibility — it explores both lex lata and lex ferenda mechanisms to adapt traditional rules to the unique features of cyber operations. Through a hypothetical case study of a cross-border cyberattack by “DigiLand” on the electrical grid of “CyberStan,” the author systematically analyzes the four core elements of state responsibility: breach of an international obligation, attribution of the act to state organs or agents, the existence of damage, and the requirement for reparation. The analysis observes that the stringent evidentiary thresholds for objective state responsibility, which require direct attribution of the hostile cyber act to government organs, are ill suited to the technical complexity and anonymity of cyberspace, where non-state actors often operate with or without implicit governmental support. 

To bridge this gap, the author proposes situating state responsibility within a dual framework that combines the no-harm principle with a due diligence standard. Under this approach, states are obliged to prevent harmful digital activities originating from their territory by enacting robust domestic cybercrime legislation, conducting thorough investigations, prosecuting perpetrators, and cooperating with affected states’ legal processes. Comparative insights are drawn from environmental law, human rights jurisprudence, and diplomatic protection cases, such as the Inter-American Court of Human Rights’ Velásquez Rodríguez decision and the International Court of Justice’s Teheran Hostages judgment, demonstrating how due diligence obligations can be tailored to the cyber context. 

The author further argues that customary international law on digital state responsibility can be cultivated through evolving state practice, governmental expert reports, and judicial decisions, thereby creating a flexible, norm-forming mechanism capable of addressing both state omissions and commissions in cyberspace. A conceptual framework is developed for assessing state due diligence in cyberspace, including criteria for evaluating legislative measures, investigative and prosecutorial effectiveness, and mutual legal assistance. The article acknowledges the limitations of relying on a hypothetical scenario and the nascent stage of digital adjudication, underscoring the need for empirical research on actual state responses to cyber incidents. It calls for further documentation of state practice, refinement of due diligence benchmarks, and the clarification of attribution standards by international dispute settlement bodies. Ultimately, the article contends that by recalibrating traditional state responsibility doctrines to suit the digital age — particularly through the integration of the no-harm principle and due diligence obligations — international law can more effectively hold states accountable for cyber-enabled harms, incentivize preventive measures, and thereby enhance legal stability in an interconnected world.

title: Cyber Attack Treaty Verification
source: I/S: A Journal of Law and Policy for the Information Society
abstract: States face a growing challenge in addressing state-sponsored cyber attacks that target critical infrastructure yet elude attribution, undermining confidence and incentivizing further aggression. The proliferation of sophisticated espionage campaigns like Axiom, which infiltrated tens of thousands of computers globally and focused on economic and political targets, highlights the urgency of a binding international instrument that limits destructive cyber operations. Recognizing that any effective cyber treaty must overcome the persistent attribution problem, this study examines how established verification measures from nuclear arms control could adapt to a cyber context. It aims to identify viable verification techniques, determine their applicability to cyber weapons, and propose a comprehensive regime capable of building interstate confidence while preserving states’ intelligence capabilities. Employing a comparative legal and policy analysis, the author canvasses a broad range of nuclear treaties—focusing on national technical means, on-site inspections, data exchanges, consultative bodies, and “whoops” clauses—and evaluates their parallels in cyberspace. Drawing on examples of intrusion detection, network monitoring, session reconstruction, log inspection, and traffic analysis, the study finds that these cyber investigations can mirror the functions of national technical means and on-site verification in nuclear accords. Limited exchanges of technical data about the most destructive cyber weapons—particularly those targeting industrial control environments and critical infrastructure—could foster transparency without neutralizing a state’s entire cyber arsenal. In addition, confidential treaty bodies akin to the SALT Standing Consultative Committee could clarify ambiguities, resolve disputes privately, and maintain classified negotiations free from public pressures. A carefully drafted “whoops” clause would accommodate inadvertent malware spread—exemplified by Stuxnet’s unintended global dispersion—by exempting minor breaches from triggering treaty withdrawal. The paper’s principal contribution is the design of an integrated verification framework that combines network monitoring, cyber forensics, selective data sharing, classified consultative mechanisms, and a calibrated fault-tolerance clause. This model addresses key deterrence dynamics by leveraging the threat of reciprocal cyber retaliation to reinforce compliance. The analysis acknowledges limitations inherent in translating traditional arms control measures to digital domains, including states’ reluctance to divulge sensitive weapon characteristics, the rapid evolution of malware, and the absence of a uniform attribution standard. It also notes political hurdles in securing commitments amidst mutual distrust. The author suggests that further research should refine the technical specifications for data exchange protocols, explore the legal parameters of cyber treaty obligations under jus ad bellum and jus in bello, and assess the operational viability of confidential consultative committees. Expanding empirical studies on state behavior and cyber deterrence dynamics will be essential to tailor verification provisions to the unique challenges posed by cyberspace.

title: Cyber Operations and International Law: An Interventionist Legal Thought
abstract: This article addresses the challenge of regulating state and non-state cyber operations under existing international law, particularly the United Nations Charter, at a time when legislators have declined to create a dedicated treaty regime for cybersecurity. It begins by highlighting the pressing problem: international lawyers perceive cyber operations as a legal vacuum that exposes states and societies to unchecked digital coercion, thus straining global peace and security. This perceived gap compels scholars to stretch established legal frameworks to encompass cyber activities and to fill what they view as dangerous regulatory voids. The article seeks to explain why this body of scholarship matters and to identify its overt and latent purposes. Specifically, it asks how international lawyers frame their contributions to global cyber governance and which argumentative strategies they deploy to subject cyber operations to existing legal instruments. Methodologically, it adopts a doctrinal and conceptual analysis, surveying seminal and recent scholarship on cyber operations and international law, and examines state pronouncements and United Nations Group of Governmental Experts reports to trace prevailing patterns of argumentation. Through this critical review, the author discerns four key interventionist patterns: problem-finding, whereby lawyers characterize the cyber realm as fraught with new threats; administrativist camouflage, in which they present themselves as technical interpreters rather than law-makers when extending the UN Charter to digital operations; consequentialist bending, which tailors the Charter’s substantive thresholds such as “use of force” or “armed attack” to fit cyber incidents; and evidentiary pragmatism, reflecting scholars’ efforts to lower or reassign burdens and standards of proof to secure state responsibility for cyber-enabled harm. The article finds that while these strategies have succeeded in establishing a predominant view that the UN Charter applies to cyber operations, they generate acute difficulties at the evidentiary stage. Attribution, causation, authorship and the cross-border dynamics of cyber incidents resist conclusive proof, exposing a self-inflicted crisis in interventionist scholarship. The contribution of this work lies in revealing the internal contradictions of current legal debates and in arguing that the most profound obstacle to subjecting cyber operations to the UN Charter is not any external state reluctance but the compounded effect of interventionists’ own doctrinal choices. The author acknowledges that his analysis is conceptual and draws primarily on scholarly texts rather than empirical case studies, which limits its direct applicability to adjudicative practice. He also notes that his focus on UN Charter frameworks may understate alternative regulatory approaches under development. Finally, he calls for further research into alternative argumentation patterns that preserve scholars’ managerial ambitions without incurring prohibitive evidentiary burdens, for comparative studies of emerging attribution mechanisms, and for empirical evaluation of how states and international institutions actually apply international law to cyber incidents.

title: From the Kalashnikov to the Keyboard: International Law's Failure to Define a Cyber Use of Force is Dangerous and May Lead to a Military Response to a Cyber Use of Force
abstract: The evolution of cyberspace as a fifth domain of warfare has outpaced the development of a coherent international legal framework, creating a critical gap in addressing cyber operations that may not constitute armed attacks yet still pose significant threats to states. This article sets forth the problem that international law’s current use of art. 2(4) of the UN Charter and the jus ad bellum and jus in bello frameworks inadequately encompasses “cyber uses of force” and “uses of cyber coercion,” leaving a structural fragility that risks uncontrolled escalation or even a military response to state-sponsored cyber activity. The author justifies this inquiry by pointing to high-profile incidents such as the Sony Pictures operation and Stuxnet that demonstrate both the increasing frequency and escalating destructive potential of cyber operations; the article aims to reconceptualize cyber discourse, define these categories of cyber activity, and propose mechanisms by which the international community can preemptively regulate them. Methodologically, the research employs a doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the Charter of the United Nations, a critical literature review of scholarly definitions of “cyber war,” and a case study examination of the Sony Pictures hack to illustrate the insufficiencies of existing norms and response options. The findings reveal that states have neither expressly nor implicitly extended art. 2(4) to include all cyber operations amounting to force or coercion, that the rhetorical prevalence of terms like “cyber war” may license overly broad national responses, and that most cyber operations fall short of armed attack thresholds yet nonetheless undermine political independence or territorial integrity. As a contribution, the author proposes a novel “Cyber Kellogg–Briand Pact” framework, modeled on the 1928 Pact’s renunciation of war, which would formally define “cyber uses of force” and “uses of cyber coercion,” stigmatize their employment as instruments of policy, clarify lawful countermeasures, and prohibit military responses to coercive cyber operations. The article acknowledges limitations inherent in a treaty analogous to the original Kellogg–Briand Pact, including potential non-signatory states, the exclusion of self-defense parameters, and the challenge of enforcing soft-law commitments; it also recognizes that its doctrinal focus may not capture all technical nuances of cyber capability development. For future research, the author suggests refining the proposed treaty’s parameters to address self-defense, elaborating compliance mechanisms for non-signatories, integrating technical thresholds for destructive potential, and studying the impact of naming and shaming practices on state behavior in cyberspace. This work lays the groundwork for a preventive normative architecture capable of stabilizing state conduct in cyber conflict before a destructive “true event” compels reactive legal development.
