title: The dynamics of cyber conflict between rival antagonists, 2001-11
abstract: This article offers the first large-scale empirical portrait of state-driven cyber conflict by systematically cataloguing and analysing cyber incidents and disputes among international rivals from 2001 to 2011. Arguing that discussions of cyberwar and cyber conflict have been dominated by speculative and sensationalist accounts, Valeriano and Maness return the debate to social science by constructing and examining a dataset of 110 discrete cyber incidents clustered into 45 cyber disputes across 126 active rival dyads. They define cyber incidents as individual malicious operations—ranging from website defacements and distributed denial-of-service attacks to data theft—launched by one state against another, and cyber disputes as campaigns comprising one or more related incidents over a given time period. Drawing on rivalry literature, deterrence theory, and theories of restraint and regionalism, they hypothesize that contrary to the popular perception of unbounded cyber aggression, states will demonstrate restraint in their use of cyber tactics and that cyber conflict will be geographically constrained to rival pairs with existing histories of tension. Using rigorous open-source coding procedures, each incident is coded for initiator, target, tactic, severity, and timing. Quantitative analysis reveals that only 20 of the 126 rival dyads engaged in any cyber conflict during the decade under study, and those that did averaged just three incidents per dyad. The most active dyad, the United States and China, accounts for 22 of the 110 incidents within five disputes, yet even this pair refrains from the most destructive forms of cyber operations. The overwhelming majority of incidents are low-intensity interactions—chiefly defacements, probes, and denial-of-service campaigns—that do not escalate into kinetic violence. The authors identify a pattern of ‘cyber restraint,’ whereby states refrain from targeting critical infrastructure or employing destructive malware, motivated by fears of retaliation, uncontrolled escalation, collateral damage and erosion of international norms. They also demonstrate pronounced regionalism: most cyber disputes occur among neighboring adversaries, notably post-Soviet states in Eastern Europe and rivals in South and East Asia, supporting the view that cyberspace does not erase traditional geopolitical constraints. The study acknowledges limitations related to open-source data and attribution challenges, and proposes future research on how emerging cyber capabilities influence the evolution of international norms, the role of non-state actors and proxies in cyber rivalries, and the effects of alliances and third-party interventions on dispute dynamics. By grounding the study of interstate cyber conflict in empirical evidence and rivalry theory, this work provides a nuanced foundation for policymakers seeking proportional and informed responses in cyberspace, rather than reactionary or alarmist measures.

title: State obligations in cyber operations
abstract: This article examines the evolving regime of international law governing State conduct in cross-border cyber operations and articulates a unified framework for State obligations in cyberspace. Beginning with the challenge posed by cyber incidents such as alleged Russian cyber tools against Estonia and Chinese-linked intrusions into U.S. networks, the author frames the normative gap created by the transboundary nature of cyber activities and the difficulty of timely attribution. Employing a doctrinal methodology grounded in treaty analysis, State practice, customary international law, and jurisprudence from international tribunals, the study addresses three core questions: (1) What legal duty do States have to resolve cyber disputes peacefully? (2) To what extent must States monitor and control cyber infrastructure under their jurisdiction to prevent transboundary harm? (3) How do established principles—due diligence, precautionary principle, due regard, and duty to cooperate—apply to cyber operations? Under Articles 2(3), 2(4), and 33–38 of the UN Charter, the paper confirms that States are obligated to settle disputes threatening international peace and security through peaceful means of their choice, a principle reinforced by General Assembly resolutions and ICJ decisions. It further identifies an emerging obligation of due diligence requiring States to monitor networks and prevent misuse of infrastructure within their territory or exclusive control. Although conceptualizations of the precautionary principle and due regard lack uniform clarity, treaty provisions and judicial opinions increasingly recognize these norms as precursors to state responsibility for transboundary cyber harm. Finally, the article highlights an obligation to cooperate in investigations and mitigation—grounded in the UN Charter and instruments such as the European Cybercrime Convention—and recommends that future research delineate thresholds for applying due diligence and precaution in cyberspace while exploring institutional mechanisms to enhance international cooperation and norm development. This synthesis of disparate legal norms offers policymakers and jurists a coherent framework to guide State behavior in cyber conflict scenarios and identifies limitations arising from nascent State practice and attribution challenges.

title: The rules of cyber-welfare: what are the issues with these rules, how can the United States respond to an attack when applying these rules, and should new rules Be enacted
source: Holy Cross Journal of Law and Public Policy
abstract: This article offers a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the existing international legal framework governing state conduct in cyberspace, specifically assessing the applicability of the United Nations Charter and the non-binding Tallinn Manual to cyber-warfare and proposing a path toward a binding treaty. Epstein begins by surveying divergent conceptions of cyber-warfare—definitions based variously on the nature of the targeted object, the medium employed, and the syntactic, semantic, or hybrid characteristics of the attacks—and illustrates each category with hypothetical scenarios ranging from denial-of-service operations to semantic manipulation of critical information systems. He then turns to the core provisions of the UN Charter—Article 2(4)’s prohibition on the threat or use of force, Article 51’s right of self-defense, and Articles 41 and 42’s complementary measures—and demonstrates how these rules, crafted for kinetic conflict, struggle to accommodate cyber operations. Epstein examines the interpretive guidance of the Tallinn Manual’s rules on use of force, threat of force, necessity, proportionality, immediacy, collective self-defense, and permissible countermeasures, identifying four principal deficiencies: the misfit of traditional “use of force” and “armed attack” definitions in cyber contexts; the Manual’s unquantified scale-and-effects test; attribution and intent challenges; and the normative ambiguity created by reliance on a non-binding instrument. To remedy these gaps, Epstein advocates convening a U.S.-led international conference to negotiate a binding cyber-warfare treaty that builds upon the substance of the Tallinn Manual while introducing: a sliding-scale and effects test with quantifiable thresholds; explicit consideration of state intent; mandatory multilateral consultations before defensive or counter-cyber actions; illustrative examples to guide interpretation; and a universal obligation, analogous to Article 2(6) of the UN Charter, to ensure compliance by non-signatories to preserve international peace and security. Acknowledging procedural and political hurdles—such as achieving consensus among diverse state actors and keeping pace with rapidly evolving cyber threats—Epstein argues that without a binding instrument, states will continue to grapple with unacceptable legal uncertainty. The article concludes by urging U.S. leadership in treaty negotiations to establish a clear, adaptable, and legally precise regime that balances the flexibility needed to address emergent cyber threats with sufficient precision to deter unlawful cyber-attacks and sustain global stability.

title: Cyber neutrality: a textual analysis of traditional jus in bello neutrality rules through a purpose-based lens
abstract: In “Cyber Neutrality: A Textual Analysis of Traditional Jus in Bello Neutrality Rules through a Purpose-Based Lens,” Major Zachary P. Augustine examines how the Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907—particularly Hague V (land warfare) and Hague XIII (naval warfare)—can and should be applied to modern cyber operations in interstate armed conflict. Against a backdrop of rising state-sponsored cyber campaigns (e.g., Stuxnet) and growing investments in offensive cyber capabilities by major powers, the article argues that a purpose-based interpretive framework is needed to preserve neutral state sovereignty and prevent belligerents from exploiting neutral territory in cyberspace. Utilizing a legal-doctrinal methodology grounded in textual analysis, Augustine first reviews the traditional neutrality rules, their scope under the United Nations Charter’s collective security limitations, and the distinction between international and non-international armed conflicts. He then addresses the challenges of attributing cyber operations for state responsibility and neutrality enforcement. The core contribution lies in three detailed case studies: the Russian cyber campaign against Estonia (2007), proxy use during the 2008 Russia–Georgia conflict, and the U.S.–Israeli Stuxnet operation against Iran’s Natanz facility. Augustine demonstrates that—analogous to prohibited wireless telegraphy stations under Article 3 of Hague V—command-and-control servers located in neutral states violate neutrality duties if used to communicate with belligerent forces. Conversely, individual packet routing over neutral infrastructure generally falls within the telegraph exception (Article 8), due to practical limitations in controlling routes and the Internet’s redundant design. The deliberate use of proxies in neutral states, however, intentionally derives military advantage from neutral infrastructure, violating territorial inviolability under Article 1 of Hague V. Augustine further contends that technical attribution to network nodes suffices to justify limited military countermeasures against proxies even when state-level attribution remains elusive, although human attribution challenges may limit deterrence against sophisticated actors. The article concludes that existing neutrality law can be preserved by focusing on functional equivalence between cyber and conventional means, avoiding the need for wholesale treaty revision. Augustine acknowledges attribution and consensus-building constraints but proposes future research into attribution technologies, collective security agreements’ applicability to cyberspace, and normative developments to bolster compliance and enforcement. His purpose-based lens thus offers a pragmatic, multidisciplinary framework for reconciling century-old neutrality norms with emergent cyber realities and safeguarding neutral states in twenty-first-century warfare.

title: The Kampala compromise and cyberattacks: can there Be an international crime of cyber-aggression
abstract: This article investigates whether the Kampala compromise’s definition of the crime of aggression, as adopted at the 2010 Review Conference and embedded in the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC), can be interpreted to encompass state-sponsored cyberattacks, thereby creating a legal deterrent against acts of cyber-aggression. It begins by tracing the decades-long struggle to define aggression in international law, from the Nuremberg Tribunal’s characterization of aggression as the “supreme international crime” through the placeholder in Article 5(2) of the Rome Statute and the Special Working Group on the Crime of Aggression’s negotiations, culminating in the Kampala compromise’s adoption of key terms—"act of aggression," "manifest violation," and the gravity threshold. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the study examines the preparatory travaux of the Special Working Group, analyzes emblematic cyber incidents, and reviews post-Kampala state practice, with particular attention to U.S. cyber doctrine and policy documents. The analysis demonstrates that although the Kampala definitions are conventionally grounded in kinetic warfare paradigms, their language can be flexibly construed by ICC judges to cover cyber operations when assessed by their impact on state sovereignty, threat to international peace, and severity of consequences. However, the article identifies significant jurisdictional and political barriers—namely the primacy of the U.N. Security Council in labeling acts of aggression and the stringent threshold for individual criminal responsibility—which render near-term prosecutions for cyber-aggression unlikely. The author warns that expansive U.S. cyber doctrines risk broadening the ambit of aggression to include routine intelligence gathering or defensive counter-intrusions, potentially influencing customary international law ahead of global consensus. Recognizing these limitations, the article argues for complementary measures to deter and address cyber-aggression, including diplomatic engagement, norm-setting initiatives such as the Tallinn Manual and International Telecommunication Union cyber-peace proposals, international standard-setting for secure network infrastructures, cooperative defensive measures, and information-sharing regimes. It further recommends that U.S. policy be recalibrated to balance normative stability with effective deterrence, and that implementation of non-binding guidance precede the eventual application of individual criminal liability. The study concludes by advocating sustained multidisciplinary efforts—legal, diplomatic, and technical—to preemptively curb cyber-aggression and promote a peaceful cyberspace before hostile acts reach the threshold of armed conflict.

title: Ethics and cyber conflict: a response to JME 12:1 (2013)
abstract: This article by George R. Lucas Jr. provides a normative, conceptual engagement with recent ethical analyses of cyber conflict, distinguishing moral from legal evaluations under international law and demonstrating that the unique characteristics of cyber weapons challenge classical just war principles. Setting the discussion against the backdrop of a burgeoning corpus of legal scholarship — exemplified by the Tallinn Manual and analyses by Dunlap, Schmitt, and Graham — Lucas observes that ethical reflection on cyber warfare remains underdeveloped. He responds in particular to contributions in the Journal of Military Ethics special issue (Vol. 12:1, 2013) and earlier essays by Randall Dipert, Neil Rowe, and others, offering a systematic critique of prevailing moral frameworks. Lucas begins by framing the ‘‘threshold problem’’: cyber operations, involving ‘‘virtual’’ harms and low attribution costs, risk lowering the threshold for resorting to force. He explores how the perception of cyber conflict as kinetically ‘‘harmless’’ may encourage premature recourse to offensive action, thereby eroding just war norms. This leads to the ‘‘accountability problem’’: the difficulty of attributing acts in cyberspace undermines state responsibility, complicates retaliation, and diminishes transparency. Lucas discusses how this accountability deficit blurs the distinction between jus ad bellum (the right to go to war) and jus in bello (conduct in war), as concerns about responsibility for cyberattacks must inform decisions to initiate or respond to conflict. He further analyzes the ‘‘discrimination and proportionality problem,’’ showing that attacks on civilian infrastructure — data networks, power grids, financial systems — can inflict widespread civilian suffering, challenging fundamental Principles of Distinction and Proportionality under the law of armed conflict. Engaging Dipert’s detailed ‘‘ontology of cyberspace,’’ Lucas acknowledges the depth of Dipert’s mapping of cyber capabilities, tactics, and strategies, but contests the view that existing just war doctrine is wholly ill-equipped. He examines James Cook’s ‘‘argument from analogy,’’ which contends that cyber operations may be assimilated into classical paradigms of force projection by analogy to air and maritime domains. Lucas argues that while analogies provide heuristic value, they often skirt ethical questions about agency, intention, and acceptable scope. He further probes anticipatory self-defense, discussing the Stuxnet operation and U.S. defensive surveillance architectures as case studies that evoke moral dilemmas: when, if ever, may a state lawfully act without full attribution of hostile intent? Lucas defends preventive measures that impose no ‘‘real-world’’ harm — such as Stuxnet’s damage confined to nuclear centrifuges — as morally permissible under just war theory’s requirements for discrimination and proportionality, provided that collateral effects on civilians are negligible. He critiques overly cautious stances that deny states the right to defend their infrastructure absent certainty of adversarial identity, contending that reasonable inference from adversary preparations justifies cyber defense. Concluding, Lucas identifies three core ethical challenges for future scholarship and policy: defining the moral ‘‘threshold’’ for cyber engagement; clarifying accountability mechanisms in attribution and response; and developing guidelines for discrimination and proportionality in virtual domains. He calls for a collaborative effort among ethicists, legal scholars, policymakers, and military practitioners to construct a ‘‘moral Tallin Manual’’ — a set of operationalized ethical guidelines paralleling legal scholarship — and recommends empirical research into decision-making under uncertainty and norm-building for anticipatory measures in cyberspace. This interdisciplinary approach aims to fuse moral rigor with practical policy prescriptions, thereby advancing both ethical theory and state practice in governing cyber operations.

title: Japan, the Ministry of Defense and Cyber-Security
abstract: This article critically examines the Japanese Ministry of Defense’s (JMoD) evolving approach to cyber-security and situates recent organizational and doctrinal developments within Japan’s broader national and international cyber-policy framework. In response to a series of high-profile Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) attacks beginning in 2011—most notably on Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and other key defense contractors—the JMoD accelerated reforms aimed at strengthening information assurance and protecting critical national infrastructure. The author documents how the JMoD rewrote supplier contracts to mandate breach reporting, communication protocols, regular system scans, continuous monitoring, data retention, encryption, and staff training. Concurrently, Japan’s top-level advisory body, the Information Security Policy Council (ISPC), and the National Information Security Center (NISC) initiated reforms to overcome stovepiping between government agencies and the private sector. The article details the establishment of new national cyber-security entities: the Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT), the Cyber Incident Mobile Assistant Team (CYMAT), the Cyber Force Center under the National Police Agency, the Initiative for Cyber Security Information Sharing Partnership (J-CSIP), the Cyber Attack Analysis Council (CAAC), and the Control System Security Center (CSSC), highlighting the emergence of a multi-agency ecosystem charged with critical-infrastructure protection. Despite these efforts, the author argues that the JMoD remains constrained by segmented bureaucracy (“tatewari gyosei”), constitutional limitations (Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution), and institutional inertia. The article contrasts Japan’s cyber-defense posture with that of its allies—particularly the United States and South Korea—showing that while Japan has published a cyber-defense doctrine and created a Cyber Defense Unit (CDU), the CDU’s staffing, funding, and operational scope fall well short of international peers. Key gaps include the lack of a clear doctrine for active cyber-defense, uncertainties surrounding legal definitions of ‘‘armed cyber-attack’’ versus ‘‘use of force,’’ and insufficient capacity for deterrence or counter-attack. The analysis further explores the role of international defense ties, especially the US–Japan Security Treaty and the October 2013 Tokyo 2+2 meeting, which affirmed joint moves toward collective cyber-defense capabilities and established a Cyber Defense Policy Working Group (CDPWG). The author shows that information assurance and the integrity of the global defense supply chain have become strategic imperatives, prompting deeper Japan–US collaboration and new regional partnerships with Australia, ASEAN members, and the UK. In conclusion, while Japan’s recent reforms represent significant strides toward centralized coordination and enhanced public-private cooperation in cyber-security, the JMoD’s capacity to deter, defend, and if necessary, conduct limited collective cyber operations remains nascent. The article calls for legal amendments to empower the Self-Defense Forces (SDF) to protect civilian infrastructure during emergencies, the development of an operational doctrine for active defense, and an intensified recruitment of cyber-specialists—potentially including ‘‘white-hat’’ or ‘‘patriotic’’ hackers—to bridge existing capability gaps and bolster Japan’s role in an emerging global cyber-security order.

title: Combatting cyber-attacks through national interest diplomacy: a trilateral treaty with teeth
source: Washington and Lee Law Review Online
abstract: This article addresses the critical gap in international cyber law and diplomatic practice exposed by state-sponsored cyber-attacks, as illustrated by the 2014 U.S. indictment of Chinese military officers for economic espionage—a measure rendered ineffective by the absence of an extradition treaty and binding multilateral legal framework. Lawrence L. Muir Jr. argues that existing bilateral negotiations with China and Russia have repeatedly failed because they overlook each state’s pursuit of national self-interest. To overcome this impasse, the author proposes a novel approach—national interest diplomacy—employing triangulation theory from Cold War diplomacy to forge a trilateral treaty between the United States, Russia, and China. The United States would first pursue rapprochement with Russia, leveraging improved bilateral relations to pressure China to either join the treaty or face diplomatic isolation. Drawing on qualitative legal analysis and historical case studies, the paper systematically examines past bilateral failures, demonstrating how misaligned incentives stalled progress, and articulates the strategic advantages and feasibility of this triangulation strategy. The core of the proposed treaty comprises enabling and establishment clauses to create a standing cyber tribunal with clear organizational structure, jurisdiction, and procedural rules governing both civil and criminal matters. The tribunal would define protected digital assets and proscribe prohibited acts across three categories—cybercrime, cyber-espionage, and cyber-warfare—while differentiating between civilian, paramilitary, and military actors. Military cyber-units would receive limited extraterritorial immunity under defined conditions to ensure state accountability, whereas private actors could face civil damages and criminal extradition to deter malicious behavior. To address the perennial challenge of attribution, the treaty would adopt a “clear and convincing evidence” standard, permitting the submission of circumstantial and technical data, and mandate cooperation between states, corporations, and intelligence agencies for evidence-sharing. Key features include delineation of procedural mechanisms for restitution of victims, incentives to deter future attacks, and enforcement through civil litigation and extradition. The paper acknowledges limitations—including attribution difficulties, reliance on corporate and intelligence cooperation, and potential exploitation of immunity provisions—and recommends future research to assess political feasibility, refine substantive and procedural norms through stakeholder consultations, and explore integration with broader trade and security agreements. By aligning national economic and security goals with collective cyber defense and embedding accountability, the proposed trilateral treaty offers a practicable, incentive-based model to transform international cyber relations from impunity to enforceable norms, thereby securing restitution, deterring aggression, and strengthening global cybersecurity governance.

title: Inverted-militarized-diplomacy: how states bargain with cyber weapons
abstract: This article addresses a critical gap in the international relations literature by examining how states leverage cyber weapons in diplomatic bargaining, a topic largely overlooked despite the rapid proliferation of military cyber capabilities. Traditional models of militarized interstate bargaining assume that credible threats require visibility and attribution; however, cyber weapons derive their potency from secrecy and deniability. This paradox has led some scholars to dismiss cyber coercion as ineffective or even mythical. Against this backdrop, Richard B. Andres introduces the concept of “inverted-militarized diplomacy,” a framework that reconceptualizes the integration of cyber operations within statecraft. Rather than initiating coercive diplomacy through explicit threats, states employing this inverted approach first execute clandestine cyber intrusions to achieve strategic gains—ranging from economic disruption to information manipulation—and subsequently engage in diplomatic channels to forestall retaliation and manage escalation. Drawing on historical analogues such as piracy and proxy irregular warfare, the author identifies three principal methods of cyber coercion: economic sabotage, political subversion, and critical infrastructure disruption, each facilitated by the plausible deniability inherent in cyber tools. Through conceptual analysis and illustrative case studies—spanning state-sponsored malware deployments, intellectual property theft campaigns, and the covert facilitation of insurgent communications—the article demonstrates how inverted diplomacy allows states to exploit surprise for immediate objectives while preserving strategic ambiguity. This model challenges prevailing theories of deterrence and signaling by showing that the sequence of force and negotiation need not follow conventional patterns. The framework underscores the need for policymakers to anticipate covert cyber operations not as anomalies but as deliberate components of diplomatic strategy. The article concludes by outlining avenues for future research, including empirical validation across diverse geopolitical contexts, exploration of legal implications under jus ad bellum and doctrines of state responsibility, and development of normative and policy instruments to regulate clandestine cyber coercion. Ultimately, inverted-militarized diplomacy provides a novel theoretical lens that situates cyber weapons within a broader repertoire of state strategies, offering both scholars and practitioners insights into the evolving intersection of warfare and diplomacy in the digital age.

title: Cyber operations as nuclear counterproliferation measures
source: Journal of Conflict and Security Law
abstract: In "Cyber Operations as Nuclear Counterproliferation Measures," Marco Roscini examines the rising trend of States deploying cyber tools to impede nuclear proliferation, with a particular focus on the Stuxnet, DuQu, and Flame malware campaigns allegedly targeting Iran’s nuclear infrastructure. The study adopts a doctrinal approach within the framework of international law, analyzing both primary rules—such as non-proliferation obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT)—and secondary rules of State responsibility codified by the International Law Commission (ILC), as well as jus ad bellum principles under the UN Charter. Roscini begins by distinguishing between cyber attacks—actions aimed at disrupting or damaging systems—and cyber exploitation—non-destructive intelligence-gathering operations. He assesses how each typology might function as a counterproliferation instrument, noting that intelligence-only malware like DuQu and Flame may lack the destructive consequences necessary to constitute a wrongful act under international law, whereas disruptive operations such as Stuxnet clearly breach multiple primary obligations.

title: Cyber deterrence isn't MAD; it's mosaic
abstract: In Cyber Deterrence Isn t MAD; It s Mosaic, Ben Buchanan critiques the prevalent reliance on the Cold War s Mutually Assured Destruction (MAD) paradigm for cyberspace, arguing instead for a nuanced, multi-dimensional deterrence "mosaic" tailored to the varied severity of cyber threats and diversity of actors. Recognizing that cyberspace presents challenges unlike nuclear deterrence—chiefly attribution difficulties, actor heterogeneity, and varying threat impact—Buchanan develops a theoretical model with two key axes: specific versus general deterrence, and absolute versus restrictive deterrence. Specific deterrence targets identifiable adversaries through credible, actor-specific consequences, while general deterrence imposes exemplar sanctions intended to influence broader groups. Absolute deterrence seeks to fully prevent a given hostile act, whereas restrictive deterrence aims only to moderate actor behavior or reduce the frequency and intensity of cyber operations. This two-dimensional typology enables policymakers to categorize cyber threats—ranging from sophisticated, state-sponsored intrusions to loosely organized hacktivist collectives—and to assign appropriate deterrence strategies. For high-severity, state-sponsored attacks, Buchanan argues absolute and specific deterrence are more credible when accompanied by clear threat communication and the potential for proportionate retaliation. In contrast, financially motivated criminals or nonstate hacktivists are best addressed through restrictive and general deterrence, given the challenges of attribution and limited targets for reprisal. Buchanan further contends that deterrence alone is insufficient: robust defensive cyber practices—network monitoring, timely patching, and penetration testing—must accompany the mosaic. Defensive measures serve to raise adversary costs, lower operational capabilities, and reinforce restrictive deterrence without risking destabilizing escalation. Unlike Cold War ballistic defenses, cyber defenses are non-destabilizing and broadly acceptable, since escalation to kinetic conflict remains possible, and defensive deployments simply complement deterrence. While the mosaic strategy acknowledges limits—especially in empirically verifying deterrence efficacy and proving that attacks did not occur due to deterrence—it offers a flexible framework for integrating legal, diplomatic, informational, and technical tools. Buchanan highlights that credible threat signaling depends critically on improved attribution mechanisms and emerging international norms. For future research, he recommends empirical case studies across geopolitical contexts to refine the model, development of cooperative international agreements to bolster restrictive deterrence against transnational cybercrime, and exploration of how evolving cyber norms can strengthen collective deterrence. Ultimately, the mosaic approach shifts the paradigm from monolithic strategies to a calibrated, context-dependent blend of punitive and defensive measures, ensuring that states can realistically deter diverse cyber threats while minimizing escalation risks.

title: Information warfare?: the case for an asian perspective on information operations
abstract: In “Information Warfare?: The Case for an Asian Perspective on Information Operations,” Alan Chong argues that Western conceptions of information warfare (IW), characterized as a strategic revolution with five defining features and rooted in liberal democratic ideology, inadequately capture the full strategic breadth of information-based conflict. Drawing on qualitative comparative analysis of contemporary cyber conflict case narratives—such as the 2007 Estonian DDOS attacks, Stuxnet’s covert sabotage of Iran’s nuclear infrastructure, the 2012 Shamoon data-wiping assault on Saudi Aramco, and the alleged activities of China’s PLA Unit 61398—alongside classical strategic texts by Sun Tzu, Mao Zedong, and Vo Nguyen Giap, Chong develops a novel framework of generic features for an Asian model of information operations (IO). He distinguishes IW as the use of symbolic resources to penetrate an adversary’s secrecy and confidence primarily in wartime and military contexts, whereas IO encompasses a seamless continuum of symbolic, diplomatic, and civilian efforts serving political objectives across both peacetime and wartime. Chong identifies key characteristics of the Asian IO model, including the intentional cultivation of attributional ambiguity to exploit cyberspace’s ‘safe havens,’ the systematic targeting of an adversary’s will through symbolic paralysis, and the integration of psychological operations, military deception, and public diplomacy within a unified strategic concept. He argues that Asian traditions, informed by the pre-digital wisdom of Sun Tzu’s emphasis on deception and intelligence, Mao’s holistic view of protracted people’s war, and Giap’s guerrilla strategies, treat information as a continuous political instrument rather than a compartmentalized military adjunct. The study highlights how these Asian IO features diverge from American paradigms that strictly separate wartime from peacetime information efforts and emphasize technological superiority. Chong’s framework broadens the strategic field beyond Western universalism, enriching policy debates on deterrence, international norms, and the legal thresholds of cyber engagement. The author acknowledges limitations inherent in selective textual interpretation of exemplar cases and classical treatises without extensive empirical validation. He calls for future research to empirically test the proposed Asian IO framework through systematic analysis of national cyber doctrines, examine its normative implications under international law and state responsibility, and integrate additional non-Western strategic traditions to refine guidelines for policy, diplomacy, and high-level cyber strategy development.

title: Anti-social networking: crowdsourcing and the cyber defence of national critical infrastructures
abstract: In “Anti-social networking: crowdsourcing and the cyber defence of national critical infrastructures,” Chris W. Johnson investigates how social media technologies have reshaped state-level cyber-attacks, exacerbating the longstanding “attribution problem” while simultaneously offering new avenues for defence. Drawing on action-research engagements and case studies involving Estonia (2007), Belarus (2008), Lithuania (2008), Georgia (2008), China (2009), and the Stuxnet attack (2010), Johnson identifies four distinct roles of social networks in cyber-conflict. First, attackers harness online communities to crowdsource distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) campaigns, disseminating malware, coordinating target selection, and mobilizing participants through appeals on social platforms. Second, social media profiles and interpersonal connections enable spear-phishing, whereby attackers exploit trust relationships—sending malicious attachments or links that appear to originate from legitimate contacts—to breach critical infrastructure networks. Third, social-network–related service models facilitate “disposable” command-and-control architectures; by embedding C2 servers within cloud and social environments, attackers obscure ownership and operation, hindering forensic traceability. Finally, states have tacitly exploited or tolerated criminal botnet networks cultivated via social media to conduct covert operations against third-party infrastructures. Through confidential interviews with military, intelligence, telecom, and critical-infrastructure stakeholders, supplemented by forensic analyses and provider data, Johnson reconstructs how these tactics unfolded in each case: how Estonia’s web-based banking and national services endured over 120 DDoS incidents; how Radio Free Europe, Lithuanian parliamentary sites, and Georgian government portals suffered politically motivated outages; how Chinese dissident and government targets were surveilled or attacked under the guise of GhostNet and other campaigns; and how Stuxnet leveraged peer-to-peer and cloud services to damage Iranian enrichment centrifuges. Building on these insights, the paper proposes a five-stage strategic roadmap for national cyber-defence that leverages social media positively: (1) proactive monitoring of social platforms to identify emerging hacktivist coordination and intersections with criminal networks; (2) systematic risk assessment through public–private partnerships, mapping vulnerabilities revealed by social-media intelligence; (3) dissemination of community-focused early warnings via specialised social channels (e.g., WARPs), accompanied by drills to ensure responsive action; (4) enhanced forensic readiness through real-time anomaly detection and social-sourced data in incident response; and (5) institutionalising lessons learned—sharing anonymised, cross-sector incident reports to counter misinformation and stimulate continuous resilience improvements. Johnson acknowledges limitations, including potential positivist bias from his dual role as researcher-practitioner and restricted access to certain state data, and calls for future work on automated social-media analytics, standardised cross-sector threat-reporting protocols, empirically validating community-based exercises, and refining legal frameworks to balance transparency and security. This multidisciplinary analysis advances understanding of how social networking both amplifies and mitigates state-sponsored cyber threats, offering policymakers and infrastructure operators actionable guidance to deter, detect, and recover from sophisticated attacks.

title: Geopolitics and Cyber Power: Why Geography Still Matters
abstract: In “Geopolitics and Cyber Power: Why Geography Still Matters,” John B. Sheldon offers a comprehensive multidisciplinary analysis that bridges international relations, strategic studies, and communications engineering to argue against the prevailing notion that cyberspace has rendered traditional geopolitical considerations obsolete. He contends that despite cyberspace’s capacity to compress time and space, its physical infrastructure—encompassing undersea and terrestrial cables, satellites, servers, and local networks—is deeply rooted in geography and remains subject to sovereign control and strategic contestation. Tracing the historical interplay between communications infrastructure and state power, Sheldon demonstrates that the ownership, distribution, and location of these physical assets shape state capabilities in cyber espionage, sabotage, and information operations, as evidenced in landmark cases such as the Stuxnet attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities and cyber assaults on Ukraine’s power grid. He highlights how the attribution, deterrence, and response frameworks in cyber conflict are inherently tied to the geographic signatures of infrastructure and actor motivations. Further, Sheldon explores the strategic implications of urbanized littorals and megacities, where dense populations and critical economic nodes intersect with pervasive networked technologies, intensifying vulnerabilities and creating complex operational environments. He argues that future conflicts will increasingly blend conventional, irregular, cyber, and information operations within these contested coastal zones, necessitating integrated doctrines and training for armies, navies, and air forces to exploit cyber capabilities for intelligence, deception, and network denial or exploitation. At the grand strategic level, Sheldon revisits classical geopolitical theories—Mackinder’s Heartland and Spykman’s Rimland—to demonstrate that while cyber capabilities do not overturn the historic rivalry between continental and maritime powers, they amplify each side’s ability to project influence and contest critical infrastructure. By examining how cyber power interacts with diplomacy, economic statecraft, and military force, he shows that an effective state strategy must integrate territorial considerations, infrastructure vulnerabilities, and geostrategic context to enhance deterrence, resilience, and crisis response. His conclusion underscores that cyberspace is neither placeless nor apolitical, and that geography remains a fundamental determinant of state cyberpower. Policymakers and analysts are thus urged to rebalance their cyber strategies by recognizing the enduring influence of territory and geopolitics in shaping digital operations and the broader dynamics of international power competition.

title: Is cyber deterrence an illusory course of action?
abstract: As cyberspace has evolved into a recognized warfighting domain, policymakers and security experts have debated the applicability of Cold War deterrence theory to hostile cyber activities targeting critical infrastructure. This paper examines whether traditional concepts of deterrence by punishment and deterrence by denial can effectively dissuade adversaries—ranging from lone hackers and hacktivists to organized criminal groups and state-sponsored cyber units—from conducting destructive operations. Grounded in a conceptual policy analysis, the study synthesizes official U.S. government strategy documents, strategic deterrence theory, and illustrative cases such as Stuxnet and historical nuclear deterrence episodes. It demonstrates that the success of nuclear-era deterrence depended on clear attribution, credible calibrated retaliation, and mutually recognized thresholds of unacceptable behavior, conditions fundamentally undermined in cyberspace by attribution challenges, actor multiplicity, and opaque signaling mechanisms. Deterrence by punishment in cyberspace falters because states cannot reliably identify or retaliate proportionally against every malicious intrusion, nor can they sustain repeatable punishments across a diverse threat landscape; deterrence by denial is constrained by adversaries’ rapid tactical evolution and persistent exploitation of basic security lapses. The analysis further argues that cyber deterrence strategies presuppose rational adversaries with assets of value; yet many cyber actors—including hacktivists or cells with diffuse structures—and closed regimes with minimal online footprints lack both treaty-based incentives and clear assets to deter. By dissecting the axioms of attribution, repeatability, and strategic success, the author contends that pre-emptive or retaliatory cyber strikes are impractical for achieving lasting stability and risk provoking escalation through misinterpretation. Instead, the study reframes strategic emphasis toward robust cyber defense postures, adaptive security controls, accountability frameworks, and performance monitoring. It highlights industry best practices, including the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s guidance on agile threat awareness and response, and the SANS Institute’s Critical Security Controls, as essential measures to reduce systemic vulnerability. Recognizing limitations inherent in theoretical modeling and reliance on open sources, the paper calls for empirical validation of deterrence metrics, development of advanced attribution technologies to strengthen credible signaling, and dynamic policy frameworks that integrate rigorous compliance standards. Ultimately, the author concludes that cyber deterrence, as currently conceptualized, is illusory; states should prioritize continuous defensive improvement, stakeholder accountability, and resilience to navigate cyberspace’s shifting threat environment.

title: Navigating "Jus Ad Bellum" in the Age of Cyber Warfare
abstract: The advent of increasingly sophisticated cyber attacks has transformed cyberspace into a battleground where nation-states wield computer code as a weapon capable of inflicting physical destruction and destabilizing critical infrastructure. Traditional jus ad bellum principles, which emerged in an era of kinetic warfare, offer scant guidance on when a cyber attack constitutes an unlawful use of force or an armed attack justifying countermeasures under the United Nations Charter. This gap has significant implications for international peace and security, as states struggle to calibrate their strategic and legal responses to digital operations that may cause irreversible harm. Recognizing these challenges, the author sets out to refine the conceptual and doctrinal underpinnings of jus ad bellum in the cyber domain, asking when and under what criteria a cyber operation crosses the threshold into armed conflict. To address this question, the paper adopts a doctrinal methodology grounded in international law scholarship, complemented by analysis of technical cyber security research and case studies of malware campaigns such as Stuxnet and large-scale denial-of-service operations. The author first clarifies definitional ambiguities by contrasting object-based definitions of cyber attack with an instrument-based perspective that emphasizes computer networks as the means by which digital weapons operate. Technical contours—such as malware propagation, reversible versus irreversible damage, attribution difficulties, and the convergence of cyber and physical systems—are examined to inform the legal analysis. Next, the paper critiques leading approaches to assessing cyber attacks under jus ad bellum: instrument-based, target-based, and effects-based models each reveal shortcomings in accommodating the unpredictable scope of malware and the diffuseness of its impacts. Drawing on this critique, the author proposes a novel analytical framework centered on cyber-physical systems, defining an armed cyber attack as one intentionally designed to inflict irreversible disruption or damage on systems that intertwine computing and physical components. This cyber-physical systems approach yields clear criteria: attacks against purely digital targets that are reversible and non-destabilizing do not constitute force, while operations threatening critical infrastructure or causing tangible destruction are deemed armed attacks, thus triggering lawful self-defense. While this framework advances the law’s ability to deter the most dangerous cyber operations and to preserve interstate stability, the author acknowledges practical limitations, including the evidentiary challenges of discerning intent and payload design, as well as the evolving nature of networked technologies that may outpace doctrinal adaptation. The paper concludes by calling for further treaty development and state practice to solidify norms, suggesting future research directions such as refining attribution methodologies, exploring proportionality in cyber countermeasures, and integrating the framework into broader strategic doctrine. By offering an objective, administrable standard that aligns with both legal principles and technological realities, this work aims to guide policymakers and legal practitioners in navigating the complexities of cyber conflict under international law.

title: Modelling attribution
source: European Conference on Information Warfare and Security
abstract: This article develops a comprehensive, process-based model for attributing responsibility for cyber incidents when they escalate into the realm of state-level conflict and security decision-making. Departing from existing technical and legal attribution frameworks, it distinguishes between two parallel processes—an apolitical criminal justice process focused on individual perpetrators, and a politically charged national security process centered on adversary identity and state sponsorship. The study identifies five key determinants that politicize attribution: the profile of the target (particularly its political nature or threat to critical national infrastructure and intellectual property), the severity and scale of damage inflicted, the apparent origin of the instigator, the technical means employed in the attack, and any public claims by political actors. Through a comparative conceptual analysis of seminal attribution models from computer science and political science and illustrative case studies of the Aramco Shamoon attack and the Sasser worm incident, the article shows how each determinant imposes distinct constraints and evidentiary standards. In criminal settings, attribution hinges on the rigorous collection and analysis of digital evidence to satisfy high judicial proof thresholds, with formal investigations led by law enforcement and judiciary bodies. Conversely, in national security contexts, attribution decisions rely on intelligence rather than formal evidence, are made within executive bodies, and reflect broader political judgments about foreign relations, deterrence strategies, and diplomatic consequences. The proposed dual-process model reframes attribution as an inherently political endeavor when certain criteria are met, guiding policymakers on when to involve executive decision-makers, calibrate evidentiary thresholds appropriately, and manage potential diplomatic fallout. Acknowledging the model’s theoretical nature and the need for empirical validation, the study recommends future research to apply the framework to a wider range of historical and contemporary cyber incidents, to develop quantitative indicators for the five determinants, and to explore interactions between evolving international norms, legal frameworks, and political attribution processes.

title: Interpretation Catalysts in Cyberspace
abstract:
In "Interpretation Catalysts in Cyberspace," Rebecca Ingber examines how discrete events and processes—what she terms "interpretation catalysts"—shape the development of international law governing state conduct in cyberspace. Ingber opens by observing that cyberspace, with its rapid technological evolution and high-profile incidents, offers a compressed timeline in which the dynamics of legal adaptation and consensus formation become especially visible. She identifies four longstanding debates in international law—adapting existing rules to new technologies, secrecy and the emergence of custom, transparency obligations, and the tension between state interests and soft-law initiatives—which are all accelerated and amplified in the cyber domain. 

Central to her argument is the concept of interpretation catalysts: juridical triggers that compel decision-making bodies—whether executive branches, intergovernmental panels, or expert committees—to formulate and articulate legal positions. Such catalysts not only force a choice of interpretation but also affect the composition of deliberative bodies, the framing of legal questions, the contextual parameters of discussion, and the incentives of participating actors. Ingber illustrates this framework through a detailed case study of the two Tallinn Manual processes. The first catalyst was the 2007 cyberattacks against Estonia, which prompted NATO’s Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence to convene experts to map out how existing jus ad bellum and jus in bello norms applied to cyber operations. Subsequently, the Manuals themselves served as ongoing catalysts, compelling states to clarify, develop, or contest their positions during sessions such as The Hague Process. 

Ingber contrasts her earlier work on U.S. executive-branch legal decision-making—where internal interpretation catalysts can singularly shape national legal positions—with the multinational, soft-law environment of the Tallinn Manuals, where expert consensus and state engagement interact. She argues that soft-law processes driven by law-of-war expertise bring practical focus on operational rules and foster engagement between scholars and practitioners, but also carry normative weight that can steer state behavior. 

A key insight is that interpretation catalysts are manipulable: actors can design or leverage such triggers to push the law toward desired outcomes. Ingber underscores this through the divergent treatment of international human rights law versus the law of armed conflict in Tallinn Manual 2.0, noting institutional challenges and critiques over the Manual’s scope. 

Ultimately, the chapter calls for attention to institutions, actors, and processes—not merely doctrinal debates—in understanding how cyberlaw evolves. The initial events and the choice of forum determine both the trajectory of legal interpretation and the enduring shape of the rules that govern state conduct in cyberspace.

title: Cyber Insecurity: Competition, Conflict, and Innovation Demand Effective Cyber Security Norms
abstract:
Neutze and Nicholas argue that the accelerating phenomenon of “cyber insecurity” among nation‐states—borne of deepening reliance on information and communication technologies (ICT) coupled with mounting vulnerabilities—demands a robust international regime of cyber security norms. They define cyber insecurity as state perceptions of threat arising from adversarial exploitation of government and critical infrastructure systems, criminal activity, espionage, and the political risks attendant to ICT dependency. This insecurity manifests domestically in intensified investment in defense, intelligence, and regulation, and internationally in diplomatic efforts to manage cyberspace risks. Yet, the authors contend that existing state‐to‐state initiatives have failed to produce a credible “rules of the road” for acceptable behavior in cyberspace. The stakes are high: states’ critical functions—economic activity, defense, public health, and political stability—are increasingly vulnerable to digital attack, as highlighted by incidents like the Saudi Aramco network disruption in 2012. Moreover, the use of proxies and ambiguity in attribution complicates traditional deterrence and response strategies. 

Through empirical survey of more than thirty national cyber policy frameworks—including those of the United States, China, Russia, European Union member states, India, and Brazil—Neutze and Nicholas observe both convergence and divergence in states’ approaches to doctrine, organizational structures, and capability development for offense and defense. While the United States’ emphasis on cyber command and intelligence sharing establishes a model that other powers may emulate or counter, regional initiatives ranging from the European Union’s Network and Information Security Directive to India’s focus on ICT innovation illustrate diverse political motivations and risk tolerances. This variability underscores the need for negotiated principles that balance security with the preservation of ICT‐driven innovation and open commerce. 

Central to the authors’ prescription is a multi‐stakeholder process that engages both governments and the private sector, which build, operate, and defend the global ICT infrastructure. They propose foundational principles—transparency, harmonization, collaboration, risk reduction, and proportionality—as the basis for cyber security norms. By involving large ICT firms alongside the Group of Twenty (G20) nations in a “global coalition,” the initiative could mirror the public‐private partnerships long employed in critical infrastructure protection and draw lessons from nuclear arms‐control frameworks. The authors stress the imperative of capacity‐building in cyber literacy for diplomats, policymakers, and industry leaders, ensuring that discussions are informed by technical realities as well as strategic considerations. 

In conclusion, Neutze and Nicholas warn that failure to establish effective cyber norms may drive military competition and stifle ICT innovation, leaving the “age of digital peril” unchecked. They call for immediate action: governments must commit to a transparent, principle‐based norms development process, and the private sector must proactively convene forums to prevent states from resuming unrestrained surveillance and cyber operations. Only through sustained public‐private engagement can global cyber insecurity be reduced and a stable, secure digital environment be maintained.

title: Hitting the cyber marque: issuing a cyber letter of marque to combat digital threats
abstract:
Major Christopher M. Kessinger’s 2013 article in Army Lawyer explores the novel application of letters of marque to cyberspace as a means of legitimizing and regulating private sector cyber defense and offensive operations. Drawing on a rich historical tradition dating from the early privateering era and the American Revolutionary and War of 1812 periods, Kessinger argues that letters of marque are a constitutionally grounded tool (U.S. Const. art. I, §8) that could expand the nation’s cyber capabilities without the political gridlock and bureaucratic inertia hampering current government efforts. The article begins by detailing the scale and impact of cyber attacks worldwide—citing millions of incidents targeting states, corporations, and international bodies, with costs in the billions. Kessinger notes the failure of many governments and industries to mount coherent offensive or defensive strategies and highlights proposals from Congress, the private sector, and research agencies that have either stalled or been constrained by legal risks, notably under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

Kessinger then traces the evolution of letters of marque from early self-help authorizations to government-issued privateer commissions, emphasizing their dual military and law enforcement functions. He shows how the Continental Congress and early American presidents, including John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, embraced privateering to augment naval forces and protect commerce. Despite the 1856 Declaration of Paris’ purported ban on privateering, the U.S. never ratified it and retains the constitutional power to issue letters of marque—a power that remains dormant but viable.

Building on historical precedent, Kessinger proposes a comprehensive modern “cyber letter of marque” regime in which the government would issue licenses to vetted, well-bonded private entities—cyber privateers—to conduct threat neutralization activities, including hack-back operations, on behalf of network owners and the state. Key elements include rigorous application criteria requiring technical expertise and substantial financial bonds; detailed rules of engagement and daily logging requirements to ensure accountability; mandatory reporting to a centralized oversight body to de-conflict operations with law enforcement and national security missions; and judicial review through the existing admiralty prize court framework under 10 U.S.C. Chapter 655, adapted to cyberspace. Sanctions for overreach—bond forfeiture, debarment from government contracts, criminal prosecution, and tort liability—would deter misuse and align incentives.

Kessinger addresses concerns about vigilantism and legal ambiguity by emphasizing that cyber privateers would operate under explicit congressional mandates and judicial oversight, just as their maritime predecessors did. He outlines the statutory and constitutional underpinnings, including the President’s authority to direct private armed vessels (33 U.S.C. §385–386) and the role of federal courts in adjudicating prizes. The article concludes that, faced with an increasingly sophisticated and damaging cyber threat environment, the United States should resurrect the letter of marque power. By integrating well-regulated private sector actors into national cyber defense and offense, a cyber letter of marque regime could provide a flexible, rapid, and constitutionally sound means of securing critical networks and deterring adversaries.

title: A Better Defense: Examining the United States' New Norms-Based Approach to Cyber Deterrence International Engagement on Cyber III: State Building on a New Frontier
abstract: Since 2010, states have confronted the growing challenge of deterring adversarial actions conducted through cyberspace, recognizing that traditional concepts of military deterrence may not readily translate into the digital domain. The United Nations Group of Governmental Experts underscored the need for norms on state behavior in Information and Communication Technologies to reduce collective risk and protect critical infrastructure, framing the debate on cyber conflict as a matter of international security. This article investigates how the United States has pursued a norms-based approach to cyber deterrence, posing the question of whether embedding cyber strategy within a normative framework can enhance stability and restraint among states. By examining official U.S. policy documents—including the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace and the Department of Defense’s Strategy for Operating in Cyberspace—alongside theoretical insights from constructivist scholarship on norm emergence and lifecycle, the author employs a qualitative policy analysis methodology enriched by international relations theory and case references to Estonia, Georgia, and the Stuxnet operation. The analysis reveals that while attribution challenges, difficulty in holding adversaries’ assets at risk, and nonstate actor involvement complicate traditional deterrence models, the U.S. norms-based strategy leverages multilateral dialogue and confidence-building measures to socialize expectations regarding acceptable state conduct. This synergy between normative engagement and military capability appears to strengthen general deterrence, imparting predictability to state behaviors and reducing opportunities for miscalculation. The article contributes a conceptual framework that links the stages of norm development—emergence, cascade, and institutionalization—to the potential evolution of norms into binding international law, thereby providing a structure for effective cyber deterrence. It argues that norms can act as “rules of the road” in cyberspace, internalized by actors and reinforced through diplomatic practice, multilateral forums, and state conduct. Notwithstanding these insights, the study acknowledges limitations stemming from the novelty of cyber norms, the uneven participation of states, potential allegations of double standards—especially in light of the U.S. and Israeli Stuxnet operation—and the political mistrust that can hinder consensus. The paucity of empirical data on compliance mechanisms and the unpredictable nature of norm internalization underscore the need for further empirical investigation. Future research should focus on mapping the processes through which specific cyber norms become legally binding, elucidating the mechanisms of compliance, and exploring how confidence-building transparency measures can pave the way for formal international agreements. By advancing an integrated approach to cyber deterrence that combines normative development, international law, and strategic policy, this study offers a novel lens for scholars and policymakers seeking to secure cyberspace through law and shared expectations rather than force alone.

title: The Road Ahead: Gaps, Leaks and Drips
abstract:
In “The Road Ahead: Gaps, Leaks and Drips,” Michael J. Glennon examines the adequacy of existing international legal frameworks to govern state conduct in cyber conflict, interrogating whether the jus ad bellum and jus in bello rules are comprehensive or marked by significant lacunae. Glennon argues that international law’s purported completeness masks critical gaps when applied to cyber operations, as illustrated by the clandestine Stuxnet campaign (codenamed “Olympic Games”). He poses foundational questions: whether such operations constitute a “use of force” under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter; if they amount to an “armed attack” permitting self-defense under Article 51; and how international humanitarian law applies to cyber actors—whether computer specialists qualify as combatants or non-combatants and the implications for detention, prosecution, and state responsibility. Surveying doctrinal literature on non liquet and the completeness of legal systems, Glennon contends that legal categories such as “force,” “attack,” and “combatant” feature blurred margins in cyberspace, undermining the premise that each fact pattern yields a single correct legal classification. 

He then explores two divergent future scenarios. In the first, a dramatic, attributable cyber shock—such as a “digital Pearl Harbor” causing widespread infrastructure collapse—would catalyze an international push for new legal norms, potentially including sanctions or expressly redefining self-defense to permit kinetic responses to cyber attacks. Drawing parallels to post-World War I and II treaty-making, Glennon suggests that high-impact incidents could generate political will for novel regulation. The second scenario envisages a “drip-drip” pattern of intermittent, small-scale cyber intrusions and disruptions—flash crashes, mysterious blackouts, unexplained accidents—that evade clear attribution and diffuse public outrage, leading states to tolerate gradual erosion of norms. He warns that in such an environment, the reciprocal security dilemma—where each side expands cyber capabilities to offset perceived threats—fuels an arms race that resists substantive legal constraint, as policymakers prioritize plausible deniability and protect their own operational freedom while restricting adversaries only weakly. 

Glennon further argues that secrecy regimes and classification of cyber methods as “sources and methods” shield operations from public and legislative scrutiny, allowing cyber engagements to proceed without accountability or democratic oversight. This opacity exacerbates the challenges of attributability and risk assessment, as responses may be based on inferred motives rather than confirmed acts. He warns that the remoteness and anonymity of cyber warfare reduce inhibitions against violence—akin to the moral distancing in drone strikes—and may lower thresholds for initiating hostilities, leading to more frequent, geographically dispersed confrontations that resemble war by stealth. 

Concluding that the likelihood of deep or broad legal regulation is low without a major attributable incident, Glennon stresses that the drip-drip scenario poses grave humanitarian and institutional risks. He urges recognition of the nuances in cyber conflict and calls for proactive international engagement to fill legal gaps and establish clearer norms before incremental cyber hostilities entrench a precarious de facto status quo.

title: International Law and Cyber Threats from Non-State Actors
source: Israel Yearbook on Human Rights, Volume 43 (2013)
abstract: In "International Law and Cyber Threats from Non-State Actors," Laurie R. Blank offers a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of how public international law governs and constrains state responses to malicious cyber operations carried out by non-state actors. The article situates cyberspace firmly within traditional legal paradigms of use of force (jus ad bellum) and the law of armed conflict (LOAC), noting that rapid technological advances have transformed cyberspace into both a battlefield and a theater for varied malicious activities, ranging from protest and espionage to acts labeled as “cyber war.” Drawing on high-profile incidents such as the 2007 Estonian denial-of-service attacks, the 2008 Russia–Georgia cyber operations, and the Stuxnet operation against Iran’s nuclear facilities, Blank highlights the challenges of attributing cyber operations to specific non-state actors and states, underscoring persistent uncertainties regarding thresholds for resort to force. Part II examines jus ad bellum questions, focusing on when cyber acts by non-state entities can constitute a “use of force” or “armed attack” under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. Employing analysis of state practice and commentary, the article elucidates how attribution difficulties, threshold assessments, and the blurred line between law enforcement and armed conflict complicate a state’s determination of when self-defense is lawful. Blank emphasizes that states must navigate these challenges carefully, as mischaracterization of cyber incidents could either unlawfully broaden the scope of self-defense or unduly limit states’ rights to respond. Part III turns to LOAC applicability, addressing how fundamental principles—distinction, proportionality, and precaution—apply once a cyber operation triggers an armed conflict. The author explores the practical difficulties of distinguishing civilian from military network nodes, warns against indiscriminate or excessive countermeasures, and details obligations to take constant care to avoid civilian harm, including advance warnings and selection of means and methods of attack. Drawing parallels with physical-world targeting practices, Blank shows how LOAC’s proportionality and precaution rules translate into digital operations, while noting that effective compliance requires robust intelligence and technical capacity to map networks and anticipate collateral effects. In Section IV, the article probes the powerful role of rhetoric in cyber policy, arguing that framing a broad spectrum of malicious cyber conduct as “war” or “attack” risks eroding legal safeguards, inflating executive authority, and blurring the distinction between law enforcement and military paradigms. Blank cautions that a “cyber war” narrative can facilitate expansive responses disproportionate to the actual threat, drawing lessons from the post–9/11 “war on terror” experience, where wartime rhetoric subsumed diverse counterterrorism measures and contributed to legal and policy overreach. She calls for precision in terminology to preserve the integrity of international legal regimes. Ultimately, the article offers a structured framework for state responses to non-state cyber threats, mapping essential paradigms in jus ad bellum and LOAC, identifying attribution constraints, and highlighting the normative impact of rhetoric. By clarifying the interplay between use-of-force rules, armed conflict law, and criminal law, Blank’s analysis equips policymakers, legal practitioners, and scholars with the tools to assess lawful and effective responses to the full continuum of cyber activities by non-state actors, reinforcing respect for international legal obligations while acknowledging the dynamic nature of cyberspace.

title: Cyber War and International Law: Concluding Remarks at the 2012 Naval War College International Law Conference
abstract: In his Concluding Remarks at the 2012 Naval War College International Law Conference, Professor Yoram Dinstein critiques the prevalent dilution of the concept of “cyber war” in both academic discourse and military deliberations, arguing for a rigorous return to the traditional contours of armed conflict under international law. Dinstein begins by lamenting that many participants conflated generic illicit cyber activities—such as data theft, malware distribution, and peacetime hacking—with the core issue of cyber operations in the context of war, thereby diverting attention from the decisive question: what constitutes cyber warfare? He insists that cyber war must be analyzed through the dual frameworks of jus ad bellum and jus in bello, the former addressing the threshold for resorting to force and the latter governing conduct once hostilities commence. Under jus ad bellum, Dinstein clarifies that the pivotal inquiry is not simply whether a cyber operation amounts to the “use of force” prohibited by Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, but whether it qualifies as an “armed attack” under Article 51, thus entitling a State to self-defense. He distinguishes between non-forcible countermeasures—such as seeking recourse through the Security Council or litigation—and the use of counterforce, permissible only in response to an armed attack. Dinstein rejects the concept of anticipatory self-defense in cyberspace as incompatible with Article 51. Turning to jus in bello, he applies the law of armed conflict (LOAC) to cyber operations, defining cyber “attacks” by their tangible effects—death, injury, or property damage—rather than by the simple planting of code. He underscores the principle of distinction, noting that civilian computers and objects may never lawfully be targeted, and that military computers are identified by their nature, use, or purpose. He further elucidates that computers of ordinary design can become legitimate military objectives if employed for military purposes, and that any doubt must be resolved in favor of civilian status. Indiscriminate cyber attacks—such as unleashing malicious software without control over its propagation—are equated with the indiscriminate use of biological weapons. Dinstein also examines the proportionality rule, stressing that anticipated civilian harm must not be excessive relative to the concrete and direct military advantage sought, and that military advantage must be assessed holistically across a campaign rather than on a piecemeal basis. Concluding, he argues against the immediate pursuit of a new treaty on cyber warfare, predicting that any such instrument would only restate existing LOAC norms in an anodyne fashion, much like the interwar Protocol on Submarine Warfare. He closes with two observations: cyber warfare levels the strategic playing field by offering less powerful States asymmetric tools to challenge major powers, and the imperative for U.S. Cyber Command is to focus on preparing for genuine cyber conflict—ensuring deterrence and readiness—rather than preoccupations with peacetime cyber issues such as intellectual property.

title: The sophistication criterion for attribution: identifying the perpetrators of cyber-attacks
abstract: This article offers a rigorous doctrinal analysis of how existing international law governing the use of force applies to cyber operations, with a particular focus on the right of self-defence and the attendant problem of attributing cyber attacks to States. Tsagourias begins by defining “cyber attacks” narrowly as operations intended to degrade, disrupt, deny, or destroy information or systems, producing both internal network effects and external material damage or human injury. Drawing on Article 51 of the UN Charter and customary self-defence norms, he argues that a cyber attack qualifies as an “armed attack” if its scale and effects meet the gravity threshold established by the International Court of Justice—namely, significant physical destruction, human harm, or debilitating disruption of critical infrastructure—even in the absence of kinetic violence. The author extends this principle to attacks targeting critical state or military infrastructures that paralyze essential governmental or defense functions, equating massive disruption alone with armed attack. He distinguishes these high-impact intrusions from “low intensity” incursions that, due to their limited harm, may not trigger the right to use force, while also addressing the multi-layered nature of modern cyber operations, where intrusion, payload deployment, and harmful effects can occur asynchronously. According to Tsagourias, an armed attack is deemed to occur upon the materialization of significant effects, although pre-emptive self-defence may be invoked if there is credible evidence of an imminent, unfolding operation. The core of the article examines attribution standards under international law, outlining three principal criteria: cyber attacks conducted by State organs or agents; attacks by non-State actors acting under the “effective control” or direction of a State; and attacks by non-State actors tolerated by, or operating from within, a State unwilling or unable to prevent them. He traces these standards to seminal State responsibility doctrines, such as the Nicaragua case’s organ control test, the ICJ’s “effective control” threshold, and due diligence obligations evolved in counter-terrorism jurisprudence. Tsagourias contends that these established frameworks are sufficiently adaptable to encompass cyber operations, thus permitting victim States to lawfully resort to self-defence when attribution criteria are met. He critically evaluates the ICJ’s restrictive view that armed attacks must be attributable to a State, arguing that such a position undermines the effectiveness and deterrent purpose of the self-defence regime. Through analysis of State practice—ranging from the denial-of-service campaigns against Estonia and Georgia to the United States’ 2001 action in Afghanistan—he demonstrates that States increasingly recognize that non-State actor cyber threats tolerated by host governments can justify self-defence. Tsagourias concludes that, although technical, evidentiary, and political challenges in attribution remain, the current use of force regime already provides a coherent legal framework for assessing when a cyber operation constitutes an armed attack and when self-defence is lawful. He cautions, however, that emerging State practice and jurisprudence will continue to refine definitions of critical infrastructure, evidentiary standards, and attribution methodologies.
