title: Cyber attack: A dull tool to shape foreign policy
abstract: Emilio Iasiello’s conference paper “Cyber Attack: A Dull Tool to Shape Foreign Policy” delivers a rigorous multidisciplinary examination of the strategic utility—and limitations—of state-level offensive cyber operations in the pursuit of foreign policy objectives. Structured around three emblematic case studies—the October 2012 distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks on U.S. financial institutions, the 2012 Stuxnet operation against Iran’s Natanz nuclear facility, and the 2007 cyber assault on Estonia’s government networks—Iasiello adopts the working assumption of state sponsorship or proxy orchestration, using intent analysis, circumstantial evidence, and open-source expert testimony in the absence of definitive attribution. The study commences by positioning cyber weapons alongside nuclear arms within the framework of deterrence theory, underscoring the stark contrasts between the transparently monitored development and assured destruction characteristic of nuclear arsenals and the opaque, attribution-resistant nature of cyber capabilities. He argues that the absence of clear attribution, a lack of genuinely destructive “shock” effects analogous to nuclear blasts, and the constrained target base of heavily networked states undermine the credibility and coercive potential of cyber operations. In each case study, despite technical success in disruption and degradation, the cyber campaigns fell short of compelling policy change or deterring adversarial behavior: the U.S. banking sector DDoS incidents produced only transient service interruptions without eliciting concessions; Stuxnet inflicted notable damage on Iranian centrifuges but failed to decelerate Iran’s nuclear ambitions or prompt meaningful diplomatic negotiation; and the Estonia attacks showcased Russia’s cyber coordination yet did not translate into political leverage over the Baltic state or NATO. Iasiello contrasts these empirical insights with prevailing U.S. cyber policy frameworks—namely the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace and the Department of Defense’s 2011 Strategy for Operating in Cyberspace—which articulate a holistic approach encompassing diplomatic, informational, military, and economic instruments under international law. Despite the establishment of U.S. Cyber Command and policy proclamations affirming the right to employ “all necessary means” in defense of national interests, Iasiello contends that offensive cyber operations remain largely symbolic, lacking the paradigm-shifting impact required for coercive statecraft. The paper concludes that until a cyber event emerges that both guarantees attribution and generates pervasive strategic fear, states will continue to prioritize traditional diplomatic and military levers over cyber coercion. By bridging technical incident analysis with strategic policy assessment, this work offers a sober reassessment of the nascent role of cyber weapons in modern interstate competition and contributes a valuable multidisciplinary perspective to the study of cyber conflict.

title: Non-state actors in cyberspace operations
abstract: This study examines the strategic challenge of cyberspace as a contested domain in modern interstate conflict, focusing on the critical role of non-state actors and their interactions with nation-states. Recognizing cyberspace’s unique characteristics—low entry cost, anonymity, legal ambiguity, and asymmetric reach—the paper maps the diverse array of non-state participants in cyberspace operations, including hacktivists, patriot hackers, cybermilitias, organized crime groups, and rogue malware authors. Through a qualitative literature review and conceptual analysis of academic studies, military doctrines, government reports, and documented cyber incidents (notably the 2007 Estonia attacks, the GhostNet espionage network, and the Stuxnet operation), the author elaborates a taxonomy of these non-state actors, detailing their motivations (political protest, espionage, economic gain, or state-directed aggression), recruitment dynamics, tactics (denial-of-service, web defacement, information leaks, espionage, and malware deployment), and varying degrees of state affiliation. The paper interrogates definitional boundaries between cyberattack, cyberwar, and traditional kinetic warfare by synthesizing existing definitions of cyberwarfare, drawing on Clausewitzian frames, and disaggregating “cyberactions” to clarify thresholds at which state-endorsed or state-utilized non-state actors may constitute acts of war under international law. Core findings indicate that many governments are actively recruiting or tolerating non-state actors to augment their cyber capabilities, leveraging their specialized skills to achieve deniable, cost-effective offensive and defensive operations. This convergence transforms cyberspace into a flexible tool of state power but raises profound legal and ethical dilemmas regarding attribution, state responsibility, compliance with jus ad bellum, and the adequacy of existing legal frameworks. The author highlights that the legal ambiguity and the paucity of verifiable cyberwarfare cases impede clear policy formulation, complicate threshold-setting for armed conflict, and challenge the enforcement of international norms. As a result, the paper calls for the development of more robust normative and legal instruments to govern state sponsorship of non-state cyber actors, enhanced attribution technologies to improve accountability, and codified conflict thresholds to guide coherent military and policy responses. The research contributes a conceptual framework for understanding state–non-state partnerships in cyberspace and offers preliminary assessments of their strategic utility and associated risks. Acknowledging limitations due to nascent empirical data, the author urges further empirical studies to refine the taxonomy of non-state cyber actors, evaluate evolving doctrinal approaches to cyber warfare, and advance multidisciplinary policy debates on how to regulate and respond to cyber conflict in the twenty-first century.

title: Neutrality in the digital battle space: applications of principle of neutrality in information warfare
source: Syracuse Journal of Science and Technology Law (JOST)
abstract: This article examines the applicability of established international legal frameworks, specifically the 1907 Hague Convention and the Hague Rules Regarding Aerial Warfare, to the emerging domain of information warfare and the principle of neutrality in cyberspace. Against a backdrop of notable incidents—including infiltration of U.S. Department of Defense networks, Stuxnet’s attack on Iran’s nuclear program, and distributed denial-of-service assaults during the Estonian and Georgian conflicts—the author argues that most offensive cyber operations capable of causing harm should be regarded as armed conflict under current international humanitarian law. Through a legal doctrinal analysis informed by treaty text, state practice, and illustrative scenarios, the article identifies the three core duties of neutral states—impartiality, intervention to prevent harm emanating from neutral territory, and repulsion of belligerent forces—and demonstrates how these translate into the digital realm. Neutral states must provide telecommunications services without discrimination, quarantine or disable compromised systems used for attacks, and adopt proactive measures to safeguard critical infrastructure. Failure to do so may permit belligerents to invoke the right of necessity and neutralize offending systems. The study also grapples with challenges unique to cyberspace: difficulties in timely attribution of attacks, uncertainty regarding notification of compromise, and the classification of information operations as armed conflict, espionage, or criminal activity. While certain cyber intrusions, such as data theft, may fall outside the Law of Armed Conflict and be more appropriately addressed through criminal or espionage channels, the authors contend that the majority of high-impact information warfare tactics that risk injury or damage—exploitation, destruction, and disruption of digital systems—demand application of existing LoAC norms. The article further explores scenarios where neutral states inadvertently host digital weapons or permit use of their infrastructure to attack belligerents, concluding that the storage of non-weaponized data backups by private companies does not breach neutrality, whereas failure to intervene against botnets or malware launches does. Recognizing the rapid evolution of cyber capabilities, the author recommends that rather than drafting wholly new treaties, the international community should adapt and refine existing neutrality rules, develop early–warning and deterrent technologies, and cultivate diplomatic consensus to guide state and non-state actors. The article concludes that the extension of current neutrality obligations to the digital battlefield offers a flexible, humane approach to governing cyber conflict, emphasizes the need for international cooperation to address attribution and notification challenges, and calls for empirical research on state practice and private sector roles in information warfare.

title: Organizing for cyberspace operations: selected issues
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract: This article investigates how States should organize military cyberspace commands to conduct both offensive and defensive operations in compliance with the law of armed conflict and broader strategic objectives, using the establishment and practices of the United States Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM) as a primary lens. It begins with the historical context of USCYBERCOM’s creation in 2009—merging Joint Task Force-Global Network Operations and Joint Functional Component Command–Network Warfare—driven by recognized gaps in Department of Defense (DoD) network defense and high-profile intrusion events such as Operation Buckshot Yankee. The study maps international responses, noting analogous developments in China, India, Russia, South Korea, Iran, Germany, and the United Kingdom, and underscores the diversity of organizational models emerging worldwide. Part II focuses on the legal vetting of cyberspace capabilities, comparing the U.S. Air Force’s policy of reviewing all cyber tools against the Army and Navy’s effect-based review by which only capabilities with potential lethal or destructive outcomes undergo legal scrutiny. Drawing on DoD policy memoranda, service-level legal review procedures, and perspectives from the Tallinn Manual, the author recommends that States adopt a differentiated review standard calibrated to operational effect, thereby balancing the imperative of legal compliance with the need for rapid capability fielding. Part III addresses precautions against harm to civilian infrastructure, analyzing the feasibility and benefits of maintaining segregated military networks—such as the NIPRnet—distinct from civilian Internet systems to minimize collateral damage, improve attribution, and strengthen legal defensibility of operations. The author contends that virtual and physical network segregation enhances operational security and upholds civilian protection obligations, though it acknowledges challenges posed by shared gateways and chokepoints. Part IV extends this discussion to the conduct of cyber attacks, evaluating proposals like the ‘carpet bomb’ botnet concept, which envisions leveraging .mil infrastructure to generate large-scale denial-of-service effects. While recognizing the technical feasibility of such dedicated offensive architectures, the analysis warns that intermingling military and civilian networks without adequate separation raises serious legal and operational risks under jus in bello. Through these sections, the paper develops a normative framework underscoring three core principles: effect-based legal review of cyber capabilities, virtual or physical segregation of military networks to protect civilian systems, and rigorous evaluation of operational practicability when determining feasible cyber command structures. Limitations stem from sparse publicly available State practice and evolving cyber technologies, yet the author identifies future research avenues—including empirical assessments of segregation efficacy and comparative studies of cyber command doctrines—to refine policy guidelines. Ultimately, the study offers actionable recommendations to ensure that as States organize for cyberspace operations, they remain fully compliant with international law while preserving strategic effectiveness in a rapidly transforming domain of warfare.

title: This means war (maybe) - clarifying casus belli in cyberspace
abstract: In “This Means War (Maybe) – Clarifying Casus Belli in Cyberspace,” Lieutenant Colonel Charles C. Poche examines the ambiguous threshold at which cyber operations can justifiably trigger a state’s right to self-defense under existing international law. Noting that cyberspace blurs the traditional distinction between espionage and armed attack, Poche argues that the lack of agreed norms governing casus belli in the cyber domain creates a dangerous gray zone that risks inadvertent escalation to armed conflict. Employing a doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the emerging Tallinn Manual framework and case-study methodology, the paper first reviews the prohibition on the use of force in the U.N. Charter and the attendant exception for self-defense. The author then details the Tallinn Manual indicators—state involvement, severity, invasiveness, immediacy, and directness—and applies these factors to two seminal incidents: the 2007 distributed denial-of-service attacks on Estonia and the 2010 Stuxnet operation against Iran. Through comparative analysis, Poche finds that while the Estonian attacks lacked the requisite severity and directness to constitute an armed attack, Stuxnet’s physical effects on Iran’s nuclear infrastructure likely met the threshold for triggering self-defense. Recognizing the expansive intermediate zone between these extremes, the paper offers a five-part framework to reduce legal ambiguity and deter miscalculation. First, it urges the United States to openly acknowledge its justified offensive cyber operations to build transparent state practice. Second, it recommends preserving clear organizational boundaries between cyber attack/defense and espionage functions to safeguard espionage’s status under the law. Third, it advocates asserting sovereign control over designated portions of cyberspace as a bright-line test of invasiveness. Fourth, it calls for deploying active cyber defenses—automated detection, tracing, and counter-strikes—within sovereign cyber territories, drawing a modern parallel to the Caroline standard’s “reflexive” self-defense. Fifth, it proposes routinely reporting active defense deployments to the U.N. Security Council to promote shared understanding of limits and expected responses, thus accelerating the crystallization of customary international law. The paper acknowledges its U.S.-centric focus and the evolving nature of cyber capabilities as limitations and suggests future research comparing these recommendations against other major cyber powers’ doctrines and exploring empirical effects of reporting active defenses on deterrence and norm formation. Poche’s work advances both scholarly and practical policymaking by delineating the contours of cyber casus belli, integrating legal theory with operational considerations, and offering concrete measures to foster clarity and stability in state behavior in cyberspace.

title: NATO, cyber defense, and international law
authors: D Fidler; R Pregent; A Vandurme
source: St. John's Journal of International & Comparative Law
abstract: This article examines the evolving nexus of cybersecurity threats, collective defense, and international law within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), assessing whether the Alliance can adapt its policies and capabilities in cyberspace before a major crisis undermines its Article 5 obligations. Drawing on a symposium that integrated three expert presentations—covering operational perspectives on NATO’s Computer Incident Response Capability (NCIRC), the legal framework for cyber operations and collective self-defense, and NATO’s doctrinal and legal responses—the authors employ a qualitative legal-political methodology to synthesize policy documents, consensus-based decision-making processes, and landmark case studies, including the 2007 Estonian cyber attacks and the 2013 PRISM disclosures. Part I outlines NATO’s historical evolution from a Cold War collective defense alliance to a security actor confronting nontraditional threats, highlighting how the Alliance’s principles of sovereignty, nonintervention, and unanimous decision-making shape its cyber defense posture. The analysis traces NATO’s operational responses, notably the establishment and mandate of NCIRC, and identifies three overarching policy approaches: a threat-centric framework emphasizing adaptation of legacy legal norms; a defense-centric stance focusing on building resilient architectures; and a technology-centric orientation privileging capability accumulation without due regard for established legal principles. Part II interrogates a policy shift from the dense legal texture of the threat approach toward a capability-driven model, uncovering constraints imposed by conservative legal interpretations, limited technology sharing among member states, and the absence of agreed rules for proactive or offensive cyber measures. Such constraints risk relegating NATO to a static, reactive ‘‘cyber Maginot Line.’’ The article highlights key legal questions regarding state responsibility, jus ad bellum in cyberspace, and the potential need to revise International Law categories as discussed in the Tallinn Manual. It concludes that, although NATO has made foundational strides in articulating a cyber threat approach and operational structures, without consensus on more dynamic defense and offense capabilities—and willingness to adapt legal frameworks—the Alliance will remain reactive. The authors propose future research on empirical evaluation of member-state technology sharing, development of cyber rules of engagement within NATO’s Nuclear Planning Group model, examination of secrecy’s impact on alliance cohesion, and legal reforms to accommodate cyber contingencies, aiming to enable NATO to lead global cybersecurity cooperation rather than trail behind.

title: A Cyber Chase in Cyber Space: How International Law Must Address the Threat of Cyber Attacks or Suffer the Consequences
abstract: In “A Cyber Chase in Cyber Space: How International Law Must Address the Threat of Cyber Attacks or Suffer the Consequences,” Leah Shellberg offers a comprehensive examination of the challenges posed by malicious operations in cyberspace to traditional international legal frameworks and proposes a novel approach to defining and governing state conduct in cyber operations. Framing cyberspace as a distinct, non-tangible domain characterized by interconnected networks, Shellberg reviews various categories of malicious cyber activities—cyber crime, espionage, terrorism, and the contested concept of cyber warfare—and underscores the inadequacy of existing terminology and legal definitions borrowed from physical conflict. Against this backdrop, she crafts a narrow yet functional definition of “cyber attack” intended for international law: a state-sponsored or proxy operation deliberately designed to harm another state’s cyber infrastructure with effects analogous to physical aggression. Shellberg justifies this tailored definition by addressing scholarly concerns over attribution, overbreadth, and the differentiation between tolerated espionage and condemnable aggression. To illustrate its practical utility, she rigorously applies her definition to two seminal case studies. First, Stuxnet—an advanced, destructive intrusion targeting Iranian nuclear centrifuges—exemplifies a prototypical cyber attack under her criteria, given its state sponsorship, intent to degrade a critical cyber-physical system, and tangible effects. Second, Operation Shady RAT, characterized by covert, long-term data exfiltration across a multitude of international targets, falls outside her attack definition due to its unclear objective to disable or degrade systems rather than to collect intelligence. Through these analyses, Shellberg demonstrates the capacity of a precise legal threshold to distinguish between espionage, historically tolerated under international law, and acts warranting diplomatic or countermeasure responses. Building on analogies to space and maritime law, she advocates adapting well-established principles—sovereignty, non-intervention, and the law of armed conflict—to cyberspace rather than inventing an entirely new regime. Shellberg calls on the United Nations to facilitate negotiations on legally binding cyber norms, emphasizing the Organization’s experience in addressing emergent technological threats. She warns that as states’ reliance on networked technologies deepens, the stakes of inaction grow, and only the international community can craft cooperative frameworks capable of maintaining global stability against transboundary cyber threats. Her multidisciplinary perspective bridges legal theory and policy practice, providing a critical foundation for the development of international cyber law and reinforcing the urgency of an international legal response to the evolving landscape of cyber conflict.

title: Cyber war and international law: does the international legal process constitute a threat to U.S. vital interests?
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract: This article examines whether the emerging international legal process regarding cyber warfare poses a strategic threat to vital U.S. interests and offers a multidisciplinary assessment of cyber conflict governance. Murphy situates his inquiry in the context of competing state-led treaty initiatives, principally from Russia and China, aiming to secure United Nations or International Telecommunications Union regulation of the Internet. Such proposals risk empowering authoritarian states at the expense of core liberal values by imposing binding restrictions on free speech, privacy, and the open flow of information. Through a detailed doctrinal analysis of relevant treaty texts, UN General Assembly debates, ITU resolutions, and key advisory opinions of the International Court of Justice (ICJ), including the Wall Construction and Congo Activities cases, the author highlights how established jus ad bellum and jus in bello interpretations potentially curtail the right of self-defense against non-State cyber threats. Murphy critiques the ICJ’s narrow treatment of Article 51, demonstrating that its state-centric view undermines responses to cyber operations carried out by insurgents or other non-state actors, a problem magnified by attribution challenges intrinsic to digital attacks. He illustrates these issues with state-sponsored malware cases: Stuxnet’s sophisticated assault on Iran’s Natanz uranium-enrichment centrifuges, and the Duqu, Flame, and Gauss operations. These incidents reveal both the strategic potency of cyber tools in eroding adversary capabilities and the legal uncertainties surrounding sovereign responses. Murphy argues that, while binding cyber-war treaties may endanger U.S. strategic autonomy and liberal norms, the U.S. and its allies should nonetheless engage pragmatically in developing “rules of the road.” Drawing on John Hollis’s economic analysis of international legal transaction costs, he proposes informal, nonbinding guidelines or “shiprider”-style arrangements—where states consent to pre-authorized, cross-border defensive cyber actions—to streamline collective responses to terrorist or criminal cyber threats. He contends that such flexible mechanisms could reconcile state sovereignty with the demands of transnational cyber security, enabling rapid self-defense and cooperative deterrence against asymmetric warfare. The article concludes by urging the U.S. to resist authoritatively binding treaty proposals that would favor authoritarian regimes while simultaneously investing in public–private partnerships and norm-building initiatives to strengthen domestic cyber defense capabilities. Murphy underscores the need for empirical research on the adoption of informal cyber norms, the design of nonbinding frameworks for espionage regulation, and the enhancement of attribution mechanisms. Ultimately, the study reframes the international legal process on cyber conflict as an arena of strategic competition, requiring a balanced U.S. approach that both safeguards national interests and contributes to cooperative global governance.

title: Cyber hostilities and the war powers resolution
abstract: This article addresses the domestic legal governance of U.S. military offensive cyber operations and examines whether such operations fall within the scope of the War Powers Resolution. Congress, through Section 954 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012, explicitly linked “military activities in cyberspace” to the War Powers Resolution, reflecting congressional intent to subject offensive cyber capabilities to the same checks as traditional kinetic forces. The author, employing a doctrinal, case-based method, analyzes legislative texts, congressional history, executive branch communications, and public reporting to trace how “hostilities” became the operative trigger for statutory reporting and withdrawal requirements under the 1973 Resolution. After reconstructing the four limiting factors articulated by the Departments of Defense and State—scale of engagement, risk of escalation, exposure of U.S. forces, and scope of military means—the article applies this rubric in a detailed case study of the Stuxnet computer virus attack in Iran. This analysis reveals that Stuxnet’s narrowly tailored objective, minimal risk of escalation due to attribution challenges and geographic containment, nonexistent U.S. personnel exposure, and exclusive use of cyber means would likely lead the executive branch to conclude that such an operation does not constitute “hostilities.” Accordingly, the War Powers Resolution’s notification and withdrawal mandates would remain unlikely to constrain stand-alone offensive cyber activities despite explicit congressional linkage. By synthesizing statutory language, executive practice, and a concrete cyber incident, the article uncovers a significant governance gap: under existing executive criteria, offensive military cyber operations consistently fail to reach the threshold of “hostilities” necessary to trigger domestic constitutional checks on the use of force. The author concludes that without revised statutory definitions or new policy mechanisms—whether through amended domestic law or treaty-based models—the War Powers Resolution will continue to exclude a growing class of state-sponsored cyber operations from meaningful democratic oversight, thereby undermining accountability in the digital battlespace. The article calls for future research on comparative legislative approaches and empirical study of executive-legislative interactions in cyber missions to develop more robust oversight frameworks.

title: Restating the Law as It Is: On the Tallinn Manual and the Use of Force in Cyberspace
abstract: The growing prominence of cyberspace as a domain of state confrontation has catalyzed intense debate over whether and how existing international law governs cyber operations amounting to the use of force. This study examines the Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare, a leading expert restatement aiming to apply jus ad bellum norms, particularly Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, to cyber operations. Recognizing that ambiguity persists over whether and how the prohibition on the use of force applies to actions that lack physical destruction or loss of life, the research asks how the Manual’s so-called ‘‘Schmitt criteria’’ should be understood in relation to existing law. It seeks to determine whether these criteria reflect lex lata, propose lex ferenda, constitute new treaty or customary rules, or function merely as political tools influencing state assessments. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the article undertakes a close textual analysis of the Manual’s introduction, Rule 11 and commentary, supplemented by key scholarly works and decisional sources. The analysis traces the Manual’s historical lineage from early normative frameworks, through Schmitt’s six criteria, to the Manual’s presentation of eight ‘‘factors’’ states ‘‘are likely to consider’’ when characterizing cyber operations as uses of force. It finds that the criteria lack substantiation in any primary source of international law—treaty, custom or general principles—and that the Manual’s self-professed intent to ‘‘restat[e] the law as it is’’ clashes with its reliance on nonlegal, predictive considerations. Nor does the Manual advocate for treaty formation or customary crystallization, instead depicting the factors as non-binding, context-dependent guides. Yet labeling them political tools overlooks their normative effect: application of the criteria directly influences determinations of state responsibility, reparation, and prospective countermeasures. By conflating ‘‘predictive’’ with ‘‘normative’’ processes, the Manual inadvertently undermines the prescriptive clarity it promises. This critique contributes a systematic typology of possible legal statuses for the criteria and reveals the Manual’s interpretative effort as more than mere law application, occupying a quasi-legislative space that deepens rather than resolves legal indeterminacy. Acknowledging its focus on textual analysis and the limited corpus of state practice available, the article calls for empirical research into how states actually invoke the criteria in diplomatic and legal fora, comparative study of analogous doctrinal evolutions in economic coercion law, and exploration of alternative normative instruments—such as treaties or a cyber-specific dispute resolution mechanism—to address the inherent indeterminacy of Article 2(4) when applied to cyber operations.

title: Keeping cool: steps for avoiding conflict and escalation in cyberspace
abstract: In “Keeping Cool: Steps for Avoiding Conflict and Escalation in Cyberspace,” Roger Hurwitz addresses the growing risks of miscalculation and unintended escalation in international cyber operations, arguing that without concrete political and strategic measures, such conflicts could spill over into kinetic warfare and undermine both global stability and the open Internet. Grounded in a qualitative, conceptual framework informed by game‐theoretic reasoning and detailed case studies—most notably the 2007 Estonia DDoS attacks and deliberations of the U.N. Group of Governmental Experts—the paper maps the institutional and diplomatic landscapes within which states may pursue deterrence, attribution, and response in cyberspace. Hurwitz identifies critical challenges: the absence of agreed red lines for use of force in cyberspace, ideological fissures among major powers that stall consensus on norms, attribution difficulties that weaken deterrence, and the inherently multi‐actor, multi‐equilibrium nature of cyber strategic interactions that complicate decision‐making. To overcome these obstacles, he proposes a structured framework of seven strategic options: (1) delaying responses to enable robust forensic attribution and thereby strengthen the credibility of proportional retaliation; (2) leveraging extracyber venues such as WTO dispute settlement and mutual legal assistance treaties to pursue redress without resorting to offensive or kinetic measures; (3) expanding and negotiating binding legal instruments—including multilateral conventions and bilateral agreements—to cover cyber investigations and cross‐border cooperation; (4) enlisting respected third‐party verifiers—from academic and private cyber researchers to international certification authorities—to “name and shame” attackers and mediate disputes; (5) harnessing diplomatic, economic, and rhetorical tools within established international orders to impose sanctions or incentives that dissuade aggression; (6) adopting confidence‐building measures, including information sharing among national CERTs and multilateral norm dialogues, to reduce mistrust and misperception; and (7) applying rhetorical disarmament to frame cyber incidents in economic or criminal terms rather than military threats, thereby biasing policy responses toward non‐escalatory options. The study illustrates these recommendations with examples—from NATO’s diplomatic support for Estonia to proposals for invoking WTO security exceptions against intellectual property theft—demonstrating how existing institutions can be repurposed for cyber conflict management. Hurwitz acknowledges limitations, including states’ reluctance to cede sovereignty, uneven institutionalization of cyber governance, persistent attribution challenges, and the complex payoffs of multi‐actor strategic environments. He calls for future empirical research on the effectiveness of confidence‐building measures, design of binding international legal instruments for cyber investigations, development of scalable multilateral forums for norm enforcement, and refinement of multi‐player game‐theoretic models to capture evolving state and non‐state interactions. By articulating politically feasible steps for conflict avoidance and escalation management, this paper contributes a comprehensive policy toolkit aimed at preserving international security and the integrity of the global Internet in an increasingly contested cyber domain.

title: Expertise, uncertainty, and international law: a study of the Tallinn manual on cyberwarfare
abstract: This article examines how international legal expertise is mobilized to articulate the scope and meaning of existing norms in light of emerging forms of cyber conflict. Focusing on the Tallinn Manual on Cyberwarfare—an expert report commissioned by NATO—the authors analyze how expert discourse addresses uncertainties inherent in applying the jus ad bellum and jus in bello frameworks of international law to cyber operations. Drawing on interpretive qualitative methods, Kessler and Werner trace the institutional role of expert commissions in constructing “institutional facts” and normative interpretations through analogical reasoning, legal definitions, and contextual factors. They emphasize the dual function of expertise: to absorb uncertainty by formulating analogies such as the International Court of Justice’s “scale and effects” test from Nicaragua, and to produce new indeterminacies by relativizing core legal concepts and exposing fractures among experts. The article highlights the Manual’s invocation of factors like severity, invasiveness, state involvement, and the prevailing political environment to guide assessments of whether cyberattacks constitute prohibited uses of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. Although these factors aim to reduce ambiguity, their empirical grounding rests on the intuitions and reputations of individual experts rather than opinio juris of states, raising questions about the legitimacy and authority of such expert-led frameworks. Moreover, the Manual officially records instances of expert dissent on foundational issues—including the qualification of cyber operations as armed attacks, the threshold for applying the laws of armed conflict, and the distinction between international and non-international armed conflict—thereby solidifying uncertainties rather than resolving them. Kessler and Werner argue that legal expertise functions as the strategic management of uncertainty: experts not only interpret law but also co-constitute the problem space by framing cyber threats, selecting analogies, and incorporating risk-based considerations into legal reasoning. This process transforms unstructured uncertainty about cyber operations into structured but contested legal norms, cementing expert authority while institutionalizing indeterminacy. Concluding that the proliferation and specialization of international legal instruments have made legal experts indispensable, the authors call for critical scrutiny of expert commissions in conflict and security law. They suggest further comparative research into how different expert bodies articulate norms amid evolving security challenges and empirical studies on how states incorporate, contest, or resist expert-produced interpretations in their legal positions and policy practices. By situating cybersecurity within broader dynamics of legal fragmentation, professional bias, and the politics of uncertainty, the study sheds light on the co-constitution of legal expertise and cyber conflict in contemporary international relations.

title: The geography of cyber conflict: through a glass darkly
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract: Ashley Deeks’s article “The Geography of Cyber Conflict: Through a Glass Darkly” provides a rigorous doctrinal analysis of how the longstanding “unwilling or unable” test from the law of neutrality and jus ad bellum can be adapted and applied to high-intensity cyber armed attacks originating from neutral or non-hostile States. Deeks begins by recalling the historical roots of the test in neutrality law, which permits a victim State to use force in self-defense against non-State actors operating from the territory of a territorial State that is either unwilling or unable to suppress the threat. She then introduces cyber-specific nuances through hypothetical case studies, most notably an Israeli scenario in which Hezbollah conducts a debilitating cyber attack on Israeli military networks via servers in Turkey. Unlike kinetic operations, cyber attacks unfold at digital speed, generate complex attribution issues, risk wide collateral effects on civilian infrastructure, and place a premium on the victim State’s technological capacity to stop ongoing attacks. Deeks dissects these distinctive factors, showing that urgency demands rapid yet careful determinations of a territorial State’s technological ability and political will, while concerns over collateral damage heighten the incentive for precise legal thresholds. She further explores the territorial State’s dilemma: if it wishes to avoid extraterritorial self-help measures, it must disclose enough of its defensive cyber capabilities or consent to limited cross-border remediation—actions that implicate sensitive intelligence equities. Deeks juxtaposes this normative inquiry with U.S. interagency practice, revealing a cautious, precautionary approach embodied in classified legal memoranda and policy debates. U.S. decision makers emphasize stringent legal review, adherence to consent principles, reputational considerations, and reciprocal implications for future State practice. This approach, she argues, seeks to avoid the diplomatic fallout and unintended escalations that could arise from ad hoc cyber self-defense measures. While affirming the continued viability of the “unwilling or unable” test in cyberspace, Deeks highlights its reliance on evolving State practice and calls for more empirical research. She urges compilation of actual State invocations of the test, development of clear procedural protocols for timely determinations of territorial State willingness and capacity, and study of lower-threshold cyber operations to refine the applicability of self-defense doctrines. In doing so, Deeks offers a conceptual framework that balances the imperatives of self-defense, technological realities, and sovereign equality, thus contributing to the development of a coherent international legal architecture for managing cyber conflict in the digital age.

title: Self-Defensive Force Against Cyber Attacks: Legal, Strategic and Political Dimensions
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract: The article addresses the critical problem of determining when a cyber attack or its threat justifies a state’s right to self-defense, focusing on the potential for malicious code to inflict severe damage on military, economic, and social systems dependent on interconnected networks. It highlights the contested nature of state vulnerability and the prospect of digital assaults causing mass disruption, framing the issue within the broader concern over modern reliance on cyberspace. This research is justified by the urgent need to clarify legal norms and strategic guidelines in an area where doctrinal debate is nascent and policy stakes are high. Its objectives are to identify reasonable interpretations of self-defense rights under jus ad bellum, assess their strategic implications for security and stability, and analyze the political context shaping governmental responses. The central question is how legal, strategic, and political dimensions interact to inform a coherent approach to military self-defense against cyber operations. Methodologically, the study adopts an interdisciplinary framework combining legal doctrinal analysis with a strategic assessment of deterrence dynamics and a political analysis of decisionmaking under uncertainty. It reviews applicable provisions of the UN Charter, examines state practice and scholarly positions, and draws on case studies such as the covert Stuxnet operation to illustrate attribution challenges and political secrecy. Key findings reveal a broad spectrum of plausible legal interpretations of cyber armed attacks, shaped by strategic asymmetries among major powers that influence how states leverage offensive and defensive cyber capabilities. Politically, the opacity of cyber incidents, high levels of required secrecy, and difficulties in proving attribution to external audiences raise the practical threshold for justifying armed responses, making small-scale or isolated cyber intrusions unlikely to provoke military retaliation. The research also finds that most significant cyber threats will occur alongside other hostile activities, meaning that states will frame cyber responses within a broader security context. The principal contribution is an integrated model demonstrating that legal analysis of self-defense claims must be informed by strategic interests and political realities. The article elucidates how legal norms may evolve unevenly, given slow-moving international law and rapidly advancing technology, and it underscores the need for calibrating self-defense thresholds that reflect both doctrine and deterrence objectives. It also illuminates barriers to developing clear state practice due to secrecy and attribution challenges. Limitations include its predominantly American perspective, which may bias assessments of power and influence in shaping international norms, and the inherent difficulty of forecasting political reactions to cyber crises. For future research, the author proposes systematic examination of subsequent state responses to cyber incidents, comparative studies of major power legal positions over time, and development of joint strategic-legal frameworks among allies to establish clearer thresholds for the use of force in cyberspace.

title: Sovereignty and cyber attacks: technology's challenge to the law of state responsibility
abstract: In “Sovereignty and Cyber Attacks: Technology’s Challenge to the Law of State Responsibility,” Peter Margulies examines the fundamental tensions between state sovereignty, costly attribution burdens, and the regulation of cyber operations under international law. Drawing on classical precedents—including the International Court of Justice’s “effective control” test in Nicaragua v. United States, the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia’s “overall control” standard in Tadić, and the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on State Responsibility—Margulies argues that existing law, shaped for kinetic conflict, is ill-suited to address the distinctive “attribution asymmetry” of cyberspace. He shows that while victim states struggle to detect and trace cyber incursions, assisting states retain far greater internal control over private proxies than law currently recognizes, fostering plausible deniability and undermining deterrence. Through a doctrinal analysis of treaty texts, case law, and the Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare, the article identifies how the Manual’s cautious alignment with lex lata perpetuates an overly stringent approach to attribution: it demands proof of direct instruction or effective control, excluding mere financing and equipping of non-state actors. To remedy this gap, Margulies proposes a novel “virtual control” standard that shifts the burden to the assisting state once a victim state adduces credible evidence of material support. Under this test, states must either disprove their assistance or show they exercised due diligence to prevent misuse. This rebuttable presumption better reflects information asymmetries—since assisting states possess superior access to evidence—and enhances deterrence by compelling grantors to monitor and regulate beneficiaries. Margulies illustrates the approach through hypothetical case studies involving denial-of-service attacks and malware intrusions, demonstrating how virtual control would clarify when a cyber operation constitutes an armed attack under Article 51 of the UN Charter and justify self-defense. He addresses objections—privacy incursions arising from enhanced monitoring, risks of escalation, and the balance between necessity and proportionality—showing that limits on in bello and ad bellum proportionality, as well as existing grantor auditing practices, mitigate these concerns. The article concludes that although states seeking plausible deniability may resist, the virtual control framework aligns legal responsibility with the realities of cyber conflict and offers a more coherent pathway for the evolution of international norms. By bridging doctrinal lacunae between cyber practice and state responsibility law, Margulies’s proposal advances a multidisciplinary cyber conflict discourse, emphasizing both legal innovation and the safeguarding of sovereignty in the digital era.

title: Anticipatory self-defense in the cyber context
authors: Terry D. Gill; Paul AL Ducheine
source: Israel Yearbook on Human Rights, Volume 43 (2013)
abstract: This article examines whether the well-established international legal framework governing self-defense under the UN Charter and customary international law extends to anticipatory action in response to cyber operations that amount to armed attacks. Gill and Ducheine begin by affirming that any use of force, irrespective of modality, falls within the Charter’s prohibition under Article 2(4), with self-defense retaining its dual basis both as an inherent customary right and as an exception codified in Article 51. They emphasize that legal concepts—"use of force," "armed attack," "necessity," "immediacy," and "proportionality"—apply identically in cyberspace, although attribution and threat assessment pose unique technical challenges. The authors distinguish between two conceivable scenarios: cyber operations conducted as adjuncts to conventional kinetic attacks and standalone cyber assaults intended to inflict significant human harm, physical destruction, or long-term infrastructural disruption. In both cases, they argue, anticipatory self-defense remains lawful against a demonstrably imminent threat when no feasible alternatives exist. However, they caution that attribution difficulties—stemming from anonymizing techniques such as botnets and multi-jurisdictional data flows—may preclude reliable identification of the attacker, thereby limiting the occasions on which preemptive action is legally justifiable. Drawing on doctrinal analysis of primary sources (UN Charter, ICJ advisory opinions, customary state practice) and analogies to historical kinetic anticipatory strikes, the authors develop a conceptual framework for distinguishing between lower-threshold intrusions and armed attacks in the cyber domain. They propose criteria for assessing the threshold of "armed attack" when digital means alone cause or threaten severe consequences, and for calibrating proportional responses in light of immediacy and necessity. While reaffirming that anticipatory self-defense is part of the international legal order and does not authorize preventive actions against hypothetical threats, Gill and Ducheine highlight that it should remain a limited measure, employed only when clear evidence of imminent digital aggression exists. They conclude by calling for improved attribution capabilities, enhanced cyber defenses, and multilateral cooperation to deter high-stakes cyber threats without eroding the integrity of the law governing the use of force.

title: Cyber-conflict, cyber-crime, and cyber-espionage
abstract: In Cyber-Conflict, Cyber-Crime, and Cyber-Espionage, David Weissbrodt offers a comprehensive legal-analytical study of the challenges posed by computer network operations (CNOs) to existing domestic and international legal frameworks. Recognizing that CNOs—ranging from distributed denial-of-service attacks to sophisticated malware such as Stuxnet and Flame—blur traditional distinctions between uses of force, espionage, and criminal activity, Weissbrodt examines how well the United Nations Charter, state responsibility doctrines, jus ad bellum, and domestic criminal statutes can accommodate these novel threats. After illustrating the rise of national cyber commands and legislative efforts in the United States and elsewhere, the author presents three case studies: Estonia’s 2007 DDoS attacks, Stuxnet’s disruption of Iran’s nuclear facilities, and the Flame espionage campaign. For each, he analyzes scale, attribution, intent, and consequences to determine whether the incidents qualify as uses of force or armed attacks under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, warrant self-defense, or fall within criminal or espionage paradigms. Weissbrodt finds that while low-impact attacks better align with existing criminal or intelligence frameworks, high-impact operations causing physical damage may meet the armed attack threshold, enabling lawful countermeasures. The article then critically assesses three principal regulatory approaches: a cyber non-proliferation treaty modeled on WMD accords, a binding international treaty or code of conduct with specific normative rules, and incremental development of customary international law through documented state practice and judicial decisions. He argues that a non-proliferation treaty is impractical owing to challenges of attribution and secretive development, while a treaty banning cyber-attacks faces insurmountable compliance and verification hurdles. Instead, he endorses fostering consistent state practice—supported by transparent reporting of responses to CNOs and engagement by international courts—to evolve binding norms over time. Acknowledging the slow pace of customary law formation, the author calls for systematic documentation of state responses, scholarly collaboration on rule-setting, and confidence-building among nations to clarify the legal status of cyber-operations. Limits include rapid technological change, attribution difficulties, and secretive cyber capability development. Overall, the article provides a multidisciplinary analysis of cyber-conflict governance, identifying paths toward an adaptable legal regime to mitigate cyber threats.

title: Below the Threshold Cyber Operations: The Countermeasures Response Option and International Law
abstract: States today face a persistent threat from cyber operations that fall below the armed attack threshold but nonetheless inflict significant harm, creating a legal and strategic dilemma as traditional self-defense measures are ill-suited to address such ‘‘below the threshold’’ intrusions. Michael N. Schmitt’s study arises from this problem, arguing that countermeasures under the law of state responsibility offer a tailored and lawful response option that bridges the gap between ineffective retorsion and overly provocative use of force. The research aims to clarify when and how states may employ cyber countermeasures in response to internationally wrongful cyber acts, asking what legal conditions, requirements, and restrictions govern their use. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the article draws on sources including the UN Charter, ICJ jurisprudence, the Articles on State Responsibility, the Tallinn Manual, and illustrative state practice involving cyber intrusions by China, North Korea, and non-state actors such as the Syrian Electronic Army. The analysis in Part II identifies the conditions precedent for countermeasures: a prior wrongful breach of an international obligation and attribution of the act to a state. Part III dissects requirements of purpose, temporality, proportionality, evidentiary standards, and the permissible scope, illustrating that countermeasures must aim to induce compliance, be proportionate to the breach, and avoid affecting third-party rights. The study finds that countermeasures provide a viable, non-forceful option to address harmful cyber activities while limiting escalation, yet they are constrained by strict attribution rules, an inability to be undertaken by private actors or collectively on behalf of another state, and a prohibition on forceful measures. These findings reveal both the promise and the limitations of countermeasures: though they expand states’ response toolkit and reinforce norms against unwarranted cyber force, they leave gaps when dealing with non-state actors or operations straddling the force threshold. The principal contribution is a comprehensive framework that adapts the law of countermeasures to cyberspace, clarifying legal standards and illustrating their operation with concrete examples. Acknowledged limitations include unresolved ambiguity over the armed attack versus use of force distinction in cyber contexts and restricted applicability when attribution to a state is unclear. Schmitt suggests future research should further develop rules of engagement and procedural guidelines for state responses, address the challenge of collective countermeasures, and refine legal thresholds for cyber uses of force. By doing so, policymakers and legal scholars can build on this work to enhance international stability and strengthen norms governing state behavior in cyberspace.

title: Cyber posturing and the offense-defense balance
abstract: Ilai Saltzman’s 2013 article “Cyber Posturing and the Offense-Defense Balance” in Contemporary Security Policy advances a realist framework accounting for how cyber capabilities reshape interstate security dynamics by altering the classical offense–defense balance. Challenging the prevailing view among some realists that cyber operations represent only incremental changes to traditional warfare, Saltzman reconceptualizes Offense–Defense theory to encompass the distinctive qualities of cyberspace—its low attribution thresholds, minimal marginal costs for attackers, and potential for rapid political-military escalation. Drawing on Robert Jervis’s and George Quester’s original formulations, he identifies the central question as whether cyber tools inherently favor offense or defense, proposing a modified conceptualization in which Offense–Defense distinctions hinge on the relative costs and risks states face when using cyber means to degrade adversary military or civilian infrastructures. Empirically, Saltzman conducts a comparative qualitative analysis of official doctrines and strategic statements from four leading actors—China, Russia, the United States, and NATO—using primary sources including defence white papers, military doctrines, and allied summit declarations. His findings reveal a convergence toward offensive cyber postures: all four actors emphasize the strategic enabler function of cyber capabilities, viewing them as force multipliers that lower barriers to attack and confer asymmetric advantages by complicating attribution. In each case, public documents indicate growing investments in specialized offensive cyber units, doctrinal acceptance that cyber operations can precede or accompany kinetic strikes, and a shift from defensive information security to proactive cyber engagement. Saltzman argues that while cyber warfare does not directly cause interstate armed conflict, it lowers the political and military threshold for escalation, transforming conflict calculus by making coercive digital actions cheaper, faster, and less publicly costly. The integration of ICT into national security thus creates a novel domain of operations that realism must accommodate: cyberspace functions as an alternative battlefield where states posture offensively to signal resolve, deter adversaries, and prepare contingency options. Saltzman acknowledges limitations due to reliance on publicly available documents and calls for longitudinal incident tracking, quantitative modeling of offense versus defense cost ratios, and investigation into norm-building processes to mitigate instability. He concludes that cyber war is neither inevitable nor decisive on its own, but its inf luence as a strategic enabler demands that prospectives theories of international security transcend territorial and kinetic assumptions. By expanding Offense–Defense theory to include cyberspace, this study offers a multidisciplinary contribution bridging international relations, strategic studies, and cyber policy, highlighting the need for theorists and policymakers to reckon with digital technologies as fundamental reshapers of the offense–defense balance and international security.

title: Computer network attacks as a use of force in international law
source: Cyber Warfare and the Laws of War
abstract: The advent of sophisticated computer network attacks such as the 2010 Stuxnet virus and the 2007 distributed denial-of-service campaign against Estonia has challenged traditional conceptions of armed force and raised urgent questions regarding the scope of international law. These incidents illustrate a growing trend in state-implicated or state-directed cyber operations aimed at critical infrastructure, prompting debate over whether such activities should be treated as uses of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. The authors justify this inquiry by pointing to both the strategic importance of cyber weapons in modern interstate conflict and the comparative legal lacunae in defining ‘force’ within cyberspace. Their research aims to clarify the conditions under which cyber actions amount to forcible measures, assess the applicability of jus ad bellum principles, and propose a doctrinal framework for addressing non-physical yet coercive cyber operations. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the authors analyze state practice, judicial decisions of the International Court of Justice, treaty provisions, and authoritative commentary. They examine technical case studies—such as Stuxnet’s disruption of Iranian nuclear centrifuges and the paralysis of Estonia’s banking and government services—to map the threshold at which cyber-induced effects translate into destruction of property, loss of life, or significant interruption of essential services. The findings reveal that cyberattacks causing physical damage or foreseeable harm to life and property clearly satisfy existing definitions of force, whereas purely information-centric operations with intangible or minimal downstream effects do not neatly align with the traditional force paradigm. The authors further identify attribution challenges and the indeterminate locus of cyber operations as complicating factors in applying established legal criteria. Their principal contribution is a refined normative model distinguishing between unlawful interference and prohibited uses of force in cyberspace: operations yielding tangible harm invoke Article 2(4) prohibitions and justify state responsibility, while non-physical data manipulations constitute wrongful acts outside the Charter’s force ban but still entailing reparations. They propose that international consensus on physical server locations may anchor jurisdiction and enforce legal obligations, thereby integrating cyber norms within existing jus cogens principles. Acknowledged limitations include the evolving technical sophistication of attacks, the difficulty of attributing responsibility in real time, and potential jurisdictional disputes when servers are hosted in third states. The authors suggest future research directions focused on empirical validation of their model through additional case studies, development of attribution technologies to strengthen legal accountability, and multilateral efforts to codify cyber-specific rules of engagement in arms control agreements.

title: Cyberattacks and the Covert Action Statute: Toward a Domestic Legal Framework for Offensive Cyberoperations
abstract: Cyberattacks have emerged as a critical domain of state conflict, capable of inflicting physical and economic damage comparable to traditional warfare while complicating attribution and oversight. Notably, the Stuxnet operation against Iran’s Natanz nuclear facility demonstrated that remotely delivered software can disable vital infrastructure and precipitate significant diplomatic and military consequences. This raises pressing questions about the appropriate domestic legal authority for the United States to employ offensive cyberoperations. The research undertaken by Aaron P. Brecher in the Michigan Law Review examines the ambiguity between military (Title 10) and intelligence (Title 50) frameworks, arguing that neither fully accommodates the unique attributes of cyberattacks or the constitutional balance between executive discretion and congressional accountability. The study aims to determine which legal regime should govern U.S. cyberattacks outside an authorized conflict and to propose mechanisms to ensure coordination with Congress while preserving operational flexibility. Employing legal doctrinal analysis, the author compares statutory and regulatory structures underlying the Covert Action Statute and military authorities, reviews the Youngstown framework for executive war powers, and analyzes the constitutional separation of powers. The methodology includes evaluation of statutory text, case law on war powers, and examples of cyber operations, with particular reference to reporting requirements, definitions of “covert action,” and the “military activities” exception. The analysis finds that the military framework lacks the reporting mechanisms necessary for meaningful congressional oversight and that reliance on Title 10 alone risks unchecked executive action. In contrast, the Covert Action Statute under Title 50 mandates advance written findings and reporting to congressional intelligence committees, thereby embedding a mechanism for legislative involvement without unduly constraining executive agility. Constitutional analysis further supports that covert cyber operations can constitute use of force and that statutory authorization under the Covert Action Statute can satisfy the War Powers Resolution’s requirements. The core contribution of the work is the proposal of an executive order establishing the covert action regime as the presumptive domestic framework for all U.S. offensive cyberoperations absent specific legislative authorization, thus standardizing procedures across agencies and solidifying congressional notification. This model bridges the gap between flexible operational authority and democratic accountability, while also preempting confusion between intelligence and military cyber activities. The study acknowledges limitations, including reliance on executive policy rather than binding statute, the potential for continued ambiguity in classifying certain cyberactivities, and the limited scope of existing reporting provisions to intelligence committees rather than the full Congress. It also recognizes the risk that the military activities exception could be overapplied to cyber operations. Future research is encouraged to explore comprehensive legislative reforms to clarify statutory definitions, expand reporting to include armed services committees, assess the international law dimensions of cyber warfare authorization, and examine institutional configurations for interagency coordination and oversight of cyber operations.

title: The significance of attribution to cyberspace coercion: A political perspective
abstract: The enduring challenge of crafting effective cyber conflict strategies has manifested in persistent debates over deterrence, yet this discourse has struggled to yield a comprehensive framework for coercion in cyberspace. Scholars and practitioners have grappled with how to deter malicious actors from conducting hostile intrusions or, more pressingly, compel them to cease ongoing successful operations, but traditional deterrence theories have proven difficult to apply in a domain characterized by anonymity and attribution uncertainties. This paper addresses the critical gap by reframing the problem from deterrence to compellence, arguing that in contemporary state-level cyber conflict the pressing requirement is to force adversaries to halt intrusions that threaten national security interests, including espionage against government systems and disruptive attacks on critical infrastructure. The study aims to advance policy discourse by proposing a cyberspace coercion framework that clarifies the dynamic elements of compellence, revisits the role of positive attribution, and identifies policy measures that balance attribution requirements with strategic objectives. To build this framework, the author employs a conceptual methodology, drawing on theoretical insights from Thomas Schelling’s coercion theory and a RAND modeling continuum of policy objectives from deterrence to compellence, and grounds the analysis in open-source case material such as the 2007 Estonia attacks and related literature on attribution challenges. The analysis reveals that compelling an actor to desist hostile intrusions depends on a calibrated combination of strong defensive measures, credible communication of retaliatory intent, targeted attribution efforts, and effective responsive actions, and that the strategic importance of unequivocal technical attribution may be overstated. Instead, the paper finds that human attribution—linking malicious acts to actors subject to state control—and political signaling can suffice to achieve compellence, allowing flexible and sometimes confidential coercive measures without undermining strategic objectives. The proposed framework contributes to cyber conflict studies by offering a novel model for assessing attribution’s role in coercion, delineating three policy options—international engagement, support for dissidents, and defensive resilience—and illustrating how attribution thresholds vary by measure and political context. While this framework is deliberately scoped and does not encompass every dimension of cyber security, it provides a heuristic for policymakers to weigh attribution requirements against political and strategic considerations. The paper acknowledges limitations in its reliance on conceptual models and open-source information, as well as the absence of quantitative validation, and notes that real-world coercion dynamics may involve additional variables. Future research is encouraged to empirically test the framework through case studies, extend analysis to non-state actors and hybrid threats, and explore how evolving international norms and legal regimes might interact with compellence strategies in cyberspace.

title: Cyber Attacks: When to Respond
abstract:
This article by M. Harmes explores the emergent challenge of classifying and responding to purely electronic operations and cyber attacks under existing legal paradigms of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and the Laws of Armed Conflict (LOAC). The rapid proliferation of interconnected digital devices and the increasing sophistication of non-kinetic assaults necessitate a reexamination of traditional frameworks designed during an era when conflict was inherently physical. The author situates the problem by tracing how states and non-state actors have historically leveraged technology to augment conventional weapons, and contrasts this with contemporary developments that enable standalone cyber campaigns to inflict significant disruption, damage, or coercion entirely through digital means. Traditional IHL and LOAC norms are fundamentally predicated on the geography and morphology of the battlefield, distinguishing combatants and categorizing uses of force in kinetic terms. Cyber operations, however, blur these lines: they can originate outside recognized conflict zones, can be conducted by actors operating invisible to conventional surveillance, and may produce effects that do not neatly map onto established notions of “attack,” “use of force,” or “armed conflict.”

Harmes critically analyzes the status quo, highlighting gaps in the existing legal architecture that could either unduly constrain a victim state’s ability to respond to cyber aggression or, conversely, permit an overbroad interpretation of armed conflict thresholds that would undermine civilian protections and escalate digital disputes into full-scale hostilities. The author examines pertinent State practice, including declaratory policies and operational responses, and surveys scholarly debates regarding the threshold at which a cyber incident constitutes an “armed attack” justifying countermeasures under Article 51 of the UN Charter. Particular attention is paid to the difficulties of attributing cyber operations with sufficient certainty to justify proportional responses without eroding the high standards of proof demanded by international law.

To address these challenges, the article proposes a novel legal framework that preserves the core humanitarian principles of distinction, proportionality, and necessity, while tailoring the concepts of “use of force” and “armed attack” to the unique characteristics of cyberspace. Key elements include a calibrated scale of response calibrated to severity and effects rather than technological modality, a flexible attribution standard that balances evidentiary rigor with operational realities, and an international mechanism for joint investigation and adjudication of significant cyber incidents. The framework also advocates for preemptive norms of responsible State behavior, including confidence-building measures, shared technical standards, and mutual assistance protocols for incident response and remediation.

Harmes concludes that while IHL and LOAC provide valuable ethical and legal underpinnings, they are insufficiently agile to address purely cyber contexts without adaptation. A specialized, multidisciplinary cyber law framework that integrates legal, technical, and diplomatic instruments offers the best prospect for ensuring that digital armed conflicts evolve within a controlled, accountable, and rights-respecting order. By anticipating future digital battlefields, the international community can better safeguard habitual legal protections and prevent the cyber domain from becoming a permissive environment for aggression and escalation.

title: Armed attack and response in the digital age
source: Cyber Warfare and the Laws of War
abstract: In “Traditional Military Activities in Cyberspace: The Scope of Conventional Military Authorities in the Unconventional Battlespace,” Major Peter C. Combe II examines the legal and doctrinal ambiguities that plague U.S. military cyber operations conducted outside acknowledged hostilities. Combe begins by situating the problem in a hypothetical Sino-Japanese dispute over the Senkaku Islands to illustrate how state-sponsored information operations, propaganda, and network intrusions can shape public perception and diplomatic risk without producing direct kinetic effects. He then traces the evolution of U.S. legal frameworks governing covert actions—codified in 50 U.S.C. § 3093—and the narrow Traditional Military Activities (TMA) exception, which exempts military-funded operations from the normal covert action approval and reporting requirements. Combe critiques the existing four-part TMA test (military command, military personnel, acknowledged hostilities, and tradition) as mechanistic, outdated, and ill-suited for the converged cyber domain where the distinction between intelligence and military information support is blurred and effects may be purely informational. Drawing on doctrinal sources including JP 3-13.2 and the Tallinn Manual, he demonstrates that reliance on “tradition” and physical effects conflicts with modern cyber practice. To restore clarity, Combe proposes a streamlined three-element analytical framework: (1) funding by the Department of Defense, which drives oversight jurisdiction to the Armed Services Committees alongside intelligence committees; (2) explicit or implicit congressional authorization, clarifying the separation of powers and executive authority; and (3) a geographic test tied to Acknowledged Operations of Hostilities (AOH), distinguishing activities within an AOH from those requiring higher executive approval when conducted outside. He supplements this test with recommendations for enhanced reporting to both intelligence and armed services committees, mandatory contemporaneous documentation of “intent to acknowledge” uncredited operations, and defined conditions precedent for public disclosure. Combe’s framework aims to streamline decision-making, preserve executive flexibility, strengthen congressional oversight, and empower U.S. military initiative in the dynamic cyber battlespace.

title: International and canadian law rules applicable to cyber attacks by state and non-state actors
source: Canadian Journal of Law and Technology
abstract:
Matthew E. Castel’s article offers a comprehensive survey of the legal frameworks governing cyber operations by state and non‐state actors, with a particular focus on Canadian and international law. After defining cyberspace as an interactive electronic terrain tethered to physical infrastructures and characterizing cyber war as state‐sponsored “weapons” crafted from malware, logic bombs, Trojan horses, and botnets, the author examines how existing norms of jus ad bellum, jus in bello, state responsibility, and the law of armed conflict apply to computer network attacks. Drawing on historical episodes—ranging from Allied psychological operations in the 1991 Gulf War to recent distributed denial of service campaigns—Castel argues that conventional rules on the use of force extend to cyber operations when they amount to armed attacks or produce effects analogous to kinetic violence. Yet he identifies persistent “grey zones” concerning the threshold of armed attack, attribution of malicious code to state organs, and territorial sovereignty in a decentralized Internet architecture. Castel then contrasts state‐sponsored cyber operations, which may invoke self‐defense and warrant classification as acts of war, with non‐state cybercrime, which better aligns with domestic criminal law and mutual legal assistance treaties.

In scrutinizing Canada’s legislative and strategic posture, Castel reviews Canada’s nascent Cyber Security Strategy, proposed amendments to the Criminal Code, and efforts to ratify the Convention on Cybercrime. He underscores deficiencies in federal cyber incident reporting, the absence of a national cyber command, and regulatory gaps that leave critical infrastructures vulnerable to cascading failures. On the international plane, the author canvasses ten multilateral proposals—from a dedicated “cyber weapons” convention and a U.N.‐led cyber compliance body modelled on the International Atomic Energy Agency, to Protocols amending the Geneva Conventions and the 1980 Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons. He highlights the promise of custom‐building customary international law through state practice, NATO’s declaration equating cyber attacks to uses of force, and emerging U.S. doctrinal shifts acknowledging cyberspace as a domain of potential armed conflict.

To bolster both deterrence and resilience, Castel recommends that Canada adopt clear rules of engagement classifying state‐sponsored cyber aggression as acts of war, ratify the Cybercrime Convention to improve cross‐border cooperation on attribution and prosecution, and establish an early‐warning system and national cyber command. He also advocates penalizing non‐compliance with international norms via traffic‐flow sanctions, mandating deep‐packet inspection by Internet Service Providers to detect malware signatures, and isolating critical civilian networks from public Internet backbones to forestall “weapons of mass disruption.” Recognizing practical hurdles—imperfect attribution, the political complexity of multilateral treaty‐making, and civil liberties trade‐offs—Castel concludes by calling for research on refining attribution mechanisms, assessing the efficacy of proposed international compliance bodies, and consolidating cyber custom through sustained state practice.
