title: Cyber Warfare Operations: Development and Use under International Law Cyberlaw Edition
abstract: Major Arie J. Schaap’s article addresses the pressing challenge of how cyber warfare operations fit within existing international legal frameworks at a time when states are rapidly developing offensive cyber capabilities. The problem statement emphasizes that cyberspace has become a new battlefield where doctrine is emerging globally yet the rules regulating state conduct remain unsettled, raising significant risks of escalatory responses and collateral damage. Schaap justifies his analysis by noting predictions that dozens of states will soon vie for cyber supremacy, underscoring the urgency for clear legal norms; his objective is to identify how international law currently applies to cyber operations and to clarify the rules governing their development and use. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, Schaap systematically analyzes state practice—focusing on the United States, China, Russia, and North Korea—alongside international treaties and conventions, including the jus ad bellum principles on use of force, jus in bello standards under the law of armed conflict, and relevant agreements such as the Council of Europe Cybercrime Convention, outer space, telecommunications, aviation, and arms control treaties. His findings reveal that while no treaty expressly prohibits cyber warfare operations, existing legal limitations stem from principles of military necessity, distinction, proportionality, perfidy, and neutrality, and that cyber attacks can constitute a use of force or violate the law of war when they inflict damage comparable to kinetic attacks. He further finds that certain treaty obligations—such as mutual assistance clauses in the Cybercrime Convention—could conflict with state denials of responsibility for cyber operations. Schaap contributes a comprehensive framework mapping key legal principles onto cyber operations, identifies gaps in state practice and treaty coverage, and highlights the potential for reduced collateral damage compared to traditional methods alongside the risk of inadvertent escalation. He acknowledges limitations inherent in legal analysis of rapidly evolving technologies and the paucity of clear state practice and opinio juris specific to cyber warfare, cautioning that his conclusions rely on analogies to existing weapons law. Finally, he calls for proactive development of international regulations to define permissibility and boundaries for cyber warfare operations before reactive, overly restrictive measures emerge in the wake of a major cyber attack. His future research directions include determining specific thresholds for use of force in cyber contexts, refining targeting rules for dual-use infrastructure, and negotiating new treaties to codify state responsibilities and norms of behavior in cyberspace.

title: Cyberwarfare and the Use of Force Giving Rise to the Right of Self-Defense Comment
source: Boston College International and Comparative Law Review
abstract: In “A Cyber Chase in Cyber Space: How International Law Must Address the Threat of Cyber Attacks or Suffer the Consequences,” Leah Shellberg offers a comprehensive examination of the challenges posed by malicious operations in cyberspace to traditional international legal frameworks and proposes a novel approach to defining and governing state conduct in cyber operations. Framing cyberspace as a distinct, non-tangible domain characterized by interconnected networks, Shellberg reviews various categories of malicious cyber activities—cyber crime, espionage, terrorism, and the contested concept of cyber warfare—and underscores the inadequacy of existing terminology and legal definitions borrowed from physical conflict. Against this backdrop, she crafts a narrow yet functional definition of “cyber attack” intended for international law: a state-sponsored or proxy operation deliberately designed to harm another state’s cyber infrastructure with effects analogous to physical aggression. Shellberg justifies this tailored definition by addressing scholarly concerns over attribution, overbreadth, and the differentiation between tolerated espionage and condemnable aggression. To illustrate its practical utility, she rigorously applies her definition to two seminal case studies. First, Stuxnet—an advanced, destructive intrusion targeting Iranian nuclear centrifuges—exemplifies a prototypical cyber attack under her criteria, given its state sponsorship, intent to degrade a critical cyber-physical system, and tangible effects. Second, Operation Shady RAT, characterized by covert, long-term data exfiltration across a multitude of international targets, falls outside her attack definition due to its unclear objective to disable or degrade systems rather than to collect intelligence. Through these analyses, Shellberg demonstrates the capacity of a precise legal threshold to distinguish between espionage, historically tolerated under international law, and acts warranting diplomatic or countermeasure responses. Building on analogies to space and maritime law, she advocates adapting well-established principles—sovereignty, non-intervention, and the law of armed conflict—to cyberspace rather than inventing an entirely new regime. Shellberg calls on the United Nations to facilitate negotiations on legally binding cyber norms, emphasizing the Organization’s experience in addressing emergent technological threats. She warns that as states’ reliance on networked technologies deepens, the stakes of inaction grow, and only the international community can craft cooperative frameworks capable of maintaining global stability against transboundary cyber threats. Her multidisciplinary perspective bridges legal theory and policy practice, providing a critical foundation for the development of international cyber law and reinforcing the urgency of an international legal response to the evolving landscape of cyber conflict.

title: State responsibility for cyber -attacks on international peace and security
abstract: Joanna Kulesza’s 2009 article “State Responsibility for Cyber-Attacks on International Peace and Security” examines the application of established international law principles of state responsibility and self-defense to the novel domain of cyber-attacks, arguing for the urgent adaptation and harmonization of legal frameworks in light of increasing interstate electronic intrusions. The study begins by contextualizing the emergence of cyber-attacks as a form of interstate aggression targeting critical infrastructures—such as power grids, banking systems, and governmental communications—and highlights documented incidents, including the coordinated 2007 assault on Estonia and a series of intrusions into U.S. defense networks during the 1990s and early 2000s. Kulesza employs a doctrinal methodology, analyzing core instruments of international law—most notably the United Nations Charter, the International Court of Justice’s jurisprudence (in particular the Teheran embassy case), and relevant customary norms—to assess whether cyber-attacks can be classified as acts of aggression under Article 2(4) or trigger the right of self-defense under Article 51. The author identifies definitional ambiguities that hinder the recognition of electronic operations as armed aggression and the difficulty of attributing cyber-operations to state actors, especially when quasi-state organizations or non-state actors are involved. Nevertheless, Kulesza posits that the principle of due diligence—requiring states to prevent harmful cyber acts emanating from their territory—offers the most viable basis for international responsibility when direct attribution is elusive. Through comparative examination of state practice and national criminal law regimes, the article uncovers significant inconsistencies in the adoption and enforcement of legislative measures addressing cyber-crime and cyber-warfare. The analysis further reveals divergent state positions regarding permissible countermeasures, with some jurisdictions contemplating extreme retaliatory options, including nuclear response, to electronic incursions. To address these challenges, Kulesza advocates for a multilateral dialogue aimed at defining clear criteria for due diligence obligations, permissible self-defense measures, and jurisdictional principles applicable in cyberspace. She proposes utilizing existing forums such as the Internet Governance Forum to advance a consensus on harmonized domestic legislation, procedural standards for criminal investigations, and model treaty provisions that operationalize an international due diligence standard. The study concludes by outlining the limitations of a purely doctrinal approach and recommends future empirical research into state compliance, enforcement capacity, and comparative legislative harmonization. By mapping the contours of state responsibility and self-defense in cyber conflict, Kulesza’s article lays critical groundwork for an international regulatory framework designed to prevent unilateral interpretations of lawful countermeasures that could escalate into conventional armed conflict.

title: Sovereignty in cyberspace: can it exist
abstract: In “Sovereignty in Cyberspace: Can It Exist?”, Lieutenant Colonel Patrick W. Franzese undertakes a comprehensive examination of whether and how the foundational principle of state sovereignty can be applied to the digital domain. Drawing from both traditional international law doctrine and comparative analysis of sovereignty regimes in maritime, air, and outer-space domains, the article argues that despite cyberspace’s borderless nature, territorial control is both achievable and necessary. Franzese begins by surveying high-profile cyber incidents, including the 2007 DDoS attacks on Estonia, the 2008 multinational espionage campaign compromising over 1,200 computers worldwide, and clandestine breaches of U.S. military and congressional networks. These case studies underscore the urgent need for a coherent legal framework to govern cyber operations and protect critical infrastructure. Employing a historical-normative methodology, the author distills principles from existing international regimes—such as maritime zones, national airspace, and space treaties—and identifies mechanisms for extending sovereign jurisdiction beyond terrestrial boundaries. Central to this analysis is a detailed breakdown of these regimes’ evolution, illustrating how states translated physical domain sovereignty into codified international law norms. Franzese then addresses four principal challenges to cyber sovereignty: (1) state recognition of cyberspace as a distinct domain requiring legal status; (2) political resistance rooted in normative commitments to online freedom and open networks; (3) protection of civilian privacy and civil liberties; and (4) technical obstacles to actor identification and border control in the digital realm. To overcome these hurdles, the article outlines practical, technology-forward solutions: the issuance of cyber identity credentials akin to Department of Defense common access cards; deployment of biometric authentication at strategic internet gateways; and implementation of “Internet border inspections” to monitor and regulate cross-border IP traffic. These proposals are justified by demonstrating the economic imperative: U.S. Department of Defense cyber defense expenditures exceeded $100 million in a recent six-month period, and potential damages from successful cyberattacks on critical infrastructure could reach billions. The centerpiece of Franzese’s policy prescription is a three-pronged framework: (i) a unilateral U.S. declaration asserting sovereign jurisdiction over its cyberspace, supported by robust border-control measures and clear statements equating cyber aggressors with terrorists; (ii) multilateral treaties obligating states to trace, prosecute, or extradite cyber perpetrators and share forensic capabilities; and (iii) proactive U.S. leadership within the United Nations to codify norms and reciprocal obligations, establish forums for standard-setting, and foster accountability for non-state actors. While acknowledging the limitations—namely the exclusion of in-depth engineering analysis and potential resistance from states unwilling to cede cyber “freedoms”—Franzese contends that technical innovation, diplomatic engagement, and expert convenings can realign national strategies with emerging norms. Ultimately, the article concludes that without a clear sovereignty regime, both states and the international community remain vulnerable to non-kinetic cyber attacks, and that reliance on ad hoc measures is insufficient: hope, he warns, is no substitute for a robust legal and institutional framework governing cyberspace.

title: Getting it right: protecting american critical infrastructure in cyberspace
abstract:
In “Getting It Right: Protecting American Critical Infrastructure in Cyberspace,” Sean M. Condron argues that the United States must fundamentally rethink its approach to defending critical infrastructure in light of evolving cyber threats. He begins by describing the low cost and accessibility of computing power and how this landscape empowers a diverse array of adversaries—including nation-states, terrorists, sympathizers, and thrill‐seekers—to launch disruptive or destructive cyber operations. Condron emphasizes that while thrill‐seekers typically seek notoriety rather than destruction, nation‐states and terrorists possess greater capabilities and, in the case of nation‐states, may integrate information warfare into military doctrine. He notes historical examples—such as China’s cyber attacks on Taiwan and suspected intrusions into U.S. federal systems—and assesses that although large-scale cyber strikes by states remain rare due to fear of retaliation, the risk is real and growing.

Condron then critiques the prevailing presumption that cyber incidents are primarily criminal matters addressed through law enforcement. Drawing on an interagency case in which hackers breached U.S. Navy and Air Force networks, he demonstrates that treating cyber intrusions as crimes delayed decisive response and risked exacerbating damage. He proposes reversing the presumption: any cyber attack on critical infrastructure should initially be treated as a national security threat, enabling robust, immediate defense actions. This shift would empower federal authorities—particularly the Department of Defense—to lead or support cyber defense under constitutional exceptions to the Posse Comitatus Act, which ordinarily restricts domestic military involvement in law enforcement. Condron analyzes these exceptions (“emergency authority” and “protection of federal property and functions”) and shows how they could lawfully justify military participation in defending critical networks.

Lastly, Condron addresses the balance between civil liberties and security. He cautions that altering the presumption of criminality must not unduly erode individual rights, and that clear procedural safeguards and public notice of protected systems are essential. He calls for international law to evolve, allowing pre-authorized self-defense measures in cyberspace without demanding definitive attribution before action. In conclusion, Condron contends that only by presuming cyber attacks on critical infrastructure to be threats to national security—and by revising domestic and international legal frameworks accordingly—can the United States secure its vital networks against future high-impact assaults.

title: Why states need an international law for information operations
abstract: In 'Why States Need an International Law for Information Operations,' Hollis examines the rapid emergence of information operations (IO) as a central feature of modern interstate conflict, spurred by events such as the April–May 2007 distributed denial-of-service attacks on Estonia. He defines IO to encompass both computer network attacks and psychological operations aimed at disrupting, corrupting, or manipulating information systems and their supporting infrastructure. The article critiques the prevailing reliance on analogies to traditional jus ad bellum and jus in bello norms—specifically the prohibition on the use of force, the requirement of civilian distinction, and the ban on perfidy—arguing that analogical application creates excessive legal uncertainty, risks inadvertent escalation, and may unduly constrain proportionate or less lethal responses. Existing international rules, while partially applicable, fail to address novel IO challenges such as accurate attribution, the proliferation of botnets, and jurisdictional gaps, and impose a complex mosaic of overlapping treaty, customary, and domestic regulations that further exacerbate state uncertainty. Hollis also highlights the insufficiency of current regimes to govern non-state actors, which are increasingly capable of mounting significant information campaigns. To remedy these deficiencies, he proposes the creation of a dedicated International Law for Information Operations (ILIO). Such a framework would consolidate legal obligations, reduce transaction costs for states combating global terrorism, and mitigate collateral damage during armed conflict by clarifying permissible IO conduct and strengthening norms against malicious behavior. Hollis outlines critical choices in ILIO design: the normative form (binding treaties versus nonbinding principles), the scope (rules-based restrictions on technologies versus conduct-based prohibitions), and institutional mechanisms (self-governing national codes, regional or multilateral treaties, framework conventions with subsequent protocols, conference-of-the-parties governance, and verification or compliance monitoring bodies). He suggests that an initial step could mirror the Lieber Code’s codification model, or follow peer regimes like the Council of Europe’s Convention on Cybercrime. The article frames ILIO as a necessary evolution in international law that balances state sovereignty with collective security, accommodates technological innovation, and engages diverse stakeholders—from government legal advisers to private-sector entities such as ICANN. Though it stops short of drafting specific rules, Hollis emphasizes future research avenues: drafting concrete ILIO provisions, developing enforcement and verification mechanisms, reconciling hard and soft law instruments, and ensuring adaptive institutional arrangements. Ultimately, Hollis calls on states, scholars, and military planners to recognize the limitations of law-by-analogy and to pursue a cohesive, robust legal framework for information operations that addresses attribution, non-state actor involvement, and the shifting dynamics of cyber conflict.

title: "Weapons like to Lightning": US Information Operations and US Treaty Obligations
abstract: In “Weapons like to Lightning”: US Information Operations and US Treaty Obligations, Smith and Lederman examine the evolving landscape of US information operations (IO) through the lens of international law, offering both critique and guidance for policymakers and military commanders. They build on the US Department of Defense Office of General Counsel’s 1999 assessment of legal issues in IO, surveying the obligations the United States has assumed under the UN Charter, the law of war, and numerous multilateral agreements. The chapter begins by defining information operations as actions taken to affect adversary information and information systems while defending one’s own, including computer network attack, electromagnetic pulse weapons, and directed-energy systems. The authors highlight that US engagement in IO requires balancing offensive and defensive needs with adherence to treaty obligations and customary international law, lest actions intended to degrade adversary capabilities inadvertently violate US commitments or generate unintended damage. After an operational overview, Smith and Lederman outline the structure of international law, distinguishing between treaty-based and customary obligations, before analyzing specific regimes. They explore how outer space law—principally the 1967 Outer Space Treaty and its related agreements on rescue, liability, and registration—limits the placement of weapons and mandates peaceful use of space-based assets. The impact of the Limited Test Ban and Anti-Ballistic Missile treaties on IO in space is also considered. Turning to communications law, they examine the International Telecommunication Union Convention’s prohibitions against willful interference with radio and satellite traffic, and note how domestic US law enforces those rules against private actors, albeit with carve-outs for military operations under presidential authority. The Law of the Sea Convention’s navigation freedoms and prohibitions against electronic interference with maritime communications are addressed, as are aviation and diplomatic law rules prohibiting hostile electromagnetic transmissions against civil aircraft and diplomatic missions. At each stage, the authors assess how these regimes intersect with information warfare, offering a checklist of relevant obligations that commanders should review before authorizing operations. The chapter also highlights the interplay between domestic surveillance statutes and international legal constraints, underscoring the need for interagency coordination and pre-approved legal frameworks. Through historical examples—from Gulf War telecom disruptions to NATO’s Kosovo campaign—the authors demonstrate how bureaucratic inertia and legal uncertainty delayed integrated IO planning, constrained the full employment of IO capabilities, and risked collateral damage to civilian infrastructure and unintended blowback. Smith and Lederman conclude by reflecting on the potential merits and challenges of negotiating a dedicated international treaty on information operations, acknowledging that technological advances will continually reshape the legal and operational questions at hand. Their analysis thus provides a foundational, multidisciplinary approach to cyber conflict policy, emphasizing that adherence to treaty commitments is not an insurmountable barrier but an essential facet of responsible statecraft in the information age.

title: Computer Network Attacks and Self-Defense
abstract: Why International Law and Norms Do Little in Preventing Non-State Cyber Attacks by Nori Katagiri examines the persistent failure of international law and normative frameworks to deter or prevent malicious cyber operations conducted by non-state actors. Katagiri argues that the state-centric foundations of international law, developed under the assumption that states are the primary actors in international relations, render these legal regimes incoherent with the modern reality of cyberspace, which is dominated by individual hackers, private technology firms, and advanced persistent threat (APT) groups. The paper identifies three interrelated gaps that undermine the effectiveness of international law: (1) Enduring conceptual ambiguities in defining “use of force,” “armed attack,” and “sovereignty” in cyberspace prevent states from uniformly invoking legal standards to curb or attribute non-state cyberattacks. Despite efforts such as the Tallinn Manuals, consensus on these definitions remains elusive, allowing states to apply subjective criteria and avoid acknowledging operations like Stuxnet as use of force. (2) The persistent attribution problem is exacerbated by a lack of clear evidentiary rules within international law. No concrete standards exist for demonstrating sufficient evidence to attribute cyber operations to specific actors or state sponsors, and non-state action attributable to states is often treated differently from state-on-state operations, further complicating legal accountability. (3) States’ reluctance to submit to enforceable norms—driven by strategic and reputational incentives—undermines compliance and enforcement. Major powers exploit legal loopholes to conduct espionage, disinformation, and intellectual property theft, while private technology firms step into the legal void as “norm entrepreneurs,” leveraging proprietary products and alliances (e.g., the Charter of Trust, Cyber Threat Alliance) to shape cyber norms in ways that diverge from state preferences. Katagiri also explores how power politics at the United Nations, particularly the split between Western democracies advocating decentralized internet governance and Russia and China promoting cyber-sovereignty, has deepened normative fragmentation. The parallel processes of the UN Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) and the Open-Ended Working Group (OEWG) illustrate both the contested nature of norm formation and the limits of consensus-based multilateralism. Against this backdrop of “cyber anarchy,” international law’s state-centric legacy not only undermines its own capacity to protect states but also enables non-state actors and norm entrepreneurs to proliferate contradictory principles. Katagiri concludes that meaningful reform requires updating core doctrinal principles—such as distinction, due diligence, and proportionality—to accommodate non-state actors’ roles and legitimizing active defense measures within a reformed international legal framework. Without such reforms, cyberspace will remain characterized by legal incoherence, normative contestation, and a precarious security environment.

title: Is it time for a treaty on information warfare?
source: International Law Studies Series. US Naval War College
abstract:
In "Is It Time for a Treaty on Information Warfare?" (2002), Phillip A. Johnson critically examines whether the international community should negotiate a dedicated treaty to regulate information warfare—especially computer network attack (CNA). Johnson opens by delineating the distinctive features of CNA that set it apart from conventional military operations: its low cost, ubiquity, reliance on dual-use commercial systems, rapid technological innovation, ease of offensive operations, and acute attribution challenges. These characteristics, he argues, undermine existing international legal constructs—such as sovereignty, use of force, and the law of armed conflict—by blurring the line between military and civilian systems and raising the potential for indiscriminate harm to noncombatants.

Johnson surveys state practice and scholarly discourse, noting a broad consensus on the imperative of international cooperation against cybercrime and cyberterrorism, yet deep divisions over formal prohibition or regulation of state-sponsored information warfare. Some states favor preemptive codification of norms before customary international law crystallizes, while others warn that the rapid pace of technological change and uneven attribution capabilities render premature treaty drafting counterproductive. To inform treaty design, Johnson synthesizes eight “revealed truths” about CNA: (1) interdependence on networked systems heightens vulnerability; (2) geography is irrelevant; (3) homogeneity of hardware/software facilitates attacks; (4) legal development lags technological innovation; (5) commercial sectors drive advances; (6) offense currently outranks defense; (7) attribution remains elusive; and (8) dual-use infrastructures complicate protection of civilians and proportionality assessments.

Drawing on analogies to existing arms control agreements—such as the Open Skies, Conventional Weapons, Chemical Weapons, and Geneva Conventions—as well as confidence-building measures and state practice, Johnson proposes a graduated framework for norm development. He contrasts a narrow convention targeting specific CNA modalities with a broader treaty encompassing all forms of information warfare, stressing the utility of incremental norm crystallization. He advocates systematic empirical monitoring of state behavior, periodic feasibility reviews, and incremental development of customary international law through practice and precedent. Johnson underscores the importance of embedding treaty negotiations within existing international institutions and of fostering transparency, verification mechanisms, and technical cooperation.

Acknowledging limitations—including the insurgent pace of innovation, evolving definitions of hostile cyber operations, and jurisdictional complexities over attribution—he cautions against overambitious legal prescriptions. Instead, he urges a balanced approach that combines proactive treaty engagement with cautious adaptation to technological evolution. Ultimately, Johnson contends that a carefully calibrated treaty process can help safeguard national security, economic stability, and civilian welfare in the digital age by ensuring that international legal norms keep pace with the strategic realities of networked conflict.

title: Computer attacks on critical national infrastructure: a use of force invoking the right of self-defense
abstract: In “Computer Attacks on Critical National Infrastructure: a Use of Force Invoking the Right of Self-Defense,” Eric Talbot Jensen argues that modern computer network attacks (CNAs) against critical infrastructure must be recognized under international law as uses of force that trigger a state’s right of proportional self-defense, including anticipatory measures. Jensen begins by describing the strategic logic of crippling civilian networks—financial, energy, communications, and media—through coordinated cyber tools, citing Chinese military literature and recent incidents such as the Microsoft breach in October 2000 and the Moonlight Maze intrusions. He contends that existing legal interpretations, rooted in the UN Charter’s Article 2(4) and 51, unduly constrain states to passive cyber defense and protracted processes of attribution, intent characterization, and state notification before mounting any response. Using a doctrinal methodology that analyzes treaty provisions, customary law, state practice, and authoritative opinions (notably Pentagon Office of General Counsel guidance), Jensen systematically examines the UN Charter, Hague Neutrality Conventions V and XIII, and Department of Defense memoranda. He distinguishes passive defense—such as firewalls and intrusion detection—from active computer network defense (CND), which involves real-time, cross-border countermeasures against intruders demonstrating hostile intent and capability by breaching network perimeters. Jensen argues that once an attacker has penetrated passive barriers, the window for effective response is “instant, overwhelming, and leaving no moment for deliberation,” thereby justifying immediate proportional action even absent traditional armed-attack thresholds. He addresses potential conflicts with neutral and host state sovereignty by invoking Articles 8–10 of the Hague Convention on Neutral Powers, which obligate neutrals to apply restrictions impartially and permit belligerent measures when neutrals cannot or will not prevent the use of their territory by attackers. He further asserts that requiring states to wait for neutral consent or to pursue domestic criminal remedies undermines deterrence and fails to protect critical networks against nonstate actors. Jensen’s normative framework calls for legal evolution to permit active CND without prior attribution or neutral-state consent, constrained by proportionality and respect for neutrality, to deter and punish CNAs effectively. He acknowledges limitations—rapid attribution remains difficult, collateral impacts in neutral networks risk breach of sovereignty, and state practice to date is insufficient to validate anticipatory cyber defense—but recommends future research on operational proportionality guidelines, rapid verification mechanisms for attacker identity and intent, and international norm-building. By reframing CNAs as uses of force warranting immediate self-defense, Jensen offers a comprehensive cyber law proposal to strengthen deterrence, preserve stability in cyberspace, and enable states to defend critical infrastructure against emerging digital threats.
